HEADLINE: Many Customers Still Balk At Push-Button Banking;
Skipping A.T.M.'s for Tellers and Passbooks

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
In an age of money machines, on-line banking and the quicksilver transfer of cash via computer, Maria Russo, a 38-year-old typist, is holding fast to another age. Hers is the gentle -- some might say fusty -- world of teller windows, withdrawal slips and passbook savings accounts.
"I never use the automated teller machines, because you never know who's lurking behind you," Ms. Russo said, passbook in hand, as she paused recently beneath the soaring ceiling of the Flushing branch of Queens County Savings Bank. "And I prefer the passbook. I have to be able to see each entry that goes in there." 
 For many baby boomers the passbook is a quaint relic of childhood, when the concept of earning interest on money made from mowing the neighbor's lawn was new and thrilling. But passbooks, those passportlike booklets that document the ebb and flow of one's savings, did not go the way of camera flashbulbs and stereo turntables.
In fact, Ms. Russo is one of a sizable number of holdouts who have simply refused to get with the program. At savings banks in New York City, 40 percent to 60 percent of customers still use passbooks.
Their very existence may surprise those who think nothing of zapping money from one stock fund to another before breakfast. But when considering the fees that customers are sometimes charged to use automated teller machines, the hassle of correcting electronic mistakes and the temptation that round-the-clock access to money brings, old-time banking is not without its merits.
Rather than try to convert customers clinging to an earlier era, some banks seem happy to allow them to remain fiscal dinosaurs because they can be so profitable, parking money in savings accounts yielding less than 2.5 percent at a time when the stock market is showing annual gains of more than 20 percent.
These customers prefer thrift institutions, which offer the option of a passbook (as opposed to a monthly statement). They visit the same branch every week to deposit their paycheck, withholding enough cash to carry them through to the next payday. They hurl verbal darts at A.T.M.'s, accusing them of being unsafe, confusing and prone to error. And they relish the face-to-face contact at the teller's window.
"It's a very serious thing for people who have sacrificed greatly to know that the person handling their money is a good person," said Joseph R. Ficalora, president of Queens County Savings Bank, where well over half of the 41,500 customers still use passbooks. "They want to look you in the eye."
Some customers go a step further, wanting to look George Washington, Alexander Hamilton and Andrew Jackson in the eye.
"We get tremendous lines of people manually depositing their paychecks and bringing their passbooks to be stamped," said Charles J. Hamm, chief executive officer of Independence Savings Bank in Brooklyn. "Some of them even withdraw the money to make sure it's there. They want to see it, smell it, feel it. And then they'll get back on line and redeposit the cash."
To a large extent, the customers who bank the old-fashioned way fall into one of two groups. They are either new immigrants skittish about the security of financial institutions who may not have enough command of English to navigate the electronic superhighway, or they are older people who may have had direct experience with stock market crashes and who are comfortable with lifelong routines.
But banking experts say young customers are also in the mix. "That's one of the myths, that it's a function of age," said Ed Furash, chairman of Furash & Company, a banking industry consulting firm in Washington. "It's an attitudinal thing, and there are many young people who are technophobes."
At the Bensonhurst branch of Independence Savings Bank, however, most of the passbook holders there on a crystalline spring day were longtime residents, like Elizabeth Minacapelli, a 77-year-old retired dressmaker.
Mrs. Minacapelli said it never occurred to her to switch from her navy blue passbook to a monthly statement. "You look at it, and you know what's there," she said. As for the automated teller machines, she does not need extra cash after bank hours. "I'm from the old school, I guess," she said.
Joseph Cotugno, another customer at the same branch, where there is no Plexiglas distancing the 22 teller windows from the customers, gave similar reasons for not getting an A.T.M. card. "I come once a week to take out $100, and I'm never out at night anyway," he said.
A retired mechanic with New York City Transit, Mr. Cotugno has banked at the Bensonhurst branch since 1953 and now, at 73, has his life savings -- $83,000 -- on deposit there, mostly in conservative savings vehicles like one-year certificates of deposit. The branch welcomes its elderly customers with a large sitting area near a special window from which a teller calls out, "Next."
"A lot of the money that actually resides in the banking system belongs to this more traditional group, and the last thing you want to do is to alienate them," said David S. Berry, director of research for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment bank that specializes in financial institutions.
Although many passbook holders also have money in the stock market, Mr. Berry said, "There are people who leave a shocking amount of money in what are fairly low-interest savings accounts."
All that money has helped savings banks reap profits through mortgage lending and refinancing. Mr. Ficalora, the president of Queens County Savings Bank, said the bank had "far more money on deposit by people who do not use A.T.M.'s than by people who do use A.T.M.'s."
Savings banks profit from such customers by taking the money on deposit in their savings accounts -- generally earning less than 2.5 percent -- and lending it out at a rate of about 7.5 percent. The spread may not be as wide as that realized by commercial banks from credit card accounts and commercial loans, but the default rate on residential loans is lower.
Queens County Savings Bank, with $1 billion on deposit, is now the 10th largest multifamily housing lender in the nation. Since the bank started to trade publicly in 1993, the stock has split four times, its value rising 800 percent. By comparison, an index of the nation's 24 largest commercial banks rose 329 percent during the same period.
Banking consultants say Brooklyn and Queens are hubs in the New York region for the more traditional banking customer, reflecting the demographics of age, ethnicity and income. Although savings banks have a disproportionate share of such customers, even a large commercial bank like Chase Manhattan reports that about a third of its three million branch customers in the region do not use cash machines.
But passbooks have been kept alive in only a half-dozen of the bank's 500 branches, mostly in Chinatown, in lower Manhattan, and in immigrant neighborhoods in Queens. "It's not a technology issue in those branches," said Ken Herz, a bank spokesman. "It relates to the fact that in their home countries there's a tremendous lack of confidence in the banking system."
But technology is an issue with many customers.
"I will not use an A.T.M.," said Carl Meyer, a 64-year-old sales executive in Manhattan, as he left the North Fork Bank branch at Avenue of the Americas and 37th Street. "I don't think they're safe, and I'm concerned about errors."
Even some bank officials are empathetic. David R. Jones, chairman of the board of Carver Federal Savings Bank in Harlem, said he watched as his 11-year-old daughter tried to withdraw $200 from a machine in another bank. Distracted by music, she hesitated a few moments when the money slid forward. "I saw the money being sucked back into the machine," Mr. Jones said.
He spent the next two and a half months trying to get his $200 from the bank, since the withdrawal had been recorded on a computer. "People say the elderly are not willing to get with it," he said. "But this is not silliness. It's not irrational. The machines are, in many cases, very difficult and are not very forgiving."
Yet banks say they are noticing a shift toward more modern ways of banking on the part of technophobes. "Even older, more conservative customers are finally coming around and doing more and more business through A.T.M.'s," said John Adam Kanas, president and chief executive officer of North Fork Bank. "But it has probably taken 15 years for them to break down those barriers."
North Fork Bank, a commercial bank with headquarters in Melville, N.Y., has systematically bought up seven savings banks in the last 10 years, including Eastchester and Home Federal, increasing its customer base to 700,000 and expanding its number of branches in the New York area to 110. The bank is soon to open a second Manhattan branch at Amsterdam Avenue and 72d Street.
Mr. Kanas views the high-maintenance customer base the bank has acquired as an asset. About half of his customers do not use the automated teller machines, while about half still have passbook accounts.
"A lot is made in our industry about the cost of our delivery system -- that is the branch," he said. "But very little is discussed about the fact that these types of traditional customers are willing to leave deposits with thrift institutions at lower-than-competitive interest rates. So it more than makes up for the cost of the delivery system."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Like many bank customers, Elizabeth Minacapelli has held on to her passbook. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. 27)

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: IN INDIA;
Hindu Nationalists Move to Rule India's Atom Era

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 16

 BODY:
As India adjusts to its new status as a nuclear weapons state, many Indians are wondering whether they should prepare for a new era of dominance by the Hindu nationalist leaders who ordered five nuclear tests this week in the country's northwestern desert.
In effect, the nuclear tests have forced India to reset its political as well as its philosophical compass. They brought worldwide condemnation to a country that had long preached the gospel of peace, with Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee proclaiming India to be the possessor of "the capacity for a big bomb" that had given it a new measure of international power. 
 But as the test series ended, many Indians concluded that the repercussions abroad, including severe economic sanctions imposed by the United States, could be matched by similarly far-reaching political effects at home.
In effect, those Indians said, Mr. Vajpayee, in approving the tests and winning the support of more than 90 percent of Indians in opinion polls, has struck a powerful blow against the opposition parties, rearranging the political landscape in the nationalists' favor.
The tests' political effects were suggested by a columnist today in The Asian Age, a newspaper that has supported the nuclear tests but warned against India's sliding into "jingoism." The writer, Seema Mustafa, a Muslim, said the Hindu nationalists were riding a tidal wave of support.
"To express a doubt about the political wisdom of this decision is to risk being dubbed an anti-national, and if you carry a Muslim name, as this columnist does, it will probably be sufficient to throw you across the other side of the border," Ms. Mustafa wrote, referring to Pakistan.
Only 10 weeks ago, the Bharatiya Janata Party that Mr. Vajpayee leads, the B.J.P., emerged from a general election with its best showing in 50 years of Hindu nationalist electioneering -- 171 seats in the 545-seat lower house of Parliament. For a nationalist movement long tarred by its link to the Hindu fanatic who assassinated Mohandas K. Gandhi, the independence leader, it was a moment of historic vindication, and enough for the nationalists to put together a governing coalition of 14 parties.
But the election showed the Hindu nationalists' weaknesses, too. Essentially, they remained a movement rooted in an arc of populous Hindi-speaking states in the country's north and west, known in India as the cow-belt states because of the region's strict adherence to Hindu traditions of cow worship. In at least 16 of India's 25 states, the nationalists remained political outsiders, dependent on alliances of convenience with regional allies that have a history of hostility with the nationalists.
Yet the election had been held in circumstances that favored the nationalists. The Congress Party, which governed India for 44 years but is increasingly rudderless and corrupt, staved off a rout only by drafting Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born heir to the legacy of the Nehru-Gandhi political dynasty, as campaign leader. The only other contender, the United Front, a broad coalition of leftist and regional parties, was discredited by its chaotic performance in national government in the 20 months after a 1996 general election.
Still, the nationalists won the support of only 26 percent of the 345 million voters, and clawed their way into government only by scrapping measures intended to shift India from its secular tradition toward a new era of dominance for the country's Hindu majority of 700 million people.
Among other things, the nationalists were forced to set aside a potentially incendiary plan to build a Hindu temple in the northern city of Ayodhya on the site of an ancient mosque that a nationalist mob razed in 1992, an event that set off the worst Hindu-Muslim rioting since 1947.
Events in the new Government's first two months in office did not favor the nationalists. Mr. Vajpayee was depicted by newspapers as a "toothless tiger" as his Government was buffeted by internal feuding, and by a relentless series of demands for special treatment. They included the quashing of criminal charges by a 27-seat parliamentary group loyal to Jayalalitha Jayaram, a former movie actress who was ousted from power in Tamil Nadu state in 1996 amid accusations that she and her associates had looted state coffers.
Indian political commentators predicted that the nationalists might be discredited for failing to fulfill their campaign promise to provide a stable administration that would break with the ramshackle governments of the past. After abandoning Hindutva, a term that refers to the notion that India should be a Hindu state, the promise of stability was their main plank. To many middle-class, upper-caste Indians who are the nationalists' political backbone, "good governance" was far more important than razing mosques.
But quietly, the Vajpayee Government was taking steps to entrench its power. The governors of several key states were replaced with known supporters of the far-right nationalist group that many regard as the real power behind the Government, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or R.S.S. Bureaucrats with Hindu nationalist sympathies were moved into top posts in key ministries in New Delhi and the states. Rumors abounded of plans to use national powers to dismiss inconvenient state governments, including the one in Tamil Nadu that has prosecuted Ms. Jayaram.
The most important move of all, the decision to carry out the nuclear tests, was apparently made as soon as Mr. Vajpayee took office on March 19. Indian newspapers have reported that top nuclear officials, including A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, regarded as the father of the Indian bomb, met with Mr. Vajpayee the same day, and left smiling broadly. About the same time, villagers in the area around Pokharan, where the tests were held, began seeing a step-up of military activity, especially at night, in sand storms and in bad weather, when American and Russian spy satellites would be blinded.
Much else is speculation. But many Indians were surprised by how openly the R.S.S. leadership displayed its influence over the new Government, many of whose leaders, including Mr. Vajpayee, are longtime party stalwarts. Key Cabinet appointments were blocked, or approved, by the group's leaders, who announced that they would keep a close watch on the new Government. Mr. Vajpayee has said the tests were motivated by a concern for India's national security, not by partisan considerations. But in an interview published on Friday by India Today, a news magazine, he hinted at the political benefits that nationalists expect to reap.
"Millions of Indians have viewed this occasion as the beginning of the rise of a strong and self-confident India," he said. "I fully share this assessment and this dream."
In another interview, with Outlook magazine, Mr. Vajpayee said "no more nuclear tests" were planned by the Government, Agence France-Presse reported today.
Opposition leaders have said the nationalists may be planning to rush into a new election in the hope of winning a parliamentary majority, something Mr. Vajpayee has denied. In any case, the nationalists could be blocked by India's Constitution, since President K. R. Narayan would be obliged to ask other parties in the current Parliament to form a new coalition. Mrs. Gandhi, the Congress Party leader, would almost certainly seek to lead a new government, pushing the nationalists into opposition.
But few doubt that the tests have created a new vulnerability for the opposition groups. One faction of the Communist Party condemned the tests as a breach of faith with India's poor, but almost every other group lined up with the Government. United Front leaders who led the last Government hastened to say they would have approved the tests if they had been re-elected, and Mrs. Gandhi, after dithering for four days, issued a statement of support, calling the testing "a national issue" that precluded partisan dissent.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Kuhn, Now Selig: Different Lines on Big Trades

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, has given his blessing to the latest -- though not necessarily the last -- round of the Florida Marlins' game of payroll purge. The trade that sent Gary Sheffield, Bobby Bonilla and Charles Johnson to the Los Angeles Dodgers, Selig said, is no different from so many others in baseball history.
Indeed, the Marlins did not ship those stars out for nothing in return. The Dodgers gave them Mike Piazza and Todd Zeile, two established and productive hitters. Before long, however, Piazza and Zeile will end their vacation in Florida and move on to another place of employment. And in return for them, the Marlins will get minor league prospects of the variety they received in last winter's trades. 
 The Marlins will not compete in the near future with Derrek Lee, Fletcher Baines, Steve Hoff, A. J. Burnett, Robert Stratton, Jesus Sanchez, Jesus Martinez, Eric Ludwick, Rafael Medina, Joe Fontenot and Oscar Henriquez. They have taken the place of players like Moises Alou, Kevin Brown, Devon White, Jeff Conine, Al Leiter and Robb Nen. Piazza and Zeile will bring more of the same.
Marlins General Manager Dave Dombrowski, who said yesterday that he had already heard from five teams about Piazza, and his staff might be sharp enough to have plucked some plums out of other teams' minor league systems and to have laid the foundation for the Marlins' next World Series championship team. But prospects have a funny way of turning into suspects.
In that regard, then, have the Marlins' deals been any different from the ones Charlie O. Finley made in 1976 when he was the maverick owner of the Oakland Athletics? Finley sold Vida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million and Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers to the Boston Red Sox for $2 million. Bowie Kuhn, then the commissioner, vetoed the sales.
"Public confidence in the integrity of club operations and in baseball would be greatly undermined should such assignments not be restrained," Kuhn wrote in his decision. In his book, "Hardball," Kuhn later wrote, "If we let Finley's deals go through, how were we going to stop the weaker clubs from selling off players to the stronger ones, and what would become of competitive balance?"
What else have the Marlins done but "sold off" players to stronger teams? Although Kuhn believed Finley was liquidating his championship team, Finley said he planned to use the money he received for Blue, Rudi and Fingers -- who could have left as free agents -- to sign amateurs and rebuild his team.
Substitute minor league players for amateur players, and that is what the Marlins are doing. Minor league players might be closer to playing in the majors than amateur players, but Finley did a good job signing amateur players who became major league stars.
So has Selig erred in allowing the Marlins to decimate their championship team? One could conclude that he has if one wishes to use Kuhn's ruling as precedent.
Maybe Selig is right and Kuhn was wrong. Kuhn did not like Finley, and perhaps was predisposed to act against anything Finley did. Perhaps Kuhn would have viewed such sales differently had they been tried by, say, Walter O'Malley, his confidant and the owner of the Dodgers.
If Selig is right and it is O.K. for the Marlins to decimate themselves and make strong teams stronger, what was wrong with the Athletics, the Yankees and the Red Sox engaging in the same practice?
H. Wayne Huizenga, the grinch who gave Florida fans the World Series championship and then snatched it away, is in the process of selling the team to a group headed by the club president, Don Smiley. With a payroll that was slashed from $53 million at the end of last season to $33 million at the start of this season and now has plummeted, with the trade, to $24 million, Smiley is still not pleased. He is aiming for no more than $16 million in each of the next three years.
Such a paltry payroll does not make a team competitive. Montreal and Pittsburgh have learned that economic fact of baseball life. The Marlins know they will not be competitive for a few years. The Athletics would not have been competitive either for a few years had Kuhn allowed Finley to sell his players.
The Yankees, who won the American League pennant in 1976, and the Red Sox, who finished 15 1/2 games back, would have been stronger if they had been allowed to buy the players. The Dodgers expect to be stronger on balance after their trade with the Marlins. Sheffield, if he finally can find happiness, should flourish offensively; Johnson will help the underachieving pitching staff in ways Piazza could not, and Bonilla will replace Zeile at third base. If the trade serves as a catalyst to get them into serious division contention, they will have Selig to thank.
Perhaps this is one time where the later non-action (Selig's) should have served as the precedent for the earlier action (Kuhn's).

HEADLINE: Can Multinationals Be Trusted?;
A Global Absurdity

 BODY:

To the Editor:
American human rights advocates pressured Nike to accept further inspection of Asian factories (Business Day, May 13). They might call this progress, but we are losing the focal point of the criticism of Nike. The point is not only the child labor and low wages in Asia; it is also the absurd enterprise of American manufacturers in the global economy. 
 Jobs are taken away from American workers, and inordinately profitable products are sold to American consumers. This may be the reality of the market economy, but who thinks that it is decent to watch the birth of a number of billionaires on one side and the destruction of the American working class on the other?
 
PAUL KAZNSKY
Berkeley, Calif., May 13, 1998
 
The writer is a visiting scholar at the University of California School of Education.

LENGTH: 2120 words

HEADLINE: A New Major Player Joins Winery Business

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
TEN years ago, Long Island's maritime wine industry, then still in its adolescence, sought gurus among chateau executives and grape-growing experts in maritime Bordeaux. It invited a team of renowned grape-cultivation and wine-making experts, and picked their brains during four days of field trips and symposiums.
Today the 25-year-old industry, 20 wineries strong -- with more on the way -- has moved into young adulthood. And the French connection is as strong as ever, perhaps even stronger, because of the imminent opening of Macari Vineyards in Mattituck. 
 When the winery-visiting season unofficially begins on Memorial Day, Macari will make its debut, and, it seems, may immediately become one of the most important players in the East End wine trade.
Conceivably, Macari may inherit the mantle of the East End's most Francophile estate, which for a quarter-century has been held by Alex and Louisa Hargrave, who are selling the Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue.
The 1998 growing season also brings three smaller producers on stream for their first agricultural year in brand-new wineries: Laurel Lake Vineyards in Laurel, Ternhaven Cellars in Greenport and Channing Daughters in Bridgehampton, which hopes to open its winery on July 4. Corey Creek in Southold, whose wines are made elsewhere, opened a tasting room recently.
Macari's resources are considerable. They begin with nearly 115 planted acres on a 334-acre estate. Thirteen varieties of grapes are planted, all but one of them French. In addition, the vineyard manager, Bernard Ramis, and winemaker, Gilles Martin, were both born in France. Mr. Martin, who is 33, has worked in France, Germany, Australia, Virginia and California.
The wines will definitely have a French orientation, said Joseph T. Macari Jr., who with his father, Joseph Sr., are co-owners. "You can make wine easier in the French style with our fruit than with California fruit," Mr. Macari Jr. said.
"I believe in the appellation controlee system," Mr. Martin said, referring to the French law intended to insure that wine expresses local conditions. "My job is to have the wines have a Long Island style. My blends, of course, are conducted through my French taste buds."
The winery, at the site of the former Mattituck Hills Winery, is opening two years after the Macaris bought the bankrupt operation from the North Fork Bank. Mr. Macari Sr. said that, over many years, more than $9 million has been invested in the enterprise: in land and planting, redesigning and redoing the former Mattituck Hills installation and buying equipment.
The Macaris own 2,000 feet of waterfront, including a bluff overlooking Long Island Sound. "We have been thinking about putting a chateau up there," Mr. Macari Sr. said.
If all goes as the Macaris plan, the winery will ultimate join the ranks of the East End's high-production estates.
The biggest is Pindar in Peconic on the North Fork: 251 acres planted in 18 different grapes, and 67,000 cases of 15 kinds of wine produced in 1997. But that's only part of the story. Duck Walk, Pindar's sister winery in Water Mill on the South Fork, has 84 acres planted: 41 on the South Fork and 43 on the North Fork (32 once belonged to Mattituck Hills). Last year it produced nearly 20,000 cases of 10 different wines from 15 grape varieties.
Second in size is Palmer in Aquebogue: 126 acres owned and leased; 11 different kinds of grapes; in 1997, 23,500 cases of 11 kinds of wine.
Before opening its doors, Macari has produced 12,000 cases in a building that is designed to handle 20,000, with further expansion possible. "Our goal is to do 30,000 cases, all with our own grapes," Mr. Macari Jr. said.
Mr. Martin joined Macari last August. He holds an enology degree from Montpellier, France's great viticultural school, and did an apprenticeship in the Vacqueyras appellation in the Rhone. He worked at Weingut Hans Lang in the Rheingau region of Germany, at Houghton in western Australia, Oasis Winery in Virginia, as a consultant for Cotes du Rhone producers and as manager and wine maker at Delas Freres in the Rhone. For six years he was assistant wine maker at the Roederer Estate in Mendocino, which some critics (myself included) consider California's best sparkling-wine house.
Macari is ready to go with five wines (the prices are approximate): a 1996 barrel-fermented chardonnay ($14); a simpler 1997 chardonnay fermented in stainless steel ($12); 1996 merlot ($16); 1997 sauvignon blanc ($12) and a 1997 rose called Rose d'une Nuit, made of about 50 percent cabernet sauvignon and 50 percent cabernet franc ($11).
A 1997 barrel-fermented chardonnay is to be released in August or September. And sometime in 1999 Macari will release a brand-named Bordeaux-style proprietary wine composed of cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc, merlot and malbec.
In addition, 500 cases of sparkling wine, a blend of chardonnay and pinot meunier, were made for release in 1999.
The Macaris are longtime North Fork residents. Part of the estate is a 140-acre potato farm that has been in the family for 35 years. The Macaris also own a total of 190 more acres in the vicinity, 20 of which will be planted to chardonnay this year, as well as 4 acres of 8-year-old merlot vines around the winery, their oldest vines.
In addition to such reds as merlot (24 acres), cabernet franc (14), cabernet sauvignon (3), malbec (2), petit verdot (2), the property also has pinot noir (2) and pinot meunier (14 acres, of which 7 will be grafted over to merlot and 3 to pinot noir this year). There are also two acres of Dornfelder, a German grape.
As for whites, in addition to the chardonnay (26 acres), viognier (9), sauvignon blanc (7), there are pinot blanc (4) and semillon (nearly 2).
The quality of Macari fruit is respected, and it has been bought by other local producers: Laurel Lake, Palmer, Pellegrini and Schneider Vineyards (which has a Cutchogue office, owns no vines or winery but buys fruit and contracts with Bedell to make wine).
Managing that fruit is Mr. Ramis, Macari's 36-year-old vineyard manager, the son of a vineyard manager in the Languedoc region of France. "I am not a graduate from the university or something like that," he said. "Everything I know, I learned in the vineyard." He worked for an organic-wine producer in St.-Chinian, a red-wine appellation in the Languedoc, before taking a job with Mr. Macari in late 1996.
"Our long-term goal is to be organic," Mr. Ramis said. "This year I am going to do 2 acres 100 percent organic. I want to see the results. If it works, more next year."
The Macaris are looking for a distributor, and hope for placements in Long Island and New York City restaurants and retail stores before long.
Laurel Lake, representing an investment that the owner, Michael McGoldrick, puts at $3 million, opened in October. His winemaker is Gregory Gove, who previously worked for Pindar and the Hargrave Vineyard.
At present it is selling six wines: 1994 and 1996 regular chardonnays (each $15) and 1995 chardonnay reserve ($16), all made from Laurel Lake fruit by Dan Kleck at Palmer before the winery was built; a 1995 cabernet sauvignon ($24; made from purchased fruit by Eric Fry at the Lenz Winery); 1997 Lake Rose, a rose of cabernet sauvignon ($10), made by Mr. Gove, and nonvintage Wind Song ($8; a blend of chardonnay, pinot blanc and Cayuga White made in the Finger Lakes region upstate).
Mr. Gove has produced a 1997 reserve chardonnay from Laurel Lake fruit, which may be released in late summer.
Laurel Lake, whose production is 6,000 cases, was started in 1994 when Mr. McGoldrick bought the nearly 30-acre San Andreas Vineyard in Laurel. Only chardonnay is planted there: 15 acres, all planted in the early 1980's.
Like the duties at every serious boutique winery, Laurel Lake's is all-consuming. Mr. McGoldrick left the real estate and automobile-transmission-repair business only to find, not surprisingly, that he doesn't so much own the winery as it owns him.
He's working systematically around the handsome New England-style building, which houses a tasting room and the wine-production equipment, focusing recently on the landscaping. Some replanting of vines is under way, and planting of cabernet sauvignon and merlot are envisioned for 1999.
Channing Daughters, the most recent South Fork winery to go into business, was bonded in 1997 and started selling wine, made elsewhere, last winter. It hopes to open a winery, a converted six-year-old barn, on July 4. Larry Perrine, the former wine maker at Gristina Vineyards, is general manager and wine maker.
He is also a partner with the proprietors, Walter and Molly Channing, who named the winery for their four young daughters.
Winegrowing, like most agricultural enterprises, is capital-intensive and high-risk -- something appreciated by Mr. Channing, a partner in a Manhattan-based venture-capital fund specializing in the medical field, the C. W. Group. He puts his gearing-up investment in the business at $1 million to $1.5 million.
The first portion of his 20 acres of vines (on a 125-acre parcel), currently overseen by John Witherspoon, the vineyard manager, was planted in 1982. The unusual label depicts another passion -- in fact, a second profession -- of Mr. Channing's: wood sculpturing. The trees he carves can be seen on his property.
At 1,500 produced cases now, Channing Daughters could increase the quantity to 3,000 without adding tanks. At present it is selling a 1995 merlot (called Sculpture Garden; $17) and 1996 chardonnay (Brick Kiln; $17). This summer will bring a 1997 Brick Kiln chardonnay ($17), a lighter 1997 Scuttlehole chardonnay ($12) and a nonvintage merlot-cabernet franc blend called Fresh Red ($12). All are estate-grown.
The winery will also release a second label, Channing Perrine, whose wines are based on North Fork grapes. The first wines will be a 1997 sauvignon blanc carrying a Mudd Vineyard designation ($14), and a 1997 riesling with a Rolling Ridge Vineyard designation ($12), the grapes having come from that tract at Peconic Bay Vineyards.
The Channings' 20 acres consisting of chardonnay (9), merlot (4), cabernet franc (1), pinot gris (2), pinot blanc (2) and Lemberger (2), a versatile red grape that has been successful in Washington State.
The co-owner of Ternhaven Cellars, Harold Watts, a professor of economics at Columbia University for 22 years, recently taught his last class. But retirement won't mean a life of ease.
Establishing Ternhaven, the East End's smallest and easternmost winery -- 550 cases a year -- needs plenty of attention, and Mr. Watts's partner, Carole Donlin, a business consultant in Manhattan, pitches in. He is prepared for the heavy work. "I recently took delivery on a used forklift," he said.
Mr. Watts made the leap into professionalism from amateur wine making. He owns five acres of land, four in vines, on Alvah Lane in Cutchogue. He puts his overall investment in the wine business at about $400,000.
His business card announces "Traditional Bordeaux Style Reds," and so far they have taken the form of 1994 and 1995 cabernet sauvignons and merlots ($15 to $20), made by Russell Hearn at Pellegrini.
All the 1997's (to appear in 1999) were made by Mr. Watts at his winery, which is partly a converted, long-vacant gasoline station. Both partners are sales managers, taking the bottles around and finding placements in Long Island and New York City outlets.
Mr. Watts's grapes are also put into a blend drolly called Claret et d'Alvah ($17), which, he says, sells particularly well on the East End. Apparently the name marries well with local boosterism.

HEADLINE: HOW CHINESE WON RIGHTS TO LAUNCH SATELLITES FOR U.S.

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
On Oct. 9, 1995, Secretary of State Warren Christopher ended a lengthy debate within the Clinton Administration by initialing a classified order that preserved the State Department's sharp limits on China's ability to launch American-made satellites aboard Chinese rockets.
Both American industry and state-owned Chinese companies had been lobbying for years to get the satellites off what is known as the "munitions list," the inventory of America's most sensitive military and intelligence-gathering technology. But Mr. Christopher sided with the Defense Department, the intelligence agencies and some of his own advisers, who noted that commercial satellites held technological secrets that could jeopardize "significant military and intelligence interests." 
 There was one more reason not to ease the controls, they wrote in a classified memorandum. Doing so would "raise suspicions that we are trying to evade China sanctions" imposed when the country was caught shipping weapons technology abroad -- which is what happened in 1991 and 1993 for missile sales to Pakistan.
The Secretary of State's decision to keep satellites on the munitions list, making it harder for them to be exported, did not stand for long. Five months later, President Clinton took the unusual step of reversing it.
Control of export licensing for communications satellites was shifted to the Commerce Department, then run by Ronald H. Brown, who was deeply interested in promoting American businesses overseas and had been one of the Democratic Party's key fund-raising strategists. Several licenses have since been approved.
A reconstruction of Mr. Clinton's decision to change the export control rules, based on interviews and documents, shows that it followed a turf war between the State and Commerce Departments, and a broader debate over how to balance America's security concerns and commercial competition in the hottest of all the emerging markets.
It also illustrates the intersection of the interests of both large American donors and surreptitious foreign donors to the 1996 campaign.
Both American satellite makers and the Chinese were delighted with the decision because the Commerce Department has dual responsibilities: licensing sensitive exports and promoting sales of American goods around the world.
One of the beneficiaries of that decision, it now turns out, was China Aerospace because its rockets could launch American satellites. An executive of the state-owned Chinese company, Liu Chaoying, is said to have provided tens of thousands of dollars from Chinese military intelligence to the Democratic Party in the summer of 1996.
Ms. Liu's involvement was described to Federal investigators recently by Johnny Chung, a Democratic fund-raiser who says he took $300,000 from Ms. Liu -- who is also a lieutenant colonel in the Chinese military -- and donated almost $100,000 of it to Democratic causes, apparently keeping the rest for his businesses.
President Clinton's decision was announced in March 1996, several months before the donations were made. But the actual change was delayed until the fall.
The White House said it did not know the source of Mr. Chung's donations and denies that the decision was influenced by campaign donations, domestic or foreign.
"This was motivated by competitiveness and streamlining bureaucracy concerns, and nothing else," Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, said in an interview two weeks ago.
On Friday, Mr. Berger's spokesman, Eric Rubin, said the decision was also part of the Administration's China policy, and specifically its effort to encourage China to clamp down on military exports.
"On many occasions, this was discussed with the Chinese Government because we believe that policy on satellite licenses is one of the tools we have to strengthen our nonproliferation policy," Mr. Rubin said.
Mr. Clinton's decision took place after months of tension with Beijing.
In January reports of China's export of nuclear technology to Pakistan and missiles to Iran caused considerable concern in Congress and the Pentagon. In early May, two months after Mr. Clinton reversed the Secretary of State, the Administration said China had agreed to curb its missile and nuclear exports. But that announcement was greeted with considerable skepticism by Republican critics, including Bob Dole, who was well on the way to getting the nomination for President.
During the campaign, the Republicans attacked Mr. Clinton for failing to curb China's sales of nuclear and missile technology to other countries.
The satellite decision in March was one element of the Administration's "carrot-and-stick-approach to working with China," said James Lilley, a former United States Ambassador to Beijing.
But in the way business and diplomacy mix in Washington's dealings with China, the decision also resonated in boardrooms on both sides of the Pacific. It satisfied the commercial interests of the American aerospace industry, which had long sought access to China's low-cost ability to launch satellites into space, aboard rockets called the Long March.
And it bolstered China's own commercial interests. Ms. Liu's parent company, China Aerospace, owns a large piece of a Hong Kong satellite operator. It also owns the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, the rocket company that launches both private satellites and tests and provides equipment for the missiles in China's nuclear arsenal. It was Great Wall that the State Department sanctioned in 1991 and 1993 for selling missiles to Pakistan.
Other powerful Chinese state enterprises also had multibillion-dollar stakes in getting access to American satellites. Among them was the China International Trade and Investment Corporation, whose chairman, Wang Jun, gained unwanted attention in the United States last year when it was revealed that he attended one of Mr. Clinton's campaign coffee meetings in the White House. The day of Mr. Wang's visit, Mr. Clinton, in what Mr. Rubin said was a coincidence, signed waivers allowing the Chinese to launch four American satellites -- though they were unrelated to the business interests of China International Trade.
"Any suggestions that these decisions were influenced by Wang Jun's presence in the U.S. is completely unfounded," Mr. Rubin said.
It is not known what motivated Ms. Liu or the Chinese military to make the donations. Ms. Liu's father, Gen. Liu Huaqing, was not only China's highest military officer but a member of the leadership of the Communist Party.
The White House and the Democratic National Committee deny any knowledge of the source of Mr. Chung's $366,000 in donations, most predating his connection with Ms. Liu, and all of which was returned.
But there is no doubt that American companies -- partners and suppliers of China International Trade and China Aerospace -- put enormous pressure on the White House. They were also important campaign contributors. For example, the chief executive of Loral Space and Communications gave $275,000 between November 1995 and June 1996 to the Democrats.
 
The Precursor
A Lobbying Effort To Persuade Bush
China's drive to obtain a steady stream of satellite technology from the United States preceded the Clinton Administration's arrival in Washington.
In 1990, just a year after the killings at Tiananmen Square, officials from China Aerospace and the Chinese Government approached Mr. Lilley, the American Ambassador, pressing for President Bush to waive restrictions enacted in the aftermath of Tiananmen that barred China from launching American satellites.
"They hit me very hard," Mr. Lilley recalled recently. "It was a prestige national program. It was putting China on the map as the big space country of the 21st century."
Mr. Bush, who became America's first permanent representative in Communist China in 1974, granted a waiver that allowed a launching on one of China's Long March rockets. In 1992, a number of Senators -- including Al Gore, then still a Senator from Tennessee -- wrote to the Bush Administration warning that China was using the launchings to "gain foreign aerospace technology that would be otherwise unavailable to it."
In the last days of the 1992 Presidential campaign, Mr. Gore made the waivers an issue, contending that President Bush "has permitted five additional American-built satellites to be launched by the Chinese."
"President Bush really is an incurable patsy for those dictators he sets out to coddle," Mr. Gore said in a speech at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.
 
The Argument
Business Leaders Pressure Clinton
Almost as soon as Mr. Clinton took office, business leaders began their campaign to drastically change his views about China.
Both Chinese and American companies were working to get satellites off the State Department's munitions list. The rules for exporting goods that are on the list are particularly tough. Congress must be notified 30 days in advance. Moreover, the State Department considers only nonproliferation issues and defers to the Pentagon's judgments.
In contrast, the Commerce Department's export-control administration solicits a host of views and must weigh the effects of its decisions on America's competitive position.
Mr. Christopher's aides also noted in their 1995 classified memorandum that "U.S. firms remain concerned there could be additional sanctions imposed on China precluding future munitions licenses," exactly the kind of sanctions that had been only recently lifted for China Aerospace's subsidiaries.
And there was a lot at stake: an estimated 14 commercial communications satellite launchings a year worldwide, costing several hundred million dollars apiece.
"The business community regarded the inclusion of civilian satellites on the munitions list as an insult," said William A. Reinsch, the Under Secretary of Commerce for export control, who fought Mr. Christopher's decision. "We're the only country that treats them that way."
The Chinese also understood that they had a huge stake in the outcome of the decision. Zuoyi Huang, president of the California subsidiary of China Great Wall, a part of the China Aerospace empire, said in an interview that his company was eager for any changes that would insure easier access to American technology.
"The license takes time," he said. "You have to get a waiver from the President. The customers can't wait. It's just pure commercial use. It's not a military threat to the United States."
 
The Review
A Decision Against And a Quick Appeal
The arguments came to a head in 1995. C. Michael Armstrong, then the chief executive of Hughes Electronics and newly chosen as the head of President Clinton's export council, asked to meet Mr. Christopher. He urged that satellites, which his company produces, no longer be treated as military goods.
The Secretary of State promised that he would conduct a detailed review in consultation with the Department of Defense, the C.I.A. and the National Security Agency and the Department of Commerce.
But the majority of the interagency group quickly found itself at odds with the aerospace industry. A major issue was how to protect encryption equipment, which is built into a satellite and interprets instructions from ground controllers who manipulate the satellite once it is in orbit. Similar devices are used to communicate with American spy satellites, and the Pentagon and intelligence agencies worried that anyone who could crack the code could take control of the satellites themselves.
On Aug. 17, 1995, a memorandum prepared for the interagency group noted that the chief executive of a satellite company told Mr. Christopher that "once it is embedded in the satellite, the encryption device has no military significance." Thus, the industry argued, there was little risk that the Chinese would get their hands on the encryption devices -- especially because American military officials are supposed to watch the satellites with care when they are in Chinese hands.
But, the memorandum went on, "the national security position" is that "the nature of the device itself," not its location, "should be used to determine whether it must be controlled as a military item."
The encryption issue was one of the main reasons the interagency group -- over the objections of the Commerce Department -- recommended that satellites remain on the munitions list. Mr. Christopher concurred. Soon after Mr. Christopher put his initials on the decision memorandum, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown appealed the decision to the President.
 
The Turnaround
The Commerce Dept. Wins a Turf Battle
The debate surrounding the appeal did not heat up for four months. The nature of the arguments that went to the White House is still unclear: many of the documents remain classified. But those that have been reviewed by The New York Times show that the White House and the Commerce Department began communicating again about the issue on Feb. 8, 1996, two days after President Clinton broke a backlog of applications for launchings by China, by approving four of them that day.
Mr. Clinton signed those waivers the same day that Wang Jun, the man who was often referred to during the campaign finance investigations as a "Chinese arms dealer," visited Washington. His company, the China International Trade and Investment Corporation, has a multibillion-dollar stake in one of Hong Kong's largest satellite companies.
That same day, Mr. Wang met with Mr. Brown, at his expansive office in the Commerce Department. And that evening, Mr. Wang attended a coffee at the White House, an event Mr. Clinton later called "clearly inappropriate." Others at the coffee said Mr. Wang never spoke during the session.
By mid-February, for reasons that are still murky, there seemed to be some urgency at the White House to decide whether to reverse Mr. Christopher's decision, shifting satellite export licensing to the Commerce Department.
A Feb. 15 State Department memorandum talks about speeding up the process because "the Administration wanted to wrap this up."
In the end, the State Department relented. Participants in the final debate said that the President concluded that the technology could be protected through the Commerce Department, just as the department protects supercomputers and other sensitive technologies.
The President's decision was announced on March 14. Commerce officials, who had just won one of Washington's nastiest turf wars, were jubilant.
"Good news," officials were told by E-mail. The electronic message went on to recommend a "low key" spin on the news that would "not draw attention to the decision."
Internal Commerce Department documents show that officials were anticipating questions from reporters and Congress about whether the decision represented an effort to ease technology transfers to China and remove items from sanctions -- some of the same concerns that figured in Mr. Christopher's decision.
In the days preceding the announcement, China had raised tensions with its Asian neighbors and the United States to new heights, firing M-9 ballistic missiles, which carried dummy warheads, into target zones 30 miles off the shore of Taiwan.
The March 14 announcement said that regulations putting into effect the President's decision would be issued within 30 days. But the bureaucratic infighting continued.
Finally, the State Department issued the regulations shifting most satellite licensing to the Commerce Department.
They were published on Nov. 5, 1996, the day President Clinton was re-elected.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "From Sanctions to Satellite Licenses"
Between 1993 and 1996, the Clinton Administration dropped its sanctions on China Aerospace, a state-owned Chinese company, for selling missiles to Pakistan and gave the company permission to launch private United States communications satellites, despite some lingering concerns in the Administration about security.
 
August 1993 -- State Department imposes economic sanctions against subsidiaries of Beijing-based China Aerospace for selling missiles to Pakistan. The sanctions bar American companies from doing business with the concerns.
 
Sept.-Oct. 1993 -- Michael Armstrong, the chief executive of Hughes Electronics Corp., tells the President the sanctions hurt his company because China Aerospace is a low-cost launcher of satellites.
 
Nov. 1993 -- The Administration signals it might ease satellite licensing procedures and Mr. Armstrong relays to the White House an encouraging reaction from his contacts in China.
 
April 1995 -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher begins an interagency review of restrictions on the export of communi-cations satellites at Mr. Armstrong's urging. The companies want to see responsibility for the issue shifted to the Commerce Department.
 
Oct. 9, 1995 -- Following hte recommendation of the Pentagon, intelligence agencies and his advisers, Mr. Christopher keeps satellites under the purview of the State Department. The Commerce Department appeals this decision to President Clinton.
 
Feb. 6, 1996 -- With the relations between the United States and China tense over Beijing's military operations and sales, President Clinton approves the launch of four American satellites by Chinese rockets.
 
Mid-February 1996 -- The White House revives the effort to ease restrictions on satellite exports, reviewing anew Mr. Christopher's decision.
 
March 8-15, 1996 -- China conducts missile tests near Taiwan, signalling its displeasure over talk of Taiwanese independence during Taiwan's elections.

HEADLINE: The New New Left

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan is the author of "John Dewey and the High Tide of American Liberalism."

 BODY:

ACHIEVING OUR COUNTRY
 Leftist Thought in
 Twentieth-Century America.
 By Richard Rorty.
 159 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $18.95. 
 Richard Rorty is a scandal to his profession. He is a philosopher who thinks that philosophy is a distraction from more important matters. He has for years argued that the pursuit of Truth -- as distinct from the humbler search for usable truths -- is fueled by self-deception. He has insisted that even if humanity all too often behaves cruelly and sadistically, we would be better off without a sense of sin. Nevertheless, Rorty has a substantial streak of filial piety. It was his hero, John Dewey, who first scandalized his philosophical readers almost a century ago by urging them to turn away from "the problems of philosophy" to "the problems of men." "Achieving Our Country" is an appeal to American intellectuals to abandon the intransigent cynicism of the academic, cultural left and to return to the political ambitions of Emerson, Dewey, Herbert Croly and their allies.
What Rorty has written -- as deftly, amusingly and cleverly as he always writes -- is a lay sermon for the untheological. Walt Whitman, another of his heroes, memorably wrote, "And I call to mankind, Be not curious about God, / For I who am curious about each am not curious about God." Rorty's gloss on this is that "there is no standard, not even a divine one, against which the decisions of a free people can be measured." We do not need to know what God wants but what we are capable of wanting and doing. Americans, at any rate Americans pre-eminently, have embarked on a voyage into uncharted waters. They have set out to realize the American dream, knowing that they will change their minds about what it is, but sharing a religious attachment to the idea of a society devoted to earthly happiness, freedom, tolerance and mutual affection.
In fact, Rorty's argument against intransigent leftists and superstitious conservatives has a still longer pedigree. At the outbreak of the French Revolution in 1789, a London Dissenting minister, the Rev. Richard Price, preached a "Discourse on the Love of Our Country," which provoked the greatest of conservative tracts, Edmund Burke's "Reflections on the Revolution in France." Price defended a rational love of country. A democratic country that cared for all its people, and governed them equitably and intelligently, we might justly take pride in. Habitual allegiance to kings and aristocrats was no condition for a free person. Price was so comprehensively buried by Burke's ragings against revolutionary excess that it has been difficult ever since for the left to express pride in country.
But Rorty thinks that national pride is the political equivalent of individual self-respect. Without it, nothing can be achieved. The obvious corruption of national pride occurs when it turns into national self-aggrandizement or into a brutal enthusiasm for simple military might. A proper love of country is entirely consistent with wanting a more effective United Nations to preserve world peace, and with regarding the Vietnam War as an unmitigated disaster -- and Rorty is indeed an internationalist who regards the Vietnam War as an unmitigated disaster. It is also consistent with being entirely unforgiving about the atrocities that besmirch the history of the United States, as they do the history of every other country. The conservative wish to take our eyes off our country's shortcomings is not one that Rorty shares.
But his main target is his allies rather than his more obvious opponents. The title "Achieving Our Country" is drawn from the famous last sentence of James Baldwin's "Fire Next Time." There, Baldwin called on the saving remnant, "the relatively conscious whites and the relatively conscious blacks," to "end the racial nightmare, and achieve our country, and change the history of the world." The point of invoking James Baldwin, of course, is that he was entirely unforgiving of his country's sins and still looked forward with hope to a better future. A left that fights for the political and economic changes that will "achieve our country" is the left that the United States once possessed and needs as much as ever, but is hardly to be seen.
This is not an unfamiliar complaint. Many writers have lamented the decline of the so-called public intellectual, and have blamed the post-1945 explosion of higher education for taking intellectual life off the street and into the ivory tower. The novelty of Richard Rorty's version of the complaint, however, lies in the very particular and very American gloss that he puts on it. Borrowing one of John Dewey's most famous and most contentious claims, Rorty, who is University Professor of Humanities at the University of Virginia, argues that some philosophical views -- almost all philosophical views, in fact -- take a "spectatorial" view of the world and therefore of human life. Philosophers have wanted to find ultimate standards, absolute standards, eternal standards, whether of Truth, Beauty or Goodness, and have supposed that their task is to measure the world by them.
FEW thinkers other than the American pragmatists have had the courage to insist that it is life itself that justifies our ideas about what is true, good or beautiful. But only someone who thinks that, or who believes it without raising the question in the first place, can have the kind of "participatory" grasp of the world celebrated by Whitman and Dewey. The bearing of this on our current discontents is the substance of the Massey Lectures on which this short book is based. The standing temptation for intellectuals is to mistake theoretical radicalism for something politically more useful. Marxism, Rorty says, is something that Americans could well have done without: "It would be a good thing if the next generation of American leftists found as little resonance in the names of Karl Marx and Vladimir Ilyich Lenin as in those of Herbert Spencer and Benito Mussolini. It would be an even better thing if the names of Ely and Croly, Dreiser and Debs, A. Philip Randolph and John L. Lewis were more familiar to these leftists than they were to the students of the 60's."
Marxism, however, is hardly the flavor of the month on American campuses. The more present threat is posed by the approach to literary and cultural studies that consists essentially in unmasking every event and every text as a shield for or a response to patriarchy and racism. It is not that Rorty thinks that the cultural left has no achievements to its credit; its attacks on the cruelties of private life and on racial and sexual insult have done a lot of good. But it has ignored the issues that the reformist left once made its own: jobs and job security, income inequality, money in politics. Combating sexism in literature is a good thing, but less good than preventing the corporate bagmen from making their rounds in Congress.
Those of us who share Richard Rorty's view that the United States of America is a grand romantic poem to which we should all contribute our best stanzas will enjoy "Achieving Our Country." What of those whom it criticizes -- despairing Heideggerians, or Foucaultian antihumanists, or even the disciples of Reinhold Niebuhr, decent liberals smitten with a deep sense of original and inescapable sin? It is hard to say. Sometimes Rorty shrugs, as if to signal that they have their visions and he has his and the facts cannot choose between them. In which case he will surely find himself saying, "I played and you did not sing; I piped and you did not dance." More often he argues, as any good social democrat might, that we would do better to try to improve the world than lament its fallen condition. On that he will carry with him a good many readers, even those who might be inclined to quibble with his views on poetry, philosophy and the history of the United States.

HEADLINE: MEDIA TALK;
As Print Revenue Ebbs, www.juneplaymate.com?

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
The on-line version of Playboy, with 25,000 paying customers, is not going to obscure the magazine's 4.5 million subscribers worldwide anytime soon. But the Internet business was the only bright spot in an otherwise dismal quarterly report this month.
The magazine publishing group reported minuscule earnings last quarter and a 30 percent decline in newsstand revenue compared with the corresponding quarter in 1997. Advertising revenue was down 11 percent. The World Wide Web site, a mixture of advertising and subscriber-supported content from the magazine, as well as a catalogue of Playboy-brand merchandise for sale, showed 84 percent growth, to $1.42 million from $772,000. 
 What does Christie Hefner, chairwoman and chief executive of Playboy Enterprises Inc., the empire started by her father in 1953, make of this? In a statement, Ms. Hefner said she thought Playboy could become "the first true global multimedia brand and do so with a much lower investment in marketing than is needed by other Internet companies."
Besides the brand, analysts say, the on-line service has another thing going for it: its content. "Adult revenue is one of the very few areas where people are willing to pay, and that opens a whole new revenue stream that The New York Times or ABCNews.com does not have available to it," said Bill Bass, an analyst with Forrester Research in Boston.
Purchased each month on the newsstand, Playboy magazine costs $61.40 a year. On line, it is free -- unless you choose a premium subscription service called Playboy Cyberclub, which offers additional features like chat rooms and archives of every Playmate and cover in the magazine's 45-year history. That costs $60 a year. LISA NAPOLI

HEADLINE: U.S. vs. Private Industry: A Look Back

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
If the Justice Department and Attorneys General of 20 states file antitrust lawsuits against Microsoft today, as they are expected to do, the ensuing fight could be one of the biggest ever between the Government and private industry over what constitutes unfair monopolistic business practices. Here are some of the biggest past cases. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

GRAPHIC: Chart:
 
DEFENDANT -- Standard Oil of New Jersey
CHARGE -- Monopolizing oil business by buying rivals, forcing rail-roads to discriminate against other rivals and buying up pipelines so that competitors could not use them.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 5 years (1906-1911)
OUTCOME -- Found guilty
RESULT -- Standard Oil was split into 34 companies, many of which are now among the world's largest oil companies, including Exxon, Mobil, Chevron and Amoco.
 
DEFENDANT -- American Tobacco
CHARGE -- Monopolizing the cigarette trade through practices like predatory pricing and excluding rivals from access to wholesalers.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 4 years (1907-1911)
OUTCOME -- Found guilty
RESULT -- Split into 16 pieces, including American Tobacco, Reynolds, Liggett & Myers and P. Lorillard.
 
DEFENDANT -- U.S. Steel
CHARGE -- Monopolizing the steel business by its sheer size. The company controlled about two-thirds of the market and met regularly with rivals to set prices.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 9 years (1911-1920)
OUTCOME -- Found not guilty
RESULT -- The Supreme Court ruled that sheer size alone did not constitute a monopoly. The decision brought a halt to big antitrust cases for almost 20 years.
 
DEFENDANT -- Aluminum Company of America
CHARGE -- Monopolizing aluminum production by its sheer size and by its ability to anticipate and satisfy demand for aluminum faster and at a lower cost than rivals.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 8 years (1937-1945)
OUTCOME -- Found guilty
RESULT -- An appeals court found that the company was anticompetitive. To remedy this, the Government auctioned off some wartime plants operated by Alcoa to smaller aluminum companies.
 
DEFENDANT -- Five movie studios
CHARGE -- Monopolizing movie distribution by owning 70 percent of the theaters, and collaborating to contraol which films were shown, where and for how long.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 10 years (1938-1948)
OUTCOME -- Found uilty
Paramount Pictures and four other studios
 
DEFENDANT -- I.B.M.
CHARGE -- Monopolizing the computer market, including computer hardware, software and services.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 13 years (1969-1982)
OUTCOME -- Case dropped
RESULT -- After the case was prosecuted by three different administrations, the Justice Department decided that the suit had no merit.
 
DEFENDANT -- AT&T
CHARGE -- Using its monopoly of local phone service to keep competitors out of the long-distance and telephone equipment markets.
HOW LONG THE CASE LASTED -- 8 years (1974-1982)
OUTCOME -- Settled
RESULT -- Settling the case on the same day as the I.B.M. suit was dropped, AT&T agreed to spin off its local phone companies.
 
(Sources: David Ross, associate professor of economics, Bryn Mawr College; Industrial Market Structure and Economic Performance by F. M. Scherer and David Ross)

HEADLINE: SIMON & SCHUSTER IN SALE TO BRITISH

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT with ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
Pearson P.L.C., Britain's largest publisher, and a Dallas investment firm agreed yesterday to buy most of Simon & Schuster's operations from Viacom Inc. for $4.6 billion in cash, accelerating the flow of America's publishing houses into foreign hands.
In one of the largest publishing deals to date, Pearson, which already owns the Penguin Group, a prominent consumer trade player, will add Simon & Schuster's education division for $3.6 billion, while the leveraged buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. will take the reference, business and professional divisions for $1 billion. 
 Pearson's empire includes such varied interests as Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and The Financial Times. The deal will make it the largest publisher of educational textbooks in the United States, a market it believes is growing because of a new baby boom and a trend toward increasing spending on education. Though trade publishing is more glamorous, educational books are more profitable.
Viacom, a media conglomerate that owns Paramount Communications and such cable television channels as MTV and Nickelodeon, will keep the consumer trade division, which last year accounted for about one-fifth of Simon & Schuster's $2.47 billion in revenue. Its imprints publish authors like Frank McCourt and Stephen King.
The deal was completed after heated competition from another leveraged buyout firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, and a group headed by Michael R. Milken, the financier who was convicted of securities fraud. It further restructures the American publishing industry, which has undergone considerable consolidation in the last decade.
Foreign companies have been aggressively buying American trade publishers. In March, Bertelsmann A.G., a German media conglomerate that already owned the Bantam Doubleday Dell Group, agreed to buy Random House from Advance Publications for $1.4 billion.
But Pearson has been the only major purchaser of educational publishers, having already acquired Scott Foresman in 1996 and Addison Wesley Longman in 1988.
Pearson's determination to seize a larger share of this side of the business fueled its victory over the two other well-financed bidders.
However, Pearson had widely been considered the front-runner. It already had a large publishing business and could benefit from major economies of scale in a merger, making the high cost of the purchase less onorous. Originally, Hicks Muse had indicated it would bid alone, and joined with Pearson only recently.
For the Viacom chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, the price was considered a strong one, since analysts had forecast the sale would fetch $4 billion to $5 billion. Mr. Redstone is considered a savvy salesman and even over the weekend bidders were still revising their offers before the Viacom board held a 10 A.M. meeting by telephone yesterday.
Mr. Milken's group, which was said to include Tele-Communications Inc., the News Corporation and two leveraged buyout firms -- the Thomas Lee Company and Apollo Advisors -- raised its bid late last week to $4.1 billion from $3.8 billion, according to a person close to the discussions. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reportedly bid about $4.2 billion, according to a person close to the talks.
Then yesterday, the Milken group learned that the Pearson-Hicks Muse team had the highest bid and so it tried to buy pieces of the company it wanted. It believed that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was itself trying to acquire other pieces and that combined, the two offers might be greater than Pearson-Hicks Muse's, the person close to the talks said. But that plan fell apart.
The Milken group had offered to buy the entire company, including Simon & Schuster's trade publishing unit, according to two people involved in the negotiations. The News Corporation, which owns HarperCollins, was said to have sought the trade book operation for itself, though its bid was very low, and was not taken seriously.
The sale will net Viacom $3.8 billion. Morgan Stanley was advising Viacom, Goldman, Sachs was advising Pearson and Greenhill advised Hicks Muse.
But even for companies heavily committed to print, the educational business has broad appeal. As Marjorie M. Scardino, Pearson's chief executive, put it yesterday in a telephone interview from London: "This is a very good time to be in the educational business. For us, this is perfectly complementary, and we believe the education market is very fast growing."
For Pearson, which had 1997 revenue of $3.8 billion from holdings that also include interests in trade and educational publishing, 50 percent of The Economist and a television programming business, the purchase is a heavy bet on print publishing.
But Marta Nichols, a research analyst who follows educational services and book publishing for Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette, pointed out yesterday that school systems in many states are adopting new curricula that require the development of instructional materials. She added that there is a swell in the school-age population from kindergarten through college and that a strong United States economy has prompted governments at both the state and Federal levels to pour millions of dollars into education.
Pearson had an operating profit of $531 million in 1997 of which roughly $100 million came from its educational publishing business. With the acquisition, Pearson, whose educational publishing had revenue of $900 million, will add $1.4 billion in sales from Simon & Schuster for a total of $2.3 billion. Simon & Schuster's educational operations will contribute $232 million in operating profits.
Pearson will compete with McGraw-Hill and Harcourt in the textbook field.
Ms. Scardino said the merger would generate cost savings in marketing distribution, back office and warehousing that could be more than $100 million. The sale will make its combined elementary and high school operations -- which had been, in the words of one publishing expert, "an also ran" -- the second- or third-largest in the business. The deal will also provide it with a strong technological offering in computer based education.
Pearson will become the leader in college publishing, bringing together Simon & Schuster, which was already the market leader with roughly 23 percent of the market, with Pearson's 8 percent of the college market.
Pearson is paying roughly 15 times Simon & Schuster's estimated 1998 cash flow of $320 million. Over the years, Pearson has been criticized for overpaying in some cases, particularly in its acquisition of Mindscape, a California computer game outfit. Though it is paying a full price for Simon & Schuster, analysts generally said yesterday that in selling off parts of the business to Hicks Muse, Ms. Scardino had found a savvy way to get the businesses Pearson wanted. It is financing the deal with bank debt.
Meg Geldens, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in London, said yesterday that she believed Pearson had paid a high price, but that if the company generated that level of cost saving, it could be a good deal. "Strategically, it certainly makes sense," she said.
For Hicks Muse, the purchase of the Simon & Schuster divisions augments a media empire that already includes major interests in radio, movie theaters and television. The firm has effective control of Chancellor Broadcasting, the nation's second-largest radio chain after the $1 billion purchase of several stations from Viacom last year. Chancellor's presence in most of the nation's major markets includes four stations in New York.
In partnership with Kohlberg Kravis, Hicks Muse also controls the nation's largest chain of movie theaters. Last October, Hicks Muse joined with NBC to buy the Lin Television Corporation for $1.7 billion.
Michael J. Levitt, a Hicks Muse partner, said that the Simon & Schuster purchase would form a foundation for further acquisitions, especially in reference, business and professional publishing.
He described the purchase as consistent with the firm's acquisitions in other areas, including branded foods. "We're interested in buying high-quality assets with excellent management teams in industries which we can consolidate," he said. "In terms of our investment strategy, it's right down the middle of the fairway."
From Simon & Schuster, Hicks Muse will receive titles that include the Betty Crocker cookbooks, Webster's New World Dictionary, Frommer's travel guides, and Macmillan computer books including the Idiot's Guide series. Mr. Levitt acknowledged that his prediction of double-digit growth in the acquired divisions would depend in part on the continued popularity of the computer guides, but noted that the same content could also be offered over the Internet.
