HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Even without 'Seinfeld,' NBC is the network that others build their fall schedules around.

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

 BODY:
FOR sheer intensity and nail-biting suspense, nothing on any show on any television network compares with what will happen this week inside suites of rooms here in New York that will be occupied by executives trying to decide which shows will go where in prime-time schedules next year.
In the space of four days, four networks and two would-be networks will announce their fall programming plans to the advertising industry in a series of elaborate stage presentations in atmospheric show business locales ranging from Radio City Music Hall to Carnegie Hall and the New Amsterdam Theater. 
 As one senior executive involved in the process put it, "Things have never been so unclear this late in the process." And the process, known as the upfront -- because the goal is to get advertisers to commit money to the networks in advance of the start of the fall season -- has never been so compressed, with all the activity crammed into 96 hours. It usually takes up to 10 days.
Driving much of the uncertainty is the situation that faces NBC, television's dominant network, which will lead off the round of schedule announcements today at Radio City.
NBC's decisions, which network executives were still mulling on Friday when programmers flew to New York from Los Angeles to prepare for the presentation, are crucial to the strategies at all the other networks because of the perception that NBC could be more vulnerable next year than in any recent year.
The reason is the absence of "Seinfeld," the pillar around which NBC built its Thursday night fortress over the last five years. Even though NBC continues to own more hits than most of the other networks put together and is coming off its best performance in a May ratings sweep in 10 years, there is a sense in the business that somebody may finally take a shot at going after NBC.
NBC has often put the other networks in its own sights and fired off programs to compete head to head with the hits on those other networks. That is one reason that no other network took the step of announcing its schedule before NBC.
No rule says that the leading network has to take the first step in this annual spring dance. NBC, whose executives have never been accused of a lack of confidence, has gone first for the last several years. NBC even went first five years ago when it was in third place.
But this season NBC gave all its competitors a chance to slide up their announcement dates by moving the NBC date one week later into May. For several previous years the network selected the second Monday in May as its announcement date. But each year that turned out to be the Monday after Mother's Day. Many executives' families protested, so NBC moved the date this year.
Another network could easily have picked last Wednesday or Friday for its presentation and helped ease the logjam this week -- none did. "They knew they had to go after NBC," said one executive with interests in many programs. "So many calls were riding on the moves NBC made."
ABC, for example, has been trying to figure whether it makes sense to move its hit comedy "The Drew Carey Show" from Wednesday to Tuesday to try to forestall NBC's growing success on that night. CBS, looking for a safe haven for comedies, has wanted to know if NBC will still try to start Wednesday night off with comedies.
Most of all, the whole industry has been on edge awaiting NBC's decisions about Thursday, a night of television so powerful that no other network has even tried to challenge NBC there since "Friends" and "E.R." began four years ago.
But Thursday has become the supreme prize in the Cracker Jack box of the television economy because of the amount of movie advertising money that has flowed into television in the last decade. Movie companies will pay premiums to reach the right audience on Thursdays because most movies open on Fridays. (Movie ads were everywhere in the "Seinfeld" finale last week.)
No network has watched NBC's Thursday machinations more closely than Fox, which would love nothing better than to get a beachhead on Thursday and some access to that movie money.
The question being debated in many program circles is, will Fox move its brush-fire hit, "Ally McBeal" to Thursday?
Even the would-be networks, WB and UPN, have had an eye on NBC, looking for a possible discard from NBC's well-stocked pile that might enhance their schedules.
Canceled shows moving from one network to another have become a new trend during upfront week. Last year ABC picked up "Something So Right," a last-minute cancellation by NBC. It did not do any better on ABC, however, possibly because ABC made the mistake of keeping it off the air for half a season.
CBS grabbed "JAG" off the NBC reject pile two years ago, and the show has become one of the most successful on the network. This year WB may be interested in picking off such likely canceled offerings as CBS's "Gregory Hines Show."
"Shows more than ever are going to be looking for a different network to pick them up," a leading TV talent agent said. "The studios have so much invested, and if a show gets canceled any time in the first year or two, they lose their whole investment. They'll be pushing every button to keep a show alive."

HEADLINE: Dominican Opposition Wins Without Chief

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17

 BODY:
Despite the death of its charismatic leader, this country's main opposition party has won a sweeping victory in congressional and municipal elections that were being closely watched in the United States because of their probable effects on efforts to curtail drug trafficking and to modernize the economy.
Based on nearly-complete official results made public today, the left-center Democratic Revolutionary Party has won at least 23 of the 30 Senate seats that were at stake in Saturday's balloting and will have a comfortable margin in the lower house of congress. 
 The party also won the most important mayoral race, in the capital, where the merengue singer Johnny Ventura, a last-minute replacement for the party's leader, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, swept to victory.
The outcome is a sharp blow to President Leonel Fernandez. He had been looking to the midterm vote to break a congressional impasse that has made it difficult to enact legislation that would open the economy and impose harsher sanctions for drug trafficking.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy with Ron Alexander

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
Floyd Landis was walking along East 61st Street when he heard the loud bark of a dog, seemingly coming from an air shaft covered by an iron grill. A fellow stroller who had also heard the barking was peering down the shaft, and both men wondered how the dog had got there. They wondered, too, whether they would be able to get him out -- until they spotted a small sign near the shaft.
ATTENTION
The dog is not trapped in a
hole, he is in a full basement
with a ramp that leads to a
nice little backyard
We understand your concern
but assure you that we treat this
dog better than we treat
ourselves.
We would appreciate not
being insulted by
unwarranted accusations.
Thank you
Max's Mom and Dad 
 At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dan Rustin overheard this interesting, if impractical, observation: "With all the people here to be seen, they ought to let the pictures walk around and hang the people on the wall."
Teresa Schmittroth took Allison Balter, her 5-year-old niece, to the Museum of Modern Art. To her aunt's amazement, Allison, who apparently had seen it on Sesame Street, said, "Let's go see the gypsy painting, the one with the gypsy laying down."
They made their way to the Impressionist galleries and Henri Rousseau's "The Sleeping Gypsy" where Mrs. Schmittroth read aloud the information on the wall label: the artist's name, nationality, date of birth and death. "What? He's dead?" Allison exclaimed. As she began to approach the painting, her aunt cautioned her not to touch it. "Why?" Allison asked. "What does he care? He's dead."
Judy Cohen was sitting on a bench in a sports store with Sasha, her 17-year-old son. While they waited for the salesman to return with some sneakers, Mrs. Cohen put her arm around her son and leaned her head on his shoulder.
"I wonder why some kids don't let their Moms hug them," she mused aloud.
She didn't wonder long. Her son knew exactly why. "Because it's annoying," he said.
Dr. Claude W. Springer, a bass singer with the Great Neck Choral Society, was relaxing during the rehearsal break when a soprano raised her hand and announced that she was moving to Vermont. "If anyone is interested, I am leaving behind. . . " she said and paused. Her fellow singers speculated -- car? furniture? books?
"A wonderful cleaning lady," she concluded. Five hands shot up.
Ruth F. Braun, whose age grants her special privilege on public transportation, recently offered her bus seat to a very visibly pregnant young woman. "I'm not sick, I'm pregnant," the woman responded. Mrs. Braun did not reply but another passenger couldn't resist. "Maybe your baby would like to sit," she said.
Dear Diary:
I was in the men's locker room of my gym talking to a friend who had reduced his weight and toned his body by exercising. He was returning from the shower with a towel wrapped around him when a new member, displaying substantial girth and sweating from exercising, looked at him and said, "You're a real inspiration to me."
My friend, thinking the remark referred to his improved physique, thanked the man and told him that he, too, could add muscle if he stuck with it.
"Muscle?" the new member exclaimed. "I'm looking forward to getting the towel to fit around my waist." DENNIS H. GREENSTEIN
Down in the subway, at 53d Street and Third Avenue, Geraldine Meeks stopped at a token window to refill her Metrocard. She was greeted by the following Catch-22 sign: "The computers are down so cards cannot be refilled. You will have to purchase tokens or new Metrocards in the following denominations (here the amounts were listed). If you cannot read, please identify yourself and I will explain it for you."
Still down in the subway, this time it's Joanne Cole going uptown on the Lexington Avenue line. A woman enters and immediately announces that she is unemployed, alone in the world and struggling to care for two teen-age sons, both of whom have dire but apparently not life-threatening diseases. A not-too-unusual subway panhandle but no, this one is different. She finishes her soliloquy, looks around, takes a deep breath and repeats the whole speech -- in Spanish.
The man who wrote this sign on his delivery hand-cart may be a curmudgeon, but he leaves more than a few passers-by with smiles. The sign: "I can only please one person a day. Today is not your day. Tomorrow doesn't look so good either."
The supermarket clerk was obviously in a bad mood, and Jerome Coopersmith was surprised at her actions -- mishandling groceries and snatching the money from customers' hands. The elderly man in front of him, who had just sampled her rudeness, looked at the clerk as he awaited his change.
"Aren't you going to tell me to have a nice day?" he asked.
"I don't have to," she snapped. "It's on the receipt."
Back above ground, a friend who flips through magazines on her daily bus journey reports that she was reading an article the other day when she noticed, or at least suspected, that the woman seated beside her was reading along with her. As she began turning the page, her suspicion was confirmed.
"Just a second," the neighbor said. "I haven't finished yet."
There was a moment of silence while the magazine owner recovered her equilibrium.
"I'll tell you what," she said. "I'll read at my own pace and I'll give you the magazine when I get off."
Not good enough.
"What if I get off first?" the woman asked.
Some things never change. Sheldon Sobel was walking in Central Park last week when he overheard the following conversation:
Father, speaking to a child about 5 years old: "Put on your sweater."
Child: "But I'm not cold."
Father: "A sweater is an article of clothing you put on when your mother is cold."
There will be an end to "Titanic" stories one of these days but this isn't the day.
Helen Graf was leaving a theater showing you-know-what when she heard a little girl, about 6 and obviously savvy in the art of propaganda, addressing her mother.
"See Mommy," she said. "That's why children should go to camp and learn how to swim."

HEADLINE: Times Mirror Weighs a By-the-Numbers Approach to Expanding Coverage of Minorities

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
In his latest challenge to the established mores of American newsrooms, Mark H. Willes, the chief executive of the Times Mirror Company and the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, is devising an unorthodox plan to give more coverage and to sell more newspapers to women, African-American, Asian and Hispanic readers.
"I have this simple-minded way of thinking you tend to do better if you measure performance," Mr. Willes said in an interview Friday. He has asked Mary E. Junck, an executive vice president of Times Mirror, to convene a meeting of senior editors in New York this month to find ways to quantify and improve coverage of women and minorities. 
 A recent exercise at The Los Angeles Times, he said, counted bylines, sources, pictures and quotes. The results confirmed Mr. Willes's perception that coverage of women and minority groups does not reflect "to the degree that it should and must, the diversity of the community that we're both reporting on and want to be read by," Mr. Willes said.
His proposed solution, however, hits one of the most sensitive nerves in any newsroom: the integrity of news coverage. A sampling of journalists turned up very few who objected to the publisher's goal and very few who were comfortable with his approach.
Indeed, Mr. Willes's determination to challenge the underlying precepts of the news business has made him a controversial internal critic in an industry more accustomed to criticism from outsiders. He has a recognizable plan of attack: identify a problem. Find quantitative measures to define it. Propose a solution that defies the profession's basic assumptions. Then proselytize to win skeptics to the cause.
To reverse circulation declines at The Los Angeles Times, he paired business and news executives and set out to measure and increase the readership of individual sections. The move provoked some scathing criticism, but also led to industry-wide debate over the need for the traditional wall between editorial and business departments.
To improve coverage of women and minorities, Mr. Willes wants the company's papers to use new quantitative models to establish a baseline of how well their coverage reflects community demographics. Then editors will be expected to do better.
"My understanding is that there's considerable flexibility here," said John Carroll, the editor of The Baltimore Sun, which is owned by Times Mirror. "No avenue has been foreclosed as long as we come up with ideas that have a high chance of success." Times Mirror also publishes Newsday, The Hartford Courant and The Advocate of Stamford, Conn.
Mr. Willes's latest suggestion for a quantitative approach to quality journalism was introduced in an interview Friday in The Wall Street Journal. In a telephone interview, he said the goal was both a moral and a business imperative. Marketing research among women and the Hispanic population, he said, showed many potential readers in these groups who feel little connection with The Los Angeles Times.
A newspaper's coverage of any issue, however, is the product of numerous factors. "You can't quantify everything," said Sharon Rosenhause, the managing editor of The San Francisco Examiner. "It sounds very arrogant when an editor says, 'I know what news is,' " she added.
"But there is some truth to that. If you don't know what news is in your community, you're not going to be an editor very long."
Nonetheless, she said, Mr. Willes "has a way of identifying problems that are not unique to The Los Angeles Times." Her preferred solution, however, centers on diversity in hiring and imagination in coverage. The Examiner has reporters covering the Hispanic, Asian, African-American and gay communities.
Vanessa Williams, the president of the National Association of Black Journalists, shares Mr. Willes's goal. "I do think you have to focus on it, otherwise it won't happen," said Ms. Williams, who is a reporter with The Washington Post. "But just as important is having a newsroom that is diverse, so that you don't have to set up all these artificial measures."
Jim Amoss, the editor of The Times-Picayune of New Orleans, agreed that newspapers fail to reflect the economic and racial diversity of their areas. But, he said, "unless the solution grows organically out of the community that's being covered, readers are going to suspect it of being phony."
To base incentive pay on such factors, he added, "warps the editorial process; it's inimical to everything newsrooms ought to be about."
Mr. Willes said that bonuses for editors who made measurable improvements had been discussed, but not developed. "If we can develop the right way to measure it," he said, "one of the good things is that we won't have to interfere with editorial independence at all. We won't have to say you have to have more stories on this or that. We'll say there are multiple ways" to get to a prescribed goal.
The message, he said, will be: "Find a way to get there."

HEADLINE: One of 3 Potential Polygram Bidders Is Said to Have Dropped Out

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
One of the three potential bidders for the music company Polygram N.V. has decided not to make a bid, a person close to the group said yesterday.
The investment group that is said to be dropping out comprises Texas Pacific; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and A. Jerold Perenchio, the chairman and chief executive of Univision Communications Inc. 
 The Seagram Corporation, widely considered the lead bidder, is said to be offering roughly $10.3 billion in a package that includes $8 billion in cash and roughly $2 billion in Seagram stock.
It was not clear yesterday whether a third group, consisting of Forstmann Little & Company and the Thomas H. Lee Company, two leveraged buyout firms, would make a bid. That team was examining Polygram financial documents yesterday.
Seagram, which already owns a record company, is thought to be the most likely to acquire Polygram. More than any rival, Seagram can justify the price because of the economies of scale such a merger offers.
Royal Philips Electronics N.V., the Dutch company that owns 75 percent of Polygram -- the balance is owned by the public -- has scheduled a board meeting for Wednesday in the Netherlands. And Polygram itself has scheduled a board meeting tomorrow. It was unclear yesterday how Philips might respond if a higher offer did emerge from the Forstmann Little team. Philips was said to have promised Seagram not to negotiate with other bidders through today. The Seagram and Polygram switchboards were closed yesterday.
The question of who would run the merged company has been widely discussed. Seagram's music operation is run by Doug Morris, a highly regarded executive but one whose expertise is primarily in the United States music industry. Polygram has an enormous overseas business, so that the question remained whether Mr. Morris would take it over, whether it might remain in the hands of current management under Alain Levy, who, as Polygram's president, oversees its worldwide operations, or whether new managers might be brought in.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
INDIA DETONATED A HYDROGEN BOMB, EXPERTS CONFIRM

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 17

 BODY:
In a disclosure with potential to accelerate further a nuclear arms race with Pakistan, Indian scientists confirmed today that the largest of the five underground nuclear tests they conducted last week involved a hydrogen bomb, a device with potentially enormous power that is known in American military circles as a "city buster."
When the first round of three tests was announced last Monday, India described the largest weapon tested as a "thermonuclear device," a term that set off a debate among weapons experts around the world about what type of weapon was involved. "Thermonuclear device" literally refers to a device that burns hydrogen fuel and, thus, has more punch than an atom bomb, the type that the United States dropped on Japan in 1945. 
 The scientists, appearing at a news conference, gave technical details of a bomb code named Shakti-1, after a Hindi word for power commonly used when referring to the most potent of the Hindu gods. The scientists said the bomb was a two-stage device involving a so-called fission trigger and a second stage that gave the bomb its main explosive force. The design, they said, was popularly known as a hydrogen bomb.
According to figures released by the scientists, the bomb had an explosive force equivalent to 43,000 tons of TNT. That would be small by comparison with the most destructive nuclear weapons built by the United States, Russia and other established nuclear powers, which have tested hydrogen bombs with explosive powers equivalent to several million tons of TNT.
But the Indian scientists said their weapon was deliberately kept small to avoid damage to populated villages near the test site in the northwestern desert of India.
The chairman of the Indian Atomic Energy Commission, Dr. Rajagopal Chidambaram, said the bomb design gave India the ability to increase its explosive power virtually at will. "In fact, we could have got much higher yields than we got," Dr. Chidambaram said. "We were limited by possible seismic damage to the villages."
Another scientist, Dr. A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, regarded as the "father" of the Indian bomb, said of the possibility of building bigger bombs, "If there is a demand, we will do it."
Hydrogen bombs come in two types. In the first, American specialists said today, scientists fill the core of a small atom bomb with hydrogen fuel, a trick that can boost its power 10 times or more.
But making a true hydrogen bomb hundreds or even thousands of times more powerful requires a more complex method. In this second variety, the secret is to harness the radiation from an exploding atomic bomb and use that to compress and heat a packet of hydrogen fuel situated not internally, but nearby.
It was such a weapon that the Indian scientists described at their news conference. Drs. Chidambaram and Kalam repeatedly emphasized that the weapon they detonated involved a "fission trigger," meaning a small atom bomb that set off the main blast, and not the other type of thermonuclear weapon, which they described as a "boosted fission" device.
They said they had developed designs for that type of weapon in laboratories, but did not test one.
In theory, the amount of hydrogen fuel ignited by the two-stage method has no limit. America's first hydrogen bomb, exploded in 1952, was 700 times more forceful than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. The Pacific isle of Elugelab, one mile in diameter, where it had been detonated, simply vanished.
But the practical considerations of putting the bomb atop a missile can quickly lead to difficulties, and it was not clear from the Indian scientists' statements today that they had been resolved.
Dr. Harold M. Agnew, former director of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the birthplace of the bomb in New Mexico, said the Indian assertion of having manufactured a true hydrogen bomb was quite believable. "It's not a giant step if you have smart people and understand the basics," Dr. Agnew said in a telephone interview.
"They could probably make bigger ones," he added, referring to true hydrogen bombs. "If you can do a little one, you can do big ones."
The news conference in New Delhi turned into another occasion for Indians to demonstrate soaring pride over the nuclear tests. The scientists were applauded by Indian reporters, asked for their autographs and generally treated much like the early American astronauts as they returned from space.
In their remarks the scientists repeatedly emphasized that they had developed the versions of the weapons tested last week on their own, without any foreign help.
But their statement that they had detonated a hydrogen bomb appeared quite likely to increase tensions with Pakistan, where Government officials have spent the days since the first Indian blasts weighing whether to respond with a nuclear test of their own and risk being punished with the same economic sanctions that the United States and other nations have imposed on India or whether they should hold off in the hope of isolating India.
For years Western intelligence experts have known that Pakistan had the ability to build an atomic bomb. But American nuclear experts have said it is far from clear that the Pakistanis could detonate a hydrogen bomb.
As India released the first technical details of its tests, the Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Gohar Ayub Khan, was quoted today as having said that it was not a question of whether Pakistan would stage a nuclear test, but when. It was unclear, however, if he was speaking on behalf of his Government.
The details from the Indians also appear to clear up uncertainty among Western geologists and weapons experts over the number of weapons tested and their explosive power. The Indians said the four other weapons, also code named Shakti, had an explosive force equivalent to 12,000 tons and 200 tons of TNT in the case of the two weapons tested with Shakti-1 on May 11 and 600 and 200 tons for those tested on Wednesday.
Immediately after the first tests, American seismologists said that they had detected only one blast and that it appeared to be much smaller than the first Indian estimates, no bigger than the equivalent of 25,000 tons of TNT. But the Indian scientists said American confusion over the size of the biggest blast could have arisen from the fact that the Shakti-1 device was detonated in a shaft separated by 1,100 yards from a second shaft containing Shakti-2, the device with 12,000 tons of TNT equivalent.
The scientists said the simultaneous detonation of the two devices had probably caused "interference" in the seismic signatures of the two blasts that misled American experts.
The scientists released a videotape of the blasts on Monday that showed a dramatic countdown at the test site in the Thar desert of Rajasthan state, 350 miles southwest of New Delhi. As the English-language count reached zero, a deep boom rang out across the desert, the ground shook violently, and a huge cloud of dust rose into the sky over the test site, a fenced area about a third the size of a baseball field. Cheers could be heard.
A chart prepared by the scientists showed that the blast occurred 5.7 seconds after 3.45 P.M., the time scheduled for the tests.
Views taken from a helicopter shortly afterward showed a crater that appeared to be 70 feet deep and several hundred feet across. A tower that had been draped in camouflage netting at the center of the site had disappeared, revealing what appeared to be a concrete walkway leading into the shaft, its sides shattered and covered with a debris of netting, twisted steel and broken sandbags. What appeared to have been tin huts on the edge of the fenced area had collapsed like a deck of cards.
At the news conference, the scientists' remarks spoke for their pride, and India's, that a country that is one of the poorest in the world, and often described as one of the most chaotic, had achieved with the nuclear tests something that only five other nations, the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France, have done.
The scientists noted that the "fissile material," or bomb fuel, was "completely indigenous," produced from nuclear reprocessing plants designed and built by Indians, and that many other systems needed to make the tests successful, including warhead designs, high-voltage triggering devices, "safety interlocks" and a command-and-control system, had all been developed by Indians, many of them in the face of an international effort to block the Indian program.
The point was made expressively by Dr. Kalam, whose official title is chief scientific adviser to the Indian Defense Minister. Dr. Kalam is of Muslim origin, a fact that lends a special irony to his role in view of the alarm about the Indian tests in Pakistan, a nation carved out of British India in 1947 as a home for Muslims.
He noted that unlike several other major figures in the Indian program, he had no training in the United States or another Western country. "I'm completely indigenous," he said.
The scientists were keen to emphasize, as Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee has, that India regards its nuclear power as defensive and that it has no plans to mount a first-strike against Pakistan or China, its potential foes.
"For 2,500 years," Dr. Kalam said, "India has never invaded anybody."

HEADLINE: A World Away, Strife Hits Home;
Indonesian Students Look Back With Guilt and Unease

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
In the basement of a mosque in Astoria, Queens, the New York chapter of the Indonesian Students Association dispensed with much of its agenda. Members discussed a fund-raiser and a Boston trip for an athletic meet. The ticklish item involved what to do about the riots and student uprisings back home.
The 25 or so young people who gathered on Saturday night are among Indonesia's children of privilege, many of them the sons and daughters of diplomats based in New York. While students in Indonesia are protesting against poverty and abuses of power by President Suharto, these students are struggling with whether to criticize a Government that includes their parents. 
 "That's how we were taught when we were kids, that we shouldn't say anything about the Government," said one student, Gigin, who declined to give his last name because his parents are diplomats. "Basically, we had to hide it. We're sick of it, but we don't know how to react."
Thousands of miles removed from the violence and upheaval, Indonesians in New York -- by one estimate about 5,000 people -- described a complicated mix of guilt, revulsion and admiration over events at home. About two dozen students and adults interviewed at the Indonesian Muslim Community Center in Astoria condemned the rioting, the targeting of ethnic Chinese and the killing of six university students by Government soldiers. They also seemed to agree that President Suharto should step down.
But the class divisions sundering Indonesia were evident at the Astoria mosque, too. As the students held a closed meeting in the basement, a group of men spoke upstairs. One man, Iskandar Rasyid, 34, a scholarship graduate student, sadly shook his head because the students were discussing an athletic competition. "They are not mature enough to know what is going on," he said.
"The students in Indonesia care about the people," he said. "But they" -- he pointed downstairs -- "they don't know. They have never felt suffering. I have a guilty feeling, actually, because I can't do anything. I can't do anything for my country."
Another man, Bambang Priatno, a union official with an A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliate, said, "they don't care about what happens in Indonesia because their families work for the Government." Mr. Priatno 47, said he joined the student movement in 1965, the "year of living dangerously," when half a million people died after President Sukarno was removed. But Mr. Priatno tempered his criticism, saying all of the Indonesians in New York "are a family. We don't talk about politics."
The large number of Indonesian Government officials in New York may explain the absence of any anti-government demonstrations locally. Mr. Priatno said Indonesian groups in Australia and Germany have held protests. He said they sent him E-mail asking, "Where are you?" He said he replied that people were "too busy" with daily life, though plans for some sort of protest, perhaps on Wednesday, a national holiday in Indonesia, are being discussed.
After the downstairs meeting ended, the students munched potato chips and lingered for an open discussion. If it was an experiment in free speech, it was not an easy one. Several students said they had never publicly criticized the Indonesian Government.
Danni Sutresna, 23, is the group's president. He is also the son of Nana Sutresna, a high-ranking official in the Indonesian Foreign Ministry and a former delegate to the United Nations.
"I'm really in a very bad position," he said. "The bottom line right now is, I think, something needs to be done. Some change needs to be done very quickly."
Several students said they worried that speaking publicly could create problems for their parents. Many would give only a first name. Some anguished over keeping quiet.
"Unlike in the United States," one student said, "we don't have freedom of speech. So if we say something bad, they come to get you."
One woman, Tassi, 21, a Baruch College student, said, "It is like screaming from inside." She said, "It doesn't mean that because our parents are working in the Government that we have to agree with what their bosses tell them to do."
Several students, though, said they thought the students in Indonesia had gone too far. "Why can't they just do civil disobedience?" asked Arnandha, a student wearing a "Rage" rock-and-roll T-shirt. "Riots? Why make it worse?"
But another student, Rinaldo, 25, of Baruch College, interrupted. "You know that students didn't make the riots. Other people made the riots."
The slaying of the six students by Government soldiers is the incident that seems to have resonated most deeply. Many of the students at the mosque have lived in New York for several years. They spoke in American accents and wore the latest fashions. The six slain students at Trisakti University in Jakarta, like themselves, were from middle- and upper-class families. When the young people were asked whether they could identify with students in Indonesia, particularly poor students, the group's vice president, Yulianto Mohsin, 21, stood, his voice trembling as he spoke. He promised to issue an official position statement soon.
"We do -- we can relate, and we do sympathize with our students in Indonesia," he said. "We are supporting them. We have to have a result from all this movement."
But what result?
"A change in leadership," one student said.
"And be more democratic," another said tentatively.
Several students said they worried about the safety of parents living in Indonesia. When one young woman agreed, adding, "you know, they are our source of income," everyone giggled a bit nervously.
As the group prepared to leave, Mr. Mohsin seemed frustrated and eager to convey a sense of commitment. "Some of us will have a role in our nation's way of developing," he said. "Deep down, we all want this change. We're hoping in the new Indonesia that we can do it better."
Yesterday, Mr. Mohsin's position statement arrived. It represented the Association of Indonesian Students in the United States, the umbrella organization for all the Indonesian student groups in the country. It condemned the killing of the students, urged President Suharto to step down and called on the National Assembly to install new leadership and implement political reform. It urged the international community to pressure Indonesia toward democratization and economic reform.
It was signed, simply, "with the greatest sadness at the standing of citizenship and governance of our home country."

HEADLINE: Voting for Higher Cigarette Prices

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee made a comprehensive anti-smoking bill stronger last week when it voted to increase cigarette taxes by $1.50 per pack over three years. That hefty increase should go far to deter youth smoking, and it is not apt to encourage widespread smuggling of cigarettes as industry propaganda suggests. Indeed, such smuggling can occur on a large scale only if the industry itself allows it.
Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, provided a key swing vote that allowed the committee to approve the tax increase by 10 to 9. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the committee's ranking Democrat, also voted for it. 
 The committee's proposal will be voted on by the Senate this week as an amendment to the tobacco bill approved earlier by the Senate Commerce Committee. The Commerce bill, drafted by Senator John McCain, would impose annual assessments on the industry that would raise per-pack cigarette prices by $1.10 over five years. Estimates are admittedly rough, but many public health experts say an increase of at least $1.50 is needed to cut youth smoking rates significantly, and experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences have recommended increases of $2 per pack.
The tobacco industry is raising the specter of a new black market in cigarettes if Congress forces a steep increase in cigarette prices. But such fear-mongering is insulting given the industry's apparent complicity in the growth of international cigarette smuggling.
Investigators of the European Union are now asking the United States Government to help combat illegal trade involving billions of American cigarettes that are smuggled into Europe to evade cigarette taxes. European authorities believe American companies knowingly sell to dealers who ship the cigarettes into the contraband pipeline, but they have been unable to get the companies to cooperate with their investigation. The companies' refusal shows they have no interest in shutting down an illicit trade that directly benefits them.
Contraband cigarettes currently in the American market are largely the result of interstate smuggling driven by vastly different levels of state tobacco taxes. A higher national tax would not add to that problem since the tax would apply to all states. Few experts believe that a black market will arise from foreign-made cigarettes because Americans are accustomed to cigarettes of higher quality than those produced in places like China.
Instead, the worry is that American-made cigarettes will be exported to avoid the new Federal tax, then smuggled back to be sold at lower prices. Just this kind of export-import operation developed in Canada after it raised tobacco taxes. Because Canada's exported cigarettes were not marked with "export only" labels, it was impossible to distinguish between contraband packs that were smuggled back and legally sold packs. Canadian officials concluded that their top domestic manufacturers, affiliated with American and British tobacco companies, were aware of and benefited from the illegal activity.
That need not happen here. Strict licensing and marking requirements can help authorities track the movement of cigarettes from manufacturers to wholesalers, distributors, exporters and retailers. Tight Federal regulations have long applied to alcohol distribution, effectively ending illegal sales of wine and spirits in this country. The Senate should ignore the scare talk and approve a strong bill that would reduce smoking by raising prices.

HEADLINE: Antitrust Talks Founder On Microsoft's 'Desktop'

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR with JOEL BRINKLEY 

 BODY:
The stakes and the drama, it seemed, could scarcely be higher. The Microsoft Corporation, emblematic titan of the nation's high-tech economy, was locked in last-minute, closed-door negotiations with the Justice Department and 20 state Attorneys General. The goal was to find a way to avert a major antitrust suit -- a confrontation that could rival the Government's assault on Standard Oil early this century in defining the ground rules of competition for decades to come.
Early Saturday afternoon, word spread that the talks had collapsed. 
 But, in fact, the negotiations did not break down. By all accounts, they never really started. After an inauspicious first meeting, they coasted to a close less than a day and a half later with little drama.
The parting shot was delivered shortly after 1 P.M. by Jeffrey H. Blattner, special counsel for information technology in the Justice Department's antitrust division. After finishing a phone call to his boss, Joel I. Klein, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, Mr. Blattner walked into the conference room of Microsoft's Washington law firm, and told William H. Neukom, the company's senior vice president for legal affairs, "I guess we're going to have to go our separate ways," people involved with the talks recalled.
The two days of talks succeeded only in convincing Microsoft on one side and the Justice Department and Attorneys General on the other side that a wide chasm divided their views of how the information-age economy does, and should, work.
Today, the Government and the states are expected to file antitrust suits accusing Microsoft of unfairly trying to maintain its monopoly in personal computer software and to extend that monopoly into the new markets of Internet software and commerce. Neither the Government nor the states will ask for a delay in shipments of Windows 98, the new version of Microsoft's operating system. Microsoft is scheduled to ship Windows 98 to computer makers today and make it available on store shelves on June 25.
The suits will ask that Microsoft be forced to loosen its contracts with personal computer makers to allow them to modify the company's software considerably. This step, the Government and the states contend, could amount to a new deal for the computer industry and open the door to genuine competition. It would allow PC makers to filter requests from consumers and decide what users see on their desktop screens instead of conceding most of that power to Microsoft.
The company says that the Government's position amounts to heavy-handed meddling in the marketplace and a threat to its corporate livelihood. "What the Government is asking would significantly hamper us from competing through innovation and would put everything we've worked for and built for the last 23 years at risk," said William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman.
The talks got off on the wrong foot on Friday morning. The Justice Department team, led by Mr. Klein, and the states group, led by Thomas Miller, the Attorney General of Iowa, and Richard Blumenthal, the Attorney General of Connecticut, were left sitting in Mr. Klein's conference room, waiting for the Microsoft team. After a half hour of waiting, one government official in the room recalled, a staff aide to Mr. Klein came in and told the group that Microsoft had apparently thought the meeting was at the Washington offices of Sullivan & Cromwell, Microsoft's law firm.
A harmless misunderstanding perhaps, but to the assembled government officials it seemed a telling one. Microsoft executives, one person in the room remarked, assume that the world will come to them.
Little more than an hour after the Friday talks began, the two sides encountered a major obstacle, which indicated that a negotiated settlement was out of reach. The issue under discussion was the control of what appears on a PC user's main screen, often generically called "the desktop." Today, Microsoft exercises a powerful control over that main screen because its Windows operating system is installed on more than 90 percent of new personal computer's sold. An operating system is the software equivalent of the computer's central nervous system.
Microsoft allows PC makers to put other software on top of Windows, but the company, through its contracts with PC makers, firmly controls the essential look and consumer experience of the desktop. Government officials said that it was an expressed willingness by Microsoft to negotiate the issue of the desktop -- sometimes called the "first screen" -- that encouraged the Justice Department to invite the company to Washington for talks on Friday.
The Government and the states had been expected to file suit against Microsoft last Thursday. But in late-night calls Wednesday that extended into dawn Thursday between Mr. Klein and Mr. Gates, the Justice Department came away convinced that Mr. Gates was suddenly ready to discuss loosening Microsoft's grip on the first screen, a government official said.
The 11th-hour Seattle-to-Washington phone calls last week followed a face-to-face meeting between Mr. Gates and Mr. Klein in Washington on May 5. Mr. Klein was encouraged enough by what he had heard to call Mr. Neukom, of Microsoft, the following day, to get further discussions started.
When the settlement talks began on Friday, the Government was expecting to negotiate over freeing up the main screen. In antitrust terms, the Government regards the issue as vital because the main screen can be seen as a gateway to the Internet -- a potential chokehold on the new but fast-growing markets for Internet commerce, news and entertainment.
In addition, the Government contends, if PC makers are free to load software on top of Windows, the freedom could, in theory, pose a threat to the Windows monopoly itself. Indeed, it was largely Microsoft's fear that the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator browser for viewing the World Wide Web had the potential to become an alternative main screen that prompted Microsoft to compete so fiercely in the market for Web browsers. Among other things, Microsoft decided to give its Internet Explorer browser away for free.
But shortly after the Friday talks began, Microsoft said it was not going to allow substantive changes to its main screen, government officials involved in the talks said. "Did they lie to us before?" said one government official. "Not necessarily. But they certainly changed their position between Thursday morning and Friday. That's what it broke down over."
Others representing the Justice Department and the states shared that view. "That was the point when people on our side felt this whole thing was futile," said another government official.
Microsoft executives fiercely deny that the company had an overnight change of heart. They say that Microsoft was willing to discuss giving PC makers more freedom than they currently enjoy to alter the main screen, though the company adds that there is no legal reason it should. Its main screen, Microsoft says, is intellectual property that by law belongs to company.
Nonetheless, Microsoft executives involved in the talks say they were willing to discuss giving PC makers greater freedom to customize the first screen to feature the services and trademarks of, say, Compaq, Gateway or Hewlett-Packard.
However, Microsoft has always resisted allowing others to modify Windows to the extent of offering substitute main screens from which other software applications can be started up, technically sidestepping the Windows desktop. "That would be tantamount to undermining our franchise by making Windows some bit of software plumbing that no one sees," one Microsoft executive said.
And Internet software, like the browser or Sun Microsystem's Java programming language, potentially has the power to undercut the control of modern computing that Microsoft enjoys with Windows.
To insure competition in Internet software, the Government also proposed the possibility of forcing Microsoft to load Netscape's Navigator browser on Windows as well as its own Explorer. Such a must-carry provision, a government official says, was only one proposal for addressing the problem of giving consumers genuine choice in the software needed for browsing the World Wide Web.
Microsoft likens a must-carry provision to telling Coke that is must include a couple of cans of Pepsi in every six-pack it ships. And antitrust experts say the courts may be skeptical about must-carry provisions because once the precedent is established for one product it could extend to many others.
Microsoft insists that it was the flexible party at the negotiating table. Its executives say they were willing to help software rivals and give PC makers more freedoms -- but not if it meant undermining its "fundamental right to determine what goes in our Windows operating system," one executive said. Throughout the talks, one company executive said, "the Government didn't move a muscle."
In any case, by the time the first day's talks concluded on Friday, the Justice Department and state representatives were doubtful that any progress could be made. Mr. Blumenthal, the Connecticut Attorney General, was discouraged enough that he returned home and did not attend the talks on Saturday. Neither did Mr. Klein, the Justice Department's antitrust chief.
When the talks resumed on Saturday at the law offices of Sullivan & Cromwell -- the venue switched from the Justice Department because the air conditioning is shut off in Government buildings on weekends -- they did not last long.
The two sides left with their opposing positions hardened, ready to do battle in court.
"It was certainly an illuminating experience," one government official recalled thinking as he gazed out the law offices overlooking the Old Executive Office Building, once the home of the nation's War Department.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Gates said the Government's position would put "everything we've worked for and built for the last 23 years at risk." (Reuters TV)(pg. A16)
 
Charts: "Government vs. Microsoft: The Battle Lines"
The conflict between the Government and Microsoft boils down to some very specific issues about what people see on their screens and what types of programs and services they use. Here is an overview:
 
WHAT MICROSOFT WANTS TO DO
About product integration -- Add new features to its Windows operating system without Government interference, especially its Internet Explorer Web browser, which it insists is now a fundamental part of Windows.
On the desktop -- Control what appears on a user's main Windows screen -- known as the desktop -- when the computer is first turned on, including Internet links to Microsoft's own sites and to sites that other companies have paid Microsoft to link to.
Regarding contracts -- Include clauses in Windows licensing contracts that prevent computer makers, Internet service providers and Web publishers from promoting products of Microsoft's competitors.
 
WHAT THE SUITS SEEK TO PREVENT
About product integration -- Limit Microsoft's ability to add features to Windows that are offered by other companies as stand-alone products, including a Web browser. This could be done by forcing Microsoft to include competitors' products or to erase links to its own features.
On the desktop -- Let computer makers determine which program icons and links to Internet sites will appear on the main Windows screen, either to satisfy customers or as part of agreements with Internet publishers or software makers. Regarding contracts -- Eliminate all contractual limitations by Microsoft on the promotion or use of competitors' products.
 
HOW CONSUMERS MIGHT BE AFFECTED
About product integration -- Microsoft says customers want new features and argues that limiting such features will stifle innovation. The Government says competition will accelerate innovation and result in lower prices.
On the desktop -- Alternative desktops would allow consumers to order the Internet options they wanted pre-installed on their PC's. A Microsoft-controlled desktop would insure a standard opening screen, regardless of computer brand.
Regarding contracts -- If the Government prevails, computer makers that license Windows would also be able to offer competing programs like Netscape's Navigator browser. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE DIPLOMACY;
Clinton Seeks to Limit Effects of India's Test by Pressing Yeltsin on Arms Pact

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, May 17

 BODY:
President Clinton urged President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today to press for the ratification of a pending nuclear weapons treaty even as the United States and its allies searched for ways to head off a nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan.
On his final day of meetings here with the leaders of the six other major industrial democracies and Russia, Mr. Clinton drew a link between American efforts to continue reducing the stores of nuclear weapons held by the former cold war antagonists and attempts to halt the spread of nuclear ability to other nations. 
 Throughout the day, the leaders awaited word -- sometimes exchanging conflicting reports -- as to whether Pakistan had detonated a nuclear device or made a decision to do so in response to the nuclear tests conducted last week by India, its neighbor and rival.
Having failed to win broad support here for economic sanctions of the type the United States is imposing on India, Mr. Clinton turned today to a strategy of branding India -- and Pakistan too, if it goes ahead with testing -- as swimming against the currents of history.
At a 45-minute, one-on-one session this morning, Mr. Clinton told Mr. Yeltsin that he would like to hold a summit meeting in Moscow this year to discuss further arms-reduction talks between the United States and Russia, but suggested that Washington would first like to see the Russian Parliament ratify the pending arms reduction treaty, known as Start-2.
Mr. Yeltsin and former President George Bush signed the treaty in 1993, and it was approved by the United States Senate in 1996, but it has become stymied in the Russian Parliament.
Ratification of Start-2 and the beginning of negotiations on Start-3, Mr. Clinton said, would send a signal to budding nuclear powers like India and Pakistan that they were moving backward while the rest of the world was moving ahead.
Any escalation in nuclear weapons development would be a "terrible signal" at a time "when the Russians and we are doing our very best to put everything in the opposite direction and to reduce the number of nuclear weapons in the world," Mr. Clinton told reporters after meeting with Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Clinton warned against seeing nuclear weapons ability as "the new measure of either national security or national greatness," a remark that seemed intended in part as a swipe at the pride displayed in India after the tests and in part as a plea to Pakistan's Government not to give in to intense domestic political pressure to match India's test.
In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation, Mr. Clinton suggested that the industrialized nations could have done more to encourage India along a path of peaceful economic development, and he warned that an unchecked arms race on the Indian subcontinent could eventually draw bigger powers into conflict.
"Have we failed to acknowledge India, the incredible achievement of maintaining 50 years of democracy under the most adverse conceivable circumstances?" Mr. Clinton said. "Probably."
"But the answer is not for India to become a nuclear power and then for Pakistan to match it stride for stride, and then for China to be brought in to support the Pakistanis and move troops to the Indian border, and then for Russia to come in and recreate in a different context the conflicts of the cold war," Mr. Clinton said. "It is a nutty way to go."
Aides said Mr. Clinton pressed Mr. Yeltsin on a number of issues, including Russia's transfer of missile technology to Iran. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, who was present at the meeting, said Mr. Yeltsin "reaffirmed in the clearest and most unambiguous terms" his commitment to cutting off the flow of missile technology to Iran.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who played host here to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan, said the gathering had been "both concerned and frustrated" by the growing tensions between India and Pakistan.
Mr. Blair said there was a general consensus that the best path was to persuade India not to hold further tests and to join the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. Mr. Blair said he had spoken to India's Prime Minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, on Friday, and that Mr. Vajpayee had told him India would promptly "begin discussions" about signing the treaty.
Mr. Clinton said Pakistan would do better in the eyes of the world not to go ahead with nuclear testing. There would be "specific political, economic and security benefits to the country if it does not test," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton did not cite any specific examples. But for the last few days White House officials here have held out the possibility that the United States might be willing to resolve a dispute with Pakistan over 28 F-16 fighter jets. Pakistan paid $658 million for the planes, but delivery was blocked by President Bush under a law that barred military sales to nations with nuclear programs. Pakistan was refunded $157 million, but the return of the rest of the money has been blocked by Congress.
Mushahid Hussain, the Pakistani Information Minister, told CNN in an interview today that resolving the F-16 issue would be like giving aspirin to a cancer patient and that the proposal "is not the answer" to Pakistan's security concerns.
Mr. Hussain also criticized the leaders meeting in Birmingham for not taking a harder line against India by adopting tough sanctions. Aside from the United States, only Japan and Canada among the major industrial countries have taken any steps to halt aid payments or impose other economic penalties on India.
"It shows there is no price tag for bad behavior," Mr. Hussain said.
The leaders of the so-called G-8 countries ranged across an array of issues in their three days in this industrial city in the English midlands. The final session this morning featured a continuation of a discussion on Saturday about preparedness for the software problems that will be caused when computers reset their calendars for the year 2000.
Mr. Blair also used Mr. Clinton's presence to help rally support for the peace plan that will be put before voters in Ireland and Northern Ireland on Friday. And in their final communique today, the leaders gave their approval to a host of initiatives, some as specific as a stepped-up fight against malaria and others as general as support for restoring financial stability to Asia. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: INDIA (98%); UNITED STATES (98%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (96%); PAKISTAN (94%); ENGLAND (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (78%); BIRMINGHAM, ENGLAND (78%);

HEADLINE: Clinton Says Chinese Money Did Not Influence U.S. Policy

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 17

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that reported political campaign contributions from China to the Democrats had not influenced his foreign policy, but he welcomed further investigation into decisions that made it easier for China to launch American satellites and possibly obtain sensitive technology.
"The decisions we made, we made because we thought they were in the interests of the American people," Mr. Clinton said, responding for the first time to reports that a Democratic Party fund-raiser told Federal investigators of funneling thousands of dollars from a Chinese military officer in the President's 1996 re-election campaign. Mr. Clinton, speaking at the end of an economic meeting in Birmingham, England, said he would determine the substance of the charges before deciding whether they would affect policy toward the Chinese Government. 
 "In any case, I think the investigation ought to proceed," he said, "and then whatever the facts are, we'll take appropriate action at that time." Mr. Clinton is planning to visit China next month.
The Justice Department's campaign finance task force is investigating whether political contributions influenced the Administration's 1996 decision to reverse a State Department policy that had categorized satellites as "munitions," making it more difficult to export them for launching aboard Chinese rockets.
In addition, several Congressional committees are looking into whether the Administration's policy shift on exporting satellite technology helped China and other countries develop and use nuclear missiles.
The New York Times reported on Friday that Johnny Chung, the former fund-raiser, had told Federal investigators that a large part of the nearly $100,000 he gave the Democrats in the 1996 campaign came from China's People's Liberation Army through Liu Chaoying, a Chinese lieutenant colonel and aerospace executive. The Democratic National Committee subsequently returned the money to Mr. Chung, who began cooperating with investigators after he pleaded guilty in March to campaign-related bank and tax fraud.
Congressional Republican leaders have accused the Administration of being influenced by American aerospace manufacturers, citing Bernard L. Schwartz, chairman of Loral Space and Communications, who gave more than $600,000 to the Democratic Party, making him the single largest personal donor.
The Administration's decision to waive sanctions and ease the export control process allowed Loral and another aerospace company, the Hughes Electronic Corporation, to export satellites to be launched atop Chinese rockets.
In his remarks today, Mr. Clinton did not directly mention the policy on satellites. But he suggested that the decision to move the authority for exporting the devices from the State Department to the Commerce Department was unanimous within his Administration.
The Administration's decision to reverse State Department policy drew concerned comments today from a leading Democrat.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking minority member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the Administration's policy switch was "serious stuff." Interviewed on "Fox News Sunday," Senator Biden said any "correlation of quid pro quo" linking campaign contributions to a shift in national security policy should be ferreted out.
Representative Porter J. Goss, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, said an independent counsel may have to be appointed to investigate the Chinese contributions if the Justice Department failed to conduct a thorough inquiry.
"The sinister element comes in when we start reading that Chinese intelligence is inserting large amounts of money," Mr. Goss said on the same program. "Now, I admit it is possible for anybody to be duped in a campaign about where money comes from. But it is very clear that the Chinese had some reason to give large amounts of money. They wanted something for it. What was it the Chinese wanted?"
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said in a television interview that the United States began permitting the launching of American satellites aboard Chinese rockets in the Bush Administration.
"The reason for that is that the telecommunications industry has a tremendous need to put satellites up into the air and that exceeds the launch capacity of the United States," Mr. Berger said on the CNN program "Late Edition." He also denied that any campaign contributions had influenced foreign policy.
Mr. Berger said that American companies did not risk passing restricted technology on to the Chinese. The satellites, he said, "are put into a black box" under the supervision of the Department of Defense "and taken to China, put on top of the missile and blown up into the sky." He said there was "not technology transfer."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY;
The Group of Seven Now Eight, Officially

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, May 17

 BODY:
This year, for the first time, the annual summit meeting of the world's seven major industrial democracies and Russia became formally known as the Group of Eight, reflecting the gradual effort to give Russia an expanded voice in global economic and political issues.
"The format is now the G-8," a spokesman for the British Government said today. "The idea was always that Russia would be included. It just took a while for the name to catch up with the reality." 
 The old Group of Seven will continue to exist in a certain sense. The seven -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan -- are free to meet without Russia on some issues, especially relating to global finance. The leaders of the seven nations gathered without President Boris N. Yeltsin during the first session here on Friday, primarily to discuss the Asian financial crisis. Mr. Yeltsin was present later when the nations discussed India, Indonesia and the situation in the Balkans.
For now, Russia will not take a place in the rotation as host of the annual event, although American officials say they expect that to happen within the next few years.
The summit meetings started in 1975.

HEADLINE: More Children Go Uninsured Despite Status For Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
A new Federal study finds that 4.7 million children far more than previously estimated -- are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled in the program and have no health insurance benefits.
The finding means that two of every five uninsured children in the United States could have coverage through Medicaid, which provides comprehensive health benefits, if they or their parents would just apply for it. 
 The study, published today in the journal Health Affairs, said 21.2 million children ages 18 or younger were eligible for Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people. But, it said, 22 percent of them were not in Medicaid or any other public or private health insurance program.
The White House had estimated that three million children were eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled. And in January, President Clinton ordered the Department of Health and Human Services to locate such children and sign them up.
Mr. Clinton has repeatedly proposed new health programs for children and has often complained that the number of uninsured Americans is increasing because of Congress's failure to enact his proposals for universal coverage in 1994. But the study suggests that the Government and low-income families have not made full use of the existing Medicaid program, which has been revised by Congress over the last decade to expand eligibility.
The main author of the new report, Thomas M. Selden, who is an economist at the Federal Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, a unit of the Public Health Service, said, "Over all, we estimate that 4.7 million children age 18 and under were uninsured despite being eligible for Medicaid." They represent 39 percent of uninsured children, a group that numbers 12 million.
Mr. Selden said he and his colleagues at the Public Health Service had identified "a much larger group of Medicaid-eligible but uninsured children than has previously been known to exist." Earlier studies focused on children ages 10 and younger and did not consider all the children who might benefit from recent state expansions of the Medicaid program, Mr. Selden said.
Changes in Medicaid since the late 1980's have nearly doubled the number of eligible children, the study found. The changes were pushed through Congress by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California.
Children who received cash assistance through the old welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, were automatically enrolled in Medicaid. But the new study found that teen-agers and children who became eligible for Medicaid because of recent program expansions were less likely to be enrolled.
These families "may have been less aware of their Medicaid eligibility, given that they were ineligible for cash assistance," the study said. In addition, it suggested, "such families may have resided in neighborhoods with lower Medicaid prevalence, which might have reduced their awareness of the program and perhaps increased their sense of stigma" associated with Medicaid. The study also makes these points:
*Of the 4.7 million children who are eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled in the program, 3.3 million are younger than age 13, and 1.4 million are between ages 13 and 18.
*Young children eligible for Medicaid are more likely than older children to be enrolled in the program.
*Sweeping changes in welfare policy made by the Federal Government and the states in the last few years could inadvertently increase the number of uninsured children. The new laws impose time limits and other restrictions on welfare benefits. Many children may still be eligible for Medicaid after they lose cash assistance, but they and their parents may have to make special efforts to get such health benefits.
Another study in the same issue of Health Affairs documents changes in insurance coverage of mental health care. The proportion of insured workers with mental health benefits has increased in recent years, the study says, but the benefits have become less generous as insurers impose stricter limits on the use of mental health services and charge higher co-payments.
Health maintenance organizations and other managed-care plans generally impose such limits, and the number of Americans in such health plans has soared in the last decade, said one of the authors, Gail A. Jensen, an expert on employee benefits at Wayne State University, in Detroit.

HEADLINE: Insurers Swindled Jews, Nazi Files Show

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
In an outburst of anti-Semitic violence that presaged the Holocaust, mobs incited by the Nazis rampaged through Berlin and other German cities on Nov. 9 and 10, 1938, smashing and torching an estimated 171 synagogues and thousands of Jewish shops and homes.
Nearly 60 years later, fresh details surrounding Kristallnacht, or "night of broken glass," have been extracted from Government archives in Moscow that have been storing Nazi documents seized by Soviet troops in 1945. 
 The Nazi Government was known to have confiscated insurance payments to Jews whose property was damaged in Kristallnacht. But the newly unearthed documents suggest that German insurance companies not only connived with the Nazis to avoid paying Jewish policyholders, but also sometimes exceeded Government guidelines and canceled unrelated life, health and pension policies on which Jews had been paying premiums for years.
Some of the documents are to be presented today at a hearing in Manhattan scheduled by the New York State Senate Insurance Committee. The panel, headed by Guy J. Velella, Republican of the Bronx, is considering legislation that would penalize European insurers who do business in New York if they failed to pay claims related to the Holocaust.
The documents, which abound with anti-Jewish slurs, include a confidential industry estimate that at least 19 of the 43 German fire insurance companies stood to suffer losses for the year if they fulfilled their obligations to Jewish policyholders for Kristallnacht. That contradicts an assertion of some German insurers that they did not profit from the Holocaust.
An agreement reached last month commits four European insurers, including the Allianz of Munich, the world's second-largest insurance company, to open their books to an international tribunal and help expedite the claims of people whose policies were seized or not honored.
Many insurers mentioned in the documents no longer exist. Allianz is cited in the industry estimate as one of the 19 companies that could expect to lose money, but does not appear elsewhere. Company officials did not respond to requests for comment.
The Nazi documents, found in February and April, remain stored in Moscow. Photocopies of some excerpts were made available by Risk International Services Inc. of Houston, a company that specializes in "insurance archeology" by searching repositories, from archives to attics, to retrieve lost insurance documents and determine their significance.
The vice president and counsel of Risk International, Douglas L. Talley, said although the research was preliminary, the documents indicate how the Nazis, with the German insurance industry's complicity, established the practice of confiscating the insurance assets of German Jews. Mr. Talley found some of the documents in Moscow in a Nazi folder marked "Insurance Affairs -- Jewish Questions."
According to William L. Shirer's "Rise and Fall of the Third Reich," after the Kristallnacht riots, three Nazi leaders -- Hermann Goring, Josef Goebbels and Reinhard Heydrich -- met with an Allianz executive who represented the German insurance industry, Eduard Hilgard. Mr. Hilgard told them that confidence in the industry would suffer if Jewish claimants were not paid, but that reimbursing them could bankrupt smaller companies.
After the war Mr. Hilgard told Allied interrogators that he had helped the companies settle Kristallnacht claims at 3 cents to the dollar.
Foreign and non-Jewish claims were paid, but Field Marshal Goring confiscated the money due Jewish policyholders. In a document dated Nov. 29, 1938, the Nova insurance company informed insurance regulators that in keeping with the confiscation order, "Jewish members of the cooperative are excluded" from receiving benefits.
In a letter dated Nov. 17, 1938, the Isar Life Insurance Stock Company said that so many Jewish clients were desperately trying to cash in their policies "that the worst fears have to be asserted for the further existence of our company." Isar asked the Government's Oversight Office for permission to deny payment or to convert policies owned by Jews to nonredeemable status.
The Economic Ministry initially balked at letting insurance companies exploit Goring's confiscation of reimbursements for Kristallnacht as a pretext for not honoring other Jewish claims. On Nov. 21, 1938, a ministry official reminded insurers that the order affected "only the insurance claims confiscated from Jews of German citizenship for the benefit of the Reich, which came due because of the events of Nov. 8, 9 and 10, 1938."
"Other insurance claims, for example, life insurance, etc., are not affected," the official wrote. "Please communicate this to the companies involved."
Other documents to be released today suggest how swiftly some companies moved to cancel life, health and pension benefits of their Jewish customers after Kristallnacht A letter from a representative of a group of health insurers dated Nov. 14, 1938, said, "To the extent insurance conditions permitted, Jewish insured were canceled already." He reminded the Government that he proposed excluding Jews in 1935 and described them as "the worst risks" who did not belong in the same risk pool as Aryans.
On Nov. 23, 1938, another German insurer selling pension annuities notified Government overseers that "we will discontinue the payment of pensions and widows' pensions beginning December of this year, insofar as the recipients are Jews."

HEADLINE: Serious Crime Fell in U.S. For 6th Year in a Row in '97

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Reports of serious crime fell across the nation in 1997, the sixth consecutive annual decrease, with the biggest drop in the Northeastern states and in big cities, the Justice Department said today.
Preliminary figures released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which collected them from 16,000 city, county and state law-enforcement agencies, showed that the overall rate of serious crime fell 4 percent, accelerating the decline of recent years. 
 Violent crimes declined by 5 percent, led by 9 percent decreases in murders and robberies. There were smaller decreases in the categories of aggravated assault, down 2 percent, and rape, down 1 percent.
Rape was the one type of crime for which the statistics showed less progress. Reported rapes declined 2 percent in 1996, 5 percent in 1995, and 4 percent in 1994.
Property crimes declined by 4 percent, led by an 8 percent drop in arson. Car thefts fell 5 percent.
The Northeastern states led the decline in virtually every category. Murders in the region declined 13 percent, total violent crimes declined 5 percent and property crimes declined 6 percent.
Experts have said several trends were contributing to the declining pace of crime. Among them were the aging of the population, a toughening of sentencing laws and the increasing numbers of people in prison. The healthy economy was also a factor, experts said.
Cities with populations over a million reported that murders and robberies each declined 11 percent. Cities with populations of half a million to a million reported murders and robberies each down 10 percent. Cities with populations of a quarter of a million to half a million reported murders down 14 percent and robberies down 10 percent.
In New York City, the total number of crimes counted in the report declined 7 percent, to 355,893 in 1997 from 382,555 in 1996. Murders declined 22 percent, to 770 from 983, and robberies dropped 10 percent, to 44,707 from 49,672. The number of reported rapes in New York City fell to 2,157 from 2,332.
