HEADLINE: Republicans Have Grip on Pennsylvania Politics

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
On the outskirts of this state capital, in a nondescript office building, Don Bailey, a beefy lawyer and former Congressman, is reviewing a legal case at his cluttered desk.
There is no overt indication that on May 19, when Pennsylvanians vote in their primary election, Mr. Bailey could wind up winning the Democratic nomination for Governor. 
 Mr. Bailey, 52, has not seen political action in a decade. He does not have his party's endorsement. He has no campaign headquarters, no campaign manager, no campaign spokesman. He does not even have a sign on his law office door here indicating he is a candidate. "Mostly," he says, "I've been working out of my car and a cell phone."
Still, he is favored in the polls to beat the endorsed Democrat, state Representative Ivan Itkin, 62, a mathematician and party veteran.
But whoever wins, neither is given much chance of unseating Tom Ridge, the successful Republican Governor who is looking at his expected second-term victory as a possible springboard to the Vice Presidential nomination in 2000.
Such is the political landscape these days in Pennsylvania, usually a robustly competitive battleground. For all intents and purposes, it has fallen under one-party rule.
Senator Arlen Specter, like Mr. Ridge a Republican, is also cruising to re-election in November. The other Senator, Rick Santorum, is also a Republican. The Republicans control both houses of the State Legislature and three of the four other statewide offices. They control 46 of the 67 counties and won 10 of the last 13 statewide judicial races.
Oddly enough, the Democrats have 470,000 more registered voters than the Republicans. But that seems a relic of the state's old manufacturing base and its weakening urban anchors in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. The state Democratic Party has virtually collapsed, fractured ideologically and geographically. At its December meeting, it could not raise a quorum.
"It's anemic," Mr. Bailey said of the party. "Everybody knows it."
Analysts point to several reasons for the dramatic change in the last few years.
One is that while Pennsylvania is traditionally a culturally conservative state, Democratic leaders have drifted toward the left. "A lot of Democrats in the hinterlands, who are pro-gun and pro-life, are not happy about the party's orientation toward liberal urban policies," said Terry Madonna, a political analyst at Millersville University.
The cities remain Democratic, but turnout in elections has dwindled so that Philadelphia and Pittsburgh now account for a combined total of about 20 percent of the statewide vote, down from 33 percent in 1964. And organized labor, once a powerful force, has lost its grip.
Beyond that, the economy is as strong here as it is elsewhere. Pennsylvania has gained 230,000 jobs since Mr. Ridge took office in 1995. The state has an enviable double-A bond rating from every major Wall Street rating agency for the first time in 30 years, and unemployment in March was 4.8 percent, among the lowest levels in a decade.
Perhaps most important, the Democrats have had trouble fielding attractive candidates.
"It's embarrassing, the difficulty they've had recruiting," said Stuart Rothenberg, editor of The Rothenberg Report, a political newsletter in Washington. "It's one thing to say the Governor is strong, or this is a status-quo environment, but they're down to third-tier candidates for both Senator and Governor."
Mr. Rothenberg added: "It can be intimidating to run against an Arlen Specter. He's a tough politician, and he can raise billions of dollars. But he's a controversial guy, and as such he should have generated a credible opponent."
The races that are sparking the most interest are between Republicans for Congress. Two incumbents -- Bill Goodling in Gettysburg and Jon D. Fox in Montgomery County, a Philadelphia suburb -- are facing tough primary challenges tomorrow.
At the moment, the Democrats have a one-man edge in the 21-man Congressional delegation (yes, all are men). And they hope to pick up two seats in November. One is that of Mr. Fox, who has three opponents in the Republican primary. No matter who wins that vote, Joseph Hoeffel, a Montgomery County commissioner and a Democrat, is expected to run a strong fall campaign. (In Mr. Goodling's district, whichever Republican prevails tomorrow is expected to have little trouble in November.)
Democrats see a more certain gain in Scranton, where Representative Joseph M. McDade, a Republican first elected in 1962, is retiring. Most analysts expect Patrick Casey, son of a former Governor, Bob Casey, to sweep the district. Scranton is the hometown of the Casey dynasty.
But the Democrats' real hopes are down the road. They are already promoting three potential powerhouse candidates for statewide office. Ed Rendell, the Mayor of Philadelphia, may run for governor in four years. And Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, a former member of Congress, is running for lieutenant governor this year, which many observers see as preparation for a Senate bid in 2000 against Mr. Santorum. But both are perceived as liberals and could have problems statewide.
The Democrats' third bright spot is Robert Casey Jr., another son of the former Governor, who, as Auditor General, is the sole Democrat holding statewide office.
"We've got a strong farm team," said Leonard Barrack, a lawyer from Philadelphia and national finance chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
Still, Democrats are nervous that the top of the ticket this time is so weak that they could have a net loss in Congress and further down the ballot in November. This is why Mr. Bailey ambled into the governor's race -- because Representative Ron Klink, from near Pittsburgh, and other Democratic office-holders told him that Mr. Itkin was too light a feather to hang their hopes on.
"It was a selfish political decision on their part," Mr. Bailey said. "They called up and said, 'I can't carry Ivan in the fall. He's too left of center, too liberal, he's a burden I can't carry.' "
Meanwhile, Mr. Ridge could not be sitting prettier. He is credited with changing the perception of Pennsylvania as a state of high taxes and gritty industry to one that is more business-friendly and high-tech. He has cut business taxes by $2 billion and overhauled the state's costly workers' compensation laws.
"I got the House, I got the Senate, we got a Republican Governor," Mr. Ridge said cheerily the other day in his oak-carved perch in the Capitol. "We can cut taxes, we can do all those things that Republicans only talk about elsewhere."
Mr. Ridge has been using his popularity to help Republicans across the state, saying he wants to rack up even bigger margins in the state house. This would insure that Republicans would dominate redistricting after the census in 2000. The party would hope to make the Congressional districts more favorable to Republicans and cement its gains.
"I spend a great deal of time on party-building," Mr. Ridge said. "It's important to remind yourself every day that things could turn quickly if you're not careful. I view this as an opportune time, and shame on us if we don't build on these political advantages."

HEADLINE: In Long Run, Jobs Help Students;
New York City Lags

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The demand for young workers has bypassed many in cities like ours (news article, May 13). The fraction of New York City teen-agers who are employed has fallen sharply since the 1960's to a level less than half the national average, and dead last of all cities. 
 A recent survey of 424 employers in New York City found that years of sluggish job growth and corporate and government downsizing of full-timers has meant that most local employers report a still-abundant supply of displaced or moonlighting adult job-seekers.
Adult competition for entry-level jobs has intensified as employers have raised the minimum schooling and work-experience levels for new hires. This is less the result of rising skill needs than a reflection of the adult applicant pool and of employers' bleak impressions of the city's public schools.
 
GREGORY DEFREITAS
New York, May 14, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Hofstra University.

LENGTH: 213 words

HEADLINE: Create Another I.M.F.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (Op-Ed, May 15) writes: "If we need a domestic lender of last resort to deal with domestic financial crises, doesn't the globalization of financial markets mean that now, more than ever, we need a lender of last resort to cope with international crises?" 
 Mr. Krugman may want to stick to economic theory and leave history to the historians, for lenders of last resort have never done more than mitigate financial crises. Instead, controls on financial transactions have provided the only reliable guarantees of financial stability.
Indeed, John Maynard Keynes and the designers of the postwar Bretton Woods system made no provisions for any "lender of last resort." Rather, they designed a system of wage-price, interest and capital controls, one that provided the foundation for three decades of economic growth and financial stability.
Although these controls were dismantled during the oil shocks of the mid-1970's, officials of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have reconsidered their merits as more direct and less costly mechanisms than lender-of-last-resort assistance.
 
WESLEY W. WIDMAIER
Fort Worth, May 15, 1998
 
The writer is a doctoral student in government at the University of Texas at Austin.

HEADLINE: WHERE FEAR LINGERS: A special report.;
A Neighborhood Gives Peace a Wary Look

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
In Washington Heights, until recently one of New York's most murderous communities, a disturbing truth reveals itself in the empty stoops on West 162d Street in late afternoon, in the thinly peopled parks overlooking the Harlem River, in the greetings not exchanged by lifelong neighbors on Audubon Avenue:
The gunfire may recede into memory, but the fear hangs on. 
 In 1991, there were 119 killings north of 155th Street in Manhattan. So far this year, the body count stands at just five. Yet while people in Times Square and other far less violent neighborhoods have greeted far less dramatic drops in crime with responses bordering on euphoria, hardly anybody is ready to celebrate here in Washington Heights.
Slowly, haltingly, after a decade and a half in a war zone, the survivors are beginning to emerge from their bunkers into the plain light of day.
New stores are opening, and without shields of bulletproof glass over the counters.
Police officers, once feared almost as much as the drug dealers themselves, have actually started hearing quiet thanks for their crime-fighting help.
And finally, at the relatively advanced age of 9, Roselia Montalvo has learned to ride a bike.
But at every step toward normal life, the memories, and the mistrust, seem to get in the way.
Hundreds of people are still recovering from some trauma of war -- the state assemblyman who saw a man shot in the back of the head and still hears the screams of the victim's wife, the eighth grader who remembers running for cover as a friend was gunned down by rival drug dealers, the woman whose 12-year-old son was killed because he had witnessed his father's murder.
Some simply discount the Police Department's murder statistics. They point out the apartments in their buildings where drugs are sold and used, or the shadows under parked cars where they see people stash guns, as signs that the supposedly safe streets are just so much hype.
Many more remain invisible, for want of a better word. Confined behind triple-locked doors, these battle-weary bystanders -- often single mothers, the elderly or immigrant couples with young children -- have yet to venture out and sense the difference for themselves.
They know that things are somehow better, but real safety still feels out of reach.
"Safe is when you could walk from the train station home, or from your corner to your building, or from the street downstairs to your apartment door, without nobody trying to bother you or follow you," said 15-year-old Ranflin Estrella. "They got a long way to go."
 
A Drug Capital Where Gunmen Ruled
The shooting started in the mid-1980's, when crack cocaine took hold in Washington Heights and gangs of recent Dominican immigrants established the area as the nation's largest wholesale drug market. Other neighborhoods, especially in Brooklyn and the Bronx, also had a strong local customer base for drugs, but Washington Heights was special.
Fed by six bridges and three major highways, Washington Heights was accessible from New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut, as well as from the rest of the city. It had one of New York's largest and most thinly stretched police precincts, the 34th. And it had an economically desperate population of Dominicans, many of whom, law enforcement officials said, applied their rich tradition of entrepreneurship and their common language with Colombian cocaine suppliers to become the perfect middlemen for crack.
Soon, the neighborhood was to drug dealers throughout the Northeast what the Hunts Point market in the Bronx is to the region's grocery stores, but with sedans instead of semitrailers, and tenement doors in place of loading docks. Operating independently, four or five drug crews might share a single block, their street peddlers swarming over cars with out-of-state plates, vying for market share literally side by side.
That free-for-all competition often turned deadly. Isaac Sanchez, who is 15, remembers seeing one business dispute resolve itself in typical fashion several years ago.
"You see that white church?" he said, pointing to the corner of 166th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. "This guy who was a friend of mine used to own a drug spot there. He was going to sell it to someone, and they started arguing over the money, and the guy shot him. I had to run inside the cigar store across the street."
Today, Washington Heights remains the region's largest distribution center for narcotics, said Police Commissioner Howard Safir. Drug arrests there -- now occurring an average of once every hour and a half -- have yet to peak and, he said, are not likely to do so for some time. But the drug trade has been greatly diminished and, for the most part, forced indoors. The streets, he said, once again belong to the police.
The change took the better part of a decade, a series of prosecutions of violent drug gangs, aggressive police tactics, money and manpower. The District Attorney's office convinced the owners of hundreds of apartment buildings to allow police officers to patrol inside, resulting in thousands of arrests a year. A new police precinct, the 33d, with 200 more officers, was carved out of the southern half of the 34th in 1994, after a long community campaign. And in 1996, Mr. Safir organized a city-state-Federal task force that pools intelligence data and responds to every reported drug incident in Washington Heights.
Gun arrests, in fact, are already down, said Deputy Inspector John Romero, commanding officer of the 34th Precinct, which until April 28 had enjoyed more than five months without a murder.
"People now aren't going to take a chance at carrying a gun, because we're stopping people for quality-of-life crimes all the time," he said. "And if they're not going out with guns, they don't have them when their tempers flare up."
Other signs of change bear out the statistics.
Edward Rivera, manager of the Rivera Funeral Home on St. Nicholas Avenue, remembers when occupied coffins would be left in the hall because the private viewing rooms were busy. "Out of every five calls we'd get, maybe three were gunshot victims," he said. "Mondays were really bad, after the weekend. And the days after holidays. In the early 90's, we could've had 10 or 15 homicides a month."
Business is slow now, he said, adding: "I don't remember the last homicide we had."
At Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, the area's only hospital, gunshot victims once rolled in on gurneys almost nightly. But surgeons removed only four bullets last year. Today, kitchen accidents and sprained ankles receive the staff's full attention, said Dr. James F. Giglio, director of emergency medicine. The trauma surgery room is dark most of the time, its swinging door locked.
 
Showing Symptoms Of War Survivors
Bodily trauma may be on the wane, but psychic trauma is another story.
Marta Pepin recalls sitting in her rocker and watching TV one afternoon in 1988, when she heard five loud bangs through her first-floor window. She turned and saw a neighbor, Ricky Santiago, fall down dead a few feet outside on Audubon Avenue.
Mrs. Pepin responded to the constant gunfire not by shrinking in fear but by organizing her fellow tenants to buy their building, in which drug dealers controlled five apartments. Four have since been evicted. But Mrs. Pepin is still afraid. Last year, the building hired a guard to keep out unwanted night visitors. The extra $16,000 a year is threatening to drive the building into bankruptcy, but Mrs. Pepin says she is loath to leave its security up to her neighbors and the police.
"You can't trust anyone," she said, sitting on a plastic slipcover in her modest but immaculate living room. "You don't know who people are. We've got nice people, but sometimes you think someone's nice, then you hear they're drug dealers. You just can't tell."
Such doubts are all too common, said Dr. Randall D. Marshall, director of trauma research at Columbia-Presbyterian.
"Once somebody's view of the world is that it's dangerous and threatening, it's difficult to change," said Dr. Marshall, whose clinic treats hundreds of residents, many with symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, an illness common among Vietnam veterans.
In wartime, at least, "it's very clear who your enemy is, who your comrade is," he said.
"The trouble here is that a lot of the threats are living within the community," he said. "People have learned that they can be exploited or harmed by anybody they come into contact with, and have to watch out."
In Washington Heights, even the most upstanding extended families lost relatives to the lure of drugs or drug money, making it impossible to see one's neighbors as simply good or bad. Savvy drug dealers carried bags of groceries for the elderly, delivered toys and meals at Christmas, held block parties in warm weather and generally cultivated their neighbors' goodwill -- and their silence.
Wary of one another, people hardly put their faith in the police. Tensions between the two have been worse in Washington Heights than anywhere else in the city, from the full-fledged riots that followed a police officer's fatal shooting of an unarmed man in 1992, to the April 1997 death of Kevin Cedeno, shot in the back by an officer who was named "cop of the month" by his colleagues soon after.
"At least the drug dealers are not here to hurt you -- they're here to make a profit," said Yvonne Stennett, who heads the Community League of West 159th Street.
Old complaints about do-nothing attitudes and slow response times only gave way to more suspicion after the new 33d Precinct brought in several officers transferred from the corruption-plagued 30th in Harlem. Since then, increasingly aggressive police tactics have convinced many law-abiding residents that officers see them as criminal suspects first.
"Nobody's really ready to let their guard down too far," said the Rev. Earl Kooperkamp, pastor of the Church of the Intercession on West 155th Street.
Lessons learned painfully, after all, are not quickly forgotten.
There are about 250 city blocks in Washington Heights and Inwood to the north. But aside from four "model blocks," where officers patrol 24 hours a day, there are few places where people seem to have relaxed. Parents still make their children carry beepers, or check in by phone every time they go from one friend's home to another. Teen-age boys stay away from parks that have supposedly been cleaned up. More and more stores are staying open in the evenings, but few women shop alone after dark.
The local Assemblyman, Adriano Espaillat, thinks a bicycle race might help. Mr. Espaillat, who like so many of his constituents once witnessed a murder in daylight, wants to hold the race this summer, to show outsiders that the neighborhood is safe to visit, but more important, he says, to prove to residents that it is safe to go outside -- a first step toward a more normal way of life.
Some people think those first steps have already been taken, that the old twisted alliances and enmities are beginning to straighten out. Deputy Inspector Garry F. McCarthy, commander of the 33d Precinct, recounted how two men he had stopped and frisked had actually thanked him afterward, once he showed them how closely they matched the description of two crime suspects. And when the police shut down five businesses on Broadway a few weeks ago for harboring drug activity, several passers-by quietly expressed their gratitude, he said.
Even young people are reexamining their past loyalties.
"The fun we had then -- now, I regret it," said Isaac Sanchez, talking about the days when his block was an open-air crack market. "Before, in the summer, the drug dealers used to do barbecues. Now, they're gone, and we can't do it any more. Nobody's got the money. But I feel guilty now. Because I used to take whatever anybody gave me. I never asked where they got it. I enjoyed it."
Others are taking risks to insure that the cease-fire holds.
Ramon Sanchez, who manages two adjoining buildings on West 162d Street, stands guard outside, making sure that the front doors lock and that no one gets inside who does not belong. He points out a "crackhead" across the street; gestures at several men, loitering near a garage, who he says are dope peddlers; and fingers a hole in the masonry that was blown out by a .357 Magnum shell.
One of the two buildings used to be overrun with dealers, said Mr. Sanchez, 58, who is not related to Isaac Sanchez.
"Out of 24 apartments, 16 had drugs," he said. "Once I caught my super selling drugs. You couldn't walk into this building. You might get held up, or you might not come back."
But he worked with the police, turning in the superintendent, turning over a batch of cocaine that a postman found in a mailbox, keeping track of who was doing what where. A year ago, largely on the strength of his information, the police hauled off 20 people living inside. Last month, again relying on Mr. Sanchez for intelligence, officers swept through the entire block and arrested 10 people on drug charges.
Mr. Sanchez is tougher than most in Washington Heights. In 1990, his daughter was attacked by a New Jersey drug dealer after she informed against him. Mr. Sanchez, then a tradesman at Columbia University, drove to the dealer's home and shot him to death. He spent four years in prison on a reduced count of manslaughter.
"I am afraid of nobody," Mr. Sanchez said. "But I was scared for my family. I was afraid to even send them to the store."
 
Neighbors Emerge To Meet as Strangers
The other afternoon, Alexandra Pena watched as her four children played outside their apartment building on West 163d Street, between Amsterdam and Broadway. Michael, 13, rode back and forth on his bicycle. Roselia, 9, danced around with a friend, announcing that she had just learned how to ride a bike herself. Justine, 7, tagged along with her sister. James, 6, scared his mother as he hung from a loose iron rail over a basement stairwell.
An unremarkable after-school scene in most places. But until a few months ago, Ms. Pena and her family were prisoners of the violent drug trade in Washington Heights.
"When Michael was 9 or 10 months old," Ms. Pena said, "we were looking out the window one day -- I was holding him -- and we saw a guy get shot in the head right here on the corner. That was Michael's first experience."
There were plenty of others; their street was one of the most dangerous in the 33d Precinct. Last August, Inspector McCarthy declared it the first of the "model blocks." After an all-out drug sweep, the police created checkpoints at both ends of the street, posted officers there around the clock, painted over graffiti and helped residents organize tenant groups and a block association. The barricades have since come down, but an officer patrols the block at all times.
And slowly, the fear has begun to lift on 163d Street. People who for years would only leave their apartments in a hurry have begun to step outside merely to be outside -- first by peering out of a doorway, then by taking a seat on a stoop, then finally taking the plunge by striking up a conversation with a stranger next door.
"We found people who lived across the street from each other for 25 years and had never seen each other," Inspector McCarthy said.
Ms. Pena said, "We were hibernating like the bears."
In safer parts of the world, her daughter Roselia might have started on a tricycle at 3, and moved up to training wheels at 5 or 6. But on 163d Street, she and her siblings could not play on the sidewalk. They could not even play in the lobby of their apartment building, where no fewer than four drug dealers would meet customers.
"I used to take them to school in the morning, pick them up in the afternoon, then take them to 101st and West End Avenue to play," said Ms. Pena, referring to her childhood home on the Upper West Side. "We lived here, but we didn't stay here. We'd come home at 8 or 9 at night. If we came too late, we'd be in danger. If we came home too early, we'd be bored, because we'd be locked up inside."
For fun, Roselia and Justine played with Barbie dolls or took rare turns at the Nintendo set that Michael monopolized. These days, Michael rides his bike, Justine has learned hide-and-seek and tag and Roselia has discovered the other children on the block. "I've made five new friends," she said, pointing to their windows in three different buildings.
Ms. Pena says her children, born into the violence, have already lost their fear. "They don't even remember most of this," she said. "The great thing is, they're getting a chance for a better life."
She envies them. "I've got to get over my fear, too," she said. "It controls you. It does not allow you to be. It makes you feel like a prisoner when you have not committed a crime."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 19, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a lingering fear of violence in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan despite a drop in crime misstated the circumstances of a fatal shooting by the police in 1992 that prompted rioting. A grand jury found that the man who was killed had drawn a .38-caliber revolver; he was not unarmed.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE POINT MAN;
Berger Manages a Welter of Crises in the Post-Cold-War White House

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
When Samuel R. Berger arrived at the White House at 7:30 A.M. last Monday he was stunned to learn that India had just completed three underground nuclear tests.
Mr. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, frantically tried to assemble the facts before breaking the news to a furious Mr. Clinton at their regularly scheduled daily meeting two hours later. How could this have happened without any warning, the President asked. 
 Only 10 days earlier, Mr. Berger, known as Sandy, met with India's Foreign Secretary, delivering a message that Mr. Clinton was determined to "make a quantum leap" in elevating the American relationship with India. While he made clear that the two countries disagreed on nuclear issues, Mr. Berger gave no warning of dire consequences if India carried out its threat to test a nuclear weapon, and even asked for advice on what sites Mr. Clinton should visit on his trip to India this fall.
And, so, at the White House, Mr. Berger had no explanation to give the President. He absorbed Mr. Clinton's wrath, recommended swift sanctions and promised to produce a decision memo within 24 hours.
Mr. Berger is dancing as fast as he can. The trade lawyer turned presidential adviser has little time or inclination to play geostrategic chess. Instead, he is struggling to manage a string of crises, work the bureaucracy, cut deals, woo Congress and spin journalists, all for a President whose passions don't normally extend beyond the water's edge.
In the six days before the India crisis erupted, Mr. Berger, 52, made an overnight, no-sleep trip to Moscow to warn Russia of possible sanctions if it did not curb missile technology transfers to Iran. He spent all day Saturday on the next steps for dealing with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and preparing for Mr. Clinton's European trip. He consulted for hours by phone on Mother's Day with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on the Middle East. In between he dealt with Indonesia, Kosovo and the strategy on Iran. He tried to stop Congress from going ahead with its moratorium on land mines and finished an Op-Ed piece on religious freedom.
"I only know how to do it this way, which is full throttle," Mr. Berger said in an interview. "And I'm sure there will come a time when I start singing 'Showboat' tunes in the Oval Office and they'll carry me out."
What often gets lost is how the pieces fit together: how adding new countries to NATO fits in with promoting a stable Russia; how the problems with the Middle East peace effort fit in with long-term American interests in the Persian Gulf; how the failure to win trade negotiating authority for the President fits in with promoting the elimination of trade barriers around the world.
"I really like him," said Henry A. Kissinger, who was criticized for doing nothing but strategic geopolitics when he held the job under President Richard Nixon. "But you can't blame a trade lawyer for not being a global strategist. The security adviser reflects what the President wants, and I don't think the President asks him to come up with a global strategy."
Mr. Berger bridles at the suggestion that the Administration has no overall strategy. He ticks off the Administration's strategic goals: an undivided peaceful Europe, restoring America's relationship with China, dealing with terrorism and drugs and creating "a new architecture" for the global economy.
"You can't be successful if you can't think strategically, and you can't be successful if you're unprepared to be focused on every detail and make sure things get done," he said. "On the one hand you're an author, and on the other hand you're a garbage collector."
As the partner who built the international business portfolio of his law firm, Hogan & Hartson, Mr. Berger himself once acknowledged, however, that "grand strategies" can be overrated. "More often than not, they are rationales developed after the fact to explain a series of relatively ad hoc decisions that turn out reasonably well," he said during a panel discussion in 1991.
But at times, behind closed doors, even Mr. Berger expresses frustration that he is ground down by the crises du jour.
"Sometimes I think the only thing we're going to do in the next two years is bomb Iraq and bail out Indonesia," a colleague quoted him as saying recently.
 
Next Door to Clinton, A Command Center
The office of the national security adviser a few steps away from the Oval Office is where Mr. Kissinger plotted the secret opening to China, where Zbigniew Brzezinski thought up ways to outflank the Russians and where Robert C. McFarlane nearly brought down a President with a scheme to sell arms to Iran to finance guerrillas in Nicaragua.
Mr. Berger uses the office somewhat differently: as the command central to slog through the dozens of items on the "to do" checklist he prepares every Sunday night.
A veteran political speechwriter, Mr. Berger worries about how foreign policies will play in the heartland. In December, for example, he persuaded Mr. Clinton to change out of his Santa Claus tie for the announcement that American troops in Bosnia would not leave on deadline.
But the heartland is where Mr. Berger also suffered his biggest political defeat, enduring humiliation at a "town meeting" on Iraq in Columbus, Ohio, earlier this year when he, Ms. Albright and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen were shouted down by angry protesters.
A risk-averse lawyer who worked for clients like Toyota and Payless ShoeSource, Mr. Berger believes more in global economic power than in the balance of power.
In his conversation with India's Foreign Secretary, Krishnan Raghunath, Mr. Berger raised the issue of India's nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles only peripherally, stressing instead the need for the world's two largest democracies to build on the common agenda of health, economics, environment and information technology.
Even after the Indian nuclear tests, Mr. Berger urged Mr. Clinton not to cancel his trip, convinced that the United States has a better chance of modifying India's behavior by engagement rather than isolation.
Certainly, no one can fault Mr. Berger for being a shirker. He works 14- to 18-hour days, has the overnight intelligence reports delivered to his home every morning, reads 10 hours on Sunday but never for pleasure and has even carried two cell phones onto the golf course.
Certainly Mr. Berger's close relationship with Mr. Clinton, whom he met at a rally during the McGovern campaign in 1972, helps him along.
He spends a minimum of 20 minutes every weekday morning with the President, and is not afraid to give him unsolicited advice.
After a tense meeting between Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Helsinki in 1997, Mr. Berger suggested that the two Presidents take time before their news conference to coordinate their answers. Mr. Yeltsin replied with stony silence.
So Mr. Berger said, "President Clinton, why is President Yeltsin so much better-looking than you?" Mr. Clinton roared with laughter. So did Mr. Yeltsin. And at the news conference, the two men were feeling good again.
When Mr. Berger moved from deputy to national security adviser in January 1997, one of his first acts was to sit down with Ms. Albright and Mr. Cohen to draft what he calls "four rules for not killing each other."
Rule 1: No friendly fire. "We don't criticize each other publicly," Mr. Berger explained.
 Rule 2: Walk ourselves back. Rather than say " 'Well, Berger doesn't know what the hell he is talking about,' Berger himself walks back and says, 'Maybe I overstated it.' "
Rule 3: Presumption of innocence. "Before you accept the fact that your colleague has been engaged in some kind of mischievous, dishonest effort, you pick up the phone and talk it through."
Rule 4: No policy by press conference. "We ought to agree to things before we make policy."
 The three also help keep the peace by meeting in Mr. Berger's office for an "ABC" lunch (Albright, Berger, Cohen) every Monday. He and Ms. Albright talk on the telephone up to 30 times a day.
 
Colleagues Praise A Team Player
Largely because Mr. Berger hears out his colleagues and treats them fairly, they have only praise for him.
Ms. Albright: "The glue for the system."
Mr. Cohen: "Honest broker."
Gen. Hugh Shelton, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff: "Runs a great meeting."
Leon Fuerth, Vice President Gore's foreign policy adviser: "A sensible American at the table."
And Mr. Berger, a one-time Congressional staffer, spends an enormous amount of time working Capitol Hill.
 Last fall, he led months of quiet diplomacy with the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, when the Senate was poised to defeat ratification of the Chemical Weapons Convention, carrying a letter to him from the President to get the treaty approved.
And last month, when Mr. Berger was told that a "killer" amendment on NATO expansion might be introduced in the Senate, he abruptly ended a high-level meeting on Iraq and ordered Mr. Cohen and a top general to Capitol Hill to argue against it. Iraq would have to wait.
 But Mr. Berger has failed to improve his relationship with journalists much since his time as deputy national security adviser.
Some reporters complained privately to the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, that "background" conversations with Mr. Berger were outright misleading.
"I have never to my knowledge lied to a reporter," said Mr. Berger, seeming genuinely surprised by the thought. "Nor would I."
When confronted with a denial of a particular story that turned out to be true, Mr. Berger admitted, "Maybe I was trying to give you not the whole truth but part of the truth."
 
Taking the Long View Of Foreign Policy
On the evening of his 29th wedding anniversary late last month, Mr. Berger stood before representatives of refugee and development organizations in a hotel ballroom to read a speech about Mr. Clinton's recent trip to Africa.
Recounting that half a million people greeted the President in Ghana, he said: "I wish Americans could see us as others do. We are a beacon, an incandescent light that gives power through our ideals, our culture, our way of life." The applause was polite.
"He is so out of touch," said Tracy Hyter-Suffern, director of world relations for the Y.W.C.A. "Maybe he picked up the wrong speech."
"So patronizing," said Elizabeth Nesbitt, a program assistant for the Academy for Educational Development.
With Mr. Clinton's personal image tarnished, there is more pressure on Mr. Berger to work on the foreign policy record Mr. Clinton will leave behind. And though he says he hates discussions about a Clinton legacy, the Africa speech fit into the Administration's thesis that the United States must use its dominance to create a new global economy and build alliances that will contribute to democratic reform and prosperity.
So Mr. Berger will soldier on, with back-breaking days and nights and a telephone line in his bedroom linking him to the White House.
"He is the Cal Ripken of national security advisers," said William Danvers, who was the White House liaison to Congress until last year. "He consistently excels in his job. The thing people will remember most about him is his streak of playing every day."

HEADLINE: A Garden Caught in a Housing Squeeze

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Gardeners look at the corner of Crimmins Avenue and East 141st Street in the Bronx and marvel at the transformation of a vacant, garbage-strewn lot frequented by drug dealers into the garden of their dreams. There are flowers, vegetables and herbs. There are tables for dominoes, a scampering puppy and even a chicken coop.
The other day they planted a tree, a Canadian hemlock. "We are here to tell heaven and earth we are planting a new tree," a man said in Spanish, as two dozen people stood in a circle. "This will be its home." 
 Not for long. Others look at the site of the Crimmins Group Association Garden and envision houses rising from the spot where two six-story apartment buildings burned down more than a quarter-century ago. They endorse the Giuliani administration's decision to turn the city-owned lot over to a nonprofit group in November for construction of three two-unit homes -- the continuation of a housing renaissance that has added 30,000 units to the borough over the last decade.
And housing remains a critical need, particularly in this tattered corner of Mott Haven, where there are just six vacancies among 921 housing units, said Lee Stuart, lead organizer for South Bronx Churches. Her group is to build the homes on the garden site.
"There is literally no place where people can move," Ms. Stuart said. "It's just tight, tight, tight."
Both gardeners and builders are convinced that they are helping the neighborhood. The community gardeners point to their history of coming into devastated slums and transforming them with sweat into urban oases. Housing advocates assert that the city's greatest need is affordable housing, though many commend gardeners for filling in the temporary voids with blossoms.
For years, the two sides have maintained something of a truce. But City Hall has begun pressing for faster development of city-owned vacant lots, partly because of tightening space for housing. To further this goal, it recently transferred the bulk of the 750 community garden sites to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
Although the city has no immediate development plans for most of the sites, the gardeners fear that their dream has begun to wither. Beginning in the early 1970's, as squatters, they began to reclaim vacant lots one by one. The process was institutionalized in 1978 when a city agency, Green Thumb, was established to oversee the gardens, using Federal anti-poverty grants. The number of gardens grew to 410 in 1983. Then the growth slowed, and began to reverse in the last year, according to garden organizations.
"Community gardeners have earned the right not to have to fight for their gardens," declared Steven Frillmann, executive director of Green Guerrillas, a principal advocate. "They are like poster people for the quality of life."
Although there have been demonstrations and court battles over the loss of gardens on the Lower East Side and Upper West Side, those are aberrations. In most cases, the gardeners leave quietly. The strongest response from most gardeners at the Crimmins Avenue site was that they just wished it was not happening.
"Maybe they give me another one," Cruz Concepcion, the garden president, said quietly. "We are poor. We need a place like this."
When the group is evicted in November, it will be the second time it has been kicked out of a garden. Three years ago, they were evicted from a smaller plot on the other side of the same block. That was also supposedly to make way for housing, but the site has never been anything but a ragtag parking lot.
At the garden's center is a "casita," or little house, with a porch and a Puerto Rican flag fluttering from the top. Some garden advocates believe that casita gardens, where hens lay eggs, men drink beer and children roll in the dirt, are the most vulnerable.
"People who are white-collar bureaucrats are going to make decisions based on the appearance of gardens," said David Lutz, program director for the Neighborhood Open Spaces Coalition, a garden supporter. "Casita gardens are not necessarily the most beautiful."
The Crimmins group was joined this spring by another gardening group, one also evicted to make way for housing. The Hostos Herbal Medicine and Cultural Garden, organized by professors and students at Hostos Community College, is devoted to cultivating plants -- sometimes the very weeds found in vacant lots -- that are believed to have healing qualities.
The Hostos group had to give up its portion of a three-acre garden in Hunts Point after its last harvest to make way for two- and three-bedroom homes.
"To pit housing against gardens is too bad, but it's really where we're at," said William Frey, vice president of the Enterprise Foundation, which builds homes for lower and middle-income families.
Housing and garden advocates say that what is needed is a standard approach for weighing the best use for each site, one that begins years before a rumbling bulldozer turns up. "You can't have these political battles at the end of the process," said Kathryn S. Wylde, former president of the New York City Housing Partnership.
In fact, Ms. Stuart said that the Crimmins group's previous garden site -- taken by the housing agency in 1995 -- may not be ideal for housing development because of its size and shape. She said the church group may give it back to gardeners, something it has done several times in the past.
From the gardeners' perspective, each new garden means back-breaking work. It took nearly a year for the Crimmins group to remove garbage, including whole abandoned cars.
During a long day of work, the local people and the Hostos gardeners seem to get along nicely. They speak in Spanish, and share folk knowledge about plants -- how juniper fights viruses and periwinkle cancer. They share pizza. On other days, they have made Spanish cheese and roast pork with rice and beans.
Working very hard was Julio Reynoso, 42, who has built fences and flower beds. "This is a way for my children not to be cramped up in an apartment," he said, "and I love plants."
He pointed to a warbler vigorously bathing in a little pool the gardeners had created. "If they build a building here," he asked, "will the bird come?"

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Guest Conductor Offers A Composer He Favors

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
There is no shortage of familiar repertory from the Mahler-Strauss wing of the early 20th century. Yet several significant musicians have been trying to make space there for Alexander von Zemlinsky, who was born in Vienna in 1871 and died in Larchmont, N.Y., in 1942. Chief among Zemlinsky's advocates is the conductor James Conlon, who led an involving performance of "Die Seejungfrau," a fantasy for orchestra, with the New York Philharmonic on Friday afternoon.
Though born just three years before Schoenberg, Zemlinsky taught counterpoint to the younger composer and introduced him to the music of Wagner. Zemlinsky was an inventive and accomplished composer, but he did not follow Schoenberg's trail-blazing path to atonality. His music remained essentially tonal, and even its dissonant quotient is not high. 
 Yet in its way, "Die Seejungfrau" is a bold work, lushly yet lucidly scored. A 45-minute tone poem, it depicts the story of a restless mermaid, who, entranced with a mortal young prince, assumes human form at great physical pain to herself. But the emotional pain that comes is even worse. The music surges forward in waves of harmonic activity and long-spun melodic lines. The tremulous, quiet opening recalls another work that begins under water, Wagner's "Rheingold." In places the music bears a similarity to Schoenberg's sprawling early orchestral works, like "Pelleas und Melisande," though Zemlinsky's harmonic language is more rooted in tonality.
Yet for all the myriad subtleties in the score that are fresh and original, the music has a pattern of cresting and subsiding that becomes cliched. You did not have to watch the percussionist, his open arms readied for a big cymbal clash, to know that another climactic outburst was about to arrive. That said, it was hard to resist Mr. Conlon's impassioned, tautly shaped performance, which he conducted from memory. And the luxuriously orchestrated music summoned luminous playing from the New York Philharmonic.
The American pianist Garrick Ohlsson was the soloist for a bracing performance of Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 1, originally written when the composer was 18, but revised extensively 25 years later. This crammed, dynamic but jumbled work is not top-drawer Rachmaninoff. But Mr. Ohlsson's virtuosic, clear-headed, incisive, no-nonsense yet sensitive playing was just what it needed.
The concert concluded with a stirring performance of Liszt's symphonic poem "Les Preludes," once a repertory staple but these days not often heard. Next to the other somewhat excessive works on the program, it sounded like a model of economy and craft, thanks to the spacious, crisp and vibrant performance by Mr. Conlon and the orchestra.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
As Commodity Indexes Fall, Palladium Still Seems Strong

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Political turmoil in Indonesia, the collapse of many economies in Asia and the threatened economic sanctions on India all sent a key commodity index to its lowest level in more than four years yesterday.
At the same time, the recent slump in the Russian stock market and the continued disruption of supplies from Russia sent the spot price of palladium over $400 an ounce -- and above the price of its sister metal, platinum, for the first time. Although the rally fizzled later in the day, palladium remains near an all-time high and could move higher. 
 The decline in the prices of copper, silver, oil, nickel, wheat and other commodities, which have been in a down trend for two years, have helped tame inflation in the United States and could give some policy makers at the Federal Reserve extra arguments against raising interest rates when they meet today.
In general, Wall Street analysts do not expect the central bank to take any action. But because of the recent strength of the economy, the sharp fall in unemployment and signs of rising wage pressures, the debate could be sharp. And any signs of easing price pressures are likely to be pointed to by policy makers who want to hold the line.
The Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities fell 2.69, to 219.27. The broader Goldman Sachs Commodity Index, which has 22 commodities, fell 1.59, to 160.50, just above its March low.
"The big story is that everything is for sale, and much of that is because of the downward spiral in the Asian crisis," said Dinsa Mehta, the managing director of global commodities at Chase Manhattan Bank.
One big decliner yesterday was silver. The price for July delivery fell 28.5 cents, to $5.287, its lowest close in almost six months. The price has now dropped 11 percent in a week, a move that was set off in part by the economic sanctions India faces because of its recent nuclear tests.
India is a major buyer of silver. Both the sanctions and the fall of the Indian currency, the rupee, are expected to cut into demand. The weaker rupee makes silver, which is priced in dollars, more expensive.
Also hurting silver is the apparent selling by investors who followed Warren E. Buffett into the metal after he announced in February that his company, Berkshire Hathaway, had bought 129.7 million ounces since July. These investors all began buying silver when it was more than $6 an ounce.
While the rally in palladium faded yesterday, it probably is not over because there is no sign yet that the Russians, the world's biggest producer, are going to ship any metal soon. The spot price of palladium rose as high as $425 an ounce yesterday, while platinum hit only $406. But palladium then fell to $387, down $15.50 on the day.
One reason the rally can continue, said Matthew Keen, J. P. Morgan's head trader for platinum group metals in London, is that "car companies are not particularly phased by the price of palladium." Catalytic converters are major users of palladium. But the unit cost per car of palladium is still relatively low.
"It is not having a material impact on our business," said Mel Stephens, the director of business news at the Ford Motor Company.
Another reason for a rally is that there are many investors who own palladium futures contracts that expire in June that can require them to deliver the metal to settle. The shortage of actual metal, therefore, could push the price much higher. "It looks like some crunch is coming," said Keith Green, the director of Johnson Matthey's marketing division, during the company's presentation of its annual survey of the platinum and palladium markets.

HEADLINE: Kohl Paints Opponent As Far Leftist

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BREMEN, Germany, May 18

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Europe's elder statesman and Germany's political colossus, launched his re-election campaign today with a harsh, personal attack on his main challenger, accusing Gerhard Schroder of steering the land toward a "leftist republic."
Seeking to offset Mr. Schroder's telegenic popularity and big lead in opinion polls, Mr. Kohl assailed the Social Democratic leader for recently permitting a political agreement with the remodeled Communist Party in the small eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt. 
 There, local Social Democrats have agreed to run the state government with tacit support from the former Communists.
If such arrangements spread to a national level, Mr. Kohl said, the result would be "insecurity, instability and the loss of the world's confidence in Germany."
Mr. Kohl was speaking at a special party meeting here of his Christian Democratic Union. Party loyalists were hoping to start reversing his flagging political fortunes. The German leader is 8 to 10 points behind Mr. Schroder in opinion surveys.
So far, Mr. Kohl seems to have drawn little benefit from a visit last week by President Clinton, who praised him as being "on the right side of history."
Indeed, as they listened to his two-hour speech -- and rose for a 10-minute standing ovation -- Mr. Kohl's followers may have concluded privately today that this was not just a call to arms, but also a valedictory for four terms and 16 years in office, spanning three American Administrations -- a record in modern Germany.
The attempt to link Mr. Schroder to a Communist threat may seem anachronistic outside Germany. But this country has long and bad memories of ideological extremes, dating not just to the cold war decades of Germany's division, but also to the rise of Communism and Nazism before World War II.
While eastern Germans routinely give a fifth of their votes to the Party of Democratic Socialism -- the former Communist Party -- the ex-Communists remain anathema to western voters. Mr. Kohl called the Social Democrats' agreement with the former Communists "highly dangerous."
Political radicalism, he said, "brought only misfortune" to Germany in this century.
Underlying Mr. Kohl's remarks is a battle for the middle ground of German politics. Mr. Schroder says he represents a "new center," challenging Mr. Kohl for the center ground that he has long regarded as his own. So Mr. Kohl seeks to depict Mr. Schroder as a Trojan horse of radicalism.
In his quest, Mr. Kohl faces the problem that many issues seem intractable: joblessness is at a postwar high, particularly in the east, where growth lags far behind western Germany. Attempts at economic reform have faltered in political stalemate.
It took no time at all for the opposition Social Democrats to point out that Mr. Kohl was 40 minutes into his speech today before he even mentioned unemployment.
"Helmut Kohl is yesterday's man," the Social Democrats said in a statement after the applause died down. "Kohl has missed his last chance."
The party gathering here was touted by Mr. Kohl's allies as a possible turning point, comparable to a similar congress before the 1994 elections. Then as now, Mr. Kohl was trailing the opposition in opinion polls and some wrote him off. Then as now, he used a pre-election party meeting to turn his followers' minds from defeat.
But then, unlike now, the voter surveys -- of which Mr. Kohl is scornfully dismissive -- were not telling quite such a tale of rejection and weariness with his rule. Then, Mr. Kohl could count on eastern Germans still hoping for the fruits of reunification. Then, there were not so many on the unemployment lines as the 4.5 million today.
And then he was 64, not 68. His age makes him an emblem of the wartime generation, while Mr. Schroder is 54 -- a slicker showman far more attuned to the baby boomers likely to shape Germany's destiny.
Even within his party there are doubts. A weekend poll found that 56 percent of the Christian Democrats surveyed predicted that Mr. Kohl would not win in September.
"Helmut Kohl stands at the end of a development," said Alexander Gaulland, an author and journalist regarded as a Christian Democratic intellectual. "He will not set foot in the promised land, like Moses."
Mr. Kohl was not so easily dismissed. "We know how to fight," he declared. "We know that without fighting, no election is won. We will not leave the field open to the others. We want to fight."
This year's vote is seen as critical, and not just because Mr. Kohl is pressing for an unparalleled fifth term . The election is seen as likely to determine how Germany -- and thus much of Europe -- is run as the Continent faces the strains of adopting a single currency, the euro, which could revolutionize its political and economic workings.
Whether Mr. Kohl fired up the party as he did in 1994 remains unclear. His image-makers called the speech combative and forward-looking. "There was a synergy," said a senior official. "He was aggressive, and the party wanted him to be aggressive."
Mr. Kohl, though, is in a particular bind. On his watch, Germany was reunified in 1990, and under his tutelage Europe has been pushed and cajoled toward integration.
"For someone like me," he said, European unity is all the more important, since in his teens he needed a pass simply to travel a few miles in Germany between the French and American occupation zones.
"Another generation will ask, 'What have you achieved?' And we will say, 'Europe,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Increase Number of Foreigners Allowed in U.S. to Fill Technology Jobs

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Heeding the calls of the high-technology industry, the Senate voted today to increase the number of foreign workers who would be allowed into the United States to fill thousands of short-term computer programming and other similar jobs.
The Senate approved the bill by a vote of 78 to 20 after a daylong debate that pitted the muscle of the high-technology companies, who say they face a crisis shortage of qualified United States workers, against the concerns of labor unions and immigration opponents. The bill would increase the number of foreign high-technology workers by 20,000 to 30,000 a year for five years. 
 "One only needs to pick up the want ads, and you will see, as these various newspapers here suggest, the spectacular amount of jobs going unfilled," said Senator Spencer Abraham, the Michigan Republican who wrote the bill.
"We need to be able to attract and find and bring to this country the highest skilled workers we can to fill these jobs, until we can find workers in our country to fill them," Mr. Abraham said.
Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman indicated she would recommend a veto to President Clinton, saying that the bill favors foreign workers over American ones.
But the House version of the bill, which takes steps to insure that Americans are not displaced by foreign workers or overlooked, could ease the Administration's labor concerns. That bill is opposed by the high-technology industry and by Mr. Abraham.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, tried to attach two similar provisions to Mr. Abraham's bill, but was voted down.
"I'm wondering what we have against Americans and American workers that we are so willing to turn over these good jobs to foreigners," said Mr. Kennedy, who added that the high-technology companies needed to do a better job of recruiting and training American workers for these jobs.
Mr. Abraham's bill, which would lapse in five years, would increase the number of visas allocated to highly skilled workers by 30,000 for 1998 and by 20,000 each year for the four years after that. If the crunch worsens, it would likely allow an additional 20,000 visas a year. Currently, there are 65,000 visas available for highly skilled workers.
Contributing to the bill's momentum on the Senate floor was the fact that this year's 65,000 visas have already been depleted, something that had not occurred before last year. Predictions for 1999 indicate that the number could be exhausted as early as February.
To accommodate the added high-technology workers, the legislation would cut back on the number of health care workers permitted into the United States, placing an annual limit of 10,000 on them and shifting them to a separate visa category.
It would also provide money to help train low-income students in high-technology skills.
For months now, high-technology executives have been making dire predictions about how the shortage of workers, mostly computer programmers, would hurt the economy and help blunt the industry's competitive edge. So eager were they to get this legislation passed that even the heavy-hitters, William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, for one, got personally involved in the lobbying.
Further complicating the problem, executives say, is that a number of workers have been diverted to work on correcting computer programs that will be thrown into chaos in 2000 for the simple reason that the year ends in 00.
Mr. Abraham said there were an estimated 330,000 existing vacancies for high-technology jobs, a void that could drive American companies abroad in their hunt for talent or could lure foreign workers to foreign competitors.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Major Indexes Show Decline For a Third Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Major stock market indexes fell for the third consecutive trading day yesterday on the dampened demand from investors concerned about the chaos in Indonesia and the Government's legal action against the Microsoft Corporation.
Political uncertainty and rioting in Indonesia has refocused investor attention on the economic problems in Asia. Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said it reminded investors that growth has slowed in the region and that American corporations could be affected. 
 While the news out of Asia weakened the stock market, bond investors interpreted the developments positively. The Asian turmoil and a sharp increase in the dollar's value bolstered bonds by encouraging foreign investors to seek a haven in the safety of dollar-denominated securities.
The dollar's advance also reflected the uncertainty in Asia, which caused a broad selloff of all Asian currencies, pushing the dollar to the highest level against the yen since September 1991.
Bonds also benefited from the belief that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise short-term interest rates when its chief governing committee meets today. Stocks, on the other hand, which had been volatile in recent weeks on interest rate expectations, virtually ignored that bullish sentiment.
"I think if the Federal Reserve were to tighten, it would surprise everyone," said Larry Wachtel, market analyst at Prudential Securities.
Since it reached a new high of 9,211.84 last Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen for three straight sessions. Yesterday it lost 45.09 points, declining to 9,050.91. Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 2.91 points, to 1,105.82, its third consecutive decline.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 15.17 points, to 1,831.62, the lowest in five weeks. It was dragged down by a 3.8 percent drop in the shares of Microsoft, which fell $3.375, to $86.0625. Yesterday, the Justice Department and 20 states filed antitrust lawsuits against Microsoft, contending the dominant software company has tried to stifle competition.
News of the legal action put a damper on the technology sector as several large issues slumped, including Hewlett-Packard, which had already fallensharply last week on unexpectedly weak earnings.
There were some spots of positive news. Dell Computer rose on expectations that today's first-quarter earnings report would exceed analyst forecasts. Promising medical treatment news sent several drug stocks higher and the market received another round of corporate mergers news. But stocks still traded lower.
The inability of the market to focus on the silver lining -- as it has done so often -- has some analysts believing that more declines loom.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Bond Prices Rally
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, pushing yields to nearly one-month lows, in a rally fed by a surge in the dollar's value and expectations that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged at its policy-making meeting today.

HEADLINE: To Clear Air With Europe, U.S. Waives Some Sanctions

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 18

 BODY:
Trying to resolve two of the toughest disputes between the United States and Europe, the Clinton Administration waived sanctions today against three foreign companies that are doing business in Iran and said that it would seek legislation to head off sanctions against businesses that operate in Cuba.
In exchange the European Union and Russia agreed to tighten control of the export of weapons technology to Iran. The European Union also agreed with the United States to set up a system to govern confiscated property in Cuba and elsewhere. 
 Administration officials said the agreements, reached after more than a year of negotiating, had taken the poison out of two vicious disputes that had affected Washington's ability to win European support on other matters.
The accords involve the Helms-Burton law and the Iran-Libya sanctions act, both of which empower the United States to punish other countries for doing business with the third parties.
Congressional Republicans were outraged at the Administration's decision. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said: "The decision is a mistake. It will send a signal to others that they can do business as usual with Iran at a time when Iran continues to pursue weapons of mass destruction and continues to sponsor terrorist acts."
Marc Thiessen, a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said: "The Europeans offered the Administration absolutely nothing in exchange for this waiver. This sends a signal to Iran that the United States is not serious about isolating their terrorist regime."
Although Mr. Thiessen said changing the Helms-Burton law would be difficult, a senior Administration official said that much time had been spent with Mr. Helms in the negotiations and that "there is a lot of understanding on the Hill for what we're trying to do."
President Clinton said because the Europeans had agreed to restrict the exports of weapons technology further, the waivers were "part of our overall strategy to deter Iran from acquiring weapons of mass destruction and promoting terrorism."
Similarly, he argued that the accord on Cuba would protect American interests "far more effectively than the United States could have done alone."
Mr. Clinton made his comments at a joint news conference in London with Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, and Jacques Santer, President of the European Commission.
The Iran-Libya act of 1996 mandates sanctions but permits the Secretary of State to waive them in the national interest.
Senior European diplomats in Washington said the Administration had agreed that companies in all European Union nations would receive similar waivers. But senior American officials said there would be no automatic waivers for countries that invested in pipelines that ran through Iran from Caspian Sea countries.
Russia received no blanket assurances, because the Administration remains concerned about the reliability of its export controls.
In the case of the Cuba sanctions, the Administration will need the cooperation of a reluctant Congress. Those sanctions apply to companies that profit from property that Cuba's Communist Government expropriated from Americans. Administration officials said legislators whom they had contacted in recent days were impressed with the outlines of the evolving agreement.
After having announced the agreements in London, Mr. Clinton flew here to address a meeting of the World Trade Organization, where he called for "an ever more open global trading system."
"Globalization and the technology revolution are not policy choices," he said. "They are facts."
He urged the organization to speed negotiations and to begin examining next year how to reduce tariffs and subsidies in agriculture. He also proposed that the agency open to the public its hearings over trade disputes. The sessions are now closed.
The accords were reached after a weekend of debate over the usefulness of economic sanctions. Of the four major European democracies at the economic summit in Birmingham, England, none agreed to follow the American lead in imposing sanctions on India for testing nuclear weapons. Nor has Russia done so, although Japan and Canada, two other participants, have.
Standing beside Mr. Clinton today, Mr. Santer called the American sanctions policy toward Iran, Libya, and Cuba illegal and counterproductive. He praised the agreement today as "getting rid of the biggest problem in our relationship."
Mr. Blair observed that what the United States called sanctions policy the Europeans called interfering with the internal affairs of other nations.
The Europeans had already agreed to drop a suit against the United States before the World Trade Organization on that issue.
The United States had been weighing sanctions against three foreign companies -- French, Russian and Malaysian -- over a joint venture to develop Iran's South Pars gas field.
In a statement Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said that she remained opposed to the energy deal, but that she found it to be in the national interest to waive the sanctions. Doing so, Ms. Albright said, would encourage Europe, Russia and Malaysia to cooperate with the United States in isolating Iraq and addressing the Asian financial crisis. She also said the waivers would encourage the Russians to ratify the Start II nuclear arms control treaty.
American officials acknowledged that the waivers would put American companies at a disadvantage in Iran. "That is the price, if I may say so, of real leadership," an official said. American energy companies are prohibited from investing in Iran by an Executive Order issued in 1995.
According to Title III of the Helms-Burton act, Mr. Clinton may waive permission for former owners of contested property to sue the foreign companies for compensation in American courts. Under the law Mr. Clinton has to exercise that waiver, if he chooses to do so, every six months. He has done exactly that since the law passed in 1996.
Another provision, Title IV, requires the Government to deny visas to executives of foreign companies that profit from the disputed property. It is that provision that the Administration is seeking to amend, to permit Mr. Clinton to waive sanctions indefinitely for European Union nations. The Administration also committed to sounding out Congress about dropping the six-month time limit for Title III waivers.
In exchange the European Union has agreed to a series of so-called disciplines to limit investment in expropriated property in Cuba and elsewhere. The rules prohibit Governments from providing such businesses loans, subsidies, risk insurance or other support, including diplomatic advocacy.
Under the agreement people who feel that their property has been illegally expropriated would be able to list their claims with a new international registry. Governments would then check that registry when companies request help with particular ventures.
In his remarks today Mr. Clinton was at pains to emphasize the needs of consumers, workers and environmentalists, whom he referred to in London as "stakeholders in our economic lives."
After failing last year to win enhanced authority from Congress to negotiate trade deals, Mr. Clinton concluded that he had done too little to assuage the fears over free trade expressed by unions, environmentalists and others. As he pledged to continue pressing Congress for the authority, he said tonight that the trade representatives gathered here had to insure that "spirited economic competition among nations never becomes a race to the bottom in environmental protections, consumer protections and labor standards."
Mr. Clinton also suggested that China was becoming a more democratic nation. "Russia and China, where the shackles of state socialism once choked off enterprise, are moving to join the thriving community of free democracies," he said.

HEADLINE: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE POLICY;
Halting Loans Isn't Enough, Both Parties Tell Clinton

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration came under intense attack in the Senate today for its unwillingness to call on President Suharto of Indonesia to step down, even as the United States and its allies changed policy by indefinitely suspending a $43 billion economic bailout of the country.
In a highly charged hearing of the Asian subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, both parties criticized the White House for putting economic stability ahead of actions to encourage democratic change and for wavering on whether to press Mr. Suharto to leave. 
 "The message should be simple and direct," said Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat. "President Suharto has got to go." Senator Paul D. Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat, said: "I think our silence is betrayal. We have to be on the side of the students."
Their critique comes amid change in American policy toward Indonesia. Less than a week ago Treasury and State Department officials said that aid would continue to flow. But today the Administration and its major allies halted three loans totaling $2.7 billion, scheduled to go in the next 48 hours by the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. Both have been working with the International Monetary Fund.
This is the first time the Administration has even implicitly tied political change -- though not necessarily Mr. Suharto's departure -- to the $43 billion aid package put together after Indonesia was hit by economic and political crisis.
The public explanation was purely logistical: with Jakarta's streets in chaos and its financial system in collapse, there is no way to track what happens to the money. The World Bank, for example, evacuated 68 expatriate officials from Indonesia over the weekend.
In testimony today, Stanley Roth, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, declined to link future aid to political change in Indonesia. But privately officials described a different policy, as debate raged over how to influence events there without much leverage. A senior Administration official said it would take more than a mere restoration of order to restart the flow of money. "It will depend on a range of factors that include social, economic and political factors, as well as the logistic issues," the official said.
Referring to the Administration, a senior official of an international financial institution dealing with Indonesia said, "They are shifting gears at high speed," adding, "They were casting the suspension of aid as a 'technical' matter while there was chaos in the streets. Now there are political conditions. We have entered the world of subliminal diplomacy."
Washington has been reluctant to urge Mr. Suharto's departure for fear of the chaos that might follow. Moreover, it is unclear who Mr. Suharto's successor might be.
In the last week, however, the calculus has changed dramatically. The chaos, it is now believed, will worsen if Mr. Suharto stays. Yet the Administration has been unwilling to reverse itself, with officials saying they are looking for some kind of ill-defined "middle ground," supporting political reform without specifying that Mr. Suharto must go. For example, officials say they want to prepare for the possibility of Mr. Suharto's staying on as titular leader even if power is transferred to others.
"We have no idea what this might look like in a week," a State Department official said today. "It's not time to get in a box we'll have to extract ourselves from on Friday."
But Senator Kerry called the result "a muddled message."
"There is no linkage of policy to any principles about the rise of a democratic government," he said. "Or if there is, they won't say so."
Administration officials say one reason for their public caution is that Washington's relationship with Indonesia is much more tenuous than its ties with the Philippines 12 years ago, when Senator Paul Laxalt was sent to tell Ferdinand E. Marcos that the time had come for him to leave.
The Philippines, a former American colony, was defended by two major American military bases. Indonesia, on the other hand, has always had a far testier relationship with the United States. Until last week the only American calls for political reform in Indonesia came in private meetings between Mr. Suharto and a series of American envoys, most notably former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. But Mr. Suharto did not respond.
In public, however, the Administration only began talking about political reform in Indonesia last week, after the rioting had begun. And even today, Mr. Roth would not specify what kinds of reform the Administration had in mind, saying that like Mr. Suharto's future, it is "up to the Indonesian people."
