HEADLINE: Alabama Governor's Race Tests Strength of Christian Conservatives

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 12

 BODY:
Even his campaign advisers are telling Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama to change the subject. But when it comes to his obsessive crusade to reconcile church and state, the Governor has maintained the relentless tenacity he once showed as a hunkered-down halfback for the Auburn University Tigers.
His defiant stands in defense of religious expression in schools and courtrooms, including threats to call out the National Guard and defy the United States Supreme Court, have earned the Governor a national reputation for zealotry -- and some serious opposition in the Republican primary for governor on June 2. 
 The campaign has exposed deep fault lines here in the heart of the Republican South. On one side are many of the Christian conservatives who have supplied the party with much of its energy and voting strength in recent years. On the other are many in the state's image-conscious business community, who fear that Mr. James is driving away investment.
"It's become a race about a set of issues that if rejected in a Republican primary will be a major setback to the pro-family movement across America," said Ralph Reed, the former director of the Christian Coalition and a consultant for Mr. James. "I think the pro-faith community is sophisticated enough to understand that."
Mr. James's opponents, who share his support for returning prayer to the public schools, counter that the race is not about beliefs. Instead, they say, it is about tactics, and whether the state can afford another governor known primarily for tilting at the Federal courts.
Although Mr. James, 63, is favored in the five-way race, many political analysts assume he will fail to win a majority in the primary and will be forced into a runoff on June 30. His most likely opponent is Winton Blount 3d, 54, a wealthy Montgomery businessman and party leader who has accused Mr. James of "playing to the worst instincts" of this notoriously populist state.
In the 1960's, one of Mr. James's predecessors, George C. Wallace, achieved legendary status in Alabama with his populist, court-bashing defense of segregation. Now, Mr. James has adopted a similar approach, with religion replacing race as the focus of his appeal.
Mr. James's stands on religion seem to be heartfelt, say those who know him best. But he has also chosen to advertise his views with stump speeches and legal briefs, making school prayer as prominent a feature of his re-election strategy as are his pledges to improve schools and hold down taxes.
In an effort to energize evangelicals, some of Mr. James's strategists have portrayed the race as a referendum on a distinct brand of social conservatism.
But Mr. James's aides also recognize that the campaign has revealed fissures within the conservative Christian movement between those who admire Mr. James's resolve and those who fear that his showmanship may undermine their cause. They have kept the prayer issue out of his television advertisements, preferring instead to aim their appeals to evangelicals through telephone calls and direct mail. And they have encouraged Mr. James to focus his remarks more on education, taxes, jobs and crime.
During the last 15 months, Mr. James has waged a guerrilla war against the courts over long-held interpretations of the First Amendment's establishment clause. The United States Supreme Court has consistently ruled in school prayer cases that the clause prohibits government from favoring religion over nonreligion. Mr. James has asserted that the courts have exceeded their authority, misread the Constitution and suppressed religious freedom.
In February 1997, he announced that he would call out the National Guard if necessary to defend the right of Judge Roy Moore of Etowah County Circuit Court to display the Ten Commandments in his courtroom. Another state court judge ruled that Mr. Moore must remove the wooden tablet, but the decision was overturned by the state Supreme Court on technical grounds.
Last June, Mr. James wrote a 34-page letter to Judge Ira DeMent of Federal District Court urging him to dismiss a challenge to a 1993 Alabama statute that permitted non-sectarian, nonproselytizing, student-initiated voluntary prayer in public schools. The letter essentially argued that the Bill of Rights does not apply to the states.
"We will have no justice in our courts or integrity in our government without the blessing of God upon us," Mr. James wrote.
Judge DeMent rejected the Governor's request, and later ruled that the school prayer statute was unconstitutional. When the judge issued an injunction last November explaining what forms of religious expression were allowed and proscribed in the schools, Mr. James vowed to "resist Judge DeMent's order by every legal and political means with every ounce of strength I possess."
This month, Mr. James petitioned the United States Supreme Court to overturn Judge DeMent's ruling, with a brief that encouraged defiance of the high court.
"In the absence of constitutional limitations, other constitutional officials throughout government owe no 'deference' to the decisions of this Court," Mr. James argued in the brief, which was written by his son, Forrest H. James 3d.
The Alabama Attorney General, Bill Pryor, a Republican, quickly distanced himself from Mr. James, saying the Governor did not speak for the state. Mr. Pryor, who was appointed by Mr. James to fill an unexpired term, has filed a separate appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. That appeal accepts the unconstitutionality of school prayer, but uses free speech grounds to challenge some of Judge DeMent's restrictions.
In addition to Mr. Blount, who finished third in the 1994 Republican primary for governor, Mr. James's other opponents in this year's primary are former Gov. Guy Hunt, 64, who was recently pardoned on a state ethics conviction and is running for the office he was forced to resign in 1993; Lewis Leslie McAllister Jr., 65, a Tuscaloosa manufacturer and local party leader, and Phillip W. Williams, 58, a former state finance director under Mr. James.
The most recent public poll, which was conducted April 27-30 for Southern Opinion Research, showed Mr. Blount (pronounced blunt) moving into contention with Mr. James. Among those who said they were likely to vote in the Republican primary, Mr. James was supported by about 39 percent, Mr. Blount by 30 percent, Mr. Hunt by 14 percent, Mr. McAllister by 9 percent and Mr. Williams by 2 percent. Seven percent said they were undecided. The margin of error was plus or minus five percentage points.
The Republican nominee, presumably with a depleted treasury, will probably face Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, a Democrat, in the general election. Mr. Siegelman is an experienced candidate who had raised $3.9 million as of April 15. With little competition in the primary, he has managed to save nearly all of it.
Support for Mr. James, who made a fortune manufacturing plastic-coated barbells before beginning his political career, is particularly anemic in Alabama's business community. Those Republicans blame Mr. James for failing to win legislative support for tort reform, for exacerbating the perception of the state as a backwater and for devoting more energy to religious issues than to economic development.
The Governor won a big victory last fall by bringing a Boeing rocket booster plant and 3,000 jobs to the city of Decatur with more than $140 million in state incentives. But it may have come too late to restore his reputation in business circles.
Mr. Blount, whose father was Postmaster General in the Nixon Administration, said the state was "thirsting to join the other states marching proudly into the 21st century." And while he emphasized that he, too, supported prayer in the schools, he said he would respect the rule of law and would not be "out running ragged on some strategy that doesn't make any sense."
After beginning their television advertising campaign, Mr. James's aides maintained that they had stopped Mr. Blount's momentum. But Mr. Blount has received endorsements in recent weeks from the leading newspapers in the state's four largest cities. And he has won the endorsement of the Coalition of Christians for Family Values, a group of evangelicals led by a Montgomery minister, Mickey A. Kirkland, who ran in the Republican primary for governor in 1994.
Mr. Kirkland said Mr. James had alienated many conservative Christians by turning the school prayer debate into a sideshow.
"I think people of faith see the sensationalizing of issues for political gain, and we despise that, detest that," Mr. Kirkland said.
He said Mr. James also lost support last month when a television station's microphone captured him cursing while signing a bill requiring silent reflection at the start of each school day. The Governor later apologized, but Mr. Kirkland said some evangelicals saw hypocrisy.
Other conservative Christian groups are firmly on Mr. James's side, and Mr. Reed expressed confidence that a heavy turnout of evangelicals would insure victory for the Governor. Robert J. Russell, chairman of the Christian Coalition of Alabama, which does not endorse candidates, predicted that Mr. James would win "tremendous support from the Christian right" because of his support for prayer in the schools and the Ten Commandments and his opposition to abortion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama greeted backers while campaigning last week. The governor's race has exposed fissures in the Republican South. (The Tuscaloosa News)

HEADLINE: Bipartisan Plan for Rescue of Social Security Involves Markets and Retirement at 70

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
A commission including members of Congress from both parties will propose a sweeping plan today to shore up Social Security, calling for the establishment of personal investment accounts and a gradual increase in the retirement age to 70.
The report is the most comprehensive package of recommendations to date for remaking Social Security in preparation for the baby-boom generation's retirement. It says the changes would keep Social Security solvent for at least 75 years without raising taxes, even as it trades some reductions in guaranteed benefits for the higher if less certain returns of the financial markets. 
 Prepared over 15 months by the National Commission on Retirement Policy, a private group of lawmakers, economists, pension experts and business executives that was assembled by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, the report is likely to wield considerable influence at the White House and on Capitol Hill as Democrats and Republicans seek solutions to one of the nation's most politically sensitive issues.
While the committee's main recommendations are sure to be hotly debated, the report underscores the speed with which once-radical options for Social Security, like the addition of an investment component, have become part of the political mainstream.
Powerful interest groups including the American Association of Retired Persons oppose creating private accounts within the Social Security system, as do many liberal Democrats.
While the Congressional Democrats and Republicans on the commission backed the investment-oriented approach, the panel had no members from labor unions or other groups that have fought to maintain Social Security as a guaranteed safety net against poverty in old age.
But with the stock market booming and people more comfortable than even a few years ago with investing on their own, Democrats including Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska have joined Republicans in backing private accounts.
"This report brought together people who really understand the issue," said Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, a Republican and a co-chairman of the commission. "It's bipartisan. It's the only plan out there scored by Social Security's actuaries as saving the system for the next century."
The report was unanimously approved last week by the commission's 24 members, including Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat, and Representatives Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, a Democrat, and Jim Kolbe of Arizona, a Republican. Senator Breaux and Representatives Stenholm and Kolbe were also co-chairmen of the commission, along with Donald B. Marron, the chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber Group, the Wall Street firm, and Charles B. Sanders, the former chairman of Glaxo Inc., the pharmaceutical company.
Mr. Marron said the proposal should play a central role as Congress and the White House move toward drafting Social Security legislation next year.
"Unlike other proposals this one has a great degree of detail and a focus as far as turning it into legislation," Mr. Marron said.
The report calls for diverting into personal investment accounts two percentage points of the 12.4 percent payroll tax levied on workers and their employers to finance Social Security. The change, which would not affect current retirees, would allow individuals a choice of investment options for the money accumulating in their Government-administered accounts, including stock-index funds and Treasury securities.
Advocates of private accounts said the higher rates of return available from investing in the financial markets would leave people with more money at retirement than they would have if they relied on the current system. Opponents say many individuals are already investing in the stock market, and that rather than making a bigger bet on Wall Street, the nation should tweak Social Security but not change its role in providing a guaranteed payment, regardless of stock prices or the economy.
Since allocating part of payroll tax receipts to investment accounts for current workers would eventually leave the system short of the money needed to pay benefits to current retirees, the report calls for the Government to make up the difference with Federal budget surpluses.
But the plan also calls for other steps to reduce the financial strain on Social Security as the 76 million baby boomers born from 1946 through 1964 start heading into retirement a decade from now.
The retirement age, already set to rise to 67 from 65 over the next few decades, would rise under the plan to 70 by 2029. The early retirement age would rise to 65 from 62 by 2017.
The presumed higher rate of return from the private accounts would be somewhat offset by reductions for many in the traditional guaranteed monthly Social Security payments.
But the cutbacks would be designed to hit the wealthy more than people with lower incomes. The report also calls for the establishment of a minimum benefit -- set at 60 percent of the poverty line for people who have worked at least 20 years, rising to 100 percent for people who have worked at least 40 years -- and would allow Social Security recipients to continue working without a reduction in their benefits.

HEADLINE: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE OVERVIEW;
U.S. AND 20 STATES FILE SUITS CLAIMING MICROSOFT BLOCKS COMPETITION OVER INTERNET

BYLINE: BY JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
The Federal Government and 20 state Attorneys General filed two broad, aggressive antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation today, launching the most concerted government attack on a single company in a generation.
The suits accuse the world's most powerful software company of using its monopoly in personal computer operating systems to win control of the Internet and software products, particularly browsers, which are necessary for viewing and interacting with the World Wide Web. 
 What is more, the Justice Department suit accuses Microsoft of having once approached its then-infant rival, the Netscape Communications Corporation, with an offer to divide the Internet market.
As Attorney General Janet Reno announced the filing of the suits this afternoon, with Attorneys General from Connecticut, Iowa and New York standing at her side, she said that Microsoft's business practices had "restricted the choices available for consumers in America and around the world."
In a meeting with reporters at Microsoft's headquarters in Redmond, Wash., this afternoon, Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, said, "This is a step backward for America, for consumers and for the personal computer industry that is leading our nation's economy into the 21st century.
"How ironic," Mr. Gates added, "that in the United States -- where freedom and innovation are core values -- that these regulators are trying to punish an American company that has worked hard and successfully to deliver on these values."
The Justice Department and Attorneys General asked the United States District Court for the District of Columbia to issue a preliminary injunction to stop the practices described in the suits immediately.
But in a curious twist in their decision to take on the company that epitomizes the supremacy of the nation's high-technology industry, they stopped short of asking the court to block the release of Microsoft's latest version of its operating system, Windows 98.
Even as the lawsuits were being filed, Microsoft began shipping the product to computer manufacturers, and it announced that it was on schedule to sell Windows 98 in stores beginning June 25.
Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust, said that the Justice Department would not try to block Windows 98 because the Government wanted to "create options, not restrict them, so we will not try to stop the shipment of the software."
With the final version of Windows 98 already shipped, it was clear that many consumers were likely to get the new operating system without the limits and remedies being sought in the lawsuits. But Mr. Klein also made it clear that his goal was not to block one piece of software but to force Microsoft to change its way of doing business.
"What cannot be tolerated -- and what the antitrust laws forbid," Mr. Klein said, "is the barrage of illegal, anticompetitive practices that Microsoft uses to destroy its rivals and to avoid competition."
In a decision that pleased the Justice Department, the case was assigned to District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who issued a ruling favorable to the Government in the antitrust case filed against Microsoft last October.
That suit charges Microsoft with violating a 1995 consent decree by forcing computer manufacturers to accept the company's browser, Internet Explorer, as a condition of licensing its Windows 95 operating system.
The new Federal and state suits would require Microsoft to sell a version of Windows 98 that does not include Internet Explorer -- or to package Netscape's Navigator browser, the principal competing product, with Windows 98.
The state suit also asks that Microsoft be forced to include a third Web browser of Microsoft's choice unless Internet Explorer is removed from the operating system.
Microsoft maintains that Internet Explorer is now part of the Windows operating system, not a stand-alone product, and therefore cannot be removed.
Dennis C. Vacco, the New York Attorney General, whose office will head the states' litigation team, said, "Our action today aims to protect consumers from a single power controlling and dominating an information infrastructure that one day may be our primary link to communications, commerce and information."
A senior Justice Department official noted that there were precedents for requiring a company to carry its competitors' products. Long-distance telephone companies, for example, have been required to allow competitors to use their lines, and one airline's reservation system has been required to carry the flight information of competing airlines.
But Mr. Gates said that neither of the alternatives described in the suits was acceptable.
"I don't think asking us to ship a competitor's product is an appropriate solution," he said. "And if they want us to re-engineer Windows to take these new features out, we'll have to turn to the courts."
The Federal and state suits also try to stop Microsoft from requiring that computer makers set up new computers so that consumers see Microsoft's main Windows screen, or desktop, when they first turn on their machines. This requirement is important to Microsoft -- and to the Government -- because the desktop can now serve as a gateway to the Internet and to every other service and piece of software available.
"At stake here," said Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut Attorney General, "is whether Microsoft's control over gateways could throttle Internet commerce -- and indeed commerce itself."
In a statement, Microsoft said: "Consumers who purchase a new PC and see the Windows desktop as the first screen are assured of the product's quality, simplicity and reliability. Once that first 'boot-up' takes place, consumers can customize the desktop in any way they like."
That may be true, Mr. Klein said, but he added that it was "quite clear" that most consumers maintained the basic desktop they were given. And a senior Government official said that the prosecutors saw the first-screen requirement as Microsoft's way of maintaining its operating system monopoly.
Without it, Mr. Klein said, computer manufacturers would be able to bring their own "interesting, challenging opportunities to consumers."
The state and Federal suits also seek to end "exclusionary contracts with providers of Internet and on-line services" that are intended to make them favor Microsoft products and services. During negotiations between prosecutors and Microsoft lawyers over the weekend, that was one area where the company initially expressed some flexibility. But the talks foundered over other issues, so no agreements were reached.
Today, Microsoft said: "Like virtually all companies in the software industry and many other industries, Microsoft has entered into various cross-promotional agreements in which Microsoft agrees to help promote and distribute a company's products and services in exchange for promoting Microsoft's technology. These agreements are legal and commonplace."
The suit filed by the state Attorneys General follows the lines of the Federal suit in most areas but adds charges of its own. For example, the states charge that Microsoft is using predatory pricing strategies to gain monopolies in other software products, including word processors and spreadsheets that are packaged in office "suites," including the market-leading Microsoft Office.
The states' suit says that Microsoft offers steep discounts only if the company's office suite is purchased for installation on a manufacturers' entire line of computers. The manufacturers "cannot afford to pay the significantly higher royalties for per-copy licenses, because their profit margins are very narrow," the suit says.
"As a result of that pricing strategy," the suit goes on, "Microsoft Office has attained monopoly power in the field of office productivity suites. By calendar year 1995, Office accounted for over 85 percent of all sales of office productivity suites, and its share of sales has increased since that time."
That pricing strategy, the suit charges, has made it "economically impractical for manufacturers to offer competing office productivity suites for preinstallation on their PC's."
In his remarks this morning, Mr. Gates said the company's products had been successful "because we did a better product."
The state suit also accuses the company of trying to take control of the E-mail software market by bundling Outlook Express, the company's E-mail program, with Windows 98. The suit does not, as some state officials predicted last week, challenge Microsoft's inclusion in Windows 98 of WebTV for Windows, an electronic program guide that shows what is on television and on certain Web sites.
Still, the suit clearly leaves the door open so that new charges can be added if more states join the effort and bring their own concerns.
The Attorneys General said they were acting to protect consumers -- and aspiring entrepreneurs -- in their states.
Iowa's Attorney General, Tom Miller, chairman of the Antitrust Task Force for the National Association of Attorneys General, said, "We are taking this action to give a fair shake to competitors and free choice to consumers in one of the most crucial industries in the nation."
Scott Harshbarger, Attorney General of Massachusetts, said the intent of the suit, from his point of view, was to make "an opportunity for Massachusetts companies to compete with Microsoft on a fair and level playing field.
"It could mean new jobs, new innovations and new choices for consumers," he said.
The states collaborating on the lawsuit are California, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Utah, West Virginia and Wisconsin. The District of Columbia, represented by the United States Attorney, also joined the action.

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE CASE;
Where Fine Lines Blur

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
The Government explained its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation today as a principled defense of the time-tested, bedrock values of capitalism, protecting consumer choice and economic competition from the predatory assault of a modern monopolist.
Standing before a battery of television cameras and lights, Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, described the case at times in business-as-usual terms. The principles, he insisted, were clear-cut; the remedies asked of the court were limited, and the theories behind the case were standard antitrust doctrine. 
 The Government's suit is aggressive in that it seeks to apply the Sherman Antitrust Act, enacted before the turn of the century, to millennium technologies. Even so, said Carl Shapiro, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and a former senior Justice Department official, it asks the court to take more of a next step than a giant leap in jurisprudence. "The suit is carefully crafted to push the law a little perhaps," Mr. Shapiro said, "but not so much that a court is being asked to embrace sweeping new theories about how antitrust applies to the software industry."
Though carefully honed, the Microsoft case -- whatever the outcome -- seems certain to be a watershed in setting the ground rules of competition in the digital age as well as the guidelines for Government intervention in a high-technology economy.
The Government sees the Microsoft case as a crucial test of how antitrust enforcement can be applied swiftly and "surgically," in Mr. Klein's words, to protect innovation and competition in the fast-paced business of computer software.
The Microsoft camp replies not only that it is innocent, but that the Government fundamentally misunderstands the facts of economic life in its industry -- and thus is running a grave risk of hobbling a dynamic part of the economy.
Yes, the company says, competitors may suffer from its business practices, such as bundling software for browsing the Internet into its Windows operating system, but those practices also result in improved products that benefit consumers.
The Government, Microsoft insists, is mistakenly bringing an industrial-era mind-set to a fluid, fast-moving field of the future. Microsoft's operating system, the central nervous system of a computer, has changed dramatically, adding dozens of new features over the years to make computers easier to use. All Windows' features, from point-and-click icons to software for sending faxes from a personal computer, were once sold as separate products.
The line between what is in the operating system and what is a separate product, says William H. Gates, Microsoft's founder and chairman, changes every couple of years, and the borderline is elusive because it is all merely a collection of the electronic 1's and 0's of computer code. The software industry, Mr. Gates believes, is different.
"This is a war between two competing philosophies," said Robert Litan, a former senior Justice Department official and the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. "It's very difficult to predict which philosophy is going to win."
The legal battle, analysts predict, will more likely be blitzkrieg than the slow trench warfare of the last big antitrust case the Government brought in the computer industry -- the 13-year suit against I.B.M., which the Justice Department abandoned as technologically irrelevant in 1982.
The Government's suit does not try to block the shipment of Microsoft's next-generation operating system, Windows 98, which the company released to computer manufacturers today and which is to reach store shelves in June.
But to try to level the current competitive field, while it pursues its antitrust suit, the Government filed a request for a preliminary injunction.
In seeking the injunction, the Justice Department is asking a United States district judge to require Microsoft to either remove its Internet Explorer browser from Windows, or include the browser of its main rival, the Netscape Communications Corporation. (The states' suit asks that Microsoft be forced to include a third Web browser of its choice unless Internet Explorer is removed.)
The proposed injunction also seeks new freedom for personal computer makers by giving them the right to install their own main screen that consumers see first when they turn on their computers. Today, Microsoft has control over the main screen -- which is important because it is viewed as a gateway from which people gain access to Internet shopping, news and entertainment.
Tactically, legal experts say, the preliminary-injunction phase of the confrontation may well decide the Microsoft case. A ruling on the Justice Department's request for an injunction will likely be made in six weeks or so. If the Government wins, it is not expected to require a product recall of Windows 98, since the remedies involve allowing PC makers to remove or alter its software.
Whichever side wins, the other side is sure to appeal -- with an appellate verdict likely to come within six months. At that point, experts say, the fast-moving nature of the software industry will surely shape the legal strategy, since six months is almost a product lifetime in software. Any forced product changes would be all but permanent, and if the Government is losing, the hightechnology marketplace may have left its suit in the dust.
"If Justice loses the preliminary injunction, time is on Microsoft's side," Mr. Litan of Brookings said. "If Microsoft loses, the Government has the upper hand."
The Justice Department's case, built around Mr. Klein's theory of a limited if essential role for antitrust intervention, inevitably raises the question of whether it goes far enough. Even if the Government wins its case, skeptics argue, a victory may well be toothless, doing little to loosen Microsoft's tight grip on computing. Indeed, some analysts say that anything short of a trust-busting-style breakup of Microsoft would likely have little effect.
"The political support isn't there in this round, but if the Government is really going to create a competitive environment, it is eventually going to have to split up Microsoft as it did with Standard Oil," said Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer who has worked for Microsoft rivals.
When asked if he might consider more drastic measures in the future, Mr. Klein ruled nothing out. Yet he emphasized that the goal of the Government's actions was not to insure the success of Microsoft's competitors. The Government, Mr. Klein said, is merely trying to open the door to some innovative company that might become the next Microsoft, rather than hobble the incumbent.
"Nothing we are doing here will or should prevent Microsoft from innovating or competing on the merits," Mr. Klein said. "What cannot be tolerated -- and what antitrust laws forbid -- is the barrage of illegal, anticompetitive practices that Microsoft uses to destroy its rivals and to avoid competition."

HEADLINE: U.S. V. MICROSOFT;
Excerpts From the Lawsuit Filed by 20 State Attorneys General

 BODY:
The following are excerpts from the complaint filed yesterday against Microsoft by 20 state Atorneys General in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. 
 The Internet browser is a separate product which competes in a separate product market from the PC operating system. Microsoft itself has consistently offered, promoted, and distributed its Internet browser as a stand-alone product separate from Windows, and intends to continue to do so after the release of Windows 98.
No other product duplicates or fully substitutes for the functionality of an Internet browser.
Internet browsers that work with one operating system will not work with another operating system without significant modification. The geographic market for Internet browsers is worldwide.
The Internet browser has the potential to enable "platform independent" applications. Internet browsers can be, and have been, developed to run on the major desktop operating systems. If an application is written to run on the browser, it can be platform-independent in the sense that it does not depend on compatibility with an underlying operating system. Rather, it depends on compatibility with the Internet browser and associated technologies.
By offering the possibility of a "middleware" layer which would, in essence, permit applications to run on any operating system, the Internet browser threatens Microsoft's Windows monopoly. If an application's ability to run no longer depends on the use of a particular operating system, consumers will no longer be required to purchase the dominant operating system in order to ensure access to a wide portfolio of desired applications. Accordingly, customers would no longer see any particular operating system as having intrinsic value simply by virtue of its ubiquity. This would, in turn, facilitate entry of other operating systems into the competitive market. Thus, while not itself an operating system, the Internet browser poses a significant potential challenge to Windows. In its current form, the Internet browser does not threaten to eliminate the Microsoft operating system, but to "commoditize" it. . . .
Through the actions described above, Microsoft has illegally attempted to prevent competition to its software products, with the following anticompetitive effects:
Actual competition between Microsoft and actual and potential competitors in the markets for Internet browser and related software, office productivity suites, and first screen and boot up access has been or is threatened to be curtailed and foreclosed;
OEM's (Original Equipment Manufacturers) have been denied, or are threatened with denial of, the benefits of a free, open and competitive market in the sale of licensing rights for Internet browsers and related software, office productivity suites, and first screen and boot up access;
Consumer purchasers of personal computers pre-loaded with software have been denied, or are threatened with denial of, the benefits of a free, open and competitive market for Internet browsers and related software, office productivity suites, and first screen and boot up access;
Barriers to entry into the markets for operating systems and office productivity suites have been raised and reinforced, tending to forestall the development of actual competition in those markets; and The states general welfare and economies have been injured through prevention of free and open competition in each of the States' economies. Plaintiff states and their citizens will be subject to a continuing, substantial and immediate threat of irreparable injury to the general welfare and economy and to competition in their states unless Defendant is enjoined from its illegal conduct.. . . .
Microsoft has monopoly power in the market for PC operating system software.
Through the actions complained of in this petition, Microsoft has willfully and illegally used its monopoly power to maintain and extend its monopoly in this market in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act. 15 U.S.C. 2. . . .
Microsoft has attempted to monopolize the market for Internet browsers through the acts and practices described above in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act, 15 U.S.C. 2. Microsoft has specific intent to achieve monopoly power in this market, and in furtherance of this intent has engaged in the exclusionary conduct described above.
There is a dangerous probability that Microsoft can and will achieve a monopoly in the market for Internet browser software through the actions complained of by the plaintiff states.

HEADLINE: Whitman Announces Plan To Improve Transportation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 18

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman outlined a $30 billion transportation plan today, a mix of new and existing initiatives with a focus on expanding mass transit and repairing bridges and highways.
In a speech in Atlantic City before the Northeast Association of State Transportation Officials, Mrs. Whitman said she envisioned a transportation system that fostered both a strong economy and a "superior quality of life" without consuming major amounts of the state's dwindling open space. The plan, with a theme of Fix It First, includes replacing nearly 2,000 aging buses and trains, upgrading bridges and highways, and easing congestion and dangerous roadways. 
 Aides said she would outline the financing for the plan on Thursday. Federal and state money already exists for some of the mass transit projects that are now in either planning or construction stages but were listed in her plan.
How much new spending will be required was unclear today. The Governor's top aides and legislative leaders are discussing increases to the state's gasoline tax, now one of the lowest in the nation at 10.5 cents a gallon. Officials said privately that the proposed increase could range from 3 to 7 cents. Each penny increase would produce about $41 million a year.
The plan now is to submit any proposed increase to New Jersey voters in a referendum in November. If they accept a higher tax, some of the proceeds would go to a dedicated fund for the purchase of undeveloped land, and the rest would go into the state's Transportation Trust Fund for mass transit and highway projects. Currently, the state and Federal governments each contribute $900 million a year to the fund. About 70 percent of gasoline tax revenues provide some of the state's contribution to the fund.
The Governor said that, given the limited amount of undeveloped land in New Jersey, the state would build what is necessary and no more. "We cannot build our way out of congestion," she said. "It's been tried, and it doesn't work."
Her administration, she said, would insure that any new transportation projects correspond with objectives in the state's master plan to limit growth in rural areas. By the year 2010, she said, she envisioned a state where air was cleaner and people were healthier, where cities served as "hubs of business and meccas for performing arts" and "people have more leisure time to spend in fields of green."
One major element of Mrs. Whitman's pledge to improve the state's quality of life is the purchase of one million acres of undeveloped land in the next decade. The other element is transportation improvements.
Her biggest single proposed expenditure -- $18 billion -- is earmarked for her Fix It First campaign.
This part of the plan calls for replacing 1,400 of the 3,000 buses in New Jersey Transit's fleet in the next five years and replacing 424 rail cars and 17 locomotives, or about 63 percent of the rolling stock, on its mass transit lines within 10 years. It also calls for an overhaul of what it defines as deficient bridges -- currently about 413 of the state's 6,300 bridges.Some 290 of the 413 are on Federal interstates or state highways, and 123 more are on roads maintained by municipalities. The plan calls for making repairs, by the year 2010, to all deficient bridges on the interstates, half of those on state highways and 25 percent of those on local roadways.
Officials at the State Department of Transportation said none of the 413 bridges are unsafe. But they said some of the bridges are old and are now too narrow for the increased traffic of recent years, and need widening. Others need repaving or minor repairs to superstructures. The plan also calls for upgrading 20 of the most rundown stations on New Jersey Transit's rail system.
Environmental groups long critical of New Jersey's transportation planning praised the Whitman plan. Janine Bauer, head of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, said the organization has been calling for a fix-it campaign for three years. "We applaud the Governor's policy statements," she said.
The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group urged that laws providing new financing for the Whitman plan must mandate that the money is spent on her proposals. "Unless you put controls on the transportation bureaucracy and the road lobby, a speech is just a speech," said Curtis Fisher, head of the organization.
Another part of the plan calls for $3 billion to improve the state's 25 most congested roadways in 5 years and 15 more within 10 years, and $4 billion more to complete work by 2002 on three light-rail lines. They include the first 10-mile stretch of a trolley line linking 34th Street in Bayonne with the train terminal in Hoboken, a 33-mile trolley line linking Trenton and Camden, and a one-mile addition to Newark's subway system to provide a rail link between the Broad Street train station in Newark and the city's main terminal, Pennsylvania Station. Officials said that $1.2 billion in Federal money has already been allotted for these lines.
A $1 billion category dealing with safety improvements calls for a 25 percent reduction in deaths in car crashes and a 50 percent cut in pedestrian fatalities by 2010. The plan says those deaths can be reduced through improved safety technology, better highway design, and a public awareness campaign for safer driving.

LENGTH: 151 words

HEADLINE: High Cost of Bailing Out Bankers;
Colonialist G-8

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your May 16 editorial "An Exclusive Economic Summit" was on target. The makeup of the G-8 -- the United States, Britain, Canada, Italy, Japan, France, Germany and Russia -- reflects neo-colonialism. It can meet annually for pontification, but the post-colonial nations of the so-called third world will not take it seriously. That the world's largest democracy, India, is not in this club makes the G-8 irrelevant to South Asia. That the world's largest nation, China, is excluded makes the G-8 irrelevant to most of the world. Surely Brazil, Latin America's largest nation, has more right to be in G-8 than Italy or Canada. 
 It's time to dismantle the prejudices of the colonial era and reconstitute G-8 to reflect the new millennium.
 
SHELTON GUNARATNE
Moorhead, Minn., May 16, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of mass communications at Moorhead State University.

HEADLINE: Iran Smiles After U.S. Waives Sanctions Against 3 Companies

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, May 19

 BODY:
Iran today trumpeted a Clinton Administration decision to waive sanctions against three foreign companies that are doing business here as a moral victory for the European Union and one that should signal an end to American attempts to deter similar investments.
"The United States finally bowed down to pressure from the European Union," the official Iranian news agency declared in a statement that was reflected across the front pages of Iranian newspapers. 
 A Government communique called on the United States to repeal altogether the legislation that requires sanctions on companies that deal with Iran. The Administration waived that requirement in the case of French, Russian and Malaysian companies involved in a $2 billion energy deal.
Iranian officials otherwise withheld formal comment about the decision. But in private conversations, economists and executives have expressed hope that it might signal the abandonment of American attempts to enlist allies in the economic isolation of the Teheran Government.
Iran, and its energy sector in particular, have made clear their hunger for an influx of foreign investment. But for two years most European and other foreign companies have moved gingerly in negotiations with Iran, as they have watched to see how vigorously the United States would enforce legislation adopted by the Republican-led Congress. The laws require the President to penalize companies that invest more than $20 million a year in the oil and gas operations of Iran or Libya. The United States has singled out those countries, accusing them of a role in sponsoring terrorism and in opposing the Middle East peace effort.
In justifying the shift, American officials said they hoped to win greater cooperation from Europe and Russia in preventing Iran from sponsoring terrorism and acquiring weapons of mass destruction.
The waiver was granted to Total of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia, which joined last year in signing a $2 billion deal to develop the enormous South Pars gas field in the Persian Gulf.
Iranian officials have suggested that a more immediate result could be a flood of further investments from European companies that had been waiting to measure the United States reaction to the deal.
In Iran the decision could further boost the standing of President Mohammed Khatami, who, since winning election a year ago, has sought repeatedly to emphasize the importance of opening Iran to greater foreign investment. Mr. Khatami, a relative moderate, has been criticized by his conservative opponents for remarks perceived as too gentle toward the West, including the United States.
But Mr. Khatami may now be able to portray the removal of the barrier to the big energy investment as the first significant fruit of his policies of increased openness.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An American at Pearson Shakes Up Status Quo

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 19

 BODY:
Pearson P.L.C. has been known as a somewhat dowdy, meandering, blue-blooded media group -- a conglomerate run more like an investment firm than an aggressive outfit. Its empire has been stitched together with interests as varied as the prestigious Financial Times, Madame Tussaud's famed Wax Museum, 60 percent of The Economist magazine, Pearson Television programming and Penguin, the consumer book publishing outfit, and a share in the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company.
"There were a lot of number fours and number fives but no number ones and twos," said Tim Rothwell, a media analyst here with Greig Middleton & Company. "It was a collection of trophies and prize assets that needed to be reinvented to raise shareholder value." 
 The announcement Sunday that Pearson would purchase most of Simon & Schuster's operations was a sign that the company was being prepared for a much tighter focus with an eye to the United States, a strategy shaped by an executive familiar with the American market -- Marjorie M. Scardino, whose eclectic career has given her such varied roles as small city lawyer to Pulitzer Prize winner to entrant to the upper tiers of the executive ranks in London, where few women have been.
Once approved by regulatory authorities, the purchase of Simon & Schuster's educational division will create a global publishing entity that ranks first in the United States. In describing the new venture Monday morning in a meeting with media analysts, the 50-year-old Mrs. Scardino said it would be "the world's leading education business."
Named chief executive 17 months ago, Mrs. Scardino set a goal, one close associate said, to realize double-digit annual growth for Pearson by refocusing the conglomerate's far-flung businesses into a sharper media orientation. She has, and as a result the company stock, which in August 1997 stood at 6.66 ($10.78), has since zoomed to 10.36 ($16.73), reached today.
Mrs. Scardino set out to get rid of some of the assets that could not achieve much more while consolidating others into strong businesses that lead in their field. The strategy, as outlined Monday by Mrs. Scardino, is to focus on specific areas of growth including trade publishing, educational publishing, and financial information, whether in print, such as The Financial Times, or in electronic forms. That included a $170 million investment to expand the United States circulation of The Financial Times to 100,000 from 30,000 -- an effort that is well under way. The Financial Times circulation in the United States has now risen to 55,000.
"For Pearson, the U.S. is a huge market and its appetite for business information is unrivaled anywhere," she said Monday in an interview. "We are appealing to people truly interested in international business."
There have been doubts. Pearson's bonds fell Monday, their price jumping 0.05 basis point amid concerns that the company had not set aside enough money to meet interest payments. Asked about this, Mrs. Scardino said she saw no problems. "We already have the borrowing set up at 7 percent interest and we have a strong balance sheet." She added that Pearson also had the option of selling some of its units that "will be better in some other's hands" to raise money.
Analysts have speculated that Mrs. Scardino, who has said she will only keep assets that are directly managed by Pearson, may move to sell its stake in "passive" investments over which the company has no management control such as its stake in The Economist or properties like Madame Tussaud's entertainment outfit, which in the words of a close associate "lacks scale, with little chance of really getting big."
Since she took over, Mrs. Scardino oversaw the sale of 700 million in assets ($ 1.1 billion). A former lawyer and newspaper publisher, Mrs. Scardino has compiled a impressive record of success, the most important of which was building up the circulation of The Economist in the United States during the nine years she served as chief executive of the Economist group. Before that, she published a small newspaper in Savannah, Ga., with her husband that won a Pulitzer Prize. She was also a partner in a law firm there.
Analysts say perhaps her best asset is her American identity and experience, having arrived in England without the burden of emotional baggage that has saddled previous managers of the conglomerate she now runs. She served notice that there would be no sacred cows and that nonperforming assets would go.
She has also installed two other Americans on the management team of six that runs Pearson. They are Michael Lynton, who manages Penguin, and Peter Jovanovich, the chief executive of Addison Wesley Longman, who was named Sunday to head the merger of Addison and Simon & Schuster's education division.
Mrs. Scardino and her team immediately set some high goals for the new merger: annual cost savings of $130 million by the year 2000 through "back office synergies" involving production, distribution, central management, property and administration. It was not clear what kind of layoffs might be in store, although some analysts expected that some similar imprints would be folded together or eliminated.
Her stronger reputation these days comes after a somewhat difficult start. The sensationalist -- as well as the serious -- British press described her, among other things, as "an unknown entity" and "not-a-big-hitter." It was enough to bring the company's shares down 2.4 percent in October 1996, when her appointment was made public.
For her part, the serene, somewhat shy executive suggested that her profile would remain indeed so low "as to be nonexistent." Monday, she described her approach as one that was military-like in its thrust: "Have a good plan, execute it decisively and do it today."
Since she burst onto the London corporate scene she has steadfastly refused to talk about her gender, personal life or family and has rarely granted interviews that departed from discussing business. Her husband, Albert, who is a freelance journalist and a former New York Times reporter, and her three children have remained completely out of the limelight.
Associates said Mrs. Scardino had initiated an engaging internal communications system, sending a "Dear Everyone" letter to Pearson's 18,000 employees. Monday morning, for instance, she sent an explanation of the Simon & Schuster deal.
Asked if she was pleased by the better response she had received in the press, she said: "It's not personal. They think we have done good things and produced some results. That's all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marjorie Scardino, an American, has been chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., Britain's largest publisher, for 17 months. (Ashley Ashwood/Financial Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Dip on Fed Inaction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve, as expected, left interest rates unchanged.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 102 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to 5.93 percent, from 5.92 percent on Monday. There was little reaction to the Fed's announcement at 2:15 P.M. 
 Until last month, many bond market participants were confident that the central bank would not move to raise short-term interest rates anytime soon. But that changed, and there is now some anxiety looking ahead to the the next meeting of Fed policy makers, the Federal Open Market Committee, in July.
"With signs of a slowing economy increasing, inflation still calm, the dollar still strong and Asia still in turmoil, the Fed decided to wait until its next powwow to see if an economic slackening actually materializes and thus provides the rationale to continue to adhere to a 5.5 percent Federal funds rate," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management.
However, he said, "in the absence of a significant moderation in business activity, many on the F.O.M.C. will want to be pre-emptive and tighten at the July 1 meeting because of fears that the extremely low rate of unemployment will exacerbate already budding wage pressures and lead directly to increasing inflationary tendencies in the overall economy."
Mr. Fine also said economic statistics over the next six weeks would be crucial to the Fed and would therefore come under intense scrutiny by bond investors.
The Government released its April housing starts report yesterday and reaffirmed what the market already knows, that the housing industry remained strong. Consequently, the housing report had little effect on the market.
Few analysts expect the market to move sharply this week. With a long Memorial Day holiday weekend looming, it is not likely that bondholders will make any large moves or make commitments.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Arms to Plowshares;
Cleaning Up Financially by Cleaning Up Oak Ridge

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
When the Energy Department looks around Oak Ridge, its huge weapons enclave some 20 miles outside Knoxville, Tenn., it sees a truly daunting cleanup problem. There are centrifuges, reactors, pumps, hundreds of acres of buildings and soil, all bearing troublesome radioactive memories of the roles they played in building nuclear bombs.
BNFL Inc. looks at the same stuff and sees $50 million worth of metals it can sell as scrap. The East Tennessee Materials and Energy Corporation sees a place to set up a waste-treatment center without fouling anyone's back yard. Blue Ridge Development sees a place where it can set up shop at a dirt-cheap rent. Bioneutrics Inc. sees a way to treat brain cancer. 
 "It seemed a crime to bury something that could be used for a purpose like this," said George F. Dilworth, president of Bioneutrics, which is building a cancer treatment center around a small nuclear reactor that the Government estimates would cost $8.5 million to dismantle, decontaminate and bury.
Apparently, lots of people agree. The disparate visions of Oak Ridge are melding, as a growing reindustrialization program lets companies clean up financially by cleaning up Oak Ridge.
Although each arrangement is different, in essence companies like Bioneutrics are bartering their services in return for materials or space. Typically, the companies agree to decontaminate a specified portion of Oak Ridge. They return cleaned-up classified equipment to the Energy Department for disposal. But they get to keep the nonclassified materials and equipment on their site, and they get to occupy the space at a deeply discounted rent.
"This program has moved up the decontamination and re-use of these buildings by at least two generations," said Robert Brown, Oak Ridge's operations asset manager.
It is also saving the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in cleanup costs and creating jobs in an area that seemed poised for economic devastation.
Not that everyone is delighted. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union, which represents many Oak Ridge workers, has tried, so far unsuccessfully, to force companies to give its laid-off workers first crack at new jobs. And while environmental officials in Washington say they have not paid close attention to the project, Environmental Protection Agency officials in Atlanta have expressed worries that the Energy Department will divert funds from cleanup to marketing.
Still, advocates seem to far outnumber critics. "It's win-win all around," said Joe W. Anderson, chairman of East Tennessee Materials. The company is cleaning up and re-using some 85,000 square feet of space, at a $2 million saving to the Energy Department, and is employing some 200 displaced Oak Ridge workers to boot. "The community gets jobs, the D.O.E. gets free cleanup, we get to resell whatever material we can salvage, and we get a place to set up shop," Mr. Anderson said.
If Oak Ridge were a private facility, industry would probably run the other way. It is a quintessential "brownfields" property -- land or buildings with a legacy of hazardous contamination. Companies often shy away from such facilities, fearing they will be held liable if the actual culprit in the contamination goes out of business, or otherwise escapes culpability for future harm.
Those are unlikely scenarios at Oak Ridge, a vast complex that was carved out of farmland during World War II, provided enriched uranium for the first atom bomb, and turned out components for nuclear weapons for years afterward. "The isotopes we used are unique to us, and there's no way 20 years from now that we could or would shift responsibility to anyone else," Mr. Brown said.
Oak Ridge probably could not afford to clean up on its own. Its budget, $3.2 billion in 1993, is now $1.9 billion and falling. The work force, 19,300 strong in 1993, is down to 14,500, and heading for no more than 7,500 within a few years. And Oak Ridge faces a domino effect: less money means fewer people means more shuttered facilities means more idle plants in need of cleaning up.
Other Energy Department weapons plants face similar budget cuts. Those that must remain open -- Sandia, in Santa Fe, N.M., which must maintain existing weapons stockpiles, is a notable example -- are bringing in extra money by letting companies use their people and facilities for industrial research. Those with particularly severe contamination -- like Rocky Flats, near Denver -- are cleaning up and shutting down. And a few facilities are experimenting with what Robert W. DeGrasse Jr., an Energy Department director, calls "the perpetual motion approach" -- they clean up some space, lease it out, and use the lease revenue to clean up other space.
But only Oak Ridge seems suited to a huge clean-it-and-keep-it approach. The gaseous diffusion process that it used to enrich uranium yields a lot of residual nickel, which has a high value on the scrap metal market. And uranium presents a less formidable health hazard and decontamination problem than do plutonium, tritium or other elements used in weapons.
"Sometimes, you can decontaminate an entire machine with simple solvent, hand-wipe, and good old elbow grease," said Joel W. Garber, vice president of American Technologies Inc., a $20 million engineering services company that is decontaminating 125,000 square feet and 200 machines at Oak Ridge.
In many ways, Oak Ridge is wiping away its history with similar ease. It recently changed the name of its old K-25 uranium enrichment facility, a 706-acre complex with 118 buildings, to the East Tennessee Technology Park. Its goal is to turn it into a self-sustaining industrial park by 2010.
The first lease was signed in May 1996, and 45 percent of the space is already in the hands of the private sector. One reason for the speed: with Congress's blessing, Oak Ridge circumvented the mountains of red tape that would normally accompany any industry-government deal by handling all transactions through the Community Re-use Organization of East Tennessee, or Croet, a nonprofit private-sector group set up expressly as Oak Ridge's real estate marketing arm.
"It would take the D.O.E. two years to do what we can do in a few months," said Lawrence Young, president of Croet (pronounced CROW-ette).
Start-up companies can get going even more quickly. Blue Ridge Development, a local real estate developer, has taken 54,000 square feet of already clean space, and is subdividing it to use as an incubator for fledgling companies.
Dan Barnett, a Blue Ridge partner, says the leases can be approved in weeks. "Someone who just needs a few hundred square feet doesn't want to wait for all kinds of negotiations and approvals," he said. "Let's face it, the private sector just knows how to move quicker."
In lieu of cleanup responsibilities, Blue Ridge gave Croet a check for $250,000 in advance rent. It will also share some of its rental revenues with Croet after two years.
Oak Ridge is not by any means getting away scot-free on its cleanup bill. In by far the biggest contract signed so far, it has agreed to pay BNFL Inc., a subsidiary of British Nuclear Fuels Ltd., $238 million over six years to clean up three contaminated buildings, comprising five million square feet of floor space.
BNFL, which has dismantled gaseous diffusion plants in England -- and which, in fact, has been decontaminating waste for commercial nuclear plants in the United States for three years -- calculates that there are at least 130,000 tons of copper, nickel and other metals it can salvage. It also figures it can resell a few electrical transformers and other pieces of equipment, particularly in developing countries.
John R. Smith, senior vice president of BNFL, which is based in Fairfax, Va., estimates that the company can get $50 million for the cleaned-up materials, bringing its total take to $288 million. That's about a quarter of what the Energy Department estimates it would cost to do the cleanup itself -- but then, Mr. Smith notes, that estimate builds in the cost of government bureaucracy and inefficiency.
"Their mind-set is making weapons, not decommissioning them," he said. "We have the experience, and at $288 million we can make a modest, sensible profit."
BNFL will hire some 300 former Oak Ridge workers to help with the cleanup and will turn the decontaminated space back to Croet to lease to companies without cleanup skills. That, in turn, will create a rental revenue stream that Croet can use to pay for even more cleanup.
While BNFL is plumbing the lion's share of metallic riches, smaller companies are being dazzled as well. American Technologies originally leased some 45,000 square feet in a relatively uncontaminated maintenance shop at Oak Ridge, with the idea of turning decontaminated metal scrap into containers for low-level radioactive waste. But soon after it moved in, it realized that the huge machine tool shop next door presented more lucrative opportunities.
So it stopped fabricating boxes -- "We realized we couldn't compete in price with cold rolled steel anyway," Mr. Garber recalled -- and agreed to decontaminate the whole area. In return, it will pocket anything it gets for the tools. The Energy Department estimates that the equipment is worth as much as $1.5 million, and Mr. Garber, who has arranged to auction it off in June, says he can get even more.
Already, the new Oak Ridge tenants are learning to use one another to maximize their profits. BNFL and American Technologies are joining forces to look for used-equipment markets in Southeast Asia. And Materials and Chemistry Laboratory Inc., an environmental testing company, is looking for a partner to help it clean up an underused Oak Ridge laboratory that it wants to use. The company wants no part of cleanup responsibilities, so it is looking to barter free laboratory testing services to a company that will do the cleanup.
"We'd pay maybe $2.35 for space that's worth $5 or $6 a square foot, so trading for the cleanup gives us a real bargain," said Barry A. Stephenson, the company's president.
Such side deals are just fine with Oak Ridge and Croet. Indeed, anything that gets Oak Ridge cleaned up more quickly sits well with them. Croet just leased clean space to Dynamic Tooling Systems, a tool-and-die company that will employ 30 local people, but that did not want to clean space itself. And Mr. Young is planning to build a conventional industrial park on 1,000 acres of uncontaminated farmland nearby.
"This area needs jobs," Mr. Young said. "And cleanup and jobs are inextricably linked."

HEADLINE: James C. McIntyre, Arts Executive, 49

 BODY:
James Carroll McIntyre, a fund-raiser for the arts and a former executive at Carnegie Hall and the Big Apple Circus, died on Friday at his home in Saylorsburg, Pa. He was 49 and also had a home in Greenwich Village.
The cause was not known, said Gary Dunning, executive director of the Big Apple Circus and Mr. McIntyre's successor in that position. 
 Mr. McIntyre was executive director from 1989 until 1995, when he resigned after testing positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Since then he had worked as an advocate for people with AIDS and as a consultant for arts organizations.
A native of Sanford, N.C., he graduated from Duke University in 1971. After graduation, he remained in Durham, N.C., and helped found the Durham Arts Center, serving as its executive director at a time when it played a pivotal role in revitalizing the downtown.
In 1971 he was named director of the corporate fund at Carnegie Hall. In that role, he oversaw the $60 million Campaign for Carnegie Hall, which financed the restoration and renovation of the auditorium. He was appointed director of development in 1985 and supervised the opening of the refurbished Carnegie Hall the following year.
He became executive director of the Big Apple Circus in New York, a popular not-for-profit performing arts center, in 1989. At his death he was a member of its board.
He is survived by his companion, Gary Rosard.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Regains Some Ground After Three-Session Decline

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
Stocks closed slightly higher yesterday, rebounding from three days of declines as Federal Reserve policy makers left short-term interest rates unchanged.
Blue-chip stocks faltered late in the session, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 3.74 points, at 9,054.65, retreating from a gain of 62 points. 
 The market opened modestly higher across the board and held onto those gains into the early afternoon as investors took a cautious stance ahead of the Fed's much-awaited announcement. News that the Fed left rates unchanged failed to ignite a rally, and a flurry of sell programs in the last two hours of trading sharply cut the market's big gains as investors locked in profits.
Software makers, drug stocks and financial-related issues posted some of the biggest gains, while semiconductor companies retreated.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite rose 14.25 points, to 1,845.87, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 3.70, to 1,109.52.
Aiding the Dow, Disney advanced 1 1/4, to 110 15/16, and J. P. Morgan climbed 1 1/8, to 129 11/16.
In technology, shares of Dell Computer extended recent gains, ending up 3/32 at 94 19/32, as investors anticipated the release of the personal computer giant's quarterly results after the close. Dell reported first- quarter results of 44 cents a share, which beat analysts' estimates.
High-flying Internet-related issues recovered some of their recent losses with Yahoo up 1 19/32 at 118 5/32 and Excite up 1 3/8 at 61.
Financial-related issues also ended broadly higher. Chase Manhattan rose 2 5/8, to 144 7/8 Citicorp climbed 1 1/2, to 155 1/2, and Republic National Bank edged up 5/8, to 132 5/8.
Oil companies finished higher amid rising crude prices. Mobil gained 7/8, to 81 3/8; Unocal climbed 13/16, to 37 13/16, and Pennzoil edged up 5/8, to 60 15/16.
Drug stocks extended their gains from Monday's rally following news of a breakthrough in the treatment of breast cancer. Warner-Lambert ended up 4 1/4 at 198 1/4, Bristol-Myers Squibb ended up 2 1/16 at 111 3/16, and Pfizer ended up 23/16 at 112 7/8.
Bucking the uptrend, semiconductor companies ended slightly weaker, with Texas Instruments down 7/8 at 58 5/16, Motorola down7/8 at 55 5/8, and Micron Technology down 1/2 at 26 1/2.
Airlines surrendered their gains after rallying earlier this morning. The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, dropped 2 1/16, to 145 7/8; the UAL Corporation, parent company of United Airlines, climbed 3/4, to 80, and US Airways fell 3/16 to 65.

HEADLINE: China Issue Resists Usual White House Defenses

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The White House scandal-control brigade has answered many a call, from Arkansas real estate deals gone sour to the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit, and has always found a way to mount a vigorous counteroffensive.
But the silence emanating from the White House this week says officials believe that reports of a "China connection" are different. Even James Carville, the most combative and vociferous of President Clinton's defenders, has been struck all but dumb. There is, it seems, no ready response to the accusations that a Chinese military officer sent nearly $100,000 to Democratic campaign accounts at the same time Mr. Clinton was overruling his own bureaucracy to relax export controls on the transfer of satellite technology to Beijing. 
 The disclosures of the past week are of a wholly new sort than the other accusations Mr. Clinton has faced in his five and a half years as President. This is not about business deals in the murky Arkansas past or the President's extracurricular activities. In this case, the Justice Department is investigating whether Mr. Clinton's official acts as President altered American foreign policy and affected the nation's security.
This campaign finance inquiry is also distinct from many of the investigations because it bears more directly on Vice President Al Gore's political fortunes than on the President's personal reputation. It was Mr. Gore who appeared at a Buddhist temple in Los Angeles to raise campaign cash in 1996, and Mr. Gore who has positioned himself as the high-tech candidate for the 21st century. Mr. Clinton has no more campaigns to run; Mr. Gore has at least one.
Mr. Gore faces added scrutiny, as well, because he has for many years spoken of the dangers of proliferation of weapon and missile technology. One White House official said that he expected Republicans to try to exploit the inquiry into transfer of satellite technology to China to tarnish Mr. Gore's image.
Having survived the dismissals of the White House travel office staff, the case of the purloined F.B.I. files, the sprawling Whitewater inquiry, the Jones suit and all its tawdry offspring, White House officials profess confidence that the President can weather the latest squall.
But there is a difference in the tone of the responses to the revelations of the Administration's dealings with China. Absent are the personal attacks on the President's accusers and the cries that the accusations are the product of mere partisan politics.
Instead, officials couch their denials in the narrowest possible terms or offer justifications of actions that are not in question. The official White House response to reports that a Chinese-American businessman, Johnny Chung, transferred almost $100,000 from an officer of China's army to the Democratic National Committee is that no one knew the true source of the money and that the money was returned when it was learned it came from overseas.
Officials also insist that the Chinese campaign cash has not bought a change in national policy on satellite exports. The policy switch -- made over the objection of then-Secretary of State Warren Christopher -- was to improve American "competitiveness" and to "streamline" bureaucracy, officials said.
During last year's campaign-finance hearings, White House spokesmen insisted that the Administration had not traded policy benefits for big donations. Now, with evidence of a major policy shift toward China, the Administration is saying that the President did not make the change because of campaign contributions.
Republicans in Congress are preparing to hold hearings on the matter in June, just before Mr. Clinton is to travel to Beijing for the first United States-China meeting on Chinese territory since the deadly crackdown on democratic protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989. Some Republicans are already calling on Mr. Clinton to delay or cancel the trip, which the White House has resisted.
But if the hearings produce new evidence of Chinese efforts to tamper with the 1996 election or to sway American policy on technology transfers, it could undermine the President's visit, which is supposed to focus on trade and democratic liberalization in China.
A certain sign that this matter is being handled differently is the absence of the bark of Mr. Carville. With no Republicans or alleged anti-Clinton conspirators to attack, Mr. Carville, in an interview, fell back on a generic defense of the President. "In no way, shape or form do I think the President or anyone else swapped out policy for money," he said.
White House lawyers and public relations officials have discussed the new evidence of Chinese contributions at morning meetings since late last week but have not devised a strategy for responding to it.
In the ordinary course of events, the White House or its surrogates would deny the accusations, attack the integrity or credibility of the accusers and try to change the subject. The approach has served Mr. Clinton well over the years.
But there has been no counter-attack this time, in part because the disclosures come from within the Administration, which has held a largely secret internal battle for years over how much to help the Chinese Government in improving its satellite-launching ability.
Mr. Clinton overruled both the Justice and State Departments, not to reward campaign contributors from China or major American aerospace companies, he insists, but to assure the economical launching of American communications satellites and to foster economic growth and political openness in China.
In brief remarks to reporters on Sunday, Mr. Clinton answered with a curt "no" when asked if he or anyone in his Administration had made decisions because of the influence of Chinese money.
Prodded further, he said: "First of all, all the foreign policy decisions we made were made based on what we believed -- I and the rest of my Administration -- were in the interests of the American people. Now if someone tried to influence them, that's a different issue and there ought to be an investigation into whether that happened. And I would support that."
