HEADLINE: Royal Ahold Set to Acquire Giant Food

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Royal Ahold N.V. extended its reach into the American supermarket business yesterday with a $2.6 billion deal to acquire the Giant Food Inc. supermarket chain.
The acquisition would strengthen Ahold's position as the biggest foreign owner of an American grocery store business and make it the fourth-largest supermarket operator in this country. It also reflects the rapid consolidation in the industry, where companies are trying to create dominant regional chains. By broadening their geographic scope, Ahold and other companies hope to benefit from greater purchasing clout, more efficient distribution and economies of scale in areas such as marketing. 
 The deal announced yesterday added a 177-store chain with revenues of $4.2 billion to Ahold's growing domestic franchise and ranks it just behind No. 3, American Stores. Ahold, based in the Netherlands, operates 830 domestic supermarkets, including Stop and Shop of Quincy, Mass. The United States stores contribute $14.3 billion to Ahold's $26 billion in annual revenues.
"This represents a significant opportunity for Ahold to basically take a well-positioned U.S. food chain and bring it to a new level," said Edward Comeau, an analyst who follows supermarket companies for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
With the purchase of Giant, which is based in Landover, Md., Ahold added 164 stores in Virginia, the District of Columbia and Maryland as well as 13 Super G stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The 28,000-employee chain, founded in 1936 as a single store, will retain its name, headquarters and management team.
"Geographically, it is the perfect, natural fit to our existing operations along the Eastern Seaboard," said Robert Zwartendijk, Ahold's chief executive officer and president of United States operations. "Strategically, Giant adds critical mass and highly developed food retailing expertise."
Ahold will pay $43.50 a share for Giant, or about $2.6 billion, a 15 percent premium over its closing price Monday, the day before the acquisition was announced. The shares rose $5 yesterday to close at $42.68. Ahold's shares, traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2, to $34.1875.
Sainsbury, Britain's second-largest food retailer, is considered the loser in the transaction for having sold its stake in a chain it had also been eyeing for a takeover. Sainsbury, which operates the Shaw's chain, is also attempting to push further into the American grocery business through acquisitions.
Sainsbury officials minimized the significance of Ahold's deal, saying that "control of Giant was a desirable but not essential element of our U.S. growth strategy."
The loss for Sainsbury, however, reflected the rapid pace at which supermarket competitors were moving to fortify potential strongholds in regions where they are under-represented. In fact, analysts said yesterday that they expected both companies to keep looking for targets, with Ahold likely to concentrate in the West since it now has a solid base in the East.
"Companies find that the easiest way to grow is to consolidate," said George Thompson, an analyst who follows supermarket companies for Prudential Securities. "They don't run into the problem of adding square footage in a market, which makes the business all the more aggressive."
In addition, after having significantly cut costs in recent years, grocery chains are now having difficulty improving their results through belt-tightening. With a leaner cost structure, more are in a position to buy competitors they could not afford a few years ago.
The growth strategy is attractive for Ahold and Sainsbury in particular because there is little room to grow through acquisitions in their own countries, where the markets are already controlled by national chains.
"It is certainly not a national business in the U.S. at this point and time," Mr. Thompson said. He added that except for Kroger, Safeway Inc. and few others, "the list in terms of size greatly diminishes."
That is rapidly changing, though, led by the market leaders' race to increase their store count and revenues by snapping up each other's businesses. Other such deals include the merger last year of Fred Meyer Inc. and Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. and the acquisition a year earlier of Vons Companies by Safeway.
The latest deal is likely to be followed by other mergers this year, analysts said, with Ahold continuing to look for its next target. The company operates 3,200 supermarkets and specialty stores in 17 countries and employs 220,000 workers.

HEADLINE: Decline in Gun Violence Bypasses Philadelphia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
For all the years he spent as a criminal and a drug user, Jose Rojas never saw the kinds of things now taking place in working-class neighborhoods like his in north Philadelphia.
"And it's going from bad to worse," Mr. Rojas, 47, said recently, sitting in the New Creation Church in Kensington, a high-crime neighborhood where he works as a lay evangelist. "During the time I was out there as a teen-ager, then in my 20's, it was relatively difficult to get weapons. Now? Kids 11, 12, 13 years old -- they're packing .45-caliber semi-automatics, Uzis, magnums, you name it." 
 And they are not afraid to use them.
While the rates of homicide and violent crime are declining in many of the country's largest cities, they are holding firm in Philadelphia. Although a slight dip over the first four months of this year has given officials some hope, the number of homicides has hovered steadily at around 400 a year for nearly a decade. A majority of the deaths were caused by high-powered handguns, and a majority of the weapons were wielded by people under 23.
The problem has become so intolerable that Mayor Edward Rendell has appointed a deputy mayor -- dubbed the gun czar -- to coordinate local and Federal efforts to stem the flow of weapons in the city. And in a move modeled after the actions against tobacco companies, he has threatened to sue gun manufacturers to recoup some of the money spent by the city's hospitals to treat gunshot victims.
Officials say they think one of the biggest factors in the high homicide rate is a 1995 gun law that has removed some of the discretion the police department had to deny permits for carrying concealed weapons.
The new law, they say, has contributed to a boom in gun buying here that has given Pennsylvania the distinction of having more licensed carriers of concealed weapons than any other state.
The legal age for buying a gun in Pennsylvania is 18, and most permit holders are legitimate gun owners. But law-enforcement experts here say that the state measure opened the door to a vibrant black market in handgun sales, in which buyers for whom routine background checks pose no problem can act as straw-man buyers and resell the guns on the street for handsome profits.
Furthermore, officials say, the sheer number of guns on the street in Philadelphia means more weapons are finding their way into the hands of young people.
Before the Uniform Firearms Action of 1995 was passed, state lawmakers recognized Philadelphia, Pennsylvania's largest city, as a special case on gun issues because of its persistently high crime rates. The police department had the right to turn down a request for a concealed weapons permit if the applicant could not demonstrate "a reasonable need." In 1994, just 1,500 permits were issued.
Over all, the new law strengthened the application process by requiring deeper background checks. But after the exception for Philadelphia was eliminated, the number of permits issued soared, to about 11,500 in 1996, said Richard A. Zapille, the Deputy Mayor appointed to lead the gun control efforts.
"That was a real blow to our efforts here," Mr. Rendell said of the gun law. "We weren't doing great before, but after the law passed, the number of permits issued to carry a concealed weapon was unbelievable."
Mr. Rendell appointed a handgun violence task force four years ago when it became evident that his city was failing to keep pace with the rest of the nation in reducing violent crime. But efforts to slow the mayhem have not made any appreciable difference in some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, despite the slight dip in the homicide rate for the first four months of this year. Guns continue to flow in, and landscapes of abandoned factories, rotting houses and trash-strewn streets only make the life of a gun-toting drug dealer seem that much more glamorous to impressionable youngsters.
"Young children walking to school see these guys all in gold, wearing rings on their fingers and $150 sneakers," said Mr. Rojas, who spent 13 months in prison on drug charges. "They are influenced just by the way they look. They think, 'I want to be like him.' They have money. They have expensive sneakers and they have guns."
A study conducted by the task force found that of 273 people charged with murder in a 40-month period through March 1997, 171 of them -- more than 62 percent -- were 22 or younger.
That is far above the national average. In 1995, the last full year for which Federal data is available, the Department of Justice found that among the 16,701 people across the country arrested for murder or non-negligent manslaughter, just 6,556 of them -- 39.8 percent -- were 22 years old or younger.
In the same year, Philadelphia's homicide rate of 30.7 per 100,000 residents was nearly twice as high as New York City's 16.1 per 100,000.
Members of the Mayor's task force, as well as community leaders like Mr. Rojas who work with them, agree that much of the reason for the pervasiveness of handguns is the same as in other cities -- drugs.
"The drugs begot guns, and they're both so entrenched now that good people feel the need to carry guns," Mr. Zapille said in a recent drive through Kensington and other low-income neighborhoods.
But Philadelphia has labored under additional burdens: The city was slow to coordinate crime-fighting with community outreach programs. Deep losses in its manufacturing base made Philadelphia's economic recovery less rapid than that of other cities, and poverty is deeply entrenched in many neighborhoods. Tougher gun laws in surrounding states have made purchases here easier by comparison.
Among the six states that border Pennsylvania, four -- New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland -- give local law-enforcement officials the discretion Philadelphia once had to deny permits to carry a concealed weapon to anyone they think does not have a legitimate reason. In West Virginia, the police have no such discretion. Ohio does not permit carrying a concealed weapon.
To quantify the magnitude of the problem in Philadelphia, the police department and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms conducted an intensive study of trafficking in all type of guns last year. The results included these findings:
*In almost half of the legitimate sales, involving 38,338 guns, two or more were bought at the same time. Almost 8 percent of the guns, 3,046, were bought in purchases of 10 or more.
*The police traced 2,865 guns recovered in arrests and found that 69 percent were bought in Pennsylvania, the highest percentage ever recorded, and a 10 percent increase over 1996. They also found that 53 percent were bought in Philadelphia, an 11 percent increase over 1996.
*Firepower on the street is rising among the youngest offenders. Of 342 guns recovered from juveniles at the time of arrest, 65 percent were semi-automatic weapons, a 13 percent increase over the relative number of comparable weapons recovered in 1996. Twenty-six percent were revolvers, a 12 percent decrease.
Defenders of the state law, which was strongly supported by State Senator Vincent J. Fumo, a Democrat from Philadelphia, argue that problems in Philadelphia stem not from the law itself but from lax enforcement of its provisions, some of which are unique among the states that allow residents to carry concealed weapons. In addition to denying a permit to anyone with a felony conviction or mental health problem, the norm for most states, Pennsylvania is now alone in banning the sale of guns to anyone who had a police record as a juvenile and to anyone classified as a "habitual drunken driver."
And starting in July, the law requires any private sale of a gun to be conducted before a licensed dealer or local law-enforcement officer.
"We chose to focus on the potential gun owner," said Christopher Craig, legal counsel to Senator Fumo. "When the law is aggressively enforced, it will have a dramatic impact in the state."
But Mr. Rendell and others scoff at the notion that those involved in illegal street sales will suddenly comply with the state gun law.
"All I know is what we're facing on the street," said Thomas L. Stankiewicz, an agent with the Federal firearms agency in Philadelphia. "We've had some success. But guns are always in demand, and the supply is readily accessible."
Philadelphia police officials said that more aggressive strategies in arresting people for illegal gun possession helped bring down the homicide rate for the first third of the year, to a projected year-end total of 321. And officials in other city agencies say new programs of community outreach and intervention are also disrupting cycles of violence.
But in Mr. Rojas's neighborhood, progress is slow. Children walking to school fear walking the blocks where gun sellers operate, he said, and on many nights, gunfire punctuates the silence.
"Sometimes it sounds like Vietnam around my house," Mr. Rojas said. "The other night I heard two different-caliber guns go off. I didn't know what was going on, but I turned to my wife and said, 'Maybe we'll read about it in the papers tomorrow.' "

HEADLINE: Fed Lets Rates Stand, Fearing Harm to Asia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve declined once again today to increase short-term interest rates, apparently determining that the threat of inflation remained remote and that the latest phase of the worsening Asian economic crisis might be exacerbated by any rate rise now in the United States.
Several weeks ago, there were hints that the Federal Reserve might be leaning toward increasing interest rates sometime soon. But a number of recent indicators, including continued low inflation and the announcement this morning of a modest decline in the starts of new housing, have lessened immediate fears of an overheating of the economy, market analysts said. 
 The decision to leave rates unchanged, at least for now, was hardly a surprise on Wall Street, where many leading economists had predicted that the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, which meets regularly to review interest-rate policy, would again sit on its hands. The markets yawned in response: The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 3.74 points, at 9,054.65, after having risen 62 points earlier in the day.
While no one knows for sure what motivated the Federal Reserve's decision, its policy makers had reason to worry that an increase now would only worsen problems in Asia. In recent weeks, there have been signs of renewed economic trouble in Thailand and South Korea, and the images of Jakarta in flames last week rekindled fear of a contagion effect that would discourage further investment in Asia.
A rate rise in the United States would likely have accelerated such a development, as investors moved to take advantage of higher returns in this country on short-term notes and bills.
"There was every risk that the United States could have exacerbated the Asian turmoil" with a rate increase, said Sung Won Sohn, vice president and chief economist of the Norwest Corporation, a $90 billion financial services manager. "And it is clear that American exports are down and imports are up, which lessens the fear that there will be continued shortages in the labor market."
Following the usual practice at its eight-times-a-year meetings, the Federal Open Market Committee issued a terse statement this afternoon simply announcing what time the session had ended and disclosing no details of its discussions.
Two days from now, it will publish details of its March 31 session, where it decided to adopt what in the jargon of central bankers is called a "tightening bias," a tilt toward higher interest rates to slow the economy.
News of such leanings in monetary policy rarely leak out of the Federal Reserve. But one theory popular today among Fed-watchers was that officials at the central bank might have been frustrated that the markets were not getting the message that rates might have to rise, and were trying to get their message across.
Since then, the crosscurrents of economic data have grown a bit more confusing.
The logic in favor of an increase in the rates the central bank controls -- particularly the overnight Federal funds rate, which determines borrowing costs across the economy -- had focused on fears that a rise in inflation was inevitable and that the United States was headed into a dangerous "asset bubble" as the stock market continued to rise.
Those urging an increase pointed to the remarkably low national unemployment rate, which recently fell to 4.3 percent. At that level, they argued, it was only a matter of time before wages rise and set off inflation throughout the economy. Some were also unsettled by an increase in the money supply.
But on the other side of the argument are a range of indicators suggesting that the economy is slowing by itself, in which case a rate increase could result months from now in turning a gradual slowdown into a severe one.
"When you look at the economic data that points to weakening sectors of the U.S. expansion -- housing, industrial production, trade -- and the dollar's recent strength, you come to the conclusion that a decision by the Fed to leave rates unchanged seemed a foregone conclusion," said John Lipsky, chief economist of Chase Manhattan Bank.
"If the Fed had raised rates today, there would have been widespread uncertainty about exactly what factors they were paying attention to," Mr. Lipsky added. "The implication would have been that if rates were hiked with so little convincing evidence that such a move was necessary, investors would have wondered if more could be on the way."
"More than Asian markets would have been unsettled," he said.
And there are hints of economic softness in the United States. Today, the Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 2.3 percent last month, to an annual rate of 1.538 million units. Many analysts had expected a small gain. Housing starts also fell in March.
As recently as last fall, there was talk of a need for the Fed to lower interest rates because of fears that the effects of the Asian crisis -- chiefly, deflation and a surge of low-cost exports to the American market -- could harm manufacturers here. Those fears proved overblown.
By early this year, the Fed was welcoming the effects of the Asian crisis. The low-cost imports, it turned out, helped to contain inflation and relieve pressure on American companies that were having a difficult time finding skilled workers.
Now the Asian calculus is beginning to change again. The Fed is evidently worried about fueling the flight of capital out of Asia by raising rates. If more money shifted across the Pacific, it could worsen the state of nearly insolvent banks in Asian countries.
At the same time, it is becoming apparent that Asian economies, which showed some signs of revival a few months ago, may now be enduring a second wave of trouble. China's economic growth is slowing, and Japan is caught in a deflationary spiral, with consumers refusing to spend. The effect on American exports is becoming more acute, and inventories in this country are rising. The yen has resumed falling against the dollar, making American goods more expensive and thus less competitive in Japan.
Weighing against those concerns is the fear that the Federal Reserve may be allowing the United States to develop an asset bubble similar to the one that burst in Japan at the beginning of the 90's. The best way to prick that bubble, some economists argue, is to raise rates now -- before it is too late. But so far at least, the Fed appears to consider that danger relatively remote.

HEADLINE: Shooting Spotlights Troubled Side of a Brooklyn Mall

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In yesterday's summertime sun, the Fulton Mall buzzed to the tune of money: as the third busiest shopping district in the city, it trails only Herald Square and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Each day, more than 120,000 people visit the strip, spending more than $1 million at the 200 stores between Adams Street and Flatbush Avenue.
"This is where the money flows," said a teen-ager from Bedford-Stuyvesant who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 But on Monday night, the mall's more troubled side became apparent, when eight people were shot on the pedestrian plaza. The shooting illustrated a side of the mall that obscures its financial success: in many ways, it is a tawdry, tattered commercial strip where a hint of menace can hang in the air, and it has failed to keep up with the resurgence of downtown Brooklyn all around it.
Recently, such large stores as Woolworth's and Nobody Beats the Wiz have closed, and the strip's movie theater has been shuttered for two years. Long gone are the days when such department stores as Martin's, Namm's, May's and Korvette's made the shopping strip a rival of Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
"It's the one feature of downtown Brooklyn that hasn't kept up with the times," Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, said of the mall. "They're totally out of step with all the positive developments."
Since 1990, the areas around the mall have been brimming with new economic activity. The Metrotech office complex has added 16,000 jobs and 10 new buildings; the four downtown colleges have had substantial enrollment increases, and a dozen blocks to the south, Atlantic Center, a large retail complex, has opened, with other complexes being built nearby. This July, the first hotel in more than 60 years in downtown Brooklyn is scheduled to open blocks away from the mall.
Businessmen and their representatives suggest that simple economics keeps the mall, originally created as an urban redevelopment project by the Lindsay administration, from changing for the better. Thomas Onorato, general manager of the Gallery at Metrotech, just off the mall, said the national chains usually want to pay rent of $20 to $30 a square foot, compared with the $90 to $120 a square foot that property owners on the Fulton Mall are able to get from independent jewelry and electronics stores that are less concerned with the mall's overall image.
At large suburban malls, one developer usually owns the entire project. This means he can offer a department store cheap rent, and get much higher rent from smaller tenants. But with the Fulton Mall split among many landlords, a single owner has less incentive to sacrifice higher rents for a better image.
The Fulton Mall Improvement Association says it is working to change this. Lou Carbonetti, executive director since August, said he has bluntly told owners that the appearance of their buildings' facades are "disgusting," and some have made improvements as a result. He has also gently urged some landlords to seek tonier tenants. "That's where you're walking a very fine line," he said.
Though Monday night's shooting may raise concerns about safety at the mall, Mr. Carbonetti cited police statistics showing a 65 percent drop in crime over the last three years. He also cited other reasons for hope: The mall's cleanliness rating, as measured by the Sanitation Department, was 100 percent in the most recent three-month marking period, putting it in the top 4 among the city's 42 business improvement districts.
But others noted that the mall still has its problems. One shopper, a Kingsborough Community College accounting student, said the mall's patrons include gang members. "There's a lot of gangs, mainly Bloods," he said, adding that the gang members tend to cluster. "You'll see like 10 on one block, 10 more on another block."
But the student, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he rarely saw violence, and that he relished the energy of the mall. "This is the heart of Brooklyn, so a lot of people from Brooklyn come here," he said. "If it was in Manhattan, it would be a tourist-type thing."
To improve its image, the business improvement district has taken a number of steps: it has hired its first horticulturist; it has bought heavy new garbage baskets; it is painting all street fixtures with graffiti-resistant paint, and it is planning weekly summer jazz concerts.
Another sign of improvement is the appearance of more Metrotech employees at lunch time. For the first few years, many refused to venture into the teeming bazaar. "I've seen much more traffic back and forth," said Michael Weiss, executive director of the business district representing neighboring Metrotech.
Mr. Carbonetti says he is trying to balance the mall's competing interests in working to improve its image.
"I don't want this to look like Madison Avenue," he declared. "I want it to look like downtown Brooklyn, the way it should be."

HEADLINE: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE CASE;
Microsoft Fight Will Be Waged On Wide Front

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation is shaping up as a high-decibel, often nasty battle to sway public opinion as well as the courts.
The Justice Department and the 20 states suing the company will use an array of tools: talk-show appearances, documents that cast Microsoft as an arrogant monopolist, testimonials from distinguished academics, and scarcely veiled threats of even further charges. 
 "We're in for a full-fledged firefight now," said Richard Blumenthal, the Attorney General of Connecticut.
No company can fight the Government with more resources or deeper pockets than Microsoft, yet it now finds itself facing an unusually cohesive alliance of Federal and state governments.
The debate over whether to try to block the shipment of the latest version of Microsoft's operating system, Windows 98, tested the ability of the Government and the states to cooperate -- and it also illustrated the mixture of economic, legal and public relations considerations in the landmark antitrust case.
Within the last week, the states finally reached a consensus and agreed with the Justice Department that trying to block the imminent release of a product that represented two years of development could well backfire in their campaign against Microsoft.
An attempt to block the shipment of Windows 98, which was released yesterday to computer manufacturers and should reach store shelves on June 25, would have certainly hurt Microsoft.
But the Justice Department determined -- and the states eventually agreed -- that trying to block Windows 98 would prove to be a misstep for both legal and public relations reasons.
After all, the case against Microsoft is being made in the name of consumer choice. How then to justify blocking a new product that undoubtedly millions of consumers will want to buy?
Legally, a request for a temporary restraining order to block the shipment of Windows 98 would have required a Federal judge to say that the uncertain harm to competition in the future from allowing Windows 98 to reach the marketplace outweighed the certain harm from stopping a ready-to-go product.
"Trying to block Windows 98 would have been the 'Hail Mary' approach to this case, a huge risk," said Robert Litan, a former senior Justice Department official who is an economist at the Brookings Institution, a research organization.
So the Government and the states agreed on a different strategy. In their suits filed here on Monday, they argue that the case against Microsoft is really about the nation's economic future.
The suits assert that Microsoft is using the monopoly power enjoyed by its Windows operating system to fend off competition unfairly and to extend its monopolistic reach into the new markets of Internet commerce and software.
Yet even if Microsoft is guilty of such misconduct, the present economic harm would seem to be slight, beyond the damage done to the company's rivals.
The Government and states, however, contend that unless steps are taken now to level the playing field, consumers will suffer in the future because Microsoft will gain a chokehold on the Internet economy as people increasingly do everything from buying cars and airplane tickets to watching movies and reading news on the Internet, whether through computers, digital television or some hybrid device.
Microsoft responds that the Government's attempt to tamper with the future will prove misguided and counterproductive.
William H. Gates, the company's chairman, on Monday called the action by the Justice Department and the states "a step backward for America, consumers and for the personal computer industry that is leading our nation's economy into the 21st century."
As part of its supporting cast, the Government today presented a respected economist, Franklin M. Fisher, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Mr. Fisher was on the other side of the last big antitrust case in the computer industry, the Justice Department's 13-year siege of I.B.M., a case dropped in 1982. In that case, Mr. Fisher was I.B.M.'s chief economic witness.
In a 23-page declaration filed today at the Federal District Court in Washington, Mr. Fisher said that he had studied the evidence in the case and had determined that Microsoft had engaged in competition-crimping behavior.
Looking to the future, he concluded that there was a "substantial probability that these anticompetitive actions will permit Microsoft to retain its power over price in operating systems and will inhibit development of Microsoft-independent innovations."
Mr. Fisher concluded, "Both would harm consumer welfare."
Trying to embarrass Microsoft in court filings is another weapon in the Government's arsenal. But again, these seemingly incriminating memos, E-mail and other documents from Microsoft executives are perhaps wielded as much for their public relations impact as for their legal value as evidence. They are intended, partly, to tarnish Microsoft's image, making companies and consumers think twice before giving the big software maker their dollars or their trust.
To be sure, the Government and states were selective in choosing which statements, depositions and memos to include in their suits and as accompanying documents. William H. Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for legal affairs, characterized the approach as "trial by excerpt." In context, and once the case goes to court, Microsoft says that what seem on the surface to be incriminating evidence will be shown to be otherwise.
Still, the court papers filed yesterday do make serious charges. For example, the Government has contended that in June 1995, Microsoft executives met with executives of the Netscape Communications Corporation, then a start-up with a program for browsing the Internet's World Wide Web.
One charge in the Government's case is that at that meeting Microsoft tried to strike a collusive deal with Netscape -- an offer that Netscape declined. The goal, the Government said, was to avoid competition in the Internet browser market.
A deposition from Marc Andreessen, Netscape's co-founder, described the June 1995 meeting and discussions about where to draw the "line" for splitting the market. "They were attempting to establish with us whether we were interested in a relationship whereby we would mutually agree to essentially not compete with each other across that line," Mr. Andreessen stated. "They would stay below that line. We would stay above the line."
The court filing also describes a deposition from Chris Jones, a Microsoft executive who attended the June 1995 meeting. The court paper states that Mr. Jones "admitted that Microsoft 'absolutely' intended to persuade Netscape not to compete."
Other court papers show both the powerful advantage enjoyed by an on-line service if given prime placement on the Windows main screen and the lengths to which Microsoft would go in pushing for more and more of the browser market.
The papers focus on strategy talks within Microsoft about whether to do a deal with America Online, the largest on-line service, in which America Online would get to place its icon on the Windows main screen, or desktop, even though Microsoft had a competing on-line service, MSN. In return, America Online would distribute Microsoft's browser exclusively to its millions of subscribers.
A deposition from a Microsoft executive stated, "Bill Gates initially strongly opposed giving America Online access to the Windows desktop, stating that doing so would be tantamount to 'putting a bullet through MSN's head.' "
Even so, Mr. Gates later changed his mind and made the deal with America Online for one simple reason -- to increase Microsoft's share of the browser market.

HEADLINE: Really Big Money Shouts in a California Contest

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 19

 BODY:
Shirley Nelson is wise to the ways of fund-raising in Northern California's Democratic politics, having rounded up campaign cash for Senator Dianne Feinstein and President Clinton, among others. But when she offered to put together a lunch for Al Checchi the other day, it was Mr. Checchi himself who opened his wallet.
"I was shocked," said Ms. Nelson, the chairman of Summit Bank in Oakland. 
 So about 350 people gathered over salad and chicken breasts in a rooftop ballroom of the Holiday Inn in Emeryville, just across the bay from San Francisco, courtesy of Mr. Checchi, to hear the multimillionaire businessman sketch out his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor, brandishing a newly printed booklet called the Checchi Plan. And at the end, there was no plea for money, only votes.
"I don't want the job unless I can create changes," said Mr. Checchi (pronounced CHECK-ee), who is making his first run for office. "I am not a professional politician. My idea of a good time is not going to be riding around Sacramento in a limousine."
The reality is that by spending more than $30 million of his money on the June 2 primary -- more than any other non-Presidential candidate in American history has ever spent on a primary and general election combined -- Mr. Checchi has already changed the face of politics in the nation's most populous state. Put another way, he has spent about half what Ross Perot spent on his 1992 Presidential race.
At the same time, Mr. Checchi, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, has simply exploited changes long aborning in California, changes that veteran politicians here say made a candidacy like Mr. Checchi's all but inevitable.
Over more than a decade, various movements intended to democratize the state's politics -- including the explosion of ballot initiatives and term limits for state officeholders -- have instead increased the influence of big-money interests from business to labor, along with the cottage industry of pollsters and consultants who package and promote them.
Mr. Checchi's candidacy is not without antecedents. Four years ago, a Republican oil heir, Michael Huffington, spent about $29 million of his own money, the previous record, in a nearly successful effort to unseat Senator Feinstein. But experts here agree that Mr. Checchi has taken the effort to a new level.
"The ability to sell soap on an initiative has now moved to the candidate world itself," said Leon E. Panetta, the former White House chief of staff and nine-term Congressman from Northern California who decided against running for governor after concluding that he could not raise enough money fast enough to challenge Mr. Checchi. "I guess it's a real test of whether or not you can come out of nowhere and invest a lot of money and win a race."
So far, Mr. Checchi has had mixed success. A blizzard of attacks on one rival, Representative Jane Harman, displaced her from an early lead in the polls, but also helped triple Mr. Checchi's own negative ratings. He has yet to break 20 percent support in the polls. And with two weeks to go, the leading candidate is the most conventional politician in the race, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a 25-year veteran of state politics.
Indeed, Mr. Checchi's candidacy has been something of a paradox. He promised to run a positive campaign but instead has run a barrage of television advertising attacking his rivals. Yet, freed from the need to raise money, he has also spent 18 months traveling around the state and talking to some 700 groups and individuals in the most old-fashioned sort of retail politicking.
Mr. Checchi is smooth and polished in speeches and forceful in one-on-one conversations, but he seemed nervous in the only joint debate of the campaign and has made his share of novice's gaffs, blurting out at one point when asked whether he would send his children to public school, "Of course not; why should I?"
He regularly recalls being inspired by the Kennedy brothers' call to civic service, and grows raspy-voiced when he recounts how Robert F. Kennedy died on the 49-year-old candidate's 20th birthday. But Mr. Checchi himself failed to vote in four of California's last six elections.
He has hired a staff of 30 policy experts and consultants and has issued a raft of simplistic, poll-tested proposals -- like a 10 percent cut in the state bureaucracy and automobile insurance rates and hiring 10,000 more police officers -- and he promises to carry them out without any mention of tax increases. But he is also the only candidate who promises bold strokes, like raising California's per-pupil spending on public education to the national average.
In an editorial endorsing him last weekend, The Sacramento Bee called Mr. Checchi "the most promising candidate by far" in the race. The editorial acknowledged that he was "confident to the point of being cocky," but it also praised his "rare combination of ability and independence."
Mr. Checchi's career in the private sector is a similar series of contrasting images. By his account, he is the grandson of Italian immigrant grocers who made his fortune by helping reshape three major American institutions: Marriott, the Walt Disney Company and Northwest. To his critics Mr. Checchi is a wheeler-dealer who was in league in the 1980's with the Bass brothers of Texas in their investment in Disney, and who parlayed his gains into a debt-heavy buyout of Northwest before seeking union concessions and a bailout from Minnesota taxpayers.
In one of the endless series of back-and-forth fax attacks that have marked the campaign, Mr. Davis's campaign manager, Garry South, said Mr. Checchi's "main success was to make himself rich while nearly crashing the airline." Indeed, Mr. Checchi's 11 million shares of Northwest stock, now valued at about $540 million, constitute the bulk of his worth.
In any event, Mr. Checchi has now invested more of his personal money in his campaign than he did in the Northwest buyout, and he is deadly serious about the quest.
"What have these folks ever changed?" Mr. Checchi asked of his rivals as he toured the venerable Italian cafes and markets of the North Beach section in San Francisco the other day, his jaw muscles clenching intently.
"They've never run anything," he continued. "You know, look at these people and ask ourselves, 'What have they run and what were the results?' And you're talking about being atop 350,000 employees, a trillion-dollar economy, managing the largest land portfolio in the United States other than the Federal Government's, and 18 million more people coming in in the next 25 years."
Mr. Checchi's stance is aggressively anti-politician, and much of the state political establishment has not known what to make of him. No less a student of California politics than Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican who is barred by law from seeking a third term, allowed at a breakfast meeting with reporters here today that there was clearly "some resentment" among Democrats over Mr. Checchi's efforts to crash their party.
The Governor predicted that Mr. Davis would be the Democratic nominee. But in making that prediction, Mr. Wilson also implicitly suggested that the Republican nominee, State Attorney Dan Lungren, had more to fear from Mr. Checchi's deep pockets than from Mr. Davis's familiar face.
For his part, Mr. Checchi has managed to win significant support from Democratic officials, including Representative Maxine Waters of Los Angeles and Antonio R. Villaraigosa, the Speaker of the State Assembly.
"Pure and simple, he won me over," said Assemblyman Ted Lempert, a Palo Alto Democrat who was among the first to endorse Mr. Checchi's candidacy last fall. "He's incredibly smart. Before I got to know him, my reaction was the same as a lot of other people's, which is I'm not going to support a guy who thinks he can come in here and buy the election. But after hearing him speak and answer a lot of questions, I'm really convinced he can be a great governor."
Mr. Lempert says it does not please him that Mr. Checchi is spending so much money, but each of Mr. Checchi's two Democratic rivals will come close to equaling the old spending record for a gubernatorial primary in the state, the $9 million spent four years ago by Kathleen Brown.
"Yeah, it bothers me," Mr. Lempert said. "But the way that Gray and Dan Lungren are raising money bothers me, too. I know there's a lot of concern about it, but to me it's a wash."

HEADLINE: Left and Right With Bill Gates

 BODY:
The legal impact of the lawsuits against Microsoft was accompanied by a more subtle upheaval in the ideological realm. The old certainties of conservative opposition to government intervention, fixed since the Reagan era, are shifting on this issue. New technologies, new business rules and, perhaps most important, the power of lobbying and campaign money are producing odd new alliances and redefining what is left and right and who is up or down.
Take, for example, the unexpected Republican support for Attorney General Janet Reno's antitrust activism. Her hand has been strengthened immeasurably because of the backing she commands from Orrin Hatch, one of the chief critics of her chronic passivity on campaign finance. Mr. Hatch, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, represents a state with at least one big software rival of Microsoft. Ms. Reno has also benefited by the fact that Trent Lott uttered not a peep of criticism about the Clinton Administration's handling of Microsoft, and Newt Gingrich sounded downright approving. The company's G.O.P. defenders are much less weighty figures such as its home-state Senator, Slade Gorton, and that ever-grumpy ideologue, Dick Armey. 
 For a long time, Microsoft was an amateur at influencing Washington. It has now stepped up its lobbying and campaign contributions. The irony is that a company long identified with a liberal point of view is trying to make up for lost time with money and hired operatives from the conservative wing of the Republican Party. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, it is the leading donor among computer companies to Federal candidates and parties. It has also hired such well-known Republican operatives as Haley Barbour, Michael Deaver, Grover Norquist and former Representative Vin Weber.
But arrayed against Microsoft is an impressive list of Republicans as well, including former Senator Bob Dole. By far the most startling antagonist of Microsoft is Robert Bork. This former judge and law professor was once known as an apostle of the Chicago School, which questioned whether there are any economic benefits to antitrust enforcement. Both Microsoft and its rivals wooed Mr. Bork, but the critics won him over. He has asserted that Microsoft violated the law by using its dominant position in computer operating systems to promote its own browser over that of its rival, Netscape, a view held by the Clinton Justice Department. No less interesting was the presence of six Republicans on the list of attorneys general filing suit this week, including Dennis Vacco in New York.
There is fracturing on the libertarian side as well. The most ringing defense of Microsoft now comes from the Cato Institute in Washington. On the other hand, some of Microsoft's critics are Silicon Valley entrepreneurs who once shared the anti-regulation position embraced by Microsoft. Now the buccaneers of high-tech want the Government to level the playing field.
Obviously a world of politics and policy driven by lobbying and campaign contributions is not a healthy place. But we may be seeing a welcome new consensus emerging that government has a role to play and that it should not be ridiculed on reflex for every intervention. This Democratic Administration is arguing that there is an intelligent place for government oversight in cyberspace, just as there is in the environment, the work place and the worlds of retirement and health care. Some surprisingly powerful Republicans seem to agree.

HEADLINE: New Broad Street Site Is Proposed To Keep Stock Exchange in Area

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Faced with the possibility that the New York Stock Exchange's quest for a new home would lead it to either Battery Park City or perhaps even New Jersey, officials of New York City and the state said yesterday that they would try to acquire five properties on Broad Street for the exchange, in a bid to insure that lower Manhattan remains the financial capital of the world.
The officials are about to open negotiations with the owners of the Broad Street parcels, which include an apartment house, a parking lot and three nearly vacant buildings, that real estate experts say could cost more than $200 million. The site is a block away from the exchange's historic home on Wall Street. 
 The buildings would be demolished to make way for a tower with two large trading floors. The Empire State Development Corporation could acquire the properties under the power of eminent domain, but that could involve a drawn out condemnation process that the state wants to avoid.
Under an informal agreement with the exchange chairman, Richard A. Grasso, if the state and city are unable to strike a deal to buy the properties within six months, the exchange would be free to move.
Although it is only a few blocks to the Battery Park City site, state and city officials and property owners fear that the loss of the exchange would be a crushing blow to the downtown real estate market, which recovered only recently from a recession in the early and mid-1990's.
"We're going to do everything we can to acquire the properties on Broad Street and keep the exchange downtown," Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine said yesterday. "If we can't do it in a quick way, then Battery Park City becomes a valid alternative."
The joint effort by the Giuliani and Pataki administrations comes 12 days after Mr. Grasso announced that the New York Stock Exchange had abandoned plans to expand in lower Manhattan and would explore a move to Battery Park City or New Jersey.
Mr. Grasso, like the heads of many of the city's investment banks, successfully grabbed the attention of city officials with his comments about talking to officials in New Jersey.
His remarks started a flurry of phone calls and meetings between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Grasso, city and state officials said.
The stock exchange, however, was looking for much more than the millions of dollars in tax breaks that the investment banks wrung from the city. It was asking for cash grants and land for a new trading floor.
Privately, stock exchange officials remain skeptical that the properties on Broad Street could be acquired without a prohibitively long legal battle with at least some of the landowners. The five properties fill much of the block bound by Broad Street, William Street, Beaver Street and Exchange Place.
But the push to satisfy the exchange, which would include steep public subsidies, is colliding with another municipal policy that was intended to revive the downtown real estate market.
Three years ago, Crescent Heights Investments, the owner of an apartment house at 25 Broad Street, was one of the first companies to take advantage of the new city tax breaks and zoning changes encouraging investors to convert some of the many vacant downtown office buildings to apartments.
Crescent Heights subsequently invested about $100 million in building and renting 345 apartments at 25 Broad that it would now be asked to tear down. In what may be the opening shot in the acquisition effort or merely a negotiating ploy for more money, Crescent Heights filed an application yesterday to have 25 Broad Street declared a city landmark, which would, if successful, prohibit demolition of the building. Crescent Heights has not returned several calls requesting comment in the last few days.
The other four property owners may be more amenable to a sale.
"We'd be more than willing to cooperate with them," said Fred Manocherian, who owns a large parking lot at 15 William Street that is part of the proposed site. "We are very anxious to make sure that the exchange stays in downtown Manhattan. But I feel that 25 Broad will be the sticking point that has to be resolved."
Even as city and state officials struggle with the future home of the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers are beginning a search for a new 500,000-square-foot headquarters, possibly in midtown Manhattan, said real estate executives who have talked to officials at the financial markets. The association, which owns the Nasdaq stock market and is acquiring the American Stock Exchange, has signed a tentative deal to open a marketing center at 4 Times Square that would include a gigantic $12 million to $18 million video sign wrapped around part of the cylindrical face of the new skyscraper being built at Broadway and 43d Street.
The departure of the American Stock Exchange from its headquarters at 86 Trinity Place would put a dent in the lower Manhattan real estate market, but not as serious as the departure of the New York Stock Exchange.
"The New York Stock Exchange, both symbolically and practically, is the center of the financial universe," said Thomas Falus, president of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate broker.
The current discussion of sites for the exchanges recalls an effort by city officials and developers seven years ago to build new trading floors and a 50-story tower across the street from the New York Stock Exchange and next to the site now under consideration.
That proposal would have created a superexchange housing both stock markets as well as the city's five commodity exchanges. Property values were plummeting in 1991 and one out of every four floors of office space was empty in lower Manhattan, so land was cheap.
The project, which financial executives and city officials now regard as a "lost opportunity," presumably would have tethered the financial industry to lower Manhattan until well into the next century. But after months of discussions, William H. Donaldson, then the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, rejected the proposal.
Since then, the city struck a series of deals with investment banks that routinely threatened to leave New York for the suburbs. When he was Mayor, David N. Dinkins granted a $106.2 million tax break to Prudential Securities, a $100 million incentive package to Morgan Stanley and a $40 million subsidy to Bear Stearns.
Mayor Giuliani, who once criticized those deals, has granted tax breaks totaling $439.1 million to 18 financial institutions, including the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest commodity market in New York.
The New York Stock Exchange has been intrigued by the idea of building a modern facility, rather than expanding near its current location, ever since it visited the new $280 million headquarters of the Mercantile Exchange at Battery Park City, which opened last year with the help of $183.9 million in tax breaks and cash from the city and the state.
The exchange would like a similar deal to build a complex at the northern end of Battery Park City on a valuable parcel known as Site 26.

GRAPHIC: Map showing locations of the Battery Park City site and the Broad St. site: A Battery Park City site, though close, seems worlds away to some. (pg. B6)

Indonesia Leader's Words Spur Crackdown in Capital
Hard-line military leaders clamped down on the capital of Indonesia in an effort to choke off plans for a huge demonstration hours after President Suharto rejected calls to step down, saying instead that he would hold elections some time in the future. Soldiers blocked key squares and intersections. Barricades also isolated the Parliament building, where thousands of protesting students had camped overnight. A1 

The student protesters are treating the Suharto Government with undisguised contempt. Hundreds of students barged into the main chamber of the House of Representatives, filling up the seats and galleries and conducting a sort of spontaneous shadow government. A10
 
The Clinton Administration has been giving crucial financial support to some of the most important Indonesian opposition groups, hoping to promote a transition to a democratic society, while also trying to shore up President Suharto. A11

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: Gingrich Plans Panel on China And Clinton Tie

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Saying that "very stark questions of national security" are at stake, Speaker Newt Gingrich announced today that he would create a special committee to investigate President Clinton's decision to waive export controls over advanced space technology to China.
Mr. Gingrich said he would propose to House Democrats that the committee be led by Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican who served in the White House counsel's office under President Ronald Reagan. 
 He said the committee would focus on issues including the recent reports that a Chinese military officer gave $100,000 in political contributions to a Democratic fund-raiser during the 1996 Presidential election and the question of whether an American satellite maker passed sensitive technological information to China.
"This has nothing to do with campaign finance," Mr. Gingrich said, seeking to elevate the issue above the recent House investigation into Mr. Clinton's 1996 campaign financing.
"This has to do with the national security of the United States," he said, "and the effort by a foreign military to penetrate our political system and the effort by some people to give the Chinese secrets in violation of American law. This is a profoundly deeper question than anything that has arisen in this Administration."
The House must vote to create a special committee, but Mr. Gingrich virtually dared the Democrats to object to such a panel, which he said would consist of five Republicans and three Democrats.
"I think the country would be very curious as to why the Democrats would not want to know that the Chinese were getting American military secrets," he said.
President Clinton said earlier this week that foreign policy had not been compromised and that he would cooperate with any investigation.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, has already signaled his opposition to a special investigative committee, and a spokesman said his position has not changed. But a senior Democratic official acknowledged last night that boycotting such a committee "is not an option. Some of our members are pretty spooked."
The Speaker's decision to create a special committee avoids the political problem of having Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, continue to head a much criticized investigation into Mr. Clinton's 1996 campaign financing and allows the Republicans to elevate the inquiry into more serious matters of national security.
Mr. Gingrich's announcement came at the end of a day in which several senior Republicans wielded foreign policy as a weapon against Mr. Clinton, accusing him of undermining the stature of the Presidency and assailing his handling of the Middle East, China and India. And Mr. Gingrich indirectly brought the former intern Monica S. Lewinsky into the argument, too, when he compared the Clinton White House to the salacious "Jerry Springer Show."
"Around the world today, the institution of the Presidency has been degraded to the point that it is viewed as the rough equivalent of 'The Jerry Springer Show' -- a level of disrespect and decadence that should appall every American," he wrote in the conservative weekly Human Events.
 Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, said that Mr. Clinton "seems to be incapable of getting cooperation on any of the things that he is trying to get from the international community. I think it's time for him to step forward and remove this shadow of doubt that seems to be hindering his ability to achieve the stature on the international scene that an American President ought to get."
The House Republican Conference gave talking points to House Republicans making some of the same points and saying that "this is not just another campaign finance law violation. This is the latest smudge on American international prestige. The President is losing his standing in the international community."
The talking points noted that Mr. Clinton could not convince the nation's allies at an international economic summit to join sanctions against India for conducting nuclear tests, and that he had trouble last year garnering international support for efforts to force weapons inspections in Iraq. And they pointed to Mr. Clinton's decision to waive sanctions against three foreign companies doing business with Iran.
Earlier in the day, at a celebration of Israel's 50th anniversary, Mr. Gingrich compared the Administration's failure to stop China and Russia from transferring weapons technology to Iran to Britain's early appeasement of Hitler.
And the Speaker criticized the Administration for trying to broker an agreement concerning the West Bank. "When I see an American diplomat suggest to Israeli generals that our understanding of their security needs on the West Bank is better than their understanding, I'm looking at someone who has been in fancy hotels too long and out of touch with reality," he said.
But most of the Republican focus today was on China. The New York Times reported last week that lawyers and officials have said that Johnny Chung, a Democratic fund-raiser, told Federal investigators that a Chinese military officer, Lieut. Col. Liu Chaoying, had funneled nearly $100,000 into Democratic campaigns.
In addition, there have been questions about whether an American aerospace company, Loral Space and Communications, received favorable treatment on high-technology exports to China. The company's chief executive officer, Bernard Schwartz, has been one of the Democratic Party's largest donors.
Loral and another company, Hughes Electronics, exported commercial satellites to China to be launched by Chinese missiles. After a Chinese rocket exploded in 1996, a Loral subsidiary helped provide a report to the Chinese without first consulting with United States officials. The company said it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation, and has denied that any sensitive information was transferred.
Mr. Clinton has denied that campaign donations affected American policy and vowed in Europe to cooperate with Congressional investigators.
House Republicans tonight pushed through a nonbinding resolution calling for immunity from prosecution for four witnesses to testify in an investigation of illegal campaign contributions to Democrats.
Mr. Gingrich today suggested that Mr. Clinton postpone his China trip and said the special committee could be up and running by mid-June. He said he wanted a separate panel because the accusations regarding China crossed the jurisdiction of a number of standing committees.
"If the President wants to cooperate we could begin facilitating the transfer of information within the next week or so," Mr. Gingrich said. "I would just suggest to you that implications that American military secrets were being given without the knowledge of the American government are very, very serious."
In another development, a House National Security subcommittee announced that some Pentagon workers who review exports for national security risks have said that they were told by a superior not to voice their opposition to the President's approval of satellite technology transfers to China last February.
Investigators for the subcommittee said that some employees of the Pentagon's Defense Technology Security Administration told them that memos they wrote arguing against the satellite exports were suppressed by their boss in an attempt to reduce the Executive Branch's record of opposition.
Pentagon officials today flatly denied the accusation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

DuPont to Buy Out Merck In Joint Drug Venture
DuPont will pay Merck $2.6 billion for its half of DuPont Merck Pharmaceutical, the joint venture they formed in 1991.
Analysts were surprised. They had been speculating about what DuPont would do with the $5 billion it is expected to receive from selling 20 percent of its oil unit, Conoco, in a deal announced last week. Page D5. 

Taking Microsoft's Battle Public
The antitrust case against Microsoft by the Justice Department and 20 states is shaping up as a high-decibel, bitter battle involving talk-show appearances to sway public opinion as well as the courts. A1.
 
Microsoft has gone on a spending spree to gain access to key people in Washington. D4.
 
Senate's Parochial View
Views in Congress about the Clinton Administration's aggressive approach to Microsoft are divided along lines closely tied to an individual lawmaker's local interests. Nowhere is the contrast greater than between Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, left, a supporter who represents Microsoft's home state, and Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, who views the company as anticompetitive and represents the home state of Novell, a Microsoft competitor. D4.
 
Pager Service Disrupted
A communications satellite operated by Panamsat spun out of operation yesterday, interrupting service to millions of pager users in the United States. The disruption caused problems for television stations, doctors and others. D6.
 
Nasdaq Up 14.25, Dow Only 3.74
Reversing a three-day decline, stocks rose. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite rose 14.25 points, to 1,845.87. But the Dow industrials closed up only 3.74 points at 9,054.65. D9.
 
Crude oil fell to the lowest settlement price in nearly a decade, with June contracts down $1.11 a barrel at $12.98. D8.
 
Dell Slightly Exceeds Estimates
Dell Computer reported a 54 percent rise in first-quarter earnings to $305 million, modestly exceeding Wall Street estimates. The company, which builds to order and sells direct to consumers, maintained strong profit margins.
 
Orange County Suits Settled
KPMG Peat Marwick agreed to pay $75 million in a settlement with Orange County, Calif., and others. D5.
 
When Ignorance Is Bliss
Uninformed investors are just as confident and aggressive in stock trading as well-informed investors, three professors at Cornell University have found. Gretchen Morgenson: Market Place. D8.
 
Pearson's Eye on America
Pearson's deal to purchase most of Simon & Schuster's operations is a sign that the blue-blooded British media group is tightening its focus with an eye on the United States. The strategy is shaped by its chief executive, Marjorie M. Scardino, an American. D2.
 
Indonesian Economy at a Standstill
Indonesia's economy is paralyzed and a potential food shortage looms in Jakarta. Although many banks and stores are reopening, most commercial activity remains at a standstill. A10.
 
Iran Trumpets Sanction Waiver
Iran trumpeted a Clinton Administration decision to waive sanctions against Total of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia, which are doing business with it, saying it should signal an end to American attempts to deter similar investments. A13.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Queens Grocer Charged In Death of Couple

 BODY:
A Queens greengrocer was arrested and charged yesterday in the killing of a Korean-American financier and his wife Sunday during a disagreement about a business loan, law enforcement officials said.
The greengrocer, Lee Kyung Bok, 35, was charged with two counts of murder in the shooting deaths of Kyung Lee, 35, and his wife So Hee Lee, 31. Mr. and Mrs. Lee were well known as moneylenders in the Korean-American community, where entrepreneurs are often willing to pay high interest rates to start up or finance their businesses. 
 The police said Mr. Bok had borrowed at least $10,000 from the Lees to cover a cash shortfall at his business, Sunny Supermarket on 48th Avenue in Woodside, and was apparently discussing the loan with the Lees as they sat inside the couple's black Lexus on 75th Street in Elmhurst.
According to a complaint filed in Queens Criminal Court, Mr. Bok shot Mr. Lee once in the head in a dispute over the money. When Mrs. Lee fled, the complaint said, Mr. Bok chased her and shot her once in the cheek. The Lees later died.
Mr. Bok's lawyer, Frank Hancock, said his client was was visiting a friend in Forest Hills, Queens when the Lees were shot. He acknowledged that Mr. Bok had borrowed at least $10,000 from the Lees, and that he was being charged at least $125 per week in interest, but he denied that there had been a dispute with them.

HEADLINE: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE SCENE;
Joyfully, Indonesian Students Thumb Noses at Authority

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 19

 BODY:
For a few surreal hours here today, Indonesia's political hierarchy seemed to be turned on its head.
Hundreds of student protesters barged into the main chamber of the House of Representatives, filling up the seats and galleries and conducting a sort of spontaneous shadow government. One young man took the podium to offer a dead-pan impersonation of Gen. Wiranto, the Defense Minister and armed forces commander, while another imitated the Speaker of the House, Mr. Harmoko. 
 Above them hung an eagle in gun-metal gray, Indonesia's national symbol, which had been plastered over with a banner demanding that President Suharto "stop unemployment and lower the price of food."
"I want to be just like the Government," said Azhari Somaad, a 27-year-old student at Mohammadiyah University in Jakarta, after he had finished an enthusiastic if disjointed speech to his hooting classmates. "If I were in the Government, I would resign and give the power back to the people."
It was the second day in a row that the Indonesian military allowed the students to bring their protest inside the gates of Parliament. And today a crowd of 15,000 giddy students had the run of the place -- occupying lobbies, hallways and offices, and even spilling out on to the domed roof, where they strung anti-Suharto banners between the flagpoles.
On a day when Mr. Suharto defied calls to step down immediately, the students are treating his Government with undisguised contempt. Loudspeakers resounded with calls for Mr. Suharto's head, while a group of students carried a freshly-painted sign that said in English: "We're sick of you."
"He grabbed the power and now we have to grab it back," said Dewi Satriani, a 26-year-old advertising student at the University of Indonesia. "He's been President for 32 years, so it is not easy for him to give it up."
Like most students, Ms. Satriani was disappointed but not surprised by Mr. Suharto's televised address. Watching the speech with friends in a common room at the University of Indonesia this morning, she shook her head in disgust as the President laid out the conditions for his departure.
Ms. Satriani dismissed Mr. Suharto's promise to hold new elections as a cynical maneuver by an autocrat unwilling to relax his grip on power, even in the face of overwhelming rejection. "I haven't got any idea of what he is planning to do," she said. "I just know I don't believe him anymore."
Rows of soldiers guarded the gates of Parliament, refusing entry to people other than students and journalists. But the soldiers did not venture into the sprawling complex, which gave the students free rein and turned Parliament into an Indonesian version of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. during spring break.
Hundreds of students mingled under a tropical sun outside the building. Inside, they camped out in lobbies and stairwells, banging plastic water bottles on the floor in thunderous chants against Mr. Suharto. Exhausted protesters slept peacefully under newspapers amid the din.
It was in the cavernous House chamber that the students most vividly demonstrated their contempt for the Government. Long the inner sanctum of a legislative body that meekly ratified Mr. Suharto's rule, the House chamber today became a playground.
Students in khaki uniforms from the Indonesian Maritime Academy sprinted around the room on the desktops. Others heckled the speakers by tossing wads of paper at them. And the unofficial leaders sitting on the rostrum elbowed each other out of the way as they tried to get a turn at the podium.
The students mocked General Wiranto, who disappointed them on Monday by announcing that the army would support Mr. Suharto. But they also taunted Mr. Harmoko, the House Speaker, who demanded that Mr. Suharto resign on Monday, only to back off somewhat today after the chilly response from General Wiranto and Mr. Suharto himself. Asked why they were mocking Parliament when Mr. Harmoko had supported to their cause, one student said: "The Parliament doesn't have the mandate of the people. We can't take it seriously."

HEADLINE: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE HOMETOWN;
In Seattle, Bill Gates Is Still a Hometown Hero

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 19

 BODY:
The money-making machine at the Microsoft Corporationpurred along today, the soldiers of software touting their new operating system while assuring friends and colleagues that no, the ride was not over. Not by any stretch.
What the Government did this week -- filing a suit that called Microsoft a predatory monopolist, using its dominance of personal computer operating systems to control future innovations -- may be the antitrust action that defines commerce for much of the next century. 
 But, perhaps because there is just so much money floating around this region as a result of Microsoft, people here say they feel no immediate threat from the Justice Department. What you hear is defiance, denial, and even the celebrated hubris.
Microsoft will fight the Justice Department, according to a dominant view from its hometown, because fighting -- and winning -- is what Microsoft does best.
"If anything, this is going to fuel the already heightened competitiveness of the company," said Scott Oki, who was one of the first 100 Microsoft employees, and now devotes his time to giving away much of his fortune and developing golf courses. "They will just hunker down and be that much better at what they do."
As for his view of the antitrust suit, Mr. Oki said, "I think it's preposterous, wrongheaded, misdirected and just plain dumb."
Microsoft, based in the Seattle suburb of Redmond, has produced a half-dozen billionaires, more than 2,000 millionaires -- most of whom would not draw a stare at the mini-mart -- and is in large part responsible for Seattle being one of the costlier places to own a home in America. But this is not a company town.
Microsoft, with about 12,000 employees, is only the fourth-largest employer, behind Boeing, Group Health Cooperative and the University of Washington. When Boeing shed two-thirds of its work force during a sharp recession 30 years ago, a famous sign implored the last person leaving town to turn out the lights.
Now, the reaction to an outside threat is one of calculation as the holders of Microsoft stock study how the Justice Department suit affects their investment. "I have friends who worked at the phone company when they broke up, and they're watching their portfolios sail along," said Laura Ruderman, who left Microsoft two months ago after five years at the company.
Microsoft, according to the consensus view around Seattle, is no turn-of-the-century Standard Oil, a Goliath ripe for breakup. And even if it were, some people say, it is worth recalling what the aging John D. Rockefeller said upon hearing that his oil monopoly was over: He told people to buy Standard Oil stock, saying it would be worth more when divided into parts, as indeed it was.
"No one's cashing in their stock options," said Julie Bick, a former group product manager at the company and author of a recent book, "All I Really Need to Know in Business I Learned at Microsoft" (Pocket Books). She said that the company was being punished simply for being successful. "It's kind of like telling a slugger on the baseball team not to hit for the fences," Ms. Bick said.
Valerie Carbonaro of Redmond, who was shopping at a boutique in Redmond yesterday, said, "In some respects I agree with the smaller companies because Microsoft has got the market. But it's part of the American way. Bill Gates started it from scratch and got it to where it is today."
That view extends to the Governor of the state, Gary Locke, a Democrat. "I don't think people or companies should be targeted by the Government just because they're smart and innovative," Governor Locke said. "You have to wonder if Microsoft is being attacked because of its success and its brains."
Justice Department lawyers and Microsoft rivals say that the company has repeatedly broken antitrust laws. They say the company has used its dominance in software operating systems -- roughly 90 percent of all personal computers run on Microsoft systems -- to stifle competition in other areas, mainly in its moves to take over the market for Internet browsers, which allow computer users to connect to the millions of sites on the World Wide Web. If successful in doing this, the critics add, a small percentage of virtually every commercial transaction on the Internet will end up in the hands of the merchants at Microsoft.
For all its hometown rooters, there are also plenty of critics of the company here, and Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, is a regular target of vicious local satire. It seems obvious, people say with a shrug, why Mr. Gates -- whose Microsoft stock alone is worth around $47 billion -- keeps personal papers from Napoleon, the man who once had designs on much of the world, among the artifacts usually on display at his new $40 million home on Lake Washington.
The money from Microsoft has clearly transformed this region. Outside of the Silicon Valley in California, the Puget Sound area -- along with the Boston area -- has the highest concentration of software companies in the nation, many dependent on Microsoft. Paul Allen, Microsoft's co-founder, has been acting as a sports and arts Medici, buying a professional football team, nearly a third of all the office space in the southern end of downtown Seattle, and building a huge new music museum. He is also, with the help of taxpayers, constructing a professional football stadium for the Seattle Seahawks, the team he owns.
Other residents have also become more active in charitable giving.
"We set a record this year for the biggest increase in United Way donations of any city," said Bob Watt, a former Seattle deputy mayor who is the chief executive of the Greater Seattle Chamber of Commerce. "The biggest increase in categories was those who gave over $10,000 apiece. And the incentive was, anyone who donated that got to have dinner with Bill and Melinda Gates. That's a small example of what this company means to this area."
But with Microsoft being only the fourth-largest employer, Mr. Watt said, few people are concerned about the Justice Department's action. "Most of the software executives I've spoken to have been saying this is not Armageddon," he said.
Still, being accused of unlawful behavior raises the question of whether Microsoft will be hurt by its cutthroat image. The answer, at least on Microsoft's home turf, was no.
"Lawsuits are not what they used to be," said Bruce Chapman, president of the Discovery Institute, a Seattle-based think tank. "People used to say where there's smoke, there's fire. Now they say, where there's smoke, there's a smoke machine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An emblem at Microsoft seeks "a computer on every desk and in every home." (Dan Lamont for The New York Times)
