HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Riffs on America in an Abstract Direction

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"Colonial Cubism," one of Stuart Davis's great late paintings, is among the first signs of maturity in his lean, sparkling retrospective at the National Museum of American Art. The high-stepping interlocking forms of this 1954 painting, rendered in well-distributed chunks of slightly off-key red, yellow and blue plus black and white, beckon from the end wall of a long hallway gallery that contains some 20 examples of Davis's often accomplished early works. They date from 1912, when the artist turned 20, to 1928, when he made his only visit to Paris.
Typically syncopated and alliterative, the title "Colonial Cubism" reflects Davis's long love affair with jazz, which he acknowledged as a crucial influence. (He was especially devoted to the stride piano of Fats Waller and Earl Hines, naming his son after the latter.) But it also sums up his achievement as a whole. 
 More than any other American painter, Davis transformed and extended Cubism into an authentic and original style, turning it to his own purposes, as did other non-Frenchmen like Mondrian, Malevich, Klee and Chagall. It's not surprising that this transition from colonized to colonizer took inspiration from jazz, America's first indigenous art form of international stature.
The arduousness of Davis's effort was spelled out by the Metropolitan Museum of Art's enormous 1991 retrospective, to such an extent that the show sometimes bogged down a bit. The National Museum's effort, which was seen last summer at the Peggy Guggenheim Museum in Venice, suffers from the opposite problem. (It was orgainized by Philp Rylands, director of the Venice Guggenheim; Elizabeth Broun, director of the National Museum, and Earl Davis, the artist's son.)
With 52 canvases and no drawings, it skims so efficiently over the high points of a five-decade career that his progress is shorn of its twists, turns, backtracks and plateaus and is given the illusion of streamlined forward momentum. Some phases are skipped altogether -- Davis's sweetly artificial New Mexican landscapes from 1923, for example.
It's not always clear where a motif comes from: the white-on-black scaffolding that shadows the colored forms of "Memo" (1956), for example, emanates from a series of ink and gouache drawings based on harbor scenes and ships' rigging, executed in the early 30's, but they are not represented here. Nor is the 1922 abstraction whose composition was reiterated virtually piece by piece in "Colonial Cubism."
But the lack of distractions compresses the essential trajectory of Davis's artistic development -- what he himself called his "amazing continuity" -- and brings his formal genius to vivid life. It also makes the two main characteristics of his art, the constancy of his subject matter and his recycling of formal motifs, fabulously evident.
Davis's subject matter remained largely unchanged throughout his life. It was, as he himself said, "the American scene," an idiosyncratic combination of landscape and still life that he simply treated in an increasingly abstract, cohesive and symbolic manner as he matured.
He began with scenes of New York in the Ashcan manner. Next came his magnificent little views of Gloucester, Mass., energetic homages to van Gogh and Gauguin, whose work he saw in the 1913 Armory Show. (These works and other exercises in Post-Impressionism from that decade are the subject of a small, dense show on view at Salander O'Reilly in Manhattan.) The 20's were devoted mostly to Cubism, which he also encountered at the Armory but didn't master until his shallow-spaced "Egg Beater" series of 1927-28. The 20's also brought occasional forays into other styles, like the nearly trompe-l'oeil renderings of cigarette papers.
In June 1928 came the 14-month trip to Paris, where Davis produced a series of delightful stage-setlike images of Parisian facades, detailing slabs of bright color with fine black lines for windows, doors, loggias and balconies and introducing language by way of shop signs. They're elegant, perhaps "minor," yet their formal punch and economy comes startlingly close to Davis's late work.
During the 1930's and 40's, Davis built up his formal artillery, sometimes to unbearable density, in pieces that usually alternated between scenes of New York and Gloucester. He produced works like the crowded "New York by Gaslight" (each corner a little painting of its own), as well as the more relaxed "Cape Ann Landscape," whose semiabstracted forms seem to reiterate a number of different views: town, country, harbor and even the New Mexican mountains, a little row of red triangles in the upper right quadrant.
Davis had important breakthroughs in this period. In "Arboretum by Flashbulb" (1942), he achieved a new optical wholeness, partly from an evenly distributed and shallow composition, in which no shape or area dominated any other. But he also introduced the idea, which he would exploit to the fullest between 1950 and his death in 1964, of limiting his colors to four or five, as Mondrian did and Pollock would.
The late 40's are represented here by only two paintings, "The Mellow Pad" and "Pad No. 4." They show Davis's formal vocabulary of words, numbers, letters, arrows, animated squiggles, spirals and jaunty shapes reaching the boiling point, while his palette becomes equally feverish.
The paintings of the years after 1950 are in many ways like beautifully made proto-Pop billboards, full of sharp color contrasts, off-kilter shapes and sprinklings of snappy words and visual wisecracks. "Int'l Surface No. 1," from 1960, spells out "New," "Cat" and "100%," on different shards of green, white or black with red highlights.
The second characteristic made apparent by this exhibition is Davis's talent as a recycler of his own material. That he frequently reached back to the 1920's, using entire early paintings as templates for late ones, cannot be thoroughly examined in a show that moves as fast as this one, although it's fun to watch the development of certain individual motifs, like the ever larger and more prominent loops, squiggles and X's. But if the exhibition doesn't always illustrate the way many of Davis's late works were cropped, edited, enlarged and more intensely colored versions of his hard-won compositions of the 20's, it does show him exercising his recycling skill in contemporaneous works.
In the exhibition's final galleries, which feature nearly 20 of Davis's post-1950 paintings, several are shown alongside fraternal twins made at virtually the same time. Sometimes the palette remains remarkably the same, with Davis rearranging the colors' placement and ratios and fiddling with compositional details. This is the case, for example, with "Rapt at Rappaport's" and "Seme," both predominantly green, orange, magenta and blue, with black and white. Sometimes the compositions remain nearly identical, but the palette is radically altered: the red, blue, black and white composition of "Ready to Wear" is restated as an eye-popping red on black scaffolding in "Cliche."
In addition to the 1922 painting that preceded it, "Colonial Cubism" (1954), also reiterates the contemporaneous "Midi," enlarging and simplifying its composition and changing its hot pastels to those slightly deviant primaries.
As Davis put it: "You have to have a subject. I take what I can get -- even one of my own paintings." His carefully plotted images had many great moments along the way, and also made possible the sustained achievement of his final years. The idea that a well-built composition could generate any number of variations may have been the most important lesson he learned from the piano playing of Hines and Waller.
 "Stuart Davis" remains at the National Museum of American Art, Eighth and G Streets N.W., Washington, through Sept. 7.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paintings like proto-Pop billboards: Stuart Davis's "Int'l Surface No. 1." (National Museum of American Art, Smithsonian Institution)

HEADLINE: Washington Opera to Stay and Grow at the Kennedy

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Effectively ending its plan to build a new opera house in an old department store downtown, the Washington Opera has reached a tentative agreement with the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to perform there more often.
The agreement, which was approved on Wednesday by the executive committee of the opera and is subject to ratification by the full boards of the opera and the center, benefits both institutions. 
 The Kennedy Center agreed to extend the company's season in the center's Opera House to 26 weeks a year from 17, a spokeswoman for the center said. The opera's repertory and reputation have been growing in recent years, and it has also been performing eight weeks a year in the center's Eisenhower Theater, which was designed for drama, not opera. Those performances will be phased out, said Suzanne Stephens, spokeswoman for the opera.
Since the Opera House seats 2,200 people and the Eisenhower half that, the opera's potential audience will grow substantially, she said. Patricia Mossel, the opera's executive director, said the company would be able to expand its season to 100 performances a season, from 74 a year.
Lawrence J. Wilker, president of the Kennedy Center, said that he was "very pleased" by the agreement.
"We have said from the beginning that they were a part of the Kennedy Center and that we would do whatever we could to make it possible for them to stay."
When asked what the center would have to drop to make dates available for the opera, he said it would reduce "ballet, musical theater and international presentations."
"In order for the opera to grow," Mr. Wilker said, "something else has to shrink."
At the same time, the company now has a choice parcel of downtown property that it can sell.
When the idea for a new opera house came up, a benefactor, Betty Brown Casey, gave the company $18 million, which it used to buy the old Woodward & Lothrop department store at a public auction in 1996. Since then, the downtown area has boomed, thanks partly to the robust economy and partly to the opening of the MCI sports arena four blocks from the abandoned department store. The store would probably sell for more than its cost.
Ms. Stephens said proceeds from a sale would go into the opera's endowment.
The executive committee's action seems to have ended a plan that had divided many leaders in Washington's arts world. Placido Domingo, the opera's artistic director, never seemed more than lukewarm in his support of a new house. And fund-raisers, especially those at the Kennedy Center and its related organizations, like the National Symphony Orchestra, were concerned that a drive to raise the $200 million that the new house was projected to cost would dry up many of their donation sources.
In announcing the executive committee's action, Ms. Mossel said, "Should the boards of the organizations approve the agreement, the opera will sign a lease with the Kennedy Center for 15 years."
She added that the opera was pleased to remain at the Kennedy Center because of the excellent acoustics in the Opera House.
The agreement will be phased in after the boards ratify it, becoming fully effective in the fall of 2002. For the season before that, the opera will perform in Constitution Hall while the Opera House is renovated.

HEADLINE: April U.S. Budget Had Record Surplus

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The United States recorded its highest monthly budget surplus ever in April as the robust economy and booming stock market generated strong tax revenue, setting the stage for the first annual budget surplus since the late 1960's.
The Government had a surplus of $124.6 billion in April, up from a surplus of $93.9 billion in April 1997, the previous record, according to a Treasury statement today. Analysts had expected a surplus of $119.4 billion. 
 Tax payments have cascaded in, with a record 64.2 percent of the population holding jobs, corporations churning out profits and Wall Street setting records. April revenues rose 14.2 percent, to a record $261 billion.
"The Treasury finds itself with an embarrassment of riches," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant at Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
The growth of Government spending has also slowed as the strong economy creates jobs and helps trim welfare rolls, Mr. Dederick said. In addition, military spending has also dropped, he said. April spending rose 1.3 percent, to $136.4 billion.
For the fiscal year to date, the budget surplus totals $54.7 billion, in contrast to a deficit of $17.2 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier, according to Treasury statistics. The White House and Congress remain at odds on how to spend the surplus.

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE POLICY;
U.S. Welcomes Resignation But Is Cool to the Successor

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration stepped up its calls today for a transition to democracy in Indonesia and, while welcoming the resignation of President Suharto, attempted to distance itself from his successor, B. J. Habibie. Senior officials said the United States assumed -- and hoped -- that Mr. Habibie's tenure as President would be a short one.
President Clinton said he welcomed "the wise decision made less than 24 hours ago by President Suharto" and that "it now gives the Indonesian people a chance to come together to build a stable democracy for the 21st century." 
 "I hope the leaders will now move forward promptly with an open and peaceful transition that enjoys broad public support," the President said in remarks in the White House Rose Garden during a ceremony to mark the expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Mr. Clinton did not mention the name of Mr. Habibie, a protege of Mr. Suharto who had been the Vice President for the last two months.
Indonesia's new President has given no indication that he intends to oversee a caretaker government. But senior Administration officials said President Habibie was clearly unsuited to lead Indonesia, given his longstanding ties to Mr. Suharto and what they called his eccentric views on economic policy.
He has been a champion of costly Government-sponsored high-technology projects, including development of an aerospace industry, that many economists think unsuitable for a developing nation like Indonesia. Like Mr. Suharto, Mr. Habibie is widely seen by Western officials as corrupt. His family is reported to control hundreds of millions of dollars in assets, with much of the wealth derived from Government contracts.
"I can't imagine that the Habibie era will be measured in years," said a senior Administration official involved in Indonesian policy who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "As best we can tell, he has no constituency anywhere. As soon as the military figures out where it wants to take the country, Habibie's out."
Administration officials said that the United States would try to forge a closer relationship with the two rival military leaders who are now seen as the true power in the Indonesian Government: Gen. Wiranto, the armed forces commander, and Gen. Prabowo, the head of an elite army unit and Mr. Suharto's son-in-law.
"We want to encourage the military commanders to move toward democracy, toward new elections as soon as feasible," the senior official said. "At this point we don't know these guys well and we don't know if they'll listen. But they are our best hope."
Officials acknowledge that the Clinton Administration has only limited leverage in promoting democracy in Indonesia, and what leverage it does have is mostly through the leadership role of the United States in the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other financial institutions that are overseeing a $43 billion rescue package for the battered Indonesian economy. The rescue plan was suspended earlier this week as a result of the political chaos in Indonesia.
"We look forward to progress toward the political and economic conditions that will permit an effective program of support for Indonesia's economic recovery," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
"The indications are that the President will announce his new Cabinet tomorrow," he said. "We look forward to seeking the composition of this Cabinet as a key measure of the direction they're going. And we hope the Cabinet will include a strong economic team as a signal of the Government's intention to undertake needed economic reforms."

HEADLINE: Zenith Approves Full-Scale Revamping

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: GLENVIEW, Ill., May 21

 BODY:
The Zenith Electronics Corporation, the struggling American television maker, approved a revamping plan today that would make its present shares worthless and its majority shareholder, LG Electronics Inc. of South Korea, the sole owner.
The proposal, which includes a prepackaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, calls for LG to convert about $200 million of debt owed to it by Zenith into all the common stock of the revamped company. 
 Zenith, based in Glenview, said all of its other creditors, as well as its vendors and employees, would continue to be paid. Present shareholders, however, would be left with nothing.
Zenith has lost money every year but one since 1985, compounding a financial squeeze faced by LG Electronics as South Korea grapples with a recession.
"This is why I came here," said Jeffrey Gannon, Zenith president and chief executive, who joined the company in January. "It was clear we had to find a way to restructure."
Zenith's shares plunged $1.375 yesterday, to close at 62.5 cents.

HEADLINE: Fed, at March Meeting, Saw Manageable Inflation Risk

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve saw an increased risk of resurgent inflation when it met on March 31, but decided to hold interest rates steady in the belief that Asian financial woes would help cool down the domestic economy and keep price increases in check, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The central bank's Federal Open Market Committee also decided at the meeting that the risks of inflation were great enough for it to signal that it expected its next move on monetary policy would be to raise rates. That decision, which normally would have been kept secret until the release of the meeting's minutes today, was disclosed earlier this month by The Wall Street Journal. 
 The Fed had previously taken the stance that it was equally likely to raise or lower rates.
"On balance, though any upsurge in inflation seemed unlikely in the nearer term, the risk that inflation might move higher over the longer run seemed to have increased," the minutes said.
The central bank voted again on Tuesday not to raise interest rates, apparently in the belief that economic growth was now moderating and that any tightening would risk further destabilizing Asia at a time of political unrest in Indonesia. The minutes of Tuesday's meeting will be released in July.
The Fed last changed rates in March 1997, when it raised the short-term Federal funds target rate to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent. Since then growth has surged and unemployment has fallen, but inflation has remained dormant.
Although the unemployment rate has declined to 4.3 percent since the March 31 meeting, increasing concern among those economists who believe that tight labor markets during robust growth inevitably lead to higher wages and prices, there have been other developments suggesting that growth is beginning to slow. Among them was a rise in the trade deficit for March to a new monthly high, indicating that demand for American products from abroad is waning.
Only one member of the 12-person committee, Jerry L. Jordan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, favored an immediate rate increase on March 31.
But the minutes suggested a livelier debate in the committee over how pressing the need for a rate increase might be. Some members were concerned that the low unemployment rate combined with continued strong demand would eventually set off a cycle of wage and price increases. They argued that the lack of price inflation resulted in part from temporary factors like a decline in oil prices. Others pointed to higher-than-expected growth in the money supply as a warning signal.
Another camp noted the absence of any broad-based price increases and said that a number of factors, including the effects of the Asian crisis and any decline in the stock market, could dampen demand and eliminate a need for any rate increase.
Over time, the Fed's rate-setting committee has been inclined toward compromise and consensus, and at the March 31 meeting it decided that the half-step of voting for a bias toward higher rates was sufficient. The vote was 11 to 1, with only Mr. Jordan dissenting.
The minutes said: "The members agreed that should the strength of the economic expansion and the firming of labor markets persist, policy tightening likely would be needed at some point to head off imbalances that over time would undermine the expansion in economic activity. Most saw little urgency to tighten at this meeting, however."
With inflation by some measures falling and the effects of the Asia crisis still uncertain, some members of the Fed committee thought they could be patient and wait for the situation to become clearer before seriously considering higher rates.
"In these circumstances," the minutes said, "a pre-emptive move to head off rising inflation could prove premature or perhaps even unwarranted; indeed, in the view of some, a tightening move was not inevitable."
Mr. Jordan has long been among the most hawkish of the Federal Reserve bank presidents on inflation, and analysts said they were not surprised that he wanted a rate increase.
Like a number of other members of the committee, he pays close attention to growth in the money supply, which has been discredited over the last decade as a predictor of inflation but now shows signs of again becoming a useful indicator.
Describing Mr. Jordan's position at the meeting, the minutes said: "While some reacceleration of reported rates of inflation was probably unavoidable, sustained rapid money growth would risk even higher inflation in future years. The durability of the economic expansion would be jeopardized by price and wage decisions reflecting expectations that the purchasing power of the dollar would decline at faster rates in the future."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Remain at Low Level

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing for state unemployment benefits rose in line with expectations last week, with first-time jobless claims increasing 8,000, to a seasonally adjusted 313,000, the Labor Department said today.
"Jobless claims remain at low levels, which signals continued strength in the labor market," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. 
 The four-week moving average for jobless claims, which smoothes out some of the volatility in the weekly report, fell to 311,500 last week from 313,000. Jobless claims fell a revised 5,000 in the previous week, to 305,000, instead of the initially reported decline of 2,000, to 307,000.
The Labor Department also said today that the number of people on the unemployment rolls increased 12,000, to 2.107 million, in the week ended May 9, close to the low of 2.035 million reached in May 1989. In the latest week, 27 states or territories had an increase in new jobless claims, while 25 said claims fell.
The insured unemployment rate -- the number of people receiving benefits divided by the number of workers covered by the program -- was unchanged for the eighth week, at 1.8 percent. The number of unemployed workers continuing to receive benefits and the state-by-state data are reported with a one-week lag.

HEADLINE: Plan to Let Employers Give Tax-Free Transit Benefits Is Included in Congressional Bill

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on a measure that would substantially cut the cost of bus and subway travel in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation by allowing employers to give workers up to $65 a month in tax-free mass transit benefits instead of salary.
The provision will be part of a sweeping $200 billion transportation bill that Congress is hurrying to finish by Friday night, in time for its Memorial Day recess. Though the broad outlines of the bill have been agreed to, House and Senate negotiators were still struggling tonight with several thorny issues, including how to allocate $167 billion in highway spending among the states over the next six years. 
 Fights also broke out today over a raft of amendments to the highway bill intended to scale back or delay Federal environmental programs, from dredging toxic PCB's from the Housatonic River in Massachusetts to establishing tougher standards for the pollutants that cause smog and haze.
Several New York State Democrats denounced the PCB amendment, which was offered by Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from Glens Falls, saying that it could lead to delays in removing PCB-contaminated soil from the Hudson River.
The General Electric Company is responsible for most of the PCB contamination in both the Housatonic and the Hudson, and will be required to pay for any cleanup ordered by the Federal Government.
Congressional aides also said tonight that they had reached broad agreement on funding for bus and subway programs, though details were not immediately available.
The aides said the agreement was expected to call for spending at least $36 billion on mass transit over the next six years, close to the amount sought by New York officials. If approved, the agreement will lead to a significant increase in Federal transit spending in New York and around the country.
Advocates of mass transit hailed today's deal on the tax-free transit benefits, saying it would encourage more employers to provide such benefits, and would sharply lower commuting costs for hundreds of thousands of people and cause a surge in transit ridership across the region.
"This is a big deal for the region," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders advocacy group. "This is a major fare cut for a very large number of people."
Though the tax-free benefit, known as Transitchek in the New York region, has been available for years, it has not caught on much because of quirks in the law, Congressional officials said. Currently, 7,000 companies and 150,000 workers participate -- numbers that transit advocates expect to double or triple with the new changes.
Under current tax law, companies can offer an employee up to $65 a month in Transitcheks, which are vouchers that can be redeemed for transit rides. But the law allows the benefit to be offered only on top of existing wages and benefits, forcing employees to negotiate higher salaries to receive it. That has discouraged not just individual workers, but also labor unions from asking for the benefit, the advocates say.
Under the new plan, employers will be able to remove $65 a month from a worker's existing pretax salary and give it to them as transit passes that are not subject to Federal, state or local taxes.
The arrangement not only cuts a worker's transit expenses but also benefits employers: their payroll costs will be reduced because they will not have to pay Social Security, unemployment or other taxes on the $65. The plan calls for increasing the benefit to $100 per month starting in 2002.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who championed the bill in Congress, said the plan would save the average commuter $600 a year by 2002. "It will make mass transit a more attractive mode of commuting and help reduce road congestion at the same time."
Mr. Russianoff said he thought the savings from the plan -- which he said could range from 25 cents to 60 cents per ride for a typical New Yorker -- would encourage more people to buy the monthly unlimited-ride passes that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to begin offering in July. Those passes will cost $63; with Transitchek, the cost would fall to $45 or less, he said.
The battle over the environmental amendments was expected to last well into the night and threatened to hold up passage of the overall transportation bill. The tactic of attaching anti-environmental provisions to big-spending bills just before they are sent to the White House has been used repeatedly in recent years to avoid contentious debate, sometimes successfully.
Mr. Solomon's amendment would delay the dredging of toxic chemicals like PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, which have been linked to cancer, from any river in the nation for 18 months, while the National Academy of Sciences completes a study on the benefits of such dredging.
Mr. Solomon has said he opposes dredging in the Hudson or Housatonic because he is concerned that the Environmental Protection Agency plans to dump the PCB-contaminated soil among the dairy farms of his district. "My entire farming community is at risk," he wrote in a letter to Representative Bud Shuster, a Pennsylvania Republican who is a lead negotiator on the transportation bill.
But word of Mr. Solomon's amendment has generated a storm of opposition from the Clinton Administration, several New York Congressmen and state legislators, raising doubts about whether it will survive in the final bill.
"This is the strongest attempt yet to get G.E. off the hook, in terms of the damage it has done to the Northeast," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat who represents Queens and Brooklyn.
Another amendment, offered by Representative Bob Wise, a Democrat of West Virginia, would block the E.P.A. from carrying out a policy intended to cut emissions of smog that drifts across state lines, causing air pollution problems in Northeastern states that are downwind from power plants and other pollution sources in the Midwest.
Yet another would stop the agency from issuing new regulations on pollution that is emitted from some outdoor paints as they dry. And a third would delay the E.P.A.'s efforts under the Clean Air Act to get some states where the air meets health standards to take further action to control pollution that cuts visibility in parks and wilderness areas.

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE LOANS;
U.S. Wants Concrete Steps by New Leaders Before It Lends More

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the United States will watch for concrete signs that Indonesia's new President is committed to addressing his nation's deep-rooted economic problems before deciding on further financial aid, Administration officials and economists said today.
The new President, B. J. Habibie, pledged today to honor the existing agreement with the fund, under which Indonesia has so far received $3.9 billion in loans out of a $9.9 billion package it signed in January. 
 But the fund announced hours before the resignation of President Suharto today that it had suspended the next disbursement -- $1 billion, scheduled for June -- until the political situation is clearer.
And Government officials and private analysts said today that the fund is skeptical about the depth of Mr. Habibie's commitment to root out corruption and to reverse some of the poor economic judgments that undermined and ultimately brought down the Suharto Government. Mr. Habibie, a protege of Mr. Suharto, is not known for his economic acumen.
Officials at the fund declined to comment today, beyond repeating statements they made on Wednesday suggesting that any resumption of aid would have to await the formation of a stable Government.
Both the I.M.F. and the United States pulled most of their economists and analysts out of Jakarta last week as anti-Government demonstrations worsened. Officials said both teams are expected to return within a week and quickly establish contact with Mr. Habibie and his cabinet.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who plays a substantial role in shaping I.M.F. policy, said it was too soon to say how the fund should proceed, but added that the change in Government was a "great opportunity for Indonesia to get back on track."
The fund's loan package was part of a $43 billion program set up earlier this year; it includes aid from the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and individual nations. About a quarter of that amount has been disbursed.
The United States pledged $3 billion as a backup to the money being provided by the international financial institutions but has not released any of it.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said Washington would wait for changes in Indonesia's political and economic policy before supporting further loans by international institutions.
"We look forward to the Government quickly creating conditions that will support Indonesia's economic recovery," the spokesman said. "That's why we hope that he will choose a cabinet that includes a strong economic team.
"And you know, the situation remains one where we need just to have a Government to work with, to make judgments about how to have progress toward the political and economic conditions that would permit an effective program."
The biggest uncertainty is whether Mr. Habibie will continue Mr. Suharto's practice of implementing the changes demanded by the I.M.F. grudgingly, haltingly and incompletely, or whether he will surprise the skeptics and, if only as a matter of political survival, lead the nation into major economic changes.
"They're going to have to get a fix on whether Habibie and the new team are serious about reform or whether this is just a game of musical chairs," said Morris Goldstein, a former top official at the fund who is now a fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Mr. Goldstein said the fund would have to take into account that Indonesia's economic situation has deteriorated since the original agreement was signed four months ago.
But he said the basic issues had not changed: Indonesian companies have about $80 billion in foreign debts that they are having difficulty paying. The banking system remains a mess, with many institutions insolvent. Economic decisions are still being made with an eye toward benefiting Government officials and their families and associates. The currency remains weak, reflecting skepticism that Indonesia is serious about swallowing its medicine.
"Everything is dependent on whether Habibie and company can convince the markets they are serious about reform," Mr. Goldstein said.
"If he's not really serious and he's not going to take ownership of the program, then there's an enormous problem. If he changes his spots and gives some indication of that by appointing people to the cabinet who are serious about reform, then he could get a turnaround and the markets will help him."

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE LEGACY;
Suharto Fostered Rapid Economic Growth, and Staggering Graft

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Like the Shah of Iran and Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, President Suharto was a reforming autocrat who clung to power so long that he undermined his legacy and considerable accomplishments.
Asia's economic crisis was the catalyst that pushed Mr. Suharto, 76, from his throne after 32 years. But in his family's unrestrained corruption and his increasingly aloof efforts to manage the forces of education and modernization he had unleashed under his "new order," Mr. Suharto alienated large parts of the military and the business class. 
 Mr. Suharto has been unceremoniously pushed from the presidency he insisted on keeping barely two months ago, when he was sworn in for another five years in the midst of enormous economical and financial turbulence. But he will be remembered for deeds and events that have little to do with the turmoil of the last few months.
He brought stability and economic development, family planning and widespread literacy and made Indonesia self-sufficient in rice.
After he overthrew Sukarno, who was a strong member of the nonaligned movement and made an alliance with Communists, Mr. Suharto made Indonesia an anti-Communist bulwark, which brought him Washington's support and indulgence. Like the Shah and Marcos, Mr. Suharto played the anti-Communism card, throwing his lot in with the Americans in the revolutionary struggle that absorbed Southeast Asia in those years.
Later, when the Vietnam War ended, he was an important player in the foundation of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which promoted capitalism in the region and helped prevent the Communist victory in Indochina from spreading. He helped keep China at bay and also was vital to a negotiated solution to the Cambodian war.
But at home Mr. Suharto suppressed freedom of speech and of the press, and his military cracked down ruthlessly on domestic dissent. He allowed his friends and his family, especially his six children, to become unimaginably rich in a country with large pockets of poverty, and as the years went by, he clearly stopped listening to criticism, even from his closest allies.
His regime was built on the pillars of anti-Communism and economic development, notes Daniel Lev, an Indonesian scholar at the University of Washington in Seattle. The end of the cold war made one pillar nearly irrelevant, and the economic contagion that swept Asia this year -- a function of "crony capitalism" and unregulated loans -- undermined the other pillar.
So an important part of Mr. Suharto's legacy, Mr. Lev says, will be the political reaction to it: the mistrust of a strong presidency and the strong popular desire for new controls against corruption, collusion and nepotism, the themes of the student uprisings against Mr. Suharto's regime.
While Mr. Suharto's recent record is mixed, his accomplishments were remarkable in the years after he took power after a failed coup attempt in 1965. In the months of anti-Communist blood bath that followed, hundreds of thousands of people died.
Even today, his role in the coup is a mystery. As the commander of the Strategic Army Reserve, Mr. Suharto met the night before the coup with the leader of the Communist Revolutionary Council, Abu Latief, who still sits in a Jakarta jail and has never disclosed what happened.
As the alleged coup unfolded in the night, Mr. Suharto and his troops stepped forward and took control of Jakarta. He quietly emerged to become President only in 1967, easing aside Sukarno, the nationalist who led Indonesia to independence from Dutch rule after World War II.
Sidney Jones, an scholar of Indonesia who is executive director of Human Rights Watch/Asia, notes that if a new Indonesian leadership wishes to make peace with the past, it would probably have to investigate Mr. Suharto's role in the coup and its aftermath, which remains Indonesia's "greatest national trauma."
"While his record is clearly mixed, he brought order, peace, stability and economic development to a fractured and desperately poor society," said Adam Schwarz, a journalism fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and author of "A Nation in Waiting" (1994), a study of Indonesia in the 1990's. "Suharto presided over one of the most durable developmental stories of this century, and he brought enormous numbers of people out from life underneath the poverty line."
Calling himself Bapak Pembangunan, or the Father of Development, Mr. Suharto succeeded in delivering at least 7 percent annual economic growth for three decades in a huge island country of 210 million, the fourth-most populous in the world. He initiated a family planning program that has been studied everywhere as a model of educated self-interest, and which did not use any significant measure of coercion, in contrast to India and China.
And he made the Indonesian economy one of the most open to foreign investment, winning friends at the World Bank and at the International Monetary Fund.
At the same time, Mr. Suharto and his children built up assets that the Central Intelligence Agency estimated at $30 billion in 1989.
"Despite the growth figures, which stick in the head," notes Mr. Lev, "it is also impressive that the family is worth $30 billion to $40 billion. And you have to ask what other uses there were for that money, and what the hidden costs were of that corruption."
Mr. Suharto also suppressed the growth of politics, believing the country too fractious and immature for democracy, Mr. Schwarz said. Mr. Suharto preached unity and quiet compromise, and kept political institutions neutered: there were no roll calls in Parliament, only decisions reached by "consensus" that was clearly engineered from above.
His "new order" was a collaborative system of co-optation, a prominent Jakarta editor said in 1990, when the corruption and nepotism were becoming visible for all to see. People lived and profited by the five D's: datang, duduk, dengar, diam, duit -- come, sit, listen, silence, money.
In what was a monopolistic state, there was quiet criticism of Mr. Suharto's wife, Siti Hartinah Suharto, known as Tien, and sometimes known as Mrs. Tien Percent. But after the rapid rise of world oil prices in the mid-1970's, Mr. Suharto's Western-educated economic advisers -- known as the Berkeley mafia, since many of them attended school there -- urged diversification and a further opening to Western investments.
The progressive deregulation of the economy and large public works projects -- praised in the West -- also led to more opportunities for graft and family privilege. And foreign companies quietly paid the necessary bribes and put the necessary Suharto children in charge of projects and monopolies.
The country moved from the "generation of 10 percent to the generation of 20 percent," said one Indonesian scholar who was careful to speak on the condition of anonymity. He estimated then that 80 percent of major contracts went to Mr. Suharto's children or friends, and even Suharto loyalists were becoming disgruntled.
But the long economic boom -- when all of Asia seemed a merrily ringing cash register and annual growth rates hit double digits -- created a lot of wealth and a growing middle class.
And with the pressure for political liberalization stemming naturally from economic development and generational change, there grew apace a vivid embarrassment and anger over Mr. Suharto's inability to distinguish between his family's interests and those of the state.
But as the society changed, politics did not, and the country was unable to engage in any public debate over key questions, Mr. Schwarz said. These included the role of the ethnic Chinese in Indonesian life; the relation of Islam and the state; the degree of Government intervention in the economy; the relationship of Java to the outer islands, and of course the role of the Suharto children.
In the 1990's, noted Ms. Jones, of Human Rights Watch, the corruption and the anger only worsened. Popular anger grew sufficiently that when Mrs. Suharto died in 1996 of a heart attack, many Indonesians preferred to believe rumors that she had been caught in a gunfight between her two younger sons over a national automobile project.
The 90's were also the period when Mr. Suharto began to make political mistakes, listening less to the Berkeley mafia and more to the trusted ally who became his heir, President B. J. Habibie. Mr. Habibie, a German-trained engineer, filled Mr. Suharto's head with a high-tech vision of a modern Indonesia, prompting hugely expensive boondoggles like Government support for Mr. Habibie's effort to build an Indonesian jet aircraft.
Mr. Suharto began to lose touch with his military, and he created a tame Association of Muslim Intellectuals, led by Mr. Habibie, to try to provide a different kind of support and legitimacy in the largest Muslim country in the world.
In November 1991, Indonesian troops opened fire in an East Timor cemetery on mourners for a young independence advocate shot by the army. At least 50 and probably 100 people died, Ms. Jones said. The massacre brought international condemnation of Indonesian policies in East Timor, which it had annexed by force in 1975 after Portugal retreated from its empire. In 1996 two proponents for democracy in East Timor won the Nobel Peace Prize. The killings also turned a small insurgency into widespread revolt throughout East Timor.
With no cold war and no Communist threat, the killings and oppression in East Timor, and the less visible repression in Irian Jaya, Indonesia's half of the island of New Guinea, turned the American Congress against Indonesia, leaving Mr. Suharto little protection when the Asian boom collapsed and the I.M.F. that once loved him demanded that he choose country over children.
Mr. Habibie, who has little popular backing, may last only a few months. As Mr. Suharto's heir, he is perceived as the man appointed to protect Mr. Suharto's children.
Ms. Jones hopes he will begin a new dialogue with the Indonesian people, release political prisoners, repeal repressive laws, set free elections and begin a serious discussion of the issue of East Timor. "But even if he does move out boldly," she asked, "will anyone trust him?"

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Seek to Make Light Trucks Safer in Crashes

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 21

 BODY:
Auto makers have quietly begun trying to design sport utility vehicles that will be less dangerous to other motorists.
Ford has secretly begun redesigning the suspensions for the Ford Explorer and Expedition, the Mercury Mountaineer, the Lincoln Navigator and future sport utility models so the vehicles will ride as much as several inches lower and be less likely to override cars' bumpers and other safety features during crashes, a Ford manager said. General Motors has designed a prototype for a new Chevrolet Suburban that also rides lower and is test-driving it. 
 Both auto makers are trying to make the bulk of the vehicle, including the bumper and steel underbody frame, ride closer to the wheels in future model years while making sure that the lowest parts of the vehicle, including the axles, ride as high as they do now to preserve the ground clearance prized by off-road drivers.
Chrysler and foreign auto makers also say they have begun looking for ways to reduce the hazards of sport utility vehicles, although their plans are not known.
"Clearly this subject has the attention of the industry," said Jerry Hirshberg, president of Nissan's North American design operations. "It's talked about in board meetings. It's talked about in engineering meetings. It's even talked about in sales and marketing meetings. I can't think of any engineers right now that are not interested in or conversant with this issue."
Sport utility vehicles are nearly three times as likely as midsized cars to kill the other driver in a collision because they are heavier, taller and have very stiff frames, Federal regulators say. Redesigning sport utility vehicles to make them less deadly to other motorists is not easy because of simple physics: heavier objects tend to inflict more damage in collisions. And loopholes in Federal fuel-economy rules allow sport utility vehicles to get considerably lower gas mileage than cars, so they weigh up to twice as much as a midsized car.
Some experts question whether sport utility vehicles with lower suspensions will be significantly safer as long as the weight difference remains. "You just lower the battering ram," said James Hall, a former G.M. executive who is now a consultant at Auto Pacific Inc., a market research firm.
But Judith L. Stone, president of Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, a Washington group, said lowering the suspensions on sport utility vehicles would not only make them less dangerous to other motorists but would also make them less likely to roll over by lowering their centers of gravity. "It's certainly a major safety decision and likely to contribute to the saving of lives," Ms. Stone said when told of the plans by Ford and G.M.
Indeed, new research by the auto industry has found that the design of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which are often built on the same chassis, has increased their deadliness.
An internal study by Ford has found that collisions between cars and light trucks kill 1,000 more car occupants each year than can be explained by the weight differences of the vehicles alone. That was apparently because the light trucks are higher and have stiffer frames, said Priya Prasad, Ford's top safety engineer on collisions between different types of vehicles. Light trucks include not only sport utility vehicles and pickups but also mini-vans, although Ford does not think mini-vans are a problem.
If light trucks were made less likely to override cars in accidents, the death rate in cars would be reduced without increasing the death rate in light trucks, Mr. Prasad said. Making the frames of light trucks less stiff would also reduce the number of deaths in cars but might slightly increase the number of deaths in light trucks, he said. Still, fewer Americans would die in traffic accidents over all if light trucks were less stiff, he said.
Mr. Prasad said he was still calculating the relative contributions of height and stiffness to the 1,000 deaths a year and hoped to have the answers in time for an international conference here on light truck safety on June 5.
Most of the extra deaths involve sport utility vehicles and pickups because mini-vans are based on car designs, Mr. Prasad said. Changing pickup truck designs could be more controversial because a far greater percentage of pickups are used for commercial purposes like farming and construction and need stiff, high-riding frames to carry heavy loads over rocky or muddy ground.
Mr. Prasad cautioned that for this and other reasons, some design-related deaths were inevitable. "My estimate is at the most, if all the design changes can be made -- and I don't think all the changes can be made -- then you're talking 1,000 people" saved each year, he said. Because light trucks commonly last 12 to 15 years, it could take that long to replace the tall, stiff vehicles already on the road, he added.
A thousand lives a year is a large number for an automotive design problem. By contrast, the furor two years ago over accidental deaths caused by air bags involved about two dozen deaths a year. On the other hand, persuading American drivers to change their behavior could result in even bigger safety gains. For example, Federal regulators estimate that if the rate of seat-belt use rose to 85 percent, from 68 percent now, 4,000 lives could be saved every year.
Traffic accidents kill 40,000 Americans each year, as many each day as died in the 1996 Valujet crash in the Everglades. About 5,000 of those deaths occur in collisions between cars and light trucks. An additional 2.3 million Americans are injured each year on the roads; the Government gathers less data on these injuries, so safety researchers pay less attention to them. But auto industry engineers say that mismatches in vehicles' height and stiffness can increase the severity of injuries.
Hans Joksch, a University of Michigan researcher who has been a leader in traffic safety since the early 1970's and has begun looking at the light truck issue, said that Mr. Prasad's estimate of 1,000 design-related deaths a year seemed "at the low end of the range" and that there might be considerably more deaths.
There are more pickups than sport utility vehicles on the road, and pickups are more likely to be driven by young men, who have the most accidents. But sport utility vehicles are a growing concern because they are getting bigger, because their sales are surging and approaching the level of pickup sales, and because safety experts say that with time, many used sport utility vehicles will be affordable for young men.
The auto industry has come under growing pressure from regulators to improve safety or face new regulations. Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said auto makers should follow the example of the new Mercedes-Benz ML320 sport utility vehicle, which was designed to inflict less damage on cars.
"I'm always amazed when people say, 'It's pure physics, we can't do anything about it,' because it's out there, it's on the street," he said.
In most sport utility vehicles, a frame of steel beams sits on top of the suspension springs. Mercedes has calculated that the typical four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicle has a front cross-beam, right behind the bumper, that is 21 to 28 inches off the ground. By contrast, Federal regulations require car bumpers to withstand impacts at a height of 16 to 20 inches off the ground. The front ends of cars are designed to crumple and absorb the energy of a crash when hit at bumper height but may not crumple properly when hit higher. The steel beams do most of the damage in a collision.
The Mercedes has a very different suspension that attaches the springs to the side of the frame. The steel beams ride lower inside the underbody of the Mercedes, with the front cross-beam just 19.5 inches high, even though the overall vehicle still has the same ground clearance as other sport utility vehicles.
Ronald Harbour, an auto industry manufacturing consultant, said that fitting similar suspensions on other sport utility vehicles would cost $100 to $250 for each vehicle, plus considerable engineering work.
Bernard Robertson, Chrysler's general manager of Jeep and pickup truck operations, said that after initially viewing sport utility vehicle collisions with cars as a problem of physics, auto makers had begun looking for ways to address the problem. "Everyone is very interested in the subject; there has been a fair amount of consciousness-raising over the last year," he said. Chrysler agreed earlier this month to be acquired by Daimler-Benz, which owns Mercedes.
Mr. Prasad and Ford spokesmen refused to discuss what Ford would do about the safety problem uncovered by the company's new research, saying they did not want to disclose their plans to rivals. But a senior Ford manager who insisted on anonymity said the company had just begun a two-stage plan to lower current and future sport utilities by several inches over the next few years.
The first stage involves resetting suspension springs on future vehicles for a slightly lower ride. That will be done as soon as feasible, the manager said. The second stage involves changing the dimensions of many suspension parts for an even lower ride and will be done over the coming years as models are redesigned, he said.
"The more we can get the alignment with the bumpers and where the crash energies are absorbed, the more it helps the problem with large vehicles and small vehicles," the manager added.
Other auto makers are taking similar steps. Joseph Spielman, G.M.'s vice president for metal parts fabrication, said that he had seen a working prototype for a new Suburban to be produced soon. The new model rides substantially lower, partly to reduce the risk to other motorists and partly to make it easier for Suburban drivers and passengers to climb in and out, he said.
Chrysler has already been working on different suspension designs for various reasons, Mr. Robertson said. Installing lower bumpers on sport utility vehicles does little good without lowering the steel beams behind the bumpers, he added.
Auto makers have also quietly begun work on lowering pickups, although the heavy payloads carried by these vehicles have made that task more difficult. The suspension design chosen by Mercedes, for example, is less suited to carrying extremely heavy weights.
In an interview last month, Mr. Prasad of Ford said that lowering light trucks would make them less dangerous in frontal collisions but might help less when they hit cars in the side. Lower-riding light trucks would do more damage to car occupants' pelvises during side impacts while still hitting them in the chest and head as well, he said. Ford plans to begin offering side air bags in all of its cars over the next three years and is studying ways to strengthen the sides of cars.
The design teams for Ford's light truck chassis have also been assigned engineers to look for ways to improve safety in crashes with other types of vehicles, and these engineers meet regularly with safety experts from Ford's headquarters.
Auto makers are also studying ways to make sport utility vehicles with less stiff bodies. Stiff vehicles tend to punch deeply into cars during collisions. Seat belts and air bags are less effective when another vehicle intrudes into a car's passenger compartment, Mr. Prasad said.
But he and auto industry executives said that it would be difficult to make sport utility vehicles less stiff without changing current Government crash tests.
Because of their relatively high rollover rate, sport utility vehicles have higher death rates for their occupants than cars of the same weight, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which is financed by auto insurers. The largest sport utility vehicles have slightly lower death rates than cars but weigh so much more that they drastically increase the risk for other motorists.

Auto makers are trying to reduce the danger that sport utility vehicles pose to other motorists, mainly by designing them to ride lower so that they are less likely during collisions to override the bumpers and other safety features of cars.
 
BUMPERS - A lower ride will make the high bumpers of sport utility vehicles less likely to override car bumpers.
 
CHASSIS - Auto makers are trying to develop chassis that, through the use of crumple zones, would be less stiff while still passing Government crash tests.
 
SUSPENSIONS - Suspensions will be readjusted to allow for a lower ride, at first by resetting the springs and later by designing new suspension parts.
 
AIR BAGS - Ford plans to offer side air bags in all of its cars and mini-vans to protect the heads and chests of occupants from the high front ends of sport utility vehicles and pickups.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Testy Forgotten Land

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER; A. M. Rosenthal is on vacation.

 BODY:
When someone says "Indians," most Americans probably think of gambling-casino operators. So isolationist have we become.
Even Washington's best minds were astonished to learn that the Indians were exploding atom bombs. 
 On first hearing the news, President Clinton is said to have cried out, "Thank God they didn't get the H-bomb while Crazy Horse was still on the warpath!"
That, at least, is what President Clinton should have cried out, if only to emphasize how completely he is in touch with the American people.
I am not saying we are so dumb we don't remember that a place called "India" can be found on a map by anybody who scored 1590 on the S.A.T.'s.
India is where "Gunga Din" was set.
Or was it Pakistan? Whatever.
So after remembering that yes, Virginia, there is an India, Washington biggies were very cross. India had been very rude. That was the considered and official opinion. Very rude.
If India had been a schoolboy, the teacher would have sent a testy note home to its mother.
Instead, President Clinton is going to cut off India's goodies. That's Washington's usual punishment for countries that irritate it. When you've got a country that needs to be taught a good lesson, cut off its goodies.
Cuba, Iraq, Libya, Iran -- no more goodies for them until they start behaving themselves. This goes double for Cuba, because it has chafed Washington almost beyond endurance by surviving for four decades in spite of having its goodies cut off.
India is not the only country that bores Americans except when it's irritating them. Who can name the President of France, the Prime Minister of Canada? Who cares what's happened lately in Cairo, Athens, Krasnoyarsk?
The people who run the world's big international corporations, that's who. As our most fervent capitalists are always explaining, the future lies in the global marketplace, kids, so don't let hometown sentimentality about American jobs and industry make you do something stupid.
We now have a commercial culture that is totally internationalist and a political culture so isolationist that O. J. Simpson, Paula Jones and Monica Lewinsky -- Americans all -- dominate the media for weeks, months, years.
Two of them have dominated the White House so thoroughly that nobody there thought to wonder what India had been up to lately.
If there had been a fierce cola struggle between Pepsi and Coke for monopoly rights in Calcutta, American business would have known about it immediately. International trouble is the business of American business.
Big-time U.S. businesses with political muscle have forced the politicians to stay awake about matters Chinese, but without smart capitalists leaning on them, the Clinton people seemed to forget that India was around.
So did the press. The media are mostly just as isolationist as the rest of the political culture. Jim Wooten of ABC seems to be the last foreign correspondent left anywhere in the world for network news.
The story that doesn't entertain has a hard time getting coverage, electronic or print. The theme song of the American media these days should be "Let Me Entertain You."
Before isolationism became stifling, tube-watching America would probably have seen somebody in New Delhi pointing out that while the U.S. might adore nuclear China, India tended to view it as a potentially hostile power on its border.
Doesn't sound very entertaining, does it?
Most of what passes for foreign news is stuff of the Princess Di variety. Newsstands are infested with it. The networks may stint on coverage of everything east of New York and west of Washington, but give them a Princess Di funeral and they dispatch their anchors across oceans. Anchors, for Heaven's sake! Men who earn nearly as much as baseball players.
Give them a Pope going head-to-head with exasperating Castro, and off go the anchors to Cuba until Monica makes the scene in D.C., whereupon it's "So long, Holy Father, we hear America crying, 'Monica, you anchors! Give us total Monica!' "
The rain forest burns. Mexico falls into ruin. India tests an H-bomb. The old arms race begins again.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Hostess of Her Own Party, 6 Nights a Week

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
THIS is a pick-up-the-pieces-and-get-on-with-your-life story. If it were a television pilot, the first scene would flash back four years, when a smart and ambitious New Jersey girl picks up the telephone to learn that her live-in lover of two and a half years, the brilliant Le Bernardin chef Gilbert Le Coze, has had what his staff calls "an accident." The young woman rushes to the hospital, but is too late. Mr. Le Coze, 49, is already dead of a heart attack. The woman, unemployed and 26, thinks her world has come to an end.
Flash forward to May 1998. Our heroine, now barely 30, is the owner of Lot 61, an art-filled former truck garage in Chelsea -- a three-month-old bar and restaurant of the minute. She holds the party after the premiere of "Godzilla," and the dinner after Giorgio Armani's April fashion show. She stands 6 feet 4 inches tall (in her three-inch green lizard-skin heels) and wears a gauzy leopard-skin dress made by her busboy. She looks good, gets good reviews and has a new boyfriend. Most important, she is doing what she has always wanted: running her own business, and presiding as hostess of her own party, six nights a week. The spirit of Mr. Le Coze, she believes, will always be with her. 
 "I'm a sitcom," Amy Sacco said.
On Wednesday evening, Ms. Sacco took a few hours out over a selection of appetizers -- the "hacked duck" spring rolls were the most interesting -- to talk about the plot lines of her life. It was 8 P.M., and Lot 61 was dotted with twentyish types in black and taupe; Drew Carey of the television show was at a table by the bar. On a wall hung "Chachi" by the painter Sean Landers, which the artist swapped for a five-figure food and bar bill. Ms. Sacco sat in a corner keeping her eye on the staff, then frowned upward when a sudden hailstorm started to pound her new roof. "I'm waiting to feel it on top of my head," Ms. Sacco said. "That's my baby. The roof is my biggest baby."
Ms. Sacco is at heart a businesswoman who likes a really good party -- a woman thrilled that her busboy-designer calls her "his own personal Barbie doll," less thrilled when the salad is so salty she takes it off the menu. She works from 11 A.M. to 2 A.M., and never liked school. But she did like restaurants.
"She is extremely intelligent," said her best friend, Maguy Le Coze, the owner of Le Bernardin and the sister of Mr. Le Coze. "It's not something that everybody has. What can I tell you? She likes what she's doing so much, it's almost like she's breathing through what she has chosen to do. She cannot speak about something else right now."
THE crucial character in Ms. Sacco's life is her mother, Bette, known for her baked ziti dinners for the Chatham High School basketball team. (Ms. Sacco's father owned a moving company.) Ms. Sacco was the youngest of 8, and her mother never had fewer than 12 at her table. "There was always room for someone extra," Ms. Sacco said. "People loved coming to our house. Because my mother was just great. If someone had a problem, they would call my mother."
Naturally the pomme does not fall far from the tree. Mom was the neighborhood hostess in suburban Chatham; her daughter grows up to be the neighborhood hostess among the art galleries of Chelsea. "Being a manager is like being a mother anyway," Ms. Sacco said. Of course this is the late 1990's, and daughter gets investors who put in $1.2 million. But that is getting ahead of the story.
"She was an unusual child," Mrs. Sacco said. "Highly spirited, very precocious. She was always annoyed with small-town stuff. She always said she was going to go someplace, and be somebody."
Amy Sacco was very soon towering over the boys in her high school class, and heading across the Hudson, midweek, to the New York clubs. Area and Palladium were favorites. And her mother knew?
"As if," she said.
Ms. Sacco worked after school at New Jersey restaurants -- she sliced scallions at the Tarragon Tree -- then went to Johnson and Wales, a restaurant school in Providence, R.I. When she graduated in 1990, she got a job through a friend at Bouley, the epicenter at the time of the New York food world. After that she was manager of the Lipstick Cafe and the restaurant Vong. She met Mr. Le Coze through friends at Bouley.
After his death, she got a job managing the Monkey Bar, then running System, a discotheque. "It was very glamorous," she said dryly. "Go to work at 8 P.M., dress in plastic, come home at 6 in the morning." Ms. Sacco then went to work for a venture capital firm as a marketing consultant. One of her jobs was to get Swiss Army sunglasses and knives into the movie "Armageddon." It was partly through the venture capital firm, and restaurant friends, that she found her investors, whom she described as "your average business guys."
Ms. Sacco had a party for her investors in December -- "300 suits," she calls them -- and was horrified when she arrived that day to find three inches of water all over her 5,500 square feet of floor. "I got out three or four dry-vacs and took out my whip," she said.
A bittersweet moment was opening night, without Mr. Le Coze. "It was the achievement of my life, the fact that I got this place off the ground," she said. "And not to have my biggest mentor in the world there to share it with me was devastating." And yet, she said, "he would have been devastated if I'd shut down my life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Amy Sacco, the owner of Lot 61, a bar and restaurant in Chelsea. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Motorola Drops Plan for Its Own Data Satellites

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to scrap its $12.9 billion plan to build a satellite network capable of delivering high-speed data communications anywhere on earth and instead join a rival but equally ambitious project to build an "Internet in the sky."
Motorola said it would invest about $750 million in exchange for 26 percent of the project, Teledesic L.L.C., which was founded by Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, and Craig O. McCaw, the cellular phone pioneer who sold his company to AT&T in 1993 for $12.6 billion. 
 Motorola pushed aside the Boeing Company to become Teledesic's prime contractor. Teledesic said yesterday that Boeing would remain an important participant in the project but it was clear that Motorola had become its main partner.
Matra Marconi Space, the joint venture of the General Electric Company of Britain and Groupe Lagardere of France, also announced yesterday that it had agreed to take part in the project.
Joining Teledesic could allow Motorola to save billions of dollars at a time when the company is struggling and casting about for a model of growth for the future. As the world's appetite for data services continues to grow, many companies are looking to the skies as the next way to deliver high-speed access to the Internet, especially in places where fiber optic links are not common.
Teledesic intends to build a network of 288 advanced communications satellites that can begin to provide high-speed, or broadband, access to the Internet and other data services in 2003.
Teledesic is one of a handful of new ventures known as LEO companies, for low earth orbit. Many of today's most heavily used satellites, including the Galaxy 4 that failed on Tuesday night, eliminating pager service for millions of Americans, are known as geostationary satellites.
These satellites are placed in a high orbit of around 22,000 miles, in the hope that they will remain pointed at the same place on the earth's surface at all times. Geostationary satellites have proved valuable for a variety of tasks including broadcasting radio and television programs. But some analysts believe they are not well suited to providing quick two-way communications because signals that bounce off them must travel more than 40,000 miles on their round trip between earth and outer space.
Teledesic wants to put its satellites only about 850 miles above earth, allowing them to provide two-way communications with less delay. Some experts, though, are convinced that the complexity of managing a network of more than 250 satellites will eventually prove overwhelming, and yesterday's announcement did little to allay their concerns.
"There was a decision from both of them that there was probably no room for two guys in the market and maybe not for one," said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a high technology consulting firm in Boston. "It's the blind leading the visibly impaired."
Motorola said last year that it would spend almost $13 billion to develop a satellite network of its own for high-speed data communications, known as Celestri. The $750 million that Motorola intends to invest in Teledesic will be a combination of cash and the value of research it will share with Teledesic. Christopher Galvin, Motorola's chief executive, would not disclose the mix at a news conference yesterday.
Motorola is also developing a separate satellite network, known as Iridium, for providing mobile telephone and paging services anywhere on the globe. That project will not be affected by the company's Teledesic ties.
Just over a year ago, Teledesic announced that Boeing had become the project's prime contractor. Mr. McCaw said yesterday that Boeing should not feel slighted by the Motorola announcement.
"We're not jilting anyone," he said. "It's about deciding who's the quarterback and who's the fullback."
Harry Stonecipher, Boeing's president, said he was not disappointed by yesterday's developments. Boeing's contract with Teledesic would have been worth $9 billion, but much of that money would have gone to subcontractors hired by Boeing to complete specialized parts of the project. Analysts noted that losing the contract probably would not hurt Boeing's financial performance.
Indeed, Howard Rubel of Goldman, Sachs said Boeing might even have done well to limit its involvement in Teledesic by agreeing to launch the satellites while avoiding responsibility for the overall project.
Mr. Rubel said a system comparable to Teledesic's could perhaps be built using geostationary technology for less than a quarter of what Teledesic is spending. "And I'm not sure the speed or the costs to the customer are going to be that much different," he said.
"There are some interesting economics that still need to be proven out," Mr. Rubel said of Teledesic's business model. "Maybe that's why Boeing said, 'I'll launch these babies and I'll be a contract-for-hire here.' "

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 485 words

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Graciousness Gap

 BODY:
With crime down and the economy up, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has reigned over a revival of New York City. That said, it is time to note that seven months into his second term, the Mayor often exhibits an unnecessary imperiousness that ultimately cannot serve his city, his political aspirations or even his legacy.
What brings this tendency into focus this week is an attack on the Mayor by the Rev. Calvin Butts, a prominent Baptist minister from Harlem. Mr. Butts labeled Mr. Giuliani a "racist" and accused him of not liking black people and of instituting policies that have not only devastated minorities but are moving New York "toward a fascist state." 
 Mr. Butts's charges are opportunistic at best, reflecting his own political ambitions and perhaps even his efforts to push commercial development in his community. While Mr. Giuliani's relations with minority communities have been marked by clumsiness and needless tension, we do not think Mr. Butts can read the Mayor's mind or prove his highly personal charge from the public record.
But his overheated comments serve as a warning to City Hall that many New Yorkers feel bruised and excluded from Mayor Giuliani's tightly controlled vision of the city. They also offer a reminder, for the Mayor, that his job is no longer about winning an election but leading a city, an entire city, not just his natural supporters. Mr. Giuliani too automatically sees a critic as a foe. The ability to verbally whip an adversary does little to build consensus for changes in the way the city works that, however laudatory in the managerial sense, can be painful for those losing jobs or services.
Despite his ill-chosen words, Mr. Butts was explaining how minorities have fared under some of Mr. Giuliani's most recent policies. The dismissal of 600 hospital workers and 1,000 homeless workers, the push to end remedial classes at the City University of New York, the enduring questions about police brutality, the workfare-welfare rules -- these issues resonate in nonwhite neighborhoods around the city. The Mayor too often answers their questions, complaints or even anger with indignation when sympathetic diplomacy would be better.
The taxi protest scheduled for yesterday is a good example. Cab drivers canceled their demonstration when the Mayor threatened to have them arrested. They asked for a meeting instead -- undoubtedly a very good alternative. The Mayor refused. ". . . we broke their strike -- destroyed it," he exulted after many cabbies stayed home.
O.K., so he destroyed the strike. What do we do now about 44,000 fuming taxi drivers? Missing too often from the Mayor's political repertoire are the schmoozing skills -- the ability to smooth ruffled feelings after his victories, the defusing of incendiary language, the compromising around the edges that can make more people feel included in Mr. Giuliani's greater New York.
