HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks Rise in Gas Tax for Transit and Conservation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, May 21

 BODY:
Risking her reputation as a tax-cutter to promote conservation and transportation, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called today for an increase of 7 cents per gallon in New Jersey's gasoline tax to help finance transportation improvements and a plan to preserve almost half the undeveloped land left in the state.
Flanked by supporters from a rare and new coalition of business and environmental leaders, Governor Whitman divided her proposed tax increase to win the support of each group. A nickel of the 7-cent increase would raise $210 million a year for new buses and trains, as well as bridge and highway repairs. The other two cents would generate $84 million a year for an annual fund of $170 million to help buy and preserve one million acres of farmland and open space over the next decade. 
New Jersey's gasoline tax now is 14.5 cents a gallon, one of the lowest in the country and far cheaper than Connecticut's 36 cents a gallon, the nation's highest, and New York's 30.4 cents. The proposed 7-cent increase would only go into effect if approved by both the State Legislature and the voters.
Mrs. Whitman said her goal of saving one million acres from developers would insure that her administration left a legacy of a "clean and green and livable" New Jersey.
"We want to give the gift of a bountiful and beautiful and economically viable state of New Jersey to our children and our grandchildren and their grandchildren," she said in Liberty State Park, with southern Manhattan serving as a backdrop across the harbor. "We want to save half the available land so future development happens where it should instead of gobbling up every inch of open land. We can and will win the race for open space."
National authorities on open space said that a trend for land preservation is spreading around the country and that they believed Mrs. Whitman's goal was one of the most ambitious yet proposed by a governor.
"It's a very impressive number for a state the size of New Jersey," said Phyllis Myers, head of State Resource Strategies, a Washington company specializing in state and local conservation campaigns.
Melanie Griffin, director of land protection for the Sierra Club, called Mrs. Whitman's proposal a "bold plan."
"We're seeing more and more that moderate Republicans are trying to improve their environmental record against sprawl," Ms. Griffin said, adding that she knew of only two larger conservation drives, both by private groups -- one to save six million acres of wilderness in Utah and another to preserve three million acres of forest in central Maine.
In addition to the $84 million from the gasoline tax, the Governor wants to use $50 million in existing proceeds from the state's tax on real estate sales and to raise $36 million from a new $3-a-day surcharge on car rentals.
Because the all these new revenues would be constitutionally dedicated for 10 years, or devoted exclusively to open-space purchases and transportation improvements, the entire package must be approved by a 60 percent vote of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature and by voters in a special referendum in November.
Legislators must agree to put the issue on the ballot, and the plan's fate in the Republican-controlled Legislature is uncertain. The President of the Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said he favored the proposed 7-cent increase. Mr. DiFrancesco said he also favored using $50 million from the real estate tax for open-space purchases, but not as part of a dedicated 10-year fund. Instead, he said he wanted the Legislature to have the power to approve or withhold that money each year.
Democratic legislative leaders said they would withhold comment on the proposal until they had studied it more.
Governor Whitman's tax proposal is a significant reversal of policy for her. Her campaign promise of a 30 percent cut in state income taxes in 1993 is widely regarded as the single issue that won her election to her first term. During that term, she sought to control the rise in municipal property taxes by trying to impose state restrictions on local school spending.
Mrs. Whitman noted today that she had signed 17 different tax cuts during her tenure. Promising a new tax, she said, was not easy. But she called the proposed gasoline tax increase the fairest and most logical way to finance her open-space and transportation plans. And, she noted, out-of-state drivers would help pay it.
She also noted that her administration was not imposing a tax increase, but giving state residents the chance to vote on it.
Asked at a press conference whether she feared her proposal would tarnish her national reputation as a tax cutter, she replied, "I could care less." The remarks drew applause from the environmentalists and businessmen with her.
This coalition, a unique mix that normally shares little common ground politically, promised today to campaign for the plan both in the Legislature and, if successful there, with voters in the fall. The group is made up of 10 corporations, including Mobil Oil, DuPont, Bell Atlantic and three electrical companies, and 10 environmental groups. It is known as the Stockton Alliance, because it formed during a retreat four years ago at Stockton State College in southern New Jersey.
The group's co-chairman, Thomas J. Gilmore, president of the New Jersey Audubon Society, said winning approval of the dedicated open-space fund is the alliance's top priority. To help with the campaign, Mr. Gilmore said the alliance is recruiting dozens of other business and environmental leaders.
A Representative of each wing of the coalition stood beside Mrs. Whitman today on the podium: Michael Catania, executive director of the Nature Conservancy of New Jersey, and Philip K. Beachem, president of the New Jersey Alliance for Action, an umbrella organization representing corporations, building contractors, engineers, labor unions, and the academic community.
Mr. Beachem said his group's primary goal was getting more money for better highways, railroads and bridges. "But philosophically, linking it with open spaces makes a lot of sense," he said. Mr. Catania talked about a legacy of preserving broad expanses of open space. "This is not a partisan issue," he said.
Over the last three years of her term, Mrs. Whitman wants to save some 313,000 acres and leave office with a fund intact for the purchase and preservation of another 700,000 acres by 2008. Forty percent of the acreage would come from paying farmers not to sell their land to private developers.
An anti-tax group, New Jersey Tax Payers Task Force, said it opposed using the money to preserve private farm land, saying any land subsidized with tax dollars should be open to everyone. "The answer to open space is zoning, not spending billions of tax dollars to keep wealthy people's estates private and undeveloped," the group's president, John Budzash, said.
The other 60 percent of the land would be purchased in equal amounts by state, county, and town governments. Besides the $170 million raised each year from the higher gas tax, the car-rental surcharge, and the real estate taxes, other financing for the land would come from proceeds of local and county land-preservation taxes, repaid open-space loans the state has already made, and an extra $50 million the Governor wants added each year to the budget. She envisioned total spending of $762.2 million during the remainder of her term and some $2.2 billion by 2008.
She said her transportation plan, announced on Monday, would cost $30 billion over 12 years. The gas tax increase would provide more money for New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund, and that would attract more matching funds from the Federal Government. About $15 billion would come from Federal funds, $13 billion from the transportation trust fund, and $2 billion from private investment.
The major elements she discussed on Monday include buying 1,400 new buses; replacing 424 rail cars and 17 locomotives in the state's mass transit system; repairing or widening 413 bridges; finishing construction of three new light rail lines and starting work on three other new commuter lines; easing congestion on 40 of the state's most crowded roadways; and making safety improvements at 100 of its most dangerous intersections.
James Benton, head of the New Jersey Petroleum Council, said the group favored the nickel increase for transportation projects but opposed the additional 2-cent increase proposed for open spaces. "We think the motor fuel tax should be dedicated to highways and other transportation improvements," Mr. Benton said.

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE INVESTORS;
Companies Fear Costs Of Suharto Partnerships

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
For American and foreign companies seeking riches in Indonesia's fast-growing market over the last three decades, President Suharto, his family and coterie of cronies have been commercial gatekeepers, sometimes becoming partners in business ventures with a brashness that would have made other Asian dictators blush.
Now, with Mr. Suharto ousted by an outbreak of popular unrest, many American, Asian and European companies are left with expensive partnerships that seem unlikely to bear fruit. Indeed, some companies privately worry that their once-vaunted alliances may prove to be liabilities in the post-Suharto era, particularly if reformers take power and investigate the foreign contribution to the country's endemic corruption. 
 "I think the opposition is going to be very sophisticated," said Jeffrey Winters, a professor of political economy at Northwestern University. "They do not want to send out a signal of revenge across the board, but they are going to carefully select those foreign companies that have been most egregious. Those that have given the biggest perks to the Suharto family should be nervous."
Few businesses flourished in Indonesia without the support of the Suharto clan. The ex-President's three sons and three daughters are among Indonesia's most active business people, presiding over several big monopoly companies and holding hundreds of passive equity stakes in foreign multinational projects involved in everything from from petrochemicals telecommunications. Allying with the Suhartos did not guarantee success, analysts say, but alienating the family insured failure.
"Access to Indonesia has long depended on having close contacts and paying for them," says Daniel Lev, a political scientist at the University of Washington and an expert on Indonesia. "There were some foreign companies that were careful to play by the rules, but they were the exceptions."
The list of Suharto allies is long, and the types of partnerships varied. But a partial rendering of companies that have developed joint ventures or offered equity stakes to the Suharto children or the ex-President's closest business partners includes Hyatt hotels, Hughes, Lucent Technologies, General Electric, Edison Mission Energy, and Freeport McMoran of the United States, Sumitomo, NEC, and Marubeni of Japan, Kia Motors of South Korea, Hopewell Holdings of Hong Kong, and Deutsche Telekom and Siemens of Germany.
None of those companies has been accused of wrongdoing. Spokesmen for several defended the alliances as part of normal business practices. Moreover, Indonesian law requires investors in some areas, including basic infrastructure and mining, to offer shareholdings to local businesses, even if that partner contributes little capital or expertise.
Still, some corporate executives with long experience in Indonesia now worry not only about the country's collapsed economy, where per capita income has plunged from about $1,200 to about $300 in six months, but also that "strategic" relationships developed over many years may suddenly become liabilities.
"You wake up one morning and find the world turned upside down -- that's how I feel," said an Asia-based executive of a European energy company that has a longstanding alliance with one of Mr. Suharto's sons. "What do we do? We go on as before and hope that whoever takes power wants to keep moving forward."
Some other companies with much at stake in Indonesia declined to comment on their businesses there, or the potential backlash against their ties to the Suharto regime. One of the biggest American investors, the New Orleans-based mining concern Freeport, is currently partners with a top Suharto ally, Mohamad (Bob) Hasan, a plywood tycoon and ex-Cabinet minister, and has had dealings with members of the Suharto family since the late 1960's.
"It is too early to tell what the result of this leadership change will be," a company spokesman said.
Lucent Technologies, the former telecommunications equipment arm of AT&T, formed its business ties with one of Mr. Suharto's daughters in the mid-1980's. A Lucent spokeswoman, Lydia Whitefield, said the company did not expect any short-term adjustments in the ownership of its digital-switch making venture.
"There's not much looking back here in terms of philosophy," she said. "We are looking forward, trying to make sure our plant is serving our customers. That's what we are worried about."
Like companies that did business in the Philippines under the long rule of Ferdinand E. Marcos, companies forging agreements with Mr. Suharto's inner court often viewed that strategy as prudent, not risky. Mr. Suharto personally vetted investment projects and routinely overturned contracts issued by his bureaucracy that he found distasteful. In doing so, the President did not disguise his bias toward his children and his closest business allies -- or their partners.
Even through much of the Asian currency crisis that eventually led to his downfall, Mr. Suharto protected those who backed his family. He stoutly defended Indonesia's "national car" project spearheaded by Hutomo Mandala Putra, his 36-year-old son, against repeated attacks from his own bureaucracy and the World Trade Organization. Kia Motors was the joint venture partner for that deal, now considered scrapped.
Guests at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Jakarta said that army troops surrounded the five-star luxury hotel during recent riots, apparently to protect the property, but did not provide similar services to nearby rivals. The Grand Hyatt is owned by Bambang Trihatmodjo, a Suharto son. The American company Hyatt International manages the hotel on his behalf.
Some foreign investors were reluctant to link up with what was Indonesia's leading family. International Business Machines, for example, has shunned partnerships with the Suhartos, Mr. Winters said. The McDonald's Corporation has also steered clear of ties with the Suhartos or their close colleagues.

New Indonesian Chief Vows Democracy and Reforms
B. J. Habibie outlined a program of reforms, clean government and economic responsibility that addressed criticisms leveled against his predecessor, President Suharto, who resigned under pressure. Mr. Habibie pledged to dedicate himself to democratization, but many of the protesters who had demanded Mr. Suharto's resignation remain unsatisfied, calling Mr. Habibie a part of the old order who also should go. A1 

The Clinton Administration stepped up calls for a transition to democracy in Indonesia and, while welcoming the resignation of President Suharto, tried to distance itself from his successor, Mr. Habibie. Senior officials said the United States assumed -- and hoped -- that Mr. Habibie's tenure as President would be short. A9

Stocks Resume Retreat, Nasdaq at Six-Week Low
A day after gains pushed blue-ship stocks sharply higher for no obvious reason, stock prices fell, and analysts saw various explanations: worries about corporate profit deceleration, worries about high prices, plus overall loss of stamina and momentum. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 39.11 points, to 9,132.37, and the S.& P. 500 index dropped 4.42, to 1,114.64. The Nasdaq index, heavily weighted with technology shares, fell 10.76 points to 1,820.99, its weakest level since early April. Page D6.
 
Treasury prices also fell, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond up to 5.92 percent from 5.89 percent on Wednesday. D6.
 
Microsoft Asks For More Time
Microsoft asked a Federal judge for seven months to prepare for a hearing in the antitrust suits filed against it this week. But the Government and the 20 states that sued want to proceed far more quickly. D2.
 
Most Beepers Beeping Again
By one estimate, paging companies have restored service for 90 percent of the millions of pagers used by Americans that conked out when a satellite failed on Tuesday night. But Panamsat, the owner, said the reason for the failure remains unclear. D3.

B. J. Habibie, Indonesia's new President, outlined an agenda of economic overhaul and responsibility that addressed key criticisms of his predecessor, President Suharto. A1.
 
Suharto, his family and friends have been Indonesia's commercial gatekeepers for three decades, sometimes becoming partners in business ventures with a brashness that would have made other dictators blush. A10.

Indonesia specialists are optimistic about its long-term economic prospects. A10.

Legislation designed to discourage teen-agers from smoking hit a potentially serious snag in the Senate, and further action was postponed until next month. The delay diminishes the prospects for final enactment of a tobacco bill this year. A22.
 
What the Fed Really Said in March
Minutes of the Federal Reserve's March 31 policy-making meeting show that as suspected, it held off raising interest rates in the belief that Asian financial problems would help repress inflation here. The Fed voted again on Tuesday not to raise rates. But the reasoning won't be disclosed until minutes of that meeting are released in July. D2.

HEADLINE: William Hewitt, 83, Responsible For Overseas Expansion of Deere

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
William A. Hewitt, who transformed Deere & Company from a midsized Midwestern tractor company to the world's largest producer of agricultural equipment, died on Saturday at his home in Rutherford, Calif. He was 83.
The cause was a heart attack, his family said. 
 As the longtime chief executive of Deere, Mr. Hewitt was responsible for the company's international expansion, which helped Deere's sales surge from less than $300 million when he became president in 1955 to more than $5 billion by the time of his retirement as chairman in 1982.
But Mr. Hewitt's boldest decision may have been to commission Eero Saarinen, the internationally known architect, to build a modern company headquarters in the middle of cornfields in Moline, Ill.
When the building was completed in 1964, it was greeted with almost universal praise, from both employees and architecture critics. And the building has stood the test of time; Paul Goldberger, the architecture critic for The New York Times, described the building in 1978 as "one of the most beautifully sited structures in contemporary American architecture," with an atmosphere of "utter dignity and serenity."
William Alexander Hewitt was born in San Francisco in 1914, and graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1937 with a degree in economics.
He served in the Navy in World War II, and retired as a lieutenant commander.
In 1948, Mr. Hewitt married Patricia Deere Wiman -- the daughter of Deere's chief executive and the great-great-grandaughter of the original John Deere, who invented a steel plow in 1837 -- and then joined the company.
After a stint in Deere's San Francisco sales office, Mr. Hewitt moved to Moline in 1954 to become executive vice president of the company. The next year, after his father-in-law died, he became president.
During his tenure, Deere became one of the first companies to recognize -- and profit from -- the shift in agriculture from small family farms to larger commercial operations.
Mr. Hewitt believed businessmen should have broad interests, and he did. He was active in civic affairs, collected art and owned a vineyard in Napa Valley. With his wife, who died in 1992, he raised horses.
In addition to serving as a director of several large public companies, Mr. Hewitt was on the board of many institutions involved in architecture, foreign aid and international affairs. In 1982, President Ronald Reagan appointed him Ambassador to Jamaica, where he served until 1985.
He is survived by two daughters, Anna Wolfe of Des Moines, N.M., and Adrienne Hewitt of Middleburg, Va.; a son, Alexander, of Denver; a sister, Adrienne Gordon, of San Francisco, and a brother, Edward T. Hewitt, of New York.

HEADLINE: SHOOTINGS IN A SCHOOL: THE TOWN;
Oasis With a Dark Side

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
There is no more idyllic spot in May than Springfield, Ore., and its sister city, Eugene, Ann Rule wrote in "Small Sacrifices,"a nonfiction work that was a paperback best seller in the late 1980's. "Sheltered by the Cascade Range to the east and the steel-blue and purple ridges of the coastal mountains on the western horizon," Ms. Rule wrote, "the valley was an oasis for pioneers a century ago."
People in Springfield spend their weekends fishing, hunting and rafting, residents said, glad to be away from the comparative hustle-bustle of Eugene, just across Interstate 5. 
 But the topic of Ms. Rule's book and yesterday's shooting in a high school cafeteria showed another side of Springfield, a mostly white, blue-collar, timber town turned bedroom community of 55,000 people that has long been overshadowed by Eugene, the home of the University of Oregon.
"Small Sacrifices" focuses onDiane Downs, a 27-year-old mother of three who was convicted in 1984 of shooting herself and her three children, and then falsely claiming that a "shaggy-haired stranger" shot them.
And just last week a 22-year-old Springfield man was convicted of kidnapping, raping and killing his 15-year-old former girlfriend and killing her new boyfriend, 15, and another 13-year-old boy in December 1995. A second defendant is awaiting trial.
Residents of Springfield say the crimes paint a skewed picture of a usually tranquil town that is economically rebounding after decades of decline.
Sony built a new microchip plant in the town. And the eastern part of Springfield, where the shooting occurred at Thurston High School, is sprouting suburban-style homes.
"This is very stunning for this community," said Norm Fox, 51, a local radio talk show host and 25-year resident of Springfield. Despite the town's star-crossed past, he said, "There's been nothing at all like this."

HEADLINE: With Attack on Giuliani, Pastor Returns to Fiery Past

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Some years ago, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d said, he decided to leave the marching in the streets and "banging on the mayor's door" to other black civil rights leaders. Instead, he decided he would knock softly on the doors of power, negotiate with city officials, cultivate relationships with the leaders of large corporations, all in an effort to attract investment, development and sorely needed jobs to his impoverished community in central Harlem.
A day after broadly condemning Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration, including branding the Mayor a racist, Mr. Butts said yesterday that he realized that his insider's approach to politics had failed, at least at City Hall. 
 "I had some hope that he was the kind of person you could deal with," Mr. Butts said, referring to the Mayor. "I've just about lost that hope."
Mr. Butts's critique of the Giuliani administration -- delivered at a news conference Wednesday at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, where he is pastor -- came as he warned that tensions between the police and Harlem residents were in danger of boiling over into an "explosion."
But even as Mr. Butts spoke Wednesday, pastors from several leading black churches, some of whom he had invited to join him at his news conference, were instead three blocks away, rallying at Harlem Hospital against the planned layoffs of several hundred workers. One of the few clergymen at Mr. Butts's side was the Rev. Benjamin F. Muhammad of the Nation of Islam's Mosque No. 7, in Harlem.
Mr. Butts's attempt at quiet diplomacy has long made him an outsider, and even a political nemesis, to the circle of more outspoken black leaders like the Rev. Al Sharpton. And far from prompting his welcome back into that fold, Mr. Butts's uncharacteristic outburst against Mr. Giuliani brought him more public criticism than praise.
In a front-page editorial yesterday, The Amsterdam News, the city's leading black newspaper, said Mr. Butts had "got the idea that he'd better get on this train of renewed black militancy before it runs over him. Black folks must not be lured by this conversion of Butts.
"It is not that we reject Butts; we simply reject his attempt at trying to lead us now, when he sees that we do not need him," Wilbert A. Tatum, the chairman of the newspaper's board and its former editor, said in the signed editorial.
Mr. Butts said that he had received dozens of telephone calls of support yesterday, although no one rose to his defense publicly.
"It hasn't hurt me in the black community," he said. "And for those people who know me and work with me in the so-called white community, I don't see it as having hurt. Why would people be upset because I'm speaking up for children, and for education, and for civil liberties?" He attributed the editorial in The Amsterdam News to Mr. Tatum's longstanding animosity toward him.
At the news conference, Mr. Butts recited a litany of instances in which he said the Giuliani administration and the police had victimized minorities, among them the layoffs at Harlem Hospital, failing to address public school construction adequately, and cutting funds for legal services for the poor. He also presented two young men, the sons of a deacon and deaconess in his church, who said they had been wrongly arrested last month by officers in a drug sweep.
Earlier in his career, Mr. Butts was a far more confrontational political presence. In 1983, he and other black ministers pressed the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch on police brutality, leading to reforms that included the hiring of the city's first black Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, and the addition of independent civilians to the panel that reviews allegations of police brutality.
But as he aged, Mr. Butts said, and after Republicans won control of City Hall and the Governor's mansion, he found himself wanting "to be able to negotiate rather than have to get out in the street all the time."
When Mr. Giuliani, as a candidate in 1993, showed up one day to discuss economic development, Mr. Butts said he was charmed.
"I said, 'Let's watch and see what happens,' " he recalled.
Mr. Butts said that he started to grow disillusioned with Mr. Giuliani soon after the Mayor took office in 1994. Mr. Butts said he met with the Mayor and several of his aides, and "talked about how to move things forward."
"Then I'd leave, and some of the stuff we'd talked about wouldn't happen," Mr. Butts said. "I'd call some of his commissioners, they'd slam the phone down. It just started deteriorating from that time on.
"Then, when you'd want to talk to him about hard issues -- health care, schools, brutality -- there'd be no response," Mr. Butts continued. He said he had held off confronting the Mayor publicly for so long because "it makes me look like a bad guy in the eyes of some New Yorkers."
"You know," he said, "you're fighting the police."

HEADLINE: SHOOTINGS IN A SCHOOL: THE OVERVIEW;
Oregon Student Held in 3 Killings; One Dead, 23 Hurt at His School

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ore., May 21

 BODY:
Minutes before the 8 o'clock bell rang to start the day at Thurston High School today, a student carrying three guns opened fire on hundreds of other students gathered in the cafeteria, killing one, the police said. Twenty-three other students were injured, five critically, by gunfire and in the resulting melee.
As the student tried to reload a .22- caliber rifle, a member of the wrestling team, who had been critically injured, tackled him, and other students helped subdue him. An hour later, the police said, at the suggestion of the 15-year-old boy, identified as Kipland F. Kinkel, officers went to his home and found two adults shot to death there. The boy's grandmother confirmed they were his parents. 
 "Kip is my grandson; he murdered his mother and father," said Katie Kinkel, who lives in Eugene, a college town that borders Springfield. Asked in an interview if she was certain, Mrs. Kinkel, badly shaken, said, "For sure."
The police said the teen-ager had been suspended from school the day before, on Wednesday, for bringing a gun to school. They said he had been charged with possession of a stolen gun and then released to his parents, who were both teachers.
As students, teachers and others in this Willamette Valley town of 55,000 people reacted with shock to the shooting, the latest in a series of fatal school shootings by students across the country, state and school officials in Oregon defended the high school's disciplining of Mr. Kinkel the day before.
The state superintendent of schools, Norma Paulus, said the school had acted responsibly on Wednesday by suspending the student, pending an expulsion after an investigation. "This is not a school problem," she said. "This is a societal problem."
The Governor of Oregon, John Kitzhaber, said: "All of us should look at how we have failed as a society and how this could happen in the heart of Oregon. It has been a priority to build prison cells and prison beds -- after the fact. These actions in no way prevent juvenile violence."
Megan Conklin, a junior who took the same school bus with Mr. Kinkel, said after the shooting, "He said on the bus that he was mad and he was going to do something stupid. He's a mean kid. He'd said some horrible things to me before."
Ms. Conklin was in the cafeteria when the shooting began. "He kicked the door, and he was in this trench coat, and I thought it was part of the play that we were supposed to have today," she said. "Then people started falling and screaming and bleeding. People were pushing to get out."
Michelle Calhoun, 17, said, "He walked in, didn't look like he was bothered by anything, and just started shooting at random. I'm angry. This is a good, happy school."
Her boyfriend, 17-year-old Mikael Nickolauson, a junior who had recently enlisted in the Oregon National Guard, was sitting nearby and was shot and killed. Tonight, Teresa Clark, a family friend answering calls to the Nickolauson home, said: "This is just a really hard time. Everything is up in the air."
At an evening news conference, the police said Mr. Kinkel probably would have shot more students if he had not been wrestled to the ground. They said they believe no one else but Mr. Kinkel was involved in the shootings at the school or the house.
Mr. Kinkel was carrying a semiautomatic, .22-caliber rifle, a .22-caliber handgun and a Glock pistol, they said. Among the critically injured was the wrestler who tackled Mr. Kinkel, Jacob Ryker.
Several students said Mr. Kinkel had been upset over teasing from older students, and that he had a temper and a troubled past. The police said that the boy had once been questioned by officers in a neighboring county for throwing rocks at cars from a freeway overpass.
Mr. Kinkel is the son of two teachers, William Kinkel, 59, and Faith Kinkel, 57. Mr. Kinkel was retired. Mrs. Kinkel was still teaching in a school district of Springfield, a working-class town near Eugene, about 110 miles south of Portland.
The Kinkel family lived in a new, rural development about 12 miles from the edge of Springfield, in a two-story frame house above the McKenzie River. They had one other child, a daughter, who is much older and does not live in town.
The boy was active in sports but in the last few years had undergone a marked change in personality, friends said.
"I coached him in soccer, basketball, and baseball," said Dave Wing, a grocery store owner, who knew the family well. "It was an excellent family. Good people. Kip had a temper though. If he didn't get his way, he would kick and shout."
Some neighbor boys said in the last years that young Kinkel started dressing in black and taking on the pose of a "Gothic," a youth persona with music and style, gloomy and dark.
"He was a good kid in grade school, but then his freshman year, he started wearing black and not talking to people," said Jessica Rose, a neighbor who rode the bus with the boy.
Some friends indicated that the boy may have intended to shoot up the school on Wednesday. . Students said he was angry about insults from seniors. On Wednesday, the police said, they were called to the school on a report of a stolen gun, questioned the boy, found the gun, and took him to the police station for booking and fingerprinting.
He was released under Oregon law for arrests on this type of offense, being in possession of a stolen weapon. The authorities said today that they would try the boy as an adult. In Oregon, because of his age he could not be executed if convicted.
The police said they did not know if the shooting at the boy's home occurred on Wednesday night or today.
The authorities said the boy took a family car to school today.
Just before 8 A.M., senior boys were gathered in the library for senior awards day, preparing to give out awards for sports and other activities. In the cafeteria, students were eating breakfast and socializing.
"I thought it was fireworks, and then I thought it was a cap gun," said Stephani Quimby, a student at the school.
"He walked in and he was wearing this big, long trench coat and he pulled out a rifle," said James Kistner, another student. "He squeezed off, I say, about three or four rounds. Then there was like a short pause. And from there on he just kept his finger on the trigger and let ammo fly."
Witnesses gave conflicting accounts of how long the shooting went on. Some students said it lasted as long as 10 minutes. "It didn't look like he was bothered by anything," Miss Calhoun said. "Like the shooting was just something he was doing."
Miss Calhoun said the dead student, Mr. Nickolauson, had been her boyfriend for nine months. She said Mr. Nickolauson was a native of Springfield, who loved science fiction.
A Springfield police officer who interrogated Mr. Kinkel, Capt. Jerry Smith, said, "When I spoke to him he was very calm."
Springfield is known as a timber town, with a rural feel, though in recent years it has been on an economic upswing with the arrival of computer-chip factories. Residents here said many students are familiar with guns, because they hunt.
The school does not have metal detectors, but it has a strict no-gun policy, and the students and teachers had spoken often about violence.
"You can't even bring a squirt gun into this school," said Shayla Johnson, a senior. She and three other friends were holding hands outside the school, where a fence was bedecked with flowers.
The wounded students were taken to two hospitals. Nineteen students were injured by gunfire. Others were hurt in the scramble to get out of the line of fire, hospital officials said.
"I ducked down, and then ran for the door -- we were all just trying to get out," said Miss Calhoun. "I'm really proud of those boys who tried to hold the kid down."
Miss Calhoun was carrying a single red rose in honor of her slain friend. "This school is the last place you would expect something like this to happen," she said.
One parent, Angela Graybow, was preparing a paper on school violence for the community college she attends. She said she believed Springfield was not immune. Once Mr. Kinkel had been arrested for carrying a gun, she said, he should not have been released. "They should have had somebody watching him," she said.
Some students said Mr. Kinkel used to make odd statements about building a bomb or committing violence, but few people took him seriously. "He threatened, people knew what was going to happen," said Pam Kelly, a junior at the school.
The police, as of today, took the bomb-building stories seriously. Fearing that the Kinkel house might be wired with a bomb, officers cordoned off several blocks.
Thurston is one of two public high schools in Springfield, and has about 1,700 students. No one interviewed could recall episodes of student violence, except a knife fight two years ago.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
City Jobless Rate Falls to 8.1 Percent

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Unemployment in New York City fell to 8.1 percent in April from 8.6 percent in March, after adjustment for seasonal fluctuations, according to New York State Department of Labor figures released yesterday by the City Comptroller's office.
The jobless level last month was the lowest in three years, but it reflected a shrinking labor force as well as a strong economy, city officials said. 
 Nationally, the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in April from 4.7 percent the month before. For all of New York State, the rate fell to 5.8 percent from 6.1 percent.
In New York City, the private sector added a seasonally adjusted 15,100 jobs in April for a four-month total of 50,600.
"This is the best four-month job gain since 1967, as far back as we have numbers," Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said.
The actual number of jobs added in April was reduced by 1,100 government positions, mostly a loss of 800 jobs from local agencies, including the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:

'Brushed Voices'
'Calligraphy in Contemporary China'
Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery
Schermerhorn Hall
Columbia University
116th Street and Broadway
Morningside Heights
Through June 6
Contemporary Chinese art has had exceptional visibility in New York in the last year. And this exhibition, tracing fresh developments in the ancient art form most closely associated with China's cultural identity, is an important cap to the season. 
 Organized by Yiguo Zhang, a graduate student in Columbia's art history department, the show includes some 60 examples of work recently produced in China, where calligraphy is enjoying an efflorescence. Public competitions, publications and academic courses devoted to the form abound, and an art historically associated with a cadre of elite practitioners has gained an ardent following that crosses social and economic lines.
With popularity has come change. Traditional scripts are used, but with characters often made big, bold and instantly readable. Fleet-looking cursive styles, suggesting modern velocity and expressive freedom, are in vogue. Western-style Pop elements appear, as in a piece by Sun Xiaoyun that combines the character for "dancing" with a newspaper photograph of Martha Graham. And in some cases, characters are eliminated altogether to produce an abstract gestural painting, as seen in the polychrome works by Luo Qi, an artist associated with the post-modern style known as calligraphyism.
Are calligraphy and abstraction ultimately irreconcilable? If they are not, how is the new hybrid work to be approached and critically evaluated? And what of the moral dimensions traditionally attributed to this painstakingly mastered art? Do they still have currency in the modern world?
These are among the many questions raised in Mr. Zhang's fine exhibition catalogue, which includes an interview with the American painter Brice Marden. The book is a model of its kind -- clearly written, clean in design, full of scholarly information -- and an essential guide to a language-based art. But even without it, the dynamism of contemporary calligraphy comes across in a show that is unmistakably a gathering of utterly distinctive voices with things both old and new to say. HOLLAND COTTER

HEADLINE: Just Do It? Nah, Just Study It!;
Working Up a Sweat Over the Deep Meaning of Sport

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
On the first day of class in her course "Sport and Contemporary America," Professor Cheryl Cole of the University of Illinois distributes photographs of Michael Jordan and then asks the students a question: What do they see?
Hint: A great athlete heading to the hoop is the wrong answer. 
 "I ask them what are the political, social, economic, cultural and psychic dimensions of what's shown in the pictures," Professor Cole said. "They don't get it, but I certainly have their attention after that."
Deep thoughts about the realm of sweat socks and jocks might seem to some people to be a contradiction. Athletes themselves usually say that success in sports means learning to shut off the internal dialogue entirely, and that at the height of physical performance too much thought only gets in the way. There is only the doing: the scoring of the basket, the sinking of the putt, the pitch and the swing. No one, in the end, can really explain how to hit a home run.
But in the academic field of sports studies, which has emerged at colleges across the country over the last decade, deconstructing Michael Jordan is only the beginning. Sport is now regarded by social scientists as a lens on human behavior, by economists as a growth industry and by feminists as a vehicle for examining and challenging sexual roles. Perhaps most important, it is being embraced by growing numbers of students. In the process, many old ideas about physical education, even the term itself, are gasping their last breath.
"Sport is being disbursed through a number of different spaces in the popular culture -- you have links between sport, fashion and music; the hip-hop style borrows from sport; Disney has an interest in a hockey team and now a cartoon show, 'The Mighty Ducks,' " Professor Cole said. "We're trying to make the connections."
Experts in this new area generally prefer the term "sport," in the singular, cosmic sense, in describing what they study -- to distinguish it, perhaps, from "sports," of the sort that people read about over breakfast or on the subway. Kinesiology has supplanted P.E. on campuses as a way of looking at how bodies perform under physical strain and training. Students in "sport and gender" courses are studying how the starchy images of female athletes from the former Soviet Union were used during the cold war for propaganda purposes. Sports marketing majors scrutinize Nike's "swoosh" as a case study in sports branding.
There are sport sociologists studying Andre Agassi's effect on definitions of masculinity among white Generation X males, sport philosophers pondering the Olympics' relationship to post-modernism, and sport ethnographers researching the socioeconomic history of women's ice hockey.
"Sport is such a wonderful empirical site to take on a lot of ideas," said Michael Messner, former president of the American Society for the Sociology of Sport, and a professor of sociology at the University of Southern California. "It has become a place for a lot of our most sophisticated thinking." Professor Cole at the University of Illinois believes that sport in the late 20th century has become a universal mirror. Thinking hard about how the nation regards Michael Jordan or how Nike combines sports images and flag-draped American symbols to sell shoes around the world, she argues, is not a mere academic parlor exercise but a way of examining race, multinational capitalism, media and culture.
High-minded study of sports is not new. Some universities in Britain and Canada, in particular, have had established sports studies programs for many years. In the United States, however, tradition long held that sports occupied the merely physical realm and was not worthy of real scholarship. But many sports scholars now say that its exclusion was, in the end, a good thing: sports studies belonged to no department that could rise to defend it as turf, or attack it as heretical. No one cared.
The departments that emerged are like quilts of unrelated threads and fabrics. One intellectual strand came, for example, from feminism. As scholars began looking for patterns in society and culture that had reinforced sexual roles, sports was an obvious example. In the business schools, the huge impact of sports, both as a business and a marketing tool, got too big to ignore. Leisure studies, which focus on how people spend their time and money on things like tourism and sporting events, got folded in as well. At Bowling Green State University in Ohio, there are psychology professors, business management and marketing professors, sociologists and kinesiologists -- all in the division of Sport Management, Recreation and Tourism, with sports as their main -- perhaps only -- point in common.
"In a lot of ways it's an uncharted territory," said Leslie Heywood, a professor of English at the State University of New York at Binghamton and the author of a new book about female bodybuilders, "Body Makers: A Cultural Anatomy of Women's Bodybuilding" (Rutgers University Press). "From English literature, to all these other areas, there's a huge potential" for new research, she said.
Professor Heywood, who is also a power lifter, said her book explores the conflict between the healing and the confidence-building that bodybuilding provides many women. Many abused women seek it out as therapy. It also examines the demeaning imagery with which they often find themselves depicted in muscle magazines.
She also noted the persistence of stereotypes of professors or Ph.D's as fussy eggheads whose closest brush with physical competition is chess club meetings. But the reality is that many in academia have taken part in sports. This is especially true of women who came of age in the 1970's and after, when their opportunities in sports expanded. Professor Heywood ran track before discovering the joy of weights. Professor Cole played water polo.
Laurence De Garis, who received his Ph.D. from the University of Connecticut's department of Sport, Leisure and Exercise Sciences this year, is in many ways an exemplar of the field: he worked his way through school as a professional wrestler.
He also used wrestling for material. His dissertation was on the ethnic and socioeconomic life of a boxing gym, Gleason's in Brooklyn. In a boxing gym, he said, stockbrokers looking for a workout might find themselves sparring with tough kids from poor neighborhoods trying to fight their way to something better. Issues of race and ambition and exploitation are everywhere as fighters' careers are made or broken. And in wrestling, he added, one can see how much of what passes for reality is really manipulated imagery.
"One of the things you learn pretty quickly in wrestling is that seeing isn't always believing -- what you see isn't always what's going on," he said. "You have to look deeper."
But these departments do more than analyze the relationship of sports and society. Their rise is a part of the story itself, of how sports and fitness and capitalism and culture and fashion blur at the edges and how sports can be an agent of change. The involvement of more girls in sports, for example, is changing attitudes toward competition and aggression, some say.
Seven years ago, when Professor Vikki Krane, a psychologist at Bowling Green, began teaching in the school's sports division, her surveys of students in her classes showed stark divisions between men and women. A crucial question in the survey was about the moral and psychological cost of victory: Was deliberately hurting an opponent to win acceptable behavior?
In the early 1990's, male students were far more likely to say yes than female students, she said. But year by year, the gap has been closing, with more and more women saying that inflicting intentional injury is an acceptable price to pay for victory.
"Now women are more similar: they're encouraged to win at all costs, just like the males are," Professor Krane said.
Sports studies have also been, in some ways, an agent of change in academia itself. The significant role of feminist scholars in the field was partly by design, many professors say, since creating sports studies required crossing many departmental lines at traditional, male-dominated universities.
"There's been a lot of feminist influence as sports studies developed," said Professor Messner at the University of Southern California. "They have been at the forefront in breaking down the boundaries."
A bittersweet consequence is that the sweaty world of physical education departments, which produced generations of gym teachers and coaches, is fading fast. At the University of Connecticut, where that department has been eliminated, the last physical education major is moving through his studies and will graduate in 2000. By contrast, the school now has 150 undergraduates and 100 graduate students doing sports studies. Dr. De Garis, meanwhile, intends to keep wrestling. Six feet tall and weighing in at 230 fighting pounds, he says he knows how to throw his weight around. He also lets the other wrestlers know about his new status.
"I make them call me Doctor," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

 BODY:
YEN FALLS. The yen fell after minutes from the Bank of Japan's April 9 meeting, released yesterday, suggested it might reduce interest rates to help the weak economy. In New York, the dollar rose to 135.90 yen from 134.78.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Buying Spree From U.S. Sets Record in Asia

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
United States takeovers of Asian companies have hit a record this year, reflecting the economic distress in parts of Asia and the opportunities that many American buyers see in picking up valuable businesses at bargain prices.
Through Wednesday, the dollar value of announced United States acquisitions of Asian companies totaled $4.85 billion, according to the Securities Data Company, which compiles data on cross-border corporate takeovers. That surpasses the previous yearly record of $4.25 billion in 1996. 
 While the total may seem small compared with the value of United States mergers announced in recent months, such as Travelers Group's $70 billion union with Citicorp, the activity shows no signs of slowing.
"Companies are pursuing opportunities that they've been interested in for a while," said Phyllis Korff, coordinator of the Asian Pacific practice at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. "We've got a stable of Fortune 500 clients along with their investment bankers who are contacting us."
Japan leads the Securities Data list in announced deals, with $2.6 billion this year, followed by Thailand, with $817 million; Indonesia, $443 million; South Korea, $404 million, and Hong Kong, $280 million.
Prominent deals for Japanese companies included the GE Capital Corporation's purchase of Toho Mutual Life for $820 million and Goldman, Sachs & Company's acquisition of Yamato Mutual Life Insurance for $455 million.
"For the first time in decades, in selected special situations, you can go in and buy specific properties," said David McCreery, an investment banker at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company with experience in Japan. But, he said, "It is still not a market where businesses are for sale; you have to make it happen."
Interest in Asia has kept bankers like Gary Stead, head of Merrill Lynch's mergers and acquisitions team in the Asia Pacific region, on the move. On a weeklong visit to New York in late March, Mr. Stead visited an average of five companies a day interested in business abroad. That was after 20 scheduled meetings in London and Paris. At Lazard Freres & Company, inquiries from domestic and European companies about acquiring Asian businesses have increased fourfold so far this year.
Experts say that it is unlikely that investors in the short term will do more than buy smaller companies that complement existing businesses because buying a large Asian company is still considered too risky until economic and political instability subsides, particularly in Indonesia.
"It's difficult for United States companies to get their arms around it quickly," Ms. Korff said. "That's why the first investment is a little smaller."
Companies likely to make the smartest acquisitions are already familiar with an Asian company's operations, either because they are involved in a joint venture or have been doing business in Asia for some time.
"You can't go out there only to bottom-fish," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "What you buy has to fit in with a strategic plan for the region or globally."

HEADLINE: Dealer in U.S. Debt Is Ending Operations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Eastbridge Capital Inc., one of the 36 primary dealers that deal directly with the Federal Reserve's securities trading desk, said yesterday that it was closing down operations.
The New York-based securities firm is a unit of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd. of Japan, which announced last year that it was closing all overseas units and affiliates to cut costs and increase efficiency. 
 Eastbridge, which was formed in 1989 and employs about 50 people, is entering into a voluntary liquidation and plans to meet all obligations and pay all creditors.
Eastbridge will enter into trades only to offset and unwind outstanding positions, the company said.
Nippon Credit Bank estimated it had 1.69 trillion yen ($12.5 billion) in bad loans on its books as of March 31, when calculated under the extended definition of bad debt used in the United States. The estimate was included in a cost-cutting plan submitted to the Government earlier this year when the bank, along with 20 other major Japanese lenders, applied for public financing to increase capital.
As a primary dealer, Eastbridge is one of 36 firms that has a business relationship with the Federal Reserve's government securities trading desk. The Fed turns to these firms to buy and sell securities, as it adjusts the amount of money in the economy. Primary dealers are also required to bid on new government securities and provide market information to the Fed.

HEADLINE: John William Berry Sr., 75; Made Fortune on Yellow Pages

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
John William Berry Sr., a philanthropist who made a fortune taking the Yellow Pages global, died on Wednesday at Miami Valley Hospital in Dayton, Ohio. He was 75 and lived in New Carlisle, Ohio.
The cause was congestive heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Berry, a native of Dayton, was one of its greatest boosters. Just this year, he pledged $7.5 million for scholarships at the University of Dayton, the largest private commitment to the school ever. Scores of other institutions of all descriptions in and around the city also benefited from his philanthropy.
The family's wealth sprang from an idea his father, Loren Murphy Berry, had in 1909 when he sold $700 of advertising to help an uncle in Marion, Ill., print a list of subscribers to his budding telephone company. The partnership took off and, under John Berry's tutelage, L. M. Berry & Company burgeoned into a $1-billion-a-year giant by the time Mr. Berry sold it to the BellSouth Corporation in 1986 for an undisclosed amount.
Loren Berry brought the Yellow Pages to mid-America; John Berry took them to the world. Yellow, incidentally, was chosen, according to company lore, because Loren Berry deemed it the best background for black type.
John Berry became the company's president in 1963 and three years later entered a joint venture with the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, ITT-World Directories. It quickly grew into the biggest Yellow Pages company outside the United States -- except that the Europeans call them Golden and Australians settled for Pink.
Mr. Berry earned a degree in business administration from Dartmouth College in 1944. He began his career as a salesman in his father's company in 1940, rose to managing director in 1960, president in 1963 and chairman in 1973.
After he sold the company, now a BellSouth subsidiary called the Berry Company, he founded Berry Investments Inc. with the proceeds. At his death, he was its chairman.
In 1992, he gave $25 million to Dartmouth, the largest individual gift in its 229-year history. He and a family foundation also paid for most of the college's $35 million Berry Library, for which ground was broken this month, next to the existing Baker Library.
Mr. Berry endowed the Loren Berry Professorship in Economics at Dartmouth in 1978 and the John W. Berry Sports Center in 1987.
He sat on the executive board committee of the Ohio Republican Finance Committee and served as a trustee of the University of Dayton and Ohio State University.
Mr. Berry is survived by his wife of 11 years, Marilynn St. John Berry; five sons, George W. of Boston, John Jr. of Dayton, David L. of San Francisco, Charles D. of Dayton, and Richard L. of Denver; a brother, Lee H. of New Albany, Ohio; two sisters, Martha Fraim of Palm Desert, Calif., and Elizabeth Gray of Oakwood, Ohio, and 18 grandchildren.
Two earlier marriages ended in divorces.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John William Berry Sr. (Associated Press, 1996)

HEADLINE: S.& L. Expands Pledge on Loans

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 22

 BODY:
Washington Mutual Inc., whose $9.8 billion purchase of H. F. Ahmanson & Company is pending, said today that it was designating $120 billion for loans to lower-income consumers and communities over 10 years.
The commitment by the company, the largest United States savings institution, includes loans and investments for affordable housing, small businesses and economic development in the western United States, Florida and Texas. The plan, which expands a $75 billion program Washington Mutual announced last year, will start in 1999, if the acquisition of Ahmanson, based in Irwindale, Calif., is completed. 
 The Seattle-based Washington Mutual's program addresses obligations under the Community Reinvestment Act, which requires banks and savings institutions to make loans available to low-income communities.
Washington Mutual agreed in March to buy Ahmanson in a deal that would create an institution with about $150 billion in assets.
Big low-income lending pledges have become a standard feature of mergers involving banks and savings institutions as the companies seek to line up support for the deals.

HEADLINE: Text of Correspondence on Waiver to Permit Satellite Export

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Following are the text of a letter from Thomas B. Ross, vice president of Government Relations at Loral Space and Communications, to Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, and the text of a memorandum for the President prepared by Mr. Berger; Larry Stein, the White House Congressional liaison, and Daniel K. Tarullo, then assistant to the President for international economic policy. The memorandum, which was declassified on Thursday, was dated Feb. 12 and dealt with a Presidential national-interest waiver for the Chinasat 8 communications satellite project by Loral. The letter from Mr. Ross was dated Feb. 13.
 
FROM THE MEMORANDUM
 
Purpose
To decide whether to waive Tiananmen sanctions to permit the licensing of communications satellites and related technology and equipment for export to China by Space Systems/Loral. 

Background
The Foreign Relations Authorization Act of 1990 and 1991, passed in the wake of the events of Tiananmen Square, suspended the licensing of exports of certain items to China, including defense articles on the U.S. Munitions List and U.S.-origin commercial satellites for launch on Chinese vehicles. These suspensions can be waived if the President reports to Congress that it is in the national interest to do so.
The Department of State, with the concurrence of the Department of Defense and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, recommends that you waive the legislative restriction on the export to China of the communications satellites and related equipment for the Space Systems/Loral (SS/L) Chinasat 8 project, worth approximately $60-65 million in U.S. content. Since 1993, you have issued 11 such waivers for U.S.-China commercial space projects, which have benefited several U.S. companies, including Loral, Iridium and Hughes, and supported our broader engagement strategy with China.
In this particular instance, however, the Criminal Division of the Justice Department has cautioned that a national-interest waiver in this case could have a significant adverse impact on any prosecution that might take place, based on a pending investigation of export violations by SS/L. Justice is investigating SS/L's unauthorized transfer of defense services to the Chinese during their joint inquiry into an explosion of a Chinese launch rocket carrying an SS/L satellite in 1996 -- a transfer that could have contributed to the Chinese ballistic missile program. SS/L acknowledges that an unauthorized transfer of technical information took place, but Justice has not decided whether it will take criminal action against SS/L. Justice believes that a jury would not convict once it learned that the President had found SS/L's Chinasat 8 project to be in the national interest. We will take the firm position that this waiver does not exonerate or in any way prejudge SS/L with respect to its prior unauthorized transfers to China. Nevertheless, if Justice's is correct on this matter, the proposed waiver might be criticized for letting SS/L off the hook on criminal charges for its unauthorized assistance to China's ballistic missile program.
In any case, we believe that the advantages of this project outweigh this risk and that we can effectively rebut criticism of the waiver. On fairness grounds, we believe it is inappropriate to penalize SS/L before they have even been charged with any crime, especially since we have had no problems with two subsequent launches of Loral satellites. In addition, the investigation deals with a transfer which took place in connection with a launch failure, an unusual occurrence, and we have since clarified for all U.S. satellite companies their obligation to obtain a separate U.S. Government license for any discussions related to a Chinese launch failure.
Moreover, the project is in the national interest because the development of China's civil communications infrastructure will promote access by Chinese citizens in remote areas to people and ideas in democratic societies. As noted below, we have routinely approved similar national-interest waivers for satellite projects using this justification and noting that the projects assist U.S. exporters. The current project also will help maintain the competitiveness of U.S. satellite exporters in a most important satellite market.
We could respond to criticisms of the proposed waiver on the following grounds:
*The Chinasat 8 project involves civilian comsat technology and will not contribute to Chinese military capabilities.
*There were no problems with unauthorized transfers of defense services in connection with two subsequent Chinese launches of Loral satellites, and State and Defense are satisfied that the technology assistance agreement proposed for Chinasat 8 will guard against unauthorized transfers in this project.
*The investigation of SS/L's unauthorized transfers is at an early stage (not yet before the grand jury, much less subject to an indictment); SS/L is entitled to the presumption of innocence until proven guilty.
*If the investigation indicates that SS/L knowingly engaged in unauthorized transfers of defense services, State can impose administrative penalties (debarment and fines) even if Justice concludes that criminal prosecution would be futile.
*If the evidence leads to such a conclusion before the Chinasat 8 project is completed, the project could be blocked by withholding or withdrawing the necessary export licenses.
On balance, we believe that these factors support a national-interest waiver for this satellite project. As with earlier waivers, we may be criticized by some members of Congress who are concerned about China's human rights and proliferation record. In that event, we are prepared to provide briefings that explain our reasons for approving the project.
 
Recommendation
That you approve the waiver and sign the letters at Tab A reporting to Congress that it is in the national interest to permit the licensing of communications satellites and related equipment for export to China in connection with the Chinasat 8 project.
Approve Backward check mark was marked here
Disapprove Nothing marked
 
TEXT OF LETTER
I recognize that you are bearing more than the usual load of responsibilities at this time, and I would not be raising this issue if it were not time urgent for us.
We are told that the request for a waiver to permit Loral to use the China Long March rocket for a satellite launch is in the West Wing, perhaps on the President's desk. If a decision is not forthcoming in the next day or so, we stand to lose the contract. In fact, even if the decision is favorable, we will lose substantial amounts of money with each passing day.
Bernard Schwartz had intended to raise this issue with you at the Blair dinner, but missed you in the crowd. In any event, we would greatly appreciate your help in getting prompt decision for us.

HEADLINE: Wyoming Is Left Out Of the Rockies' Boom;
Population, Already Smallest, Is Falling

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: CASPER, Wyo., May 15

 BODY:
With the nation's smallest population, windswept Wyoming has been called a small town with a very long main street. Now that street has become a one-way highway leading out of state.
While neighboring Colorado, Utah and Idaho are experiencing some of the fastest population growth rates in the nation, Wyoming, which has only 481,000 people, actually lost population last year as 3,000 residents moved away. Its population of young families dropped by about 20 percent in the 1990's. 
 At the University of Wyoming in Laramie, about half of this year's graduates plan to move out of state, according to a recent survey. "Frankly, I don't know of any of them that are going to stay in state," said William Lindberg, chairman of the department of mechanical engineering, one of the areas hit hardest by the exodus of graduates. "We are educating them to go out of state. We are a marvelous exporter of talent."
While the rest of the Rocky Mountain region has become an envied example of job creation and income growth, Wyoming recently ranked 50th in the nation for creating jobs that add value to a product. In the last 15 years, wages in the state have slumped, to 21 percent below the national average from 11 percent above the national average.
"Everywhere else is blossoming -- but we are just blah," said Gus Fleischli, a mining supplier whose three children have moved out of state for jobs.
With a small population, unalluring scenery in much of the state and mixed feelings about growth, Wyoming has seen the Rocky Mountain boom largely pass it by. Battered by a barrage of statistics, more and more state residents have stopped straddling the fence about development and are climbing on the growth bandwagon.
"Wyoming is going to grow," Jim Geringer, the state's Governor, vowed at a recent business conference here. The Governor plans to inaugurate the Wyoming Business Council, a new development agency with a $23 million budget, next month in Cheyenne, the state capital.
There are signs that the regional economic boom is spilling into southeast Wyoming. With low taxes, low wages, low energy costs and little state government regulation, it often ranks as the nation's cheapest state in which to do business.
"You have given me a $24 million check to be here," said Bob Peck, vice president of a telephone service center, addressing the business conference here. Since moving his 550-employee operation from Florida to Cheyenne six years ago, he said, his company, Safecard Services, has saved $4 million a year.
In Casper, a city that has lived through 70 years of the ups and downs of the oil patch, Boise Cascade Office Products announced last month that it would open a national customer service center here, providing employment for 300 people.
And even though Wyoming still ranks 50th in terms of technology employment, Quark Inc., a Colorado software company, opened a processing and distribution plant last year in Cheyenne, just over the border from Colorado. Indeed, without a personal income tax or corporate income tax, Wyoming is emerging as a low-tax alternative to Colorado.
But planners seeking growth have to contend with several obstacles. As the mountain towns are booming, the plains towns are hemorrhaging population. Teton County's magnificent mountains draw floods of tourists annually. Jackson Hole has become a booming playground for the rich, with Wyoming's busiest airport and land values that have quadrupled in the 1990's. But much of the landscape seen by visitors on Wyoming's two interstate highways is flat, treeless and windswept.
Officials also have to deal with Wyoming's standoffishness about change. In a survey conducted last fall for the Wyoming Heritage Foundation, a leading business group, one-quarter of respondents did not want the state to spend more money on economic development, and 8 percent described the biggest threat to the state economy as "people moving here."
Wyoming's stubborn streak is captured by the image of a cowboy on a bucking bronco, which has been enameled on state license plates for decades. But central as the cowboy myth is to Wyoming, the reality is that only 4 percent of residents work on ranches or farms. Half of the state's employment is in government or tourism. Nationwide, Wyoming ranks second in term of Federal financing per capita, about $5,200 per person. Every year, the state gets eight tourists for every resident.
Some mainstays of the economy are leery of growth. Large landowners fear that population growth will lead to a proliferation of five-acre ranchettes, with ensuing increases in property values and taxes. But with Sotheby's auctioning off Wyoming ranch land this summer, the rest of the nation has already discovered Wyoming real estate. During the 1990's, ranch land values climbed by 9.5 percent a year, without any corresponding increase in ranch output.
Wyoming is also the state most dependent on the energy industry -- a Venezuela on the high plains. Oil, gas, coal and mineral taxes account for about 40 percent of the state budget -- one of the nation's highest ratios. In 1996, these taxes added up to $862 million, the equivalent of $1,800 for every state resident. These cash cows allowed the state to enshrine in its constitution a ban on any personal income tax.
Yet over the last 15 years, the total dollar value of Wyoming's oil and gas production dropped in half, hitting $2.2 billion last year. In the kind of calculus made in all oil exporting nations, for each $1 drop in oil prices, Wyoming loses $10 million in tax revenues. In the last year, oil prices dropped roughly in half. Energy companies are wary of population growth because they fear that they will pay the bills for new schools and roads.
The result of the energy industry roller coaster is a Wyoming landscape dotted with ghost towns from the 1960's and 1970's, too modern to be quaint.
But energy is still where the investment dollar is. With demand strong for Wyoming's low sulphur coal, the state tripled its coal production in the last 15 years, becoming the nation's largest producer. Believed to hold the nation's largest natural gas reserves, Wyoming is increasing gas production at a steady clip.
With energy companies largely headquartered out of state and half of the state's land owned by the Federal Government, Wyoming has often felt like an economic colony. People in Cody, Wyo., drive to Billings, Mont., to shop, people in Rock Springs, Wyo., drive to Salt Lake City for amusement parks, college students in Laramie, Wyo., drive to Denver for the bars and for major-league sporting events.
Last fall, some Wyomingites realized how fragmented their state had become when Wyoming politicians were spotted chatting up constituents at Denver Broncos' football games.
Now a small reverse migration may be starting, as businesses start crossing from northern Colorado into Cheyenne, already Wyoming's most populous city. Mr. Fleischli, who grew up in Cheyenne, a city of 55,000, said, "I went to the Chamber of Commerce meeting the other day, and I was amazed at how many people I didn't know."

HEADLINE: SHOOTINGS IN A SCHOOLHOUSE: THE TOWN;
Attack Hits Home for Many in a Middle-Class Neighborhood Both Modern and Rural

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ore., May 22

 BODY:
First, a chain-link fence was erected outside the suburban high school here to keep out deer. Then gates were added to keep out drug dealers. Today the fence bore flowers, poems and prayers in memory of teen-agers shot by a fellow student.
"They try to protect us, then it comes from within," said Kelly Bachelder, a 16-year-old junior standing a few feet from the Thurston High School cafeteria where a 15-year-old, identified by the police as Kipland P. Kinkel, sprayed rifle fire on Thursday morning. 
 All day long today, students, graduates, neighbors and parents came to the fence around the school, leaving bouquets of lilies wrapped in florist cellophane, red roses in a household vase, a sprig of pink rhododendrum blooms from a backyard garden. Several mourners said they felt as if they were in a bad dream, acting out scenes they had watched on television from the comfort of their living rooms, images from distant places like Pearl, Miss.; West Paducah, Ky., and Jonesboro, Ark.
"All that didn't greatly affect me -- I didn't know anyone there," said Emily Payne, a sophomore, talking about the recent school shootings in those communities. "Now I know half the people in the hospital."
Little in the solidly middle-class Thurston district of Springfield lends itself to easy pop psychology. One of Oregon's fastest-growing neighborhoods, Thurston has a landscape of bicycle paths, flowering shrubs and neatly kept homes that quickly gives way to cow and horse pastures and the foothills of the Cascades. A 10-minute drive from the university city of Eugene, Thurston shares Oregon's tolerant "western New England" politics and its high-technology "Silicon Forest" economy.
But 45 minutes from the hunting and camping of Willamette National Forest, Thurston also embodies Oregon's cultural mix, where half the households have guns and half have home computers.
In a setting where many people grow up with guns, it is the use of them by children to shoot classmates that has alarmed people.
"Kids used to go into the school parking lot with rifles on racks in their trucks," said Greg Deedon, a 30-year-old Springfield Fire Department paramedic who attended high school here in the mid-1980's. "But it never ever crossed our minds to use our rifles against someone else."
Mr. Deedon and two other paramedics were tying blue ribbons around telephone poles on Main Street, part of a Fire Department campaign called "Let It Stop Here." He and his colleagues, all fathers of young children, attributed the generational difference to the desensitizing levels of casual violence now found on television and in video games and music.
They quickly cited a video game that urged players to "kill all the people," songs on the radio about "kill, kill, kill" and a Marilyn Manson concert T-shirt that says: "Just kill yourself, hang yourself."
At the high-school fence, Emily Payne, 15, agreed, saying the problem was not guns, but attitudes toward violence. "There are too many guns in movies. People see people pulling out guns and blowing each other away," said Miss Payne, who is growing up in a household where hunting rifles are kept unloaded and locked in an upstairs cabinet.
The Rev. Polly Moak, a Congregational minister, said that the only way to break the cycle of student killings was to tighten controls on guns.
"Access to guns has to be greatly restricted," she said, watching television camera crews hovering around a knot of weeping girls. "We could become another England. They see the same violent things we do, but they don't have the guns."
