HEADLINE: Pocket Change, Not Social Change;
New Deals Give New Yorkers Small but Instant Benefits

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Sales tax cuts on clothing. Free rides on the Staten Island Ferry. Reduced express-bus fares. Suburban railroad ticket discounts. Bonus Metrocard rides on city transit and free transfers between buses and subways. E-Z Pass discounts for bridge, tunnel and New York Thruway tolls. And, thanks to the state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, planned for Thursday, customers will soon see their electricity bills cut by about 20 percent; just before Election Day, they'll be getting refund checks, too.
New York has long demanded more from its taxpayers than most other states demand from theirs. It still does, but New York voters might forget that when faced with the array of rebates, discounts and buy-one-get-one-free offers that Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have been giving away lately. 
 When they ran for office, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani both promised to change New York's status as a symbol of big government and high taxes. They have reduced the size of government and the overall tax burden. (And just last month, the Governor reminded voters of his affinity for a smaller government by cutting $760 million worth of programs from the Legislature's budget.)
But going beyond conventional, one-shot tax cuts, they appear to be leading the nation with a stream of small but steady benefits. Especially in an election year, tangible pocketbook savings, like free transfers between the subway and bus, are vivid daily reminders of what government has done for you lately.
"We've gone from the era of big public works to big discounts," said Dr. Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center. "Government is looking more and more like a big retailer. They're targeting their customers -- their constituents -- with tax credits, abatements and price discounts. We've gone to a kind of coupon government. It's like the coffee shops where you get the 11th cup free."
This smorgasbord of government givebacks, each aimed at a particular constituency, means that millions of New Yorkers have already begun to reap annual savings of hundreds of dollars. Families qualifying for multiple programs may net thousands.
Still more savings are in the works. In coming months, the state is scheduled to cut auto registration fees, give tax credits to the elderly with incomes under $60,000, and grant rebates on personal income and homeowner property taxes in the city and on school taxes outside the city. Unlimited-use transit passes are to make their debut this summer.
All this sudden generosity -- a veritable era of New Deals -- is a departure from the New York traditions of ribbon cuttings for big public works projects and the announcements of bold new social programs.
The reversal reflects new political and economic realities. Long dominated by liberal Democrats, New York finally yielded to the national backlash against big government and took a conservative Republican turn with the elections of Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki.
And now, after being squeezed by the recession of the early 1990's, the Governor and Mayor are enjoying a surge of surplus revenues from the recovering economy, especially on Wall Street.
Although some critics dismiss the new approach as a vote-getting ploy, proponents like Mr. Pataki say it reflects a sea change in social and economic philosophy.
"Government takes too much," Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said in an interview. "And we're doing as much as we can on as many fronts as we can to bring down the costs that have taxed people out of their homes and driven out jobs from the community."
Givebacks are also starting to crop up elsewhere. "State governments are trying to be more customer-oriented, so maybe we are getting a little more sophisticated," said Brian J. Weberg, program director for the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Last year, Oregon sent each taxpayer a $280 refund check. New Jersey has sent property tax rebates to qualified homeowners for several years. In Connecticut, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, wrangled an agreement from the General Assembly to send tax refunds of up to $200 per family in July.
A recent survey by the National Governors Conference of state-of-the-state messages found governors proposing property tax relief in Alabama, Kentucky, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Virginia and Wisconsin, as well as in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
Government handouts are routinely denounced when they take the form of welfare grants, corporate subsidies, tax breaks for the wealthy and payments to farmers for not growing food. But couched as rewards deserved by the hard-working middle class, they are irresistible.
"The cuts are great," said Vinnie Tranchina, who was riding the Staten Island Ferry one spring day after a night shift in Manhattan as a heating and air-conditioning mechanic. The free ferry and free bus transfers have lowered his annual commuting costs to about $750 from $1,625. A fellow rider, Sebastian Trovato, a videotape technician, added, "The fare cuts are the equivalent of a pay raise."
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Chairman, E. Virgil Conway, recalled the emotional "thank you" he got from an office secretary for abolishing two-fare transit zones in the city. "There were tears in her eyes," he said. "Between her and her husband, they figured it saved $1,500 a year -- enough extra for them to afford to adopt a child."
Granting benefits has proved especially tempting in a campaign season. "This is the political equivalent of Christmas, except this Santa Claus comes only once every four years," said Hank Morris, a Manhattan political consultant. "It's a modern version of giving out goodies to political leaders, but going over their heads and directly to the people. In a close election, it can and would be the difference."
Pollsters like John Zogby expect the benefits to garner votes for the generous politician. "One would have to be a fool to suggest it hasn't helped," he said. Noting that transit discounts aid city residents, most of whom are Democrats, he said, "New York City is not an area Pataki's going to win, but he's chipping away at the opposition's base and shoring up his statewide totals for his national aspirations."
And now, politicians vie to outdo each other. A Democratic contender for Governor, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, has been pressing for 12 Metrocard rides for the price of 10, literally one-upping Mr. Pataki's formula. And Democrats in the State Senate have proposed a $100 tax refund and a $250 cut in State University tuition.
Political rivals are also jockeying for credit. Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly Speaker, was an early proponent of cutting the sales tax on clothing as what he called "a gift to the people." The idea did not remain his for long. "Pataki was smart enough to get in front of the parade on that," said Frank J. Mauro, a former Democratic Assembly aide and now director of the nonprofit Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group based in Albany that is financed by foundations and unions.
The politicians rarely ignore a chance to publicize the benefits. Mr. Pataki recently sent a letter to hundreds of thousands of homeowners reminding them to apply for new property tax breaks. Mr. Giuliani capitalized on sales tax moratoriums by going on barnstorming-style shopping sprees.
And officials are spending millions of tax dollars on "public service" television, radio and print promotions that critics say are virtual re-election ads. "These are all thinly veiled campaign spending," said Gene Russianoff of the New York Public Interest Research Group. "They've elevated it to an art form. No good deed goes uncredited. I'm surprised they haven't put the Governor's picture on the Metrocard."
Critics say the taxpayer savings trade away the future for the present. "It trivializes government," said Dr. Moss of N.Y.U. "In an era of two-term limits, politicians want to do immediate things to catch attention. Nobody wants to invest in a Second Avenue subway because there's no direct payoff."
Another problem: The benefits ultimately cost billions of dollars in lost revenue and may not survive if the economy sours. "The Governor doesn't have much of a rainy-day fund," warned Fred Siegel, a fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, the Washington-based think tank of the moderate Democratic Leadership Council.
Mr. Pataki's fans tout him as the state's first Governor to cut transit fares. Yet transit advocates say that while they love the discounts, the savings still do not make up for the fare increases and curtailed services that Mr. Pataki imposed in 1995.
Old-style general tax cuts are losing favor because they seem to make little impression on taxpayers. In 1995, the state cut personal income taxes by a fourth. Yet many taxpayers forgot about the cut. "I think they learned a lesson," Mr. Mauro said of policy makers. "That cut cost almost $4 billion, but their polling showed that people didn't feel anything."
"Broad-based tax cuts have no sex appeal," said Arthur J. Kremer, former chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. "Now it's targeted tax cuts, to do good things plus get votes. If you're going to give people a tax cut, at least let them know they got it. Eleven rides for the price of 10 -- people relate to that."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Issues Extend Selloff, Weakening Market
The stock market fell yesterday for the fourth time this week, hurt by drops in Dell and other technology shares on further worries about the impact of Asian economic problems. Losses among drug stocks also led the market down. 
 The Dow industrials lost an early 31-point gain to end 17.93 points lower at 9,114.44, still finishing the week with a gain of 18.44 points. But the Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, dropped sharply for the third consecutive day, down 17.93 points, to 1,805.00, for a weekly loss of 41.77 points. Trading was slow heading into the Memorial Day weekend. Page D3.
 
Treasury prices gained modestly. The 30-year Treasury yield eased to 5.90 percent from 5.92. A week ago the yield was 5.97 percent. D3.
 
Six Deaths Among Viagra Users
Pfizer and the Food and Drug Administration said six users of the company's drug Viagra had died. Although it remains unclear whether the deaths were related to the drug, Pfizer's stock fell 3.4 percent. A8.
 
Computer Associates Jackpot
The three top executives of Computer Associates will get $1.1 billion worth of the software company's stock under a compensation plan that awards them based on share performance. More than half the award goes to Charles B. Wang, the chief executive. Had the award been divided evenly among all 9,850 employees, each would have received shares worth about $113,000. D15.
 
The N.Y.S.E. will start accepting comments next month on a new rule that gives member companies more leeway to adopt stock option plans without shareholder approval. D3.
 
Brazil Sets Phone Company Split
Brazil approved the breakup of the state-controlled telephone company Telebras into 12 holding companies, an important step toward the company's $20 billion sale in July. D14.
 
U.S. Takeovers in Asia Soar
United States takeovers of Asian companies have hit a record, reflecting the economic distress in parts of Asia and the bargains many American buyers see in picking up businesses there. D2.
 
South Korea's unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent in April, a record. D2.
 
Reichmann in Big U.S. Buying Spree
Paul Reichmann, the Canadian developer, has purchased 18 office buildings and 6 shopping centers in the United States for a total of $350 million. D3.
 
Economic Sanctions for Aiding Iran
The Senate voted nearly unanimously for legislation that would punish foreign companies that provide sensitive missile technology or expertise to Iran. Clinton advisers are urging a veto, but support for the bill in Congress makes it veto-proof. A3.
 
Questions About Air Safety System
A billion-dollar air traffic control system to start service next spring lacks alarms and safeguards to warn of an impending failure, the system's maintainance technicians say. Their union is seeking to delay the phase-in but Federal aviation officials plan to proceed anyway, though they agree a better alarm system would be desirable. A8.
 
New Light on Nazi Gold Trade
The Swiss Government endorsed a wartime trade in looted Nazi gold, and in at least one instance, Swiss bankers deliberately sought out gold they knew to be looted, declassified United States documents show. A4.
 
New Challenge to Teamster Leader
The head of the teamsters' 250,000-member warehouse division will campaign against James P. Hoffa for the union's presidency, after indications that another Hoffa challenger was withdrawing from the race. A8.

HEADLINE: In a Poor District, Success With New Curriculum

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 22

 BODY:
At the heart of the final State Supreme Court ruling Thursday in the decades-long battle over funding for urban schools was a prescription for instituting a single teaching method to lift reading and math scores.
That prescription is the Success for All program, a comprehensive and highly structured curriculum that has been at work in this poor Monmouth County district for the last six years. Under the court's ruling, state education officials must extend the program to all of the state's 28 "special needs districts" -- primarily urban school districts with poorly performing students, little property wealth and a host of social problems, like poverty and unemployment. The program is to be introduced to the approximately 300 schools in these districts at a rate of 50 schools per year. 
In the time that it has been at work in Asbury Park, the program has been attacked by some as too rigid and structured. Others have embraced it, adopting a fervor usually reserved for 12-step programs as they intone its slogans. ("If you work the program, the program will work for you" is one.)
Objective measures indicate the program is working, although some of the improvements have been modest. Reading scores among elementary pupils over the last five years have risen like a series of stair steps. At the middle school level, state testing of eighth graders showed 76 percent of them writing at grade level in 1997 compared with 46 percent in 1996, and 80 percent reading at grade level compared with 75 percent in 1996.
But with its emphasis on family support for pupils, many of the program's benefits are less tangible, said Alberto Reinoso, the principal of the Thurgood Marshall Elementary School.
Mr. Reinoso described how pupils who are at risk of failure are identified and helped by the program's family support teams, made up of teachers, administrators, counselors and parent coordinators -- residents of the school district who act as liaisons between parents and the school. Mr. Reinoso described how support teams discovered one pupil who was not eating because his mother had died and his father could not cook, another who was sleeping in class because he had no bed at home, and a third who was missing school because he had no winter coat. In the first case, school staff members took turns preparing meals for the family for two months until the father learned to cook. In the second, the school bought the family a bed, and in the third case, school officials started an annual coat drive to make sure that problem would not arise again for any of their 720 pupils.
"What has happened as a result is that the community is no longer thinking of the schools as a place where a bunch of white teachers who don't really care are just collecting a paycheck," Mr. Reinoso said. "And all of this has happened because Success for All really believes in parental involvement."
Developed at Johns Hopkins University's Center for Research on the Education of Students Placed at Risk, the program is the brainchild of Robert Slavin, a psychologist who first tested it 13 years ago in a Baltimore public school. Since then, Success for All has spread to 750 schools in 40 states. At one time, professionals from the schools using the approach were so few that they could meet for retraining in a single annual convention in a Baltimore hotel, said Kathy Ahl, Thurgood Marshall's full-time Success For All "facilitator," a professional trained by John Hopkins to help teachers carry out the program. Now, Success for All teachers hold three regional meetings a year in large convention hotels.
Mr. Reinoso said the program had been well received by teachers, who in recent years have been confronted with several "often faddish" teaching approaches. At the heart of Success for All is a standardized approach to reading and writing instruction. Johns Hopkins provides the course materials and sets the schedule of exercises, which is strict. The center at Johns Hopkins also insists on "cooperative learning," in which pupils are encouraged to work together while teachers move among them to defuse potential conflicts, Ms. Ahl said.
"It's good because it takes the focus off the teacher and fosters the independent learning that we are aiming for," she said. "It makes us teachers the 'guide on the side' rather than the 'sage on the stage.' "
On a recent day, these approaches could be seen at work in three classrooms amid a low buzz of what the teachers like to call "positive noise."
Jessica Evans's first graders worked in groups of three to help one another construct three- or four-sentence paragraphs representing alternative outcomes to a story they had read aloud in class. Time spent: 20 minutes, then on to the next task.
In Tia Ramseur's third-grade classroom, pairs of pupils scattered across the room and arranged their chairs in love-seat configurations. They alternated reading pages of a story to each other, one pupil helping to decode the text when a partner stumbled. Time spent: 15 minutes, then on to vocabulary.
In Margaret George's fifth-grade class for pupils considered talented and gifted, teams of four children each constructed miniature replicas of archaeological sites using dirt and plaster fossils in a shoebox. Time spent: 20 minutes, then on to a related writing exercise.
Ms. George said she uses the Success for All materials and approach even though she is not required to, because the program provides continuity for pupils who may encounter the program in another class, and because "it adds a richer and fuller dimension" to the material she covers. "I was wary at first because I thought that it might impose too much structure and inhibit creativity for me and students," she said. "But that all changed when I saw how flexible it is. Sometimes we just have to use the set time limits as suggestions."
Mr. Reinoso said that in addition to the cost of about $70,000 per year per school for materials and training from Johns Hopkins, schools also must hire an attendance officer, a parent coordinator and a program facilitator. Schools also must be willing to use substitute teachers trained in the program when a regular teacher is absent or being retrained. Because of the commitment that is required, Johns Hopkins will not let a school introduce the program until 80 percent of its teachers vote to do so.
In the schools, there have been heated debates over whether Success for All is an administration-centered program, in that it gives principals clear criteria by which to measure a teacher's performance, or whether it is a teacher-centered program that provides strict guidelines, materials and lesson plans. Ms. Ahl eschews both labels.
"It's really a child-centered program," she said.
The emphasis on parental involvement was on display today as Geneva Johnson, the school's parent coordinator, conducted a session for two dozen parents -- some of whom work part time in the school as paid aides -- to learn about New Jersey's welfare reform program from a state social services worker. The program, Work First, tries to get mothers off welfare and into jobs in private industry. Ms. Johnson said the session provided important information in a district where 63 percent of the households were headed by single mothers and 28 percent of all families were on public assistance.
"I'm on welfare and I'm a part-time aide in the school, and this meeting today gives me a chance to know what's available for me," said Tina Dingman, the mother of three pupils at the school. "But just being in the school allows me to know what's going on with my children. Plus, my kids and all of the kids look up to the parent aides."

HEADLINE: An Arts Revival Grows in New York Schools

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
New York City schools, enjoying the biggest infusion of money for art and music in more than two decades, are bringing back orchestras and field trips and art classes that had been dropped as luxuries during budget crises.
But the effort has not reached schools evenly, and many get by with only the slimmest offerings. 
 Almost 500 art and music teachers have been hired this school year, 400 more are being recruited for next fall, art and music coordinators are back in each school district for the first time since the 1970's and the city has provided several hundred schools with grants for art and music instruction. In addition, 61 of the city's 1,100 schools have received sizable grants to develop arts programs.
The enhancements are the tangible benefit of twin multimillion-dollar arts programs, one financed by the philanthropist Walter Annenberg and other donors, the other by City Hall.
Still, despite the public support, there is no citywide curriculum for the arts, unlike the core subjects of math and science, or even a consensus on how the arts should be taught. Stark disparities have emerged, and like so many others in the huge, uneven system, the differences reflect varying levels of enthusiasm from principals and other school leaders, and the focus of each school's academic program.
Generally, poorer schools offer less exposure to the arts, though the Schools Chancellor has tried to add music and art in the handful under his direct control. In more affluent schools, the music never died; parents immediately stepped in with their own funds when the school system withdrew money.
Buoyed by a healthy economy and a growing realization by arts organizations that many urban schools have effectively lost any cultural sensibility, the drive to restore arts and music in New York parallels efforts nationwide. California's education commissioner has proposed a $200 million plan to restore arts education; a national consortium of arts educators, backed by the Department of Education, has developed voluntary national standards for arts education, and a survey of education budgets in cities large and small showed restorations of money for art and music classes.
Arts advocates in New York hope to erase what they consider an embarrassment: a city famous for the arts had all but excised them from its public schools during the fiscal crises of the mid-1970's and recession of the 1980's. Of the more than 14,000 teachers who lost their jobs, art and music teachers were often the first to go. Many bands and orchestras went silent.
How far art and music have come in New York City -- and how far they need to go -- is evident in schools across the five boroughs.
Every afternoon at William Maxwell High School in Brooklyn, a cacophony blares from the second floor as students with a lot of heart but little experience blow hard into their shiny new saxophones, clarinets and trumpets. To Barbara Elk, the school's principal, it is "a beautiful noise" for a school that until this year had not had a music teacher in three years or a band in about seven.
Or enter the gym at Public School 165 in Flushing, Queens, and a curious drama unfolds. Fifth graders, lead by a sixth grade mentor, shimmy and prance across the parquet floor, retelling the story of the Titanic through dance.
At the other end of the spectrum is P.S. 180 in Harlem, a school of stubbornly low test scores. The local district's arts education coordinator wants the new principal, Joseph Furey, to improve art and music, but he contends that the school's success will be measured in reading and math.
"What comes first?" Mr. Furey asks. "Music?"
Still, the progress in many schools has made some arts advocates hopeful of change for the better, but no one predicts instant, universal improvement.
Sharon Dunn, the school system's special assistant for the arts, estimates it will take a few years before all schools have either art or music programs for all their students. And while Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew vows never to preside over the decimation of art and music education, people in and outside of the system are skeptical about his ability to reach all schools. There is concern that when money dries up or a dedicated teacher or principal moves on, programs will suffer.
"A lot of people say they want to make it so the arts programs are not personality-dependent, so that if the leadership in a school changes or a wonderful teacher leaves the program it won't die," said Nancy Shankman, the director of arts for Bronx high schools who has been involved with arts education for 36 years.
"However, very honestly I don't know that that will ever happen," she said. "The bottom line is that many of the principals in the system now have come through the New York City school system in the last 20 years and have not had music and art in their lives, and therefore it is not part of their frame of reference."
 
The History
Fiscal Crises Leave Arts in the Lurch
Before the cuts began in the 1970's, most schools had at least one art or music teacher. By 1991, two-thirds of the elementary schools had none. Many principals made do with outsiders or assigned regular classroom teachers to art or music classes, though they often had little arts training.
Elementary schools were hit particularly hard, because their pupils are not required under state education standards to receive art or music instruction. The state requires junior high students to receive a year of music and a year of art, and high school students need a semester of each to graduate, though the requirements are routinely waived. And where they are not, classes can be deadly dull, administrators say.
"We're talking showing slides on the wall and calling it art appreciation," said Leonard Trerotola, who supervises art education for a group of Staten Island and Brooklyn high schools.
Over time, arts, cultural and philanthropic organizations, now numbering at least 129, entered the void. They began providing visiting artists or trips to museums or other assistance for schools, for nothing or a nominal charge.
In addition to their altruism, institutions from Lincoln Center to the Brooklyn Museum entered the schools out of concern that having a city of young people with little exposure to the arts ultimately would threaten the survival of concert halls or museum galleries.
"It helps develop the audience of the future, which is of special importance in a city like New York, where the arts are an integral part of the economic life," said Martin Segal, former director of Lincoln Center and an organizer of the just-concluded Arts Education Week, during which cultural institutions and schools showed off their art and music endeavors. "Nobody is born loving Mozart."
What started the current return to the arts was a grant from the Annenberg Foundation. The publishing magnate Walter H. Annenberg pledged $500 million in 1993 to education reform nationwide. Part of that money, $12 million, has gone to New York City's public schools for academic programs in the arts. The $12 million is seed money, to be matched two to one by private donations to finance a $36 million program. So far, $10.6 million has been raised.
In the program, which is competitive, only 61 schools out of about 500 that applied have received grants, most of them $75,000 a year, to develop arts programs in cooperation with nonprofit cultural institutions, like the Metropolitan Opera.
A committee of teachers, administrators and arts consultants recommend which schools should receive grants. The Center for Arts Education, the board of nonprofit organization created to administer the Annenberg grant, has the final say.
A vast majority of schools, like P.S. 165, already provided some arts programs. From now on, a greater effort will be made to reach schools with little arts programming, said the project administrator, Hollis Headrick of the Center for Arts Education.
P.S. 165 uses the money in part for its dance program, created with the help of Kathleen Isaac, a dancer. The program fosters creativity, helps schoolchildren appreciate dance and gives them some exercise. The grant was "manna from heaven," said the principal, Petronella Cellura.
Regular classroom teachers at P.S. 7 in the Bronx troop up to the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx, where they receive basic art lessons themselves to carry back to their students. Toting a pad of his own modest scribblings of river scenes, Paul Tomizawa, a first-year teacher, wants to use the nearby Hudson River as a motif for science, math and art instruction in his third-grade classroom. "I'm dying for some arts ideas other than using crayons on construction paper," he said.
City Hall and the Board of Education realized that the Annenberg program would not reach most schools. Last year, his re-election year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council agreed to provide $75 million during three years to promote arts and music instruction. The Mayor has proposed doubling next year's arts budget to $50 million from $25 million.
The program, called Project Arts, has restored art and music coordinators to each local school district for the first time in two decades, and has given grants of $40 to $60 a child to about 350 schools for art and music instruction. In large schools, that is enough to hire a teacher, and in smaller ones it has paid for desperately needed supplies like instruments and paints.
 
The Future
Getting Support From All Sides
Which schools have good arts programs is often determined by the zeal of parents, principals and superintendents, creating stark disparities that are not lost on the students. Even with the Annenberg program and more city money for arts education, some schools in more affluent areas rely on donations from parents.
At P.S. 234 in TriBeCa, for instance, fourth and fifth graders take music lessons twice a week, paid largely through the $50,000 the parents' association raises each year through such activities as silent auctions.
At the same school, city money pays for beginning music instruction -- vocal training and percussion lessons on wood blocks -- for kindergartners through third graders. The result is that all of the 650 students take art or music at least once a week, and usually more, because several classroom teachers incorporate them in reading and writing lessons, says the principal, Anna Switzer. Without the money raised by the parents' association, many fewer students would be exposed to art and music, despite the new infusion of city money.
"I realize we're very lucky," said Morgan Pratt, a fifth-grade violin student. "Some schools have classes in the bathroom."
Although it is hard to find a school completely devoid of art, P.S. 180 in Harlem comes close. Thanks to the district art coordinator, Shelly Alpert, it offers visual art instruction to fourth and fifth graders by a visiting artist from the organization Studio in a School.
But a majority of the more than 400 students make do without a full-time art or music teacher, relying mostly on occasional visits from professional singing groups. Some teachers make an effort, like Kathleen Forbes, a prekindergarten teacher who on a recent afternoon danced and sang with her pupils to "Skip to My Lou" warbling from a phonograph.
But Mr. Furey, the principal, contends that the need to address flagging reading, writing and math performances leaves little room for what he considers extras. "We may have greater needs," Mr. Furey said. "Reading and math absolutely take priority."
And he does not think that many of his students are ready for intensive art or music. "You put art out there and the students destroy it," he said, adding that he sees their musical tastes as limited. "What do they know about music? They know rap and gangsta rap."
In the so-called Chancellor's District, made up of 12 failing elementary and middle schools under Dr. Crew's control, each school has restored music, art or both to the curriculum. But reading, math and other core subjects take precedent, and the schools rarely allow field trips because they cut in on instructional time.
"My kids have to read," said Marjorie Elliot, who coordinates art for the special district.
 
The Quandary
Art for Art's Sake, Or Means to an End?
Even with the infusion of resources, the school system has not decided what constitutes good art education. Sharon Dunn, Dr. Crew's special assistant for arts education, prefers an approach combining music and art instruction with basics like reading and math..
This approach played out on a recent day at P.S. 43 in the Far Rockaway section of Queens. The art teacher, Joanne Ellis, read "The Mountain That Loved a Bird," written by Eric Carle, to 24 second graders. She then gave them paper, colored pens and other materials, and minutes later they chattered away about their own purple birds and yellow mountains.
But some warn against tying the arts too closely to other subjects, worried that doing so leaves little room for students to follow their imaginations. And they argue that the very notion that arts must be connected to other subjects suggests that the arts are not worthy in their own right.
Even as schools debate the best way to teach the arts, many educators say they worry that despite the current commitment, the future of arts education will depend largely on the economy.
"Well, the bull market will continue until the next millennium," jokingly said Terry Baker, a private art education consultant advising the Annenberg initiative. "My feeling is without a good economy it's going to be hard to sustain it. Maybe as people see things work well for the kids they will be likely to support it, though, even in a bad economy."
That hope is enough to gratify many a teacher. "It's incredible," said David Steinberg, the music teacher at William Maxwell High School, listening to the tentative strains of his students trying to play their music scales. "I try to keep myself from dancing."
 
Do Arts Aid Learning? A 2-Edged Sword
 Behind the re-emerging patchwork of painting and mime and music in New York City schools is an academic study of how instruction in the fine arts affects brain development and the ability to learn other subjects.
Some educators have argued that the study of art and music helps with the study of academic subjects. But others, particularly experts in brain development, are contending that the research is not conclusive and that the arts should be accepted as valuable on their own.
While at the University of California at Irvine, Frances Rauscher, a researcher now at the University of Wisconsin at Oshkosh, conducted a pioneering study showing that preschoolers who took piano lessons improved their spatial temporal reasoning, the kind used to solve puzzles. A companion study showed similar, but more modest, gains for college students who listened to classical music.
But Dr. Rauscher said she is dismayed that her conclusions are often taken too far and are used to justify music education.
"We may learn the A B C's better by singing them, but that is not learning musical concepts," she said. "I think there is a real danger in developing a philosophy around infusion."
Likewise, Howard Gardner, the Harvard University professor of education whose theories of multiple intelligences have gained wide popularity among educators, worries about carrying the argument that music aids math education too far.
"Those who live by the sword must die by the sword," Dr. Gardner said. "That is, if you claim that the reason to teach music is to make kids into better mathematicians, and those claims turn out to be unsubstantiated, then you have lost the rationale for music classes."

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE SUCCESSOR;
U.S. Companies Wary Of Their Prospects Now

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Earlier this month, 40 American business executives on a trade mission to Indonesia met with a man who had recently been appointed Vice President. The man, B. J. Habibie, assured his skeptical visitors that unlike his predecessors, he had real power over domestic and foreign policy.
And, according to a businessman who was there, he also assured them that he was committed to economic reform. 
 Doubts about whether Mr. Habibie had real power were partly erased this week when he was named President, replacing Mr. Suharto. But whether Mr. Habibie, who is faced with rescuing Indonesia from economic collapse, is truly committed to reform is something some American executives still question.
"We have concerns here," one businessman said. "He doesn't have a track record that suggests conservative fiscal management. It's just the opposite."
Of all Indonesian officials, Mr. Habibie is perhaps the best known to American business executives, largely because of his role in spearheading Indonesia's efforts to develop an aircraft business, where he worked with companies like Boeing and General Electric.
An aeronautical engineer by training, he was also Minister for Science and Technology, which meant that virtually any American company wanting to sell computers or telecommunications equipment in what was a fast-growing Indonesia probably came in contact with him.
But American businesses have mixed views, on one hand describing Mr. Habibie as visionary, but also saying he is prone to reckless projects, like the decades-long effort to develop an airplane industry, something extremely difficult for a country at Indonesia's state of development.
A 70-seat commuter plane was produced, and Mr. Habibie announced plans to build a manufacturing plant in the United States, but the plane has not yet been certified by the Federal Aviation Administration, orders have been few and no American factory has been built.
The project is now being cut back as part of the multibillion-dollar aid agreement with the International Monetary Fund.
"He's certainly an extremely intelligent guy and he's also a guy who has demonstrated a commitment to the future," said David Rothkopf, a former Commerce Department official who is now president of the Newmarket Company, an international advisory firm based in Washington. "With the force of his personality, he can make improbable things happen -- at least to a certain degree."
Mr. Habibie, who speaks English and German, is often described as full of energy and enthusiasm, a person who talks a mile a minute, goes off on tangents and is almost impossible to shut up once he gets going.
"He always has ideas," said Ernest Bower, president of the U.S.-Asean Business Council, a group of 400 American companies with business interests in Southeast Asia. "It seems like they are hitting him like electric shocks."
Many questions remain about what will happen during Dr. Habibie's tenure, even how long it will last, and whether the military will support him. What matters most is not Mr. Habibie's personality but whether he can bring stability to the market.
Still, some business executives say he could be good for American business.
"I think it will be a big boost for American business," said George Benson, a Washington-based consultant to American oil companies who spent much of his career working for Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil company.
"He's tight with Boeing, he's tight with G.E. He's been here and comes every year. He's on a first-name basis with a whole flock of c.e.o.'s of big corporations."
Mr. Habibie's interest in technology could open opportunities for American companies.
Scott McNealy, chief executive of Sun Microsystems, once described Mr. Habibie as "an energetic Renaissance man who knows and understands technology from aerospace to computers." His office, Mr. McNealy wrote afer his 1993 visit to Jakarta, was "more like a museum for model planes, hundreds of them."
But some Americans worry that Mr. Habibie's ties are stronger to Germany, where he went to college and spent many years working at an aircraft company, and to Japan, a big investor in Indonesia.
Although the new President has championed technology in Indonesia, he is not a big believer in free markets. He has been extremely close to Mr. Suharto, which makes people question whether he will really dismantle the network of crony capitalism that Mr. Suharto erected.
Some also question his sincerity about human rights reforms. When he met with the American business delegation this month, he brushed off questions about rights issues, noting that the United States also has problems, and adding that any abuses in Indonesia were the result of rogue police officers or soldiers.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Indonesian Troops Retake The Parliament Building
Indonesia's Army retook Parliament in a midnight raid by hundreds of soldiers, who pushed, prodded, and cajoled more than 2,000 students to leave the complex they had occupied for five days. There were no casualties reported in the operation, which lasted barely two hours, but witnesses said some students initially resisted the soldiers. A1
 
The leader of Indonesia's military consolidated his power under the country's new President, B. J. Habibie, left, removing another general who was his chief rival. Diplomats said they expected the removal of two other prominent commanders loyal to the ousted general. A7 

Irish Vote on Referendum
Citizens in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic voted together for the first time in nearly 80 years in a referendum that would completely transform the island's political institutions and social traditions. Officials will begin counting the hand-marked ballots today, and they said the results would not be announced until the afternoon there. A6
 
Senate Votes for Sanctions
The Senate voted to punish foreign enterprises or institutions -- especially in Russia -- that provide sensitive missile technology or expertise to Iran. The House passed the same measure by voice vote in November, so the bill now goes to the White House, where the President is being advised to veto the bill. A3
 
Senate Acts on Arms Control
The Senate approved legislation that some arms-control experts warned would greatly undercut enforcement of an international treaty banning chemical weapons. A3
 
Earthquake in Bolivia Kills 33
A powerful earthquake killed at least 33 people in central Bolivia, and officials feared that there could be more dead among the 100 people missing in the rubble of two towns. A3
 
Files Hint at Swiss Action
Declassified United States documents suggest for the first time that the Swiss Government itself endorsed the Swiss trade in looted Nazi gold and that, in at least one instance, Swiss bankers sought out gold they knew to be looted. The documents were said to have been uncovered in research for a major United States Government report on Switzerland's Nazi gold transactions last year. A4
 
Gingrich to Skip Embassy Site

HEADLINE: Papers Show White House Staff Favored a China Satellite Permit

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The White House released a trove of internal documents today showing that President Clinton approved the Chinese launching of an American satellite last February after his top staff advised him that the economic and diplomatic advantages outweighed the opposition of Federal prosecutors.
The prosecutors had warned that the approval would jeopardize their investigation into the satellite maker's earlier, unauthorized help to China's rocket program, the President was told in the memorandums. 
 The documents, demanded by Congress, were made available to the news media today by the White House, which argued that they showed that the President, while aware of the risks, approved the launching on the basis of policy debate and not because the chairman of the satellite company, the Democratic Party's largest personal contributor, was pressing hard for a decision.
"I think the decision was the correct one," Mr. Clinton said in remarks in the White House Rose Garden, where he came to talk about the highway bill that passed Congress today, but was clearly prepared for questions on China. It "was based on what I thought was in the national interest and supportive of our national security," he said.
The President said the Justice Department's concerns were evaluated and balanced against the views of all the other participating departments, who "concluded that, on balance, we should go forward."
But Republicans questioned the President's decision and promised further inquiries. They said a preliminary review of the 394 documents the White House released raised troubling questions about Mr. Clinton's decision to overrule Justice Department objections to a Presidential waiver to allow the launching.
"There's no question there were plenty of red flags at the time," said Representative Christopher Cox, the California Republican who will head a House select committee examining the China issues.
The documents paint a fascinating portrait of the intense struggles surrounding Mr. Clinton last February as he weighed whether to allow the satellite launching and ignore the pleas of prosecutors and the probable outrage from some in Congress.
A top State Department official had warned White House staff members that the satellite company, Loral Space and Communications, engaged in "unlawful" and "criminal" activity by providing valuable help to the Chinese rocket program.
And the chairman of the company, Bernard L. Schwartz, combed a White House dinner on Feb. 5, looking for Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, to plead for a decision on the satellite launching, a decision worth tens of millions of dollars to the company.
As it all played out, with the company arguing it needed an immediate decision, the senior White House staff were concluding that the President's broader strategy of engaging China should not be endangered by blocking the launching.
"We believe that the advantages of this project outweigh this risk, and that we can effectively rebut criticism of the waiver," said the memorandum to Mr. Clinton, dated Feb. 12, 1998, and signed by Mr. Berger, Larry Stein, the Congressional liaison, and Daniel K. Tarullo, assistant to the President for international economic policy.
"The project is in the national interest," the memorandum said, "because the development of China's civil communications infrastructure will promote access by Chinese citizens in remote areas to people and ideas in democratic societies." In addition, it said, "the current project also will help maintain the competitiveness of U.S. satellite exporters in a most important satellite market."
The President's top advisers warned him in the memorandum that his approval might be seen as letting Loral's space subsidiary "off the hook on criminal charges for its unauthorized assistance to China's ballistic missile program."
But they also said it would be unfair to "penalize" Loral by denying a license "before they have even been charged with any crime."
On Feb. 13, Loral's lobbyist, Tom Ross, pleaded with Mr. Berger for a "prompt decision" and mentioned how Mr. Schwartz "had intended to raise this issue with you" a week earlier at the dinner for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain "but missed you in the crowd."
White House spokesmen noted that Mr. Ross's letter was dated the day after the staff memorandum to the President recommending approval of the launching.
On Feb. 18, the President approved the deal.
Mr. Schwartz was the largest personal contributor to the Democrats last year and has donated almost $1 million since 1995. His name is not in the memorandums sent to the President for his approval.
Mr. Ross, Loral's vice president of government relations, said today that he "considered it perfectly proper for me to make an inquiry on the timing of the issue."
He said it would also have been proper for Mr. Schwartz to have asked for a prompt decision because "there is a distinction between that and demanding a favorable decision."
The documents were made available to the House International Relations Committee on the eve of a long holiday weekend. The committee requested them on May 7 after a story in The New York Times disclosed the President's decision despite the objections of Justice Department officials. A week later, it was also disclosed that a China aerospace executive funnelled almost $100,000 from the Chinese military to the Democratic Party in 1996, according to an account by a Democrat fund-raiser, Johnny Chung, who is cooperating with investigators after pleading guilty to campaign-related bank and tax fraud charges.
The chairman of the House committee, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of New York, said today that the documents raised "some troubling questions that will have to be pursued," and that the committee was awaiting further documents from the White House and other agencies.
The Justice Department is also weighing whether to investigate the President's approval for Loral, and if so, whether it should be done by its own campaign finance task force or an independent counsel, law-enforcement officials said.
The new documents complicate that decision because two senior Justice officials have played dual roles: advising the White House against Mr. Clinton's approval for Loral and deciding now whether to investigate that approval.
Today's release of documents comes as Mr. Clinton's policy on Chinese satellite launches is caught up in a cross current of diplomatic, legal and political issues.
In a month, the President is going to China, where he hopes to improve space cooperation with Beijing. But the House of Representatives this week may have upset his summit plans by overwhelmingly adopting amendments that ban future exports of American satellites to China.
Republicans said such exports may jeopardize national security by giving China the ability to learn space technology that can improve its ballistic missile capabilities.
The Clinton Administration argues that stringent safeguards insure that national security is protected and that American satellite companies need to maintain their competitiveness in an important global market, points made in the memorandum to Mr. Clinton. China, which offered low-cost services, launches about 10 percent of American satellites.
At the center of the debate is the criminal case that prompted prosecutors to express their concerns to the White House. In the spring of 1996, Loral officials helped the Chinese investigate why a rocket carrying a Loral satellite exploded. The company acknowledged that it turned information over to the Chinese without telling the Government.
The President was told by his advisers that Loral "acknowledges that an unauthorized transfer of technical information took place but Justice has not decided whether it will take criminal action against" the company.
"Justice believes that a jury would not convict once it learned that the President had found" the latest Loral satellite launching "to be in the national interest," the memorandum stated.
As a result of sanctions imposed after the killings at Tiananmen Square in 1989, satellites can be exported to China only through a Presidential waiver demonstrating that the launch is in the national interest.
Loral maintains its officials did nothing wrong. A Loral fact sheet released this week said that all its scientists did was an analysis that confirmed the findings of Chinese scientists.
But the State Department's top defense trade regulator, Will Lowell, told a White House lawyer that Loral "went beyond analysis to telling cause of failure and how to prevent," according to the lawyer's notes of the conversation.
Mr. Lowell also told the lawyer that he thought Loral's behavior was "criminal" and "unlawful," but he added that even though the company was "likely to be indicted," it was "hard to pull the plug" on a license without an indictment.
The cost of delaying approval for Loral -- which might have cleared up the question of whether the company would be indicted -- was estimated by White House aides at $4-6 million, the documents show.
In the end, the concerns of regulators like Mr. Lowell and Justice Department prosecutors from the criminal division were given less weight than the views of top-ranking political appointees and the diplomatic and commercial imperatives.
On Feb. 13, White House counsel Charles F.C. Ruff wrote a memorandum to Mr. Berger, the National Security Adviser, noting the failure of the highest officials at the Justice Department to weigh in on the satellite decision. And curiously, the documents released today contained no written communications from anyone at the Justice Department.
"The department had every opportunity to weigh in against the waiver at the highest levels and elected not to do so," Mr. Ruff wrote, adding that Mr. Berger could himself balance "the national security and criminal justice interests."
Mr. Berger already had. A day earlier he and other top advisers recommended that the President go forward with his approval.
Meanwhile, the Justice Department, despite its earlier concerns, is proceeding with the investigation, officials said.

HEADLINE: $200 Billion Bill For Public Works Passed by Congress

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Congress overwhelmingly approved today the largest public works program in the nation's history, voting to spend more than $200 billion over the next six years for roads, bridges, buses, subways, ferries and even parking garages in virtually every Congressional district.
The size of the bill, which increases Federal transportation spending by 44 percent from the $145 billion in the previous six-year plan, underscores the shifting political ground in Washington, where spending of this magnitude was almost unthinkable a year ago. 
 But with the Federal budget now in balance, the national economy still vigorous and Congress facing fall elections, the appetite for new and bigger highway and mass transit projects was both voracious and bipartisan. The House passed the bill by a vote of 297 to 86, and the Senate by a vote of 88 to 5. President Clinton said he would sign the bill.
The bill significantly increases transportation spending in every state except Massachusetts and is laden with $9.3 billion for more than 1,400 projects selected by members of Congress for their districts.
New York will receive $353 million to build a tunnel under the East River that will allow Long Island Rail Road trains to stop at Grand Central Terminal, reducing commuting times and costs for about 100,000 people who work on the East Side. The state will also get money to purchase two new boats and rebuild terminals for the Staten Island ferry, refurbish Battery Park and convert part of the General Post Office at Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, also known as the Farley building, into the new Pennsylvania Station.
New York will also see its Federal mass transit funding rise by more than 50 percent, to about $1 billion a year -- a significant turnabout from earlier versions of the bill, which called for substantially less spending on bus and subway programs.
The bill includes a provision that would substantially cut the cost of bus and subway travel for some commuters in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation by allowing employers to give workers up to $65 a month in tax-free mass transit benefits instead of salary.
New Jersey will receive $26 million to help finance a network of roads connecting the New Jersey Turnpike with the Hudson County waterfront.
The plan, which will also require a large investment of state funds, is expected to reduce the chronic traffic jams outside the Holland Tunnel and increase development opportunities on the waterfront.
Connecticut's projects include $19 million to construct an interchange on Interstate 95 in New Haven as well as funds for a bicycle and pedestrian walkway in East Hartford, improvements on the commuter rail lines linking New Haven and Stamford and a widening of Route 4 in Stonington.
"This measure may not be perfect, but it's the right economic medicine for Connecticut," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat.
Some dissenters said the legislation would force Congress to scale back other initiatives not just this year but well into the future. To help pay for the bill, Congress approved reductions of $1.8 billion for services to low-income families and $15 billion for payments to veterans who suffer disabilities resulting from smoking while in the military.
"The power of the highway lobby and the pressure to sprinkle road and bridge projects in Congressional districts all over the country created an overwhelming political force that succeeded in securing spending increases that few would have envisioned just a year ago," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center of Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit policy analysis group.
Until a week ago, President Clinton threatened to veto the bill if it called for lavish spending that would require deep cuts to other domestic initiatives. But today, Mr. Clinton said Congressional negotiators had pared the bill to acceptable levels, calling it a "historic bill to strengthen our transportation system" and "a principled compromise."
"It strengthens our commitments to encouraging mass transit, to protecting the environment, to expanding opportunities to disadvantaged businesses, to moving more Americans from welfare to work with transportation assistance," the President said in a news conference.
Once signed, the legislation, known as the Transportation Efficiency Act for the 21st Century, will replace the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act.
That legislation, when it was enacted in 1991, was intended to move Federal transportation policy beyond the era of interstate highway construction and toward financing other types of programs, from subways to bike paths to high-speed ferries.
The bill passed today calls for spending $165 billion on highway and bridge projects, $36 billion on mass transit and $2 billion on safety programs over the coming six years. In an unusual arrangement, the measure will guarantee that revenues collected from an 18.3-cent-per-gallon Federal tax on gasoline will be spent only on transportation.
The provision will prevent Congressional appropriators from using money designated for highway and transit projects for budget balancing or other programs, a typical practice of the past.
Throughout the recent days and right up until final passage, there were intense behind-the-scenes battles over how the funds should be divided among states. In the end, states from the South and West, which have traditionally received smaller shares of Federal transportation spending, saw their portion of total spending increase significantly, at the expense of Northeastern states.
"Most everyone felt they were treated pretty darn fair," said Senator John H. Chafee, a Republican from Rhode Island who was the lead Senate negotiator on the bill.
The bill insures that at least 90.5 percent of the gas tax revenues each state sends to the Federal Government are returned in transportation spending. To achieve that, states like Texas will see their Federal transportation spending increase by 60 percent or more, while states like Connecticut will receive an increase of just 13 percent, to $408 million a year.
New York's Federal highway spending will increase by 35 percent, to $1.3 billion a year, while New Jersey's will grow by 30 percent, to $676 million a year.
Still, Congressmen from the Northeast said they came out of the fight in better shape than they had expected, largely because the size of the total pot was expanded so much. "We made the best of a bad situation," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey.
Under a provision of the bill, employers will be able to remove $65 a month from a worker's existing pretax salary and give it to them as transit passes that are not subject to Federal, state or local taxes.
The arrangement not only will cut a worker's transit expenses by as much as 60 cents per ride but also will benefit employers whose payroll costs will be reduced because they will not have to pay Social Security or other taxes on the $65. The bill calls for increasing the benefit to $100 per month starting in 2002.
The program, known as Transitchek in the New York area, will also reduce the cost of the monthly unlimited-ride passes that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to begin offering for subways and buses in July. Those passes will cost $63; with Transitchek, the cost would fall to $45 or less. Mass transit advocates predict that as a result, bus and subway usage will increase substantially.
"I am pleased to report that the demise of mass transit as reported by some is premature," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who was the chief Senate negotiator on mass transit issues.
The tunnel under the East River, known as the East Side Connector, is projected to be a nine-year project that will allow Long Island Rail Road trains to stop at Grand Central Terminal; now, they complete their journeys at Pennsylvania Station on Manhattan's West Side. State officials say about 100,000 commuters must then take taxis, buses or subways back to the East Side for work at an average cost of $900 per commuter a year.
The bill includes a provision that will make State Highway 17, which runs from New York City's northern suburbs along the Pennsylvania border to the state's western reaches, into a Federal highway. The designation means that the state will receive more than $10 million in additional Federal funds each year for maintaining the road.
New York will also receive $20 million to construct a new interchange at the junction of Interstate Highways 84 and 87 in Newburgh and $15 million to paint the Hell Gate Bridge connecting Queens and Manhattan.
The bill also includes $6 million to study moving the elevated portion of the West Side Highway that extends from West 59th to West 72d Streets. Donald J. Trump has called for moving the highway because it could obscure views of the Hudson River from his proposed Riverside South high-rise development.
Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Democrat whose district includes that section of the highway sharply objected to the study, saying that the highway was just renovated at the cost of $80 million. "These taxpayer funds would be used to benefit one person: Donald Trump," Mr. Nadler said.
Mr. Nadler's aides said Representative Sue Kelly, a Republican from Westchester, had asked for the funds; Ms. Kelly could not be reached for comment this evening.
During final negotiations, several House members tried to insert amendments designed to delay or weaken Federal environmental programs, ranging from removing toxic sediments in the Housatonic River in Massachusetts to setting tougher standards for the pollutants that cause smog and haze. But most of those amendments were blocked during negotiations with the Senate.

HEADLINE: Bill to Punish Giving Missile Help to Iran Passes in Senate

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The Senate voted nearly unanimously today to punish foreign enterprises or institutions -- especially those in Russia -- that provide sensitive missile technology or expertise to Iran.
The overwhelming vote, 90 to 4, reflects the Senate's growing alarm at Iran's drive to build long-range rockets that could threaten American troops and allies in the Mideast, and frustration with Moscow for failing to curb missile know-how to Iran. 
 "Iran is a terrorist state under U.S. law," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. "This bill addresses a clear and present danger."
The House passed the same measure by voice vote last November, so the bill now goes to the White House. But President Clinton's national security advisers are urging him to veto it on the grounds that it would poison relations with Russia and other countries. Both chambers, however, approved the bill by veto-proof margins.
When asked today if the legislation hampered the President's hands-on foreign policy, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said, "There is that concern, and it is a real one."
Capitol Hill has been jolted in recent days by momentous developments in proliferation issues. In May, India exploded five nuclear devices and raised fears that Pakistan would follow suit. And Congress is weighing accusations that Mr. Clinton's decision in 1996 to relax export controls on satellites to China may have allowed Beijing to improve the accuracy of its nuclear-tipped missiles.
The bill approved today, the Iran Missile Proliferation Sanctions Act, would require the Administration to identify foreign companies or other entities that send to Iran equipment or expertise that helps it to develop its own ballistic missiles. The legislation does not call for sanctions against countries.
Companies or other entities that violate the law would face economic sanctions and a cutoff of United States Government grants and loans. The President could waive the penalties for national security reasons or if new information exonerated a suspected violator.
Economic sanctions are a favorite tool of Congress to influence foreign policy. But the Administration has argued that sanctions are becoming counterproductive and undermine its ability to conduct the affairs of state.
Just this week, the Administration tried to resolve a sticky dispute with its European allies by waiving sanctions against foreign companies doing business in Iran. Those sanctions stemmed from laws that require the President to impose penalties on any company investing more that $20 million a year in the oil or gas industry in Iran.
The legislation approved today does not specifically mention Russia. But lawmakers clearly had Moscow in mind when they wrote the bill. Russia has repeatedly promised to clamp down on the sale of missile technology to Iran, but Russian authorities have been unable or unwilling to stop the leakage.
For example, Iran has started a program to build a missile called the Shahab 3, which has a range of 800 miles, long enough to reach Israel, Turkey and Saudi Arabia.
The missile is based on a North Korean design, but Iran has also relied on Russian expertise to develop the technology.
In March, customs officials in Azerbaijan stopped a Russian shipment of 22 tons of stainless steel, which could be used to make Scud missiles, before it crossed the border into Iran.
The Administration fought desperately to delay the Senate vote today. Five times in the last six months, the Senate agreed to postpone a vote while American officials coaxed and cajoled Russia to toughen its enforcement.
Mr. Clinton dispatched his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, to Capitol Hill on Tuesday, and invited a group of Senators to the White House on Wednesday night to try to buy more time. But the Senate's patience finally ran out.
"We have a measured response to a real problem," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, said on the Senate floor today. "The real problem is the development of Iran's long-range ballistic missile capacity. We're dealing with a serious threat to American national security."
Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, said: "Iran has become the most serious threat to the stability in the Middle East. This sends a signal that selling missile technology to Iran is unacceptable."
Only a handful of Senators came to the Administration's defense today, arguing that the bill would hurt United States leverage over Russia to curb its arms sales to Iran.
"The Administration had made significant progress over the six months with the threat of this bill in place," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, who opposed the bill. "I'm trying to approach this from a practical point of view: How do we insure this doesn't continue?"
Senator Biden said it was unrealistic for the Senate to expect the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, to have "his finger on" every one of his Government's disparate agencies.
Two Republicans, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, and one other Democrat, John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, also opposed the bill.
In an otherwise decisive drubbing, the Administration won one small concession today. The Senate approved an amendment by Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, to change the bill's retroactive effective date to January 1998 from August 1995.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 27, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about Senate approval of a bill to penalize foreign enterprises that provide restricted missile technology or expertise to Iran misstated the next step. The bill now goes to a House-Senate conference committee to work out minor differences, not directly to the White House.

HEADLINE: Word and Image;
The Oldest Bias

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
The media, like societies through history, have been dominated by the young. It's time to look again.
In my field of vision, there is only one correspondent truly covering the terror-filled front of old age. He is Donald M. Murray, The Boston Globe's 73-year-old weekly columnist, a poet in prose: 
 "I am not elderly, I am old and proud of it. I am aged, like a good cheese; I am a walking history book, an elder of the tribe, tested, tempered, wise.. . .I can leave parties early.. . .I can enjoy melancholy, even revel in it. I don't have to smile so hard it hurts my face.. . .I can nap during the sermon.. . .Best of all, I can say no in a society that expects everyone else to say yes, to volunteer, to contribute, to participate."
Like it or not, affirmative action works. Just as MTV proves that it takes youth to know youth, Murray proves that it takes age to truly know age. Yet with the conspicuous exception of the septuagenarian geniuses at "60 Minutes," old-timers have been virtually banished from the media business. And that causes serious neglect of the needs and attributes of the elderly. Reporting on old age has been left almost entirely to the prejudices of the young, who favor growth, not decline, and who avert their eyes from the darkness that old folks confront.
As one of the neglected, I probably understate the case. Many of us in the last decades of life have been brainwashed into a state of denial. Misled by nips, tucks, dyes and Viagra, we are lured into betraying our class. A less self-conscious observer would say that Americans are drunk on youth and have warped the media's view of the old.
Television scoffs at viewers over the age of 49 and disregards their tastes in programming. Even when it addresses disease, the evening news avoids the pains of the present and rushes to embrace the miracle cures promised to the young. This bias toward youth is blamed on advertisers, who themselves have been misled into believing that the under-50 crowd is less sclerotic in its spending habits and more susceptible to 30-second propaganda pitches.
Newspapers, too, are alarmed by survey research that shows their readers are getting older. They think that news, like tobacco, is addictive and pine for the days when the comics and sports that hook the kids were available only in print. They are buying pathetic commercials (on television!) that beg parents to read a paper to their children.
The news media's "ageism" reflects newsroom realities. Most reporters lose their legs by age 40 and most editors are retired before 65. But the population as a whole is aging. In 1900, only 4 percent of Americans were over 65; the percentage now is 13. In 25 years, it will be at least 20 percent and a quarter of them will be over 85.
Even the few media analysts who grasp the trend underestimate the wealth and health of the old and see them mainly as a burden to the young. They think of the elderly as dependent if not helpless, unproductive if not idle, demanding rather than deserving. Yet the majority of the old are self-sufficient, middle-class consumers with more assets than young couples and with both time and talent to offer society. Poverty is now more a condition of the young than the old and sociologists discern the emergence of a potent cohort of woopies -- well-off older people.
Still, in the shrewd observation of Thomas R. Cole, the director of the Institute for Medical Humanities at the University of Texas, the elderly have been "marginalized by an economy and culture committed to the scientific management of growth without limit" and by "relentless hostility to physical decline." And as Dr. Robert N. Butler, the founder of the International Longevity Center, recently warned Congress, the rapidly growing elderly population will truly become a burden if society continues to neglect research into frailty and dementia and fails to help the old remain productive.
The obvious way to meet this challenge is to arouse the media with some urgent affirmative action. We need more seasoned -- and elderly -- correspondents to cover the travails of "retirement" and the march toward death. We need more Donald Murrays, and to inspire other writers by reprinting his work.
Murray insists on talking about death because he has discovered that most doctors won't:
"Minnie Mae and I touch more often than is usual this week. We seize the day . . .doing what has to be done, enjoying what is, not what may or may not be.. . .We each fight our lonely battles with fear and despair, but Minnie Mae and I remind each other to stop and pay attention to what is important: family, friends, neighbors, the sunlight in our woods that we notice only because of the shadow's edge."
Murray counters the smugness of athletic youth by recording the great effort he expends daily searching for the remote control, rocking himself out of an easy chair, climbing the stairs, turning in bed, straining through bifocals and racing through the supermarket to reach the men's room in time. "This sedentary life isn't easy," he reports. "Salute when you jog past me, youngster."
The most radical of all of Murray's columns, I think, was addressed to a young reader -- obviously an offspring "scrunched in the sandwich generation between a child and aging parents" -- who asked for advice about how to deal with the parents for whom she has increasing responsibility:
"I certainly cannot resist an open invitation to give advice. And that is my first suggestion. Ask for advice. You don't have to take it.. . .I was impressed one late evening, during our courtship, when Minnie Mae said that love is easy, respect is more important -- and often more difficult. As we get older we treasure respect."
My unasked advice to the media: there's a market growing out there, and a job to be done.
