HEADLINE: Humankind Battles for Scrabble Supremacy

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a staff writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
The day before they defended the honor of their species in Scrabble, Matt Graham and Joel Sherman convened for a final training session. Matt, who lives in a studio apartment in Manhattan crammed with dictionaries and word lists and Scrabble newsletters, went out to Joel's small house in the Bronx, which was crammed with the same stuff. The living room's decorative highlight was a Scrabble board showing the final game of last year's world championship, in which Joel defeated Matt.
The two sat down in Joel's kitchen at a computer much like the one they were about to play the next day. Deep Blue had already dethroned the human chess champion, occasioning great angst over the species' mental powers, but so far there had no been serious challenge in Scrabble. The match was being sponsored by The New York Times Magazine as part of the 50th anniversary of Scrabble's birth, in which The Times played a small role. Alfred Butts, the unemployed architect from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., who developed the game, determined how many tiles of each letter to include (12 E's, 6 T's, 1 Q) by laboriously counting how often each letter appeared on the front page of The Times and other New York dailies. 
 Joel turned on a program called Video Flashcards, and the letters AEEGINRTS appeared on the screen. Joel immediately began typing GRATINEES (meaning to cook food with a crust). "There's also AGENTRIES and RESEATING," he said. "What else?"
"STINGAREE," Matt said, referring to an alternate name for the stingray fish. They moved on, coming up with most possibilities in seconds. When ADEEIRRST appeared, Matt broke it down instantly: "ARTERIES, with a D left over. STEADIER, with an R. DREARIEST." They were briefly stumped by ACCEHOPUS, but within 20 seconds Joel saw CAPOUCHES.
"Is that some kind of handbag?" he asked idly.
"Some kind of hood or cowl," Matt replied, which was correct but also, of course, besides the point. At this level, you cannot get bogged down in definitions. Success requires the discipline to spend hours a day memorizing lists of playable words. It also helps if, like Matt and Joel, you are free from distractions like day jobs and marriage.
Joel, who is 36 and has been playing Scrabble since he was 6, graduated from the Bronx High School of Science, dropped out of college, worked as a bank teller and then quit, partly because of health problems. (On the Scrabble circuit he's known as G.I. Joel due to his gastrointestinal ailments.) Full-time Scrabble is not a lucrative career -- last year Joel made $35,000 -- but he survives on a small inheritance and by living at home with his father and brother. "I realize it seems crazy to spend so much time on the game," he says, "but it happens to be the one thing I've found that I can do better than most other people."
Matt, 32, who grew up in Indianapolis, dropped out of high school and came to New York to be a stand-up comic. He took up Scrabble only seven years ago, and plays on the circuit in between his appearances at comedy clubs and "Late Night With Conan O'Brien." He does not do Scrabble jokes. There's not much overlap between his worlds. "Comedy can be frustrating because it's so subjective," he says. "The nice thing about Scrabble is that it's so clear-cut. It doesn't matter how the audience is feeling. It doesn't matter if you're not a brainiac with a degree from the right school. If you score higher, you win."
Like most top players on the Scrabble tournament circuit, both Matt and Joel know perhaps 80,000 playable words, at least twice as many as the average person. But the guys' silicon opponent, a computer program named Maven, knows the entire dictionary -- 100,000 words of eight letters or less -- and can unscramble 5,000 anagrams in a second. Maven did not have to train the day before the match. The words were all securely imbedded in its memory, in a CD-ROM available in stores for $29.95.
Maven was created by Brian Sheppard, who started dabbling with the program in 1983 during an internship at I.B.M.'s research center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., home of the Deep Blue chess program. He began by programming Maven to quickly find every word that could be played each turn, grunt work that's easy for a computer. Then came the hard part: strategy.
The computer had to learn how to "bingo," the key to championship play. Bingo is Scrabble slang for using all seven tiles in your rack on one turn, good for a 50-point bonus. Experts often get two or three bingos in a game by thinking ahead instead of just going for the highest score every turn. They unload clunky letters like U or Q or W and try to maintain a balanced mix of consonants and vowels that easily combine into seven-letter words. They also try to set up spots on the board for their bingos while not leaving too many openings for the opponent.
Humans use intuition and experience to make these decisions. Maven relies instead on formulas that Sheppard developed by letting the computer play millions of games. These formulas can leave Maven blind to obvious dangers ahead -- it sometimes makes needlessly "volatile" plays, as they are called, that leave high-scoring openings for the opponent. But although Maven had lost a previous confrontation with humanity -- a brief two-game contest at a scientific conference last year -- Sheppard was confident that it would win the full best-of-11 match at The Times.
"I can almost guarantee you that Maven will play better than Matt and Joel," said Sheppard, who now works for Hasbro, the toy company that sells the Scrabble CD-ROM with the Maven program. "There are some situations in which they'll see something that Maven misses. But it will never get fatigued or miss a bingo."
Matt, the brash, impetuous member of the odd couple, refused to believe he was an underdog. "We have a slight edge," he said. "This omnipotent, all-seeing machine still makes the stupidest blunders."
Joel was more restrained, in keeping with his mild-mannered approach to Scrabble and life. "We're no better than evenly matched with Maven," he said. "The computer will make mistakes, but it has perfect word knowledge. There's just so much the human mind is capable of processing."
Man met machine on the top floor of the Times building during a seven-hour match. Playing jointly with one rack of tiles, Matt and Joel sat across a table from a Toshiba laptop loaded with Maven. John D. Williams Jr., the executive director of the National Scrabble Association, acted as referee, and before long he was hearing complaints that the computer was cheating. These were not unexpected, given one of Maven's idiosyncrasies: it picks the tiles for both players. Sheppard says most players prefer to have Maven handle tile-drawing chores, but some of the top players don't like it, and it was easy to understand Matt and Joel's suspicion as the first game started. Cursed with bad tiles, they were reduced to playing paltry words like BAN, while Maven demolished them with GROSZY (Polish coins) and DICKIEST (British slang for faultiest).
"Look, we know to play GROSZY and DICKIEST, too," Matt said after the game. "But we're working with bad racks, and it always seems to be that way with Maven. How can you not be suspicious of a machine that won't let you pick the tiles?"
Humanity's tiles improved the next game, which Matt and Joel won with help from three bingos (UPHEAVE, STEWPAN and MISEATEN). They lost the third game, and then got another bad break at the start of the fourth. Matt and Joel drew EEIJTVW and knew immediately what the best play was: JEW, which is legal in tournament play as a lower-case verb. (The noun JEW is illegal because it's capitalized.)
Maven, however, would not allow JEW. More precisely, the corporate marketers of Maven would not allow it. Five years ago, a woman who was playing Scrabble with a Holocaust survivor came across the word in the Official Scrabble Players Dictionary and complained, and before long Hasbro was confronted with protests from the Anti-Defamation League. The leading Scrabble players, many of whom are Jewish, united in defense of free speech (and higher scores), but the controversy escalated. Besides protests about various slurs, there were letters from sensitive censors like the one who wrote, "I personally find the most offensive words in the English language to be WAR and GUN." Hasbro responded by expurgating JEW and dozens of other objectionable words.
So Matt and Joel settled for playing VIEW, which left them stuck with the J for another turn. They fell behind and never caught up. "Maybe we would have lost anyway," Joel said afterward. "But JEW might have made a big difference."
Maven had its bad moments, too, blowing the next game by leaving an opening for Matt and Joel -- a gaffe no human expert would have committed. (See Diagram 2.) Then, having cut Maven's lead in games to 3-2, Matt and Joel blundered (and eventually lost the game) by trying to play ZYMIC. Joel assured Matt it was a word -- a derivation of ZYME, a fermenting agent -- but the computer knew better, and they lost the turn.
"You said you were definitely sure it was a word," Matt said testily.
"I was definite," Joel replied. "I can be definite and still be wrong. That's a human quality."
The strain on the humans was starting to show. During the next game, they had a long argument over whether to play PIQUE or PIQUET (a card game), and then slumped in disgust when Maven pulled out a victory with a dramatic bingo. (See Diagram 3.) They were now behind 5-2, a game away from defeat. Near the end of the eighth game they were narrowly ahead and about to play a rack containing a blank and DIMTUU. The computer, which was being asked on each turn how it would play the humans' rack, instantly saw a bingo -- TRIDUUMS, three-day periods of Catholic prayers -- and flashed its recommendation on a screen visible to a small audience of fans but not to Matt and Joel. It took them more than a minute to find the word, and even then they weren't sure it was legitimate.
"TRIDUUM is definitely a word," said Joel. "But is TRIDUUMS the right plural?"
It has to be right, Matt said. If the plural were TRIDUA, we'd know that word, and we don't. Let's do it. I want to bingo in style. I want to show this inanimate object a thing or two. Matt started to put out the tiles for TRIDUUMS, and the audience relaxed: humanity had not been bested by the computer on this turn.
But then came an even more splendid moment for the species. Joel suddenly spotted an intricate danger beyond Maven's comprehension. At this point, there were only six tiles left to be drawn from the pool, and if the humans played TRIDUUMS they would draw all six. With no tiles left in the pool, Maven could end the game during its next turn by playing a bingo, and the humans would be penalized for the tiles left in their rack, which would cost them the game. So Matt and Joel instead played MU (the Greek letter). Sure enough, Maven bingoed on the next turn with ORNITHES (bird varieties) and had to draw the final tiles from the pool. Then Matt and Joel played a bingo, SITUATED, to win the game. If they had thought like Maven and played TRIDUUMS, they would have lost.
Unfortunately for humanity, that was the high point. Maven got better tiles the next game, and the frustrated humans made one elementary mistake. (See Diagram 4.) They also got into a screaming argument over the relative merits of ENTASIA (muscle spasms) versus TAENIAS (Greek headbands). The dispute was so intense that Joel, who normally expresses displeasure by saying, "Oh, crud!" uttered one of the obscenities banned from the new Scrabble dictionary. At the end, when the guys' only chance to win was to play a bingo, Maven sealed its victory by dealing them a rack consisting of BGJNRVY.
The final score was 6 games to 3, which was not a fair representation of humanity's relative skill. The humans made a few minor mistakes, but on most turns they chose the same play recommended by Maven -- and sometimes a better one. "All this proved was that Maven could give itself better tiles," Matt said. "With even tiles, I think we'd have an edge." Joel still thought they were at best equal to Maven.
Sheppard was impressed at how well the humans had played, and he conceded that the computer's lopsided win had been due to better tiles. Both sides agreed that humans and Maven are closely matched -- but only for now. Sheppard has a powerful new version of Maven, which he hopes to release next year, that analyzes the possible responses by the opponent to each move under consideration. With this extra oomph, Maven is expected to become the undisputed champion.
"Maven will never have our intuitive feel for a board position," Joel said, "but the new Maven will be able to do so many computations that it will probably be unbeatable."
It may seem sad that the most popular human word game is being conquered by a machine, but no matter how good Maven gets at analyzing permutations of letters, it will remain incapable of the verbal skills that Matt and Joel displayed during the dinner after the match. For dessert they ordered TIRAMISU, a bingo word that Maven had played for its come-from-behind victory in the seventh game. "That was the last straw, Maven giving itself that bingo," Matt said. "You know what I felt ready for at that moment? TIRAMISU plus NA."
Joel understood instantly. "SANITARIUM," he said.

Man and machine both have their strong points on the Scrabble field, as illustrated by these examples. On this turn, early in the fourth game, Matt and Joel were burdened with unwieldy consonants: A D H O T T Y. They found an elegant way to unload one of the T's, the H and the Y, scoring 39 points. Can you find it? Answer: Using the E in REWAX, the men played THEY, also forming TI (the musical note), HE and JOEY (a young kangaroo). By leaving their rack balanced evenly between vowels and commonly used consonants (A, D, O, T), Matt and Joel improved their chances of scoring a "bingo" on a subsequent play -- which they did two moves later; 2. Maven was ahead 314-278 when it blew the fifth game on this turn. Working with E E G L S U and a blank, the computer considered several plays near the bottom of the board. One possibility was to put LUGES underneath SUBAH, forming SUBAHS (which are provinces in India). Another was to use the H in SUBAH to make HUGE. Which was smarter? Answer: Maven chose HUGE, which Matt and Joel promptly turned into HUGER by running AVOIDER down the far-right column, collecting bonuses for all seven tiles and for covering a red triple-word-score square -- 93 points in all, enough for the win. A human expert would have dismissed HUGE as too "volatile (p. 22); 3. Even so, the computer managed to use all seven tiles to take the lead and eventually prevail. What was its sweet concoction? Answer: In the bottom-right quadrant, off the T in LAITY, Maven played TIRAMISU for 74 points; 4. In the ninth game, Matt and Joel were experiencing something that computers don't: fatigue. Two moves earlier, they had a screaming argument over ENTASIA, the term for the spasmodic contraction of a muscle. (Joel wanted to play TAENIAS, a headband worn in ancient Greece.) Now, trailing 186-133, they were stuck with a miserable-looking rack: C D D D L T U. Tired and grumpy, they played hurriedly and overlooked a common word that would have been a better choice. What was the best play? Answer: Matt and Joel played a dud in the lower-right corner (running DOWN from SIZED) for 30 points, which left them with an unbalanced rack of four consonants. They overlooked Maven's first choice in this position, to spell CUDDLE by using the E in SIZE. Besides scoring more points, 32, this move would have unloaded mediocre tiles and given them a chance to draw a better rack (Scrabble Board Photograped by Bill Steele for The New York Times) (p. 23)

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Q&A/Nicholas S. Perna;
How Asia's Crisis Helped State's Economy

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
IT is Nicholas S. Perna's job to peer into the future and forecast economic trends. "Reading computer printouts and chicken entrails," he said, quoting a friend's characterization of his work. He focuses on Connecticut and the surrounding region -- New England, New York and New Jersey.
Dr. Perna, who received his doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has worked as an economist for several banks and government institutions, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He is chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group in Hartford. 
 Recently Dr. Perna discussed Connecticut's economy, its strengths and weaknesses and some predictions. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How do you forecast the economic climate?
A. The process is eclectic. I am an avid computer user but I have learned over the years that good solid judgment is also important. This is especially true when we have no precedents -- like the collapse of the currency in East Asia. A good auto mechanic today is comfortable using advanced diagnostic technology but can tell by the sound and the feel of the engine what's going on. What that means is we're not blindly driven by black box models of the economy. We try to take into account as many things as we possibly can.
Q. Connecticut is generally thriving. Will it continue indefinitely?
A. Here we are nationally in the midst of the best economy in more than a generation. The key question is: Is it going to last? That's very important whether you're in California or Connecticut. We're very much an open economy. What happens in Connecticut this year, next year or five years from now, is far more in the hands of the national economy than it is in our own hands in a sense. We can do a lot here that will affect the outcome but if the national economy goes into recession, then inevitably there will be a recession here.
The last time the national economy went into recession, the early 1990's, we went down as a state three times as long and got hit five times as hard. The period during which jobs declined, 1989 to 1992, lasted three years. The national recession was only one year in length. Nationally the economy lost about 2 percent of its jobs. Connecticut lost 10 percent of its jobs.
Q. What's different today?
A. There's a recession out there someplace. It doesn't seem to be around the corner. When you have an economy, that is in some respects nationally running flat out, the odds of something tipping it over are fairly high. Are recessions inevitable? Not in the sense that some people believe in long term cycles. I call them the bio-rhythmic school of economics. I think like bio-rhythms there's not a lot of information in it. There are no truly long term inevitable cycles. Cycles have causes to them. Nationally we've had as little as one year between recessions and as long as 10 years.
We have an incredibly low inflation rate. It's probably as low as it's going to go. It will probably pick up in the next 12 to 18 months. But the pickup will be within ranges that are quite mild by historic standards. By that I mean we are running at 1.5 percent inflation now and in a year from now it might be up a percentage point to 2.5.
In 1980 the prime rate was 21.5 percent. Today it's 8.5. In 1980 someone looking for a fixed rate, 20-year mortgage would have paid about 18 percent. Today it's 7 percent. Much of that difference between then and now reflects a far better inflation environment. Some of it reflects the budget surplus.
Q. Does the crisis in Asia affect Connecticut's economy?
A. The initial effects have been positive for the nation and Connecticut. It's pretty much agreed upon by economists that the Federal Reserve would have raised interest rates last fall because the economy was growing too fast to be sustained.
The Asian crisis affected us for two reasons. It slowed the U.S. economy because there were fewer exports and more imports. It helped to keep a lid on prices, which led to interest rates being significantly lower than they would otherwise be. Connecticut people who wanted to refinance their homes in the last couple of months to take advantage of getting out from their 8 or 9 percent mortgages, are benefiting from some of the fallout from the Asian problem. It has had a positive spillover effect on the stock market. As a generalization, lower interest rates mean higher stock prices.
We're getting some evidence that exports are being retarded in Connecticut. Imports are being accelerated. One reason is that the dollar buys far more in Asian currency than it did before. The other side of the coin is that it's now more expensive to buy U.S. goods. Companies like Pratt and Whitney and G.E. could eventually feel some fallout. Because they have such huge backlogs it might be awhile. Exports have been a significant source of growth in Connecticut.
Q. Connecticut has a budget surplus. What in your opinion is the best use of that money?
A. It seems to me that we are doing very well as a state. What we're not sure of is to what extent the largesse we are seeing in our national and local treasuries is permanent. I think that at this point the best policy to follow is one of prudence. That means either measured modest tax cuts, if that's what you want, or refurbish the rainy day fund. I think this is a perfect opportunity to put even more aside for a rainy day. Given my druthers I'd prefer to see much more put into rainy day funds over tax cuts. Maybe a recession would be the time to use some of the rainy day fund to tackle deferred maintenance projects at UConn and other things that are worth doing. When a recession occurs, costs are lower and the economy benefits from the stimulation.
Q. How healthy is the Connecticut real estate market?
A. We had rampant real estate speculation in the 80's. That meant that we were overbuilding like there was no tomorrow in Hartford, Fairfield County, residential real estate, condos. It then took years to work that off. Unfortunately there were other causalities. It dragged down a number of banks and real estate firms. We don't have that today. I think you could make the case that we could be underbuilt in certain types of real estate. What comes to mind immediately is apartments in much of the state.
Q. Why don't Connecticut cities thrive in good times?
A. Connecticut cities almost defy gravity. When things are bad, cities are bad. When things are really good, cities still don't participate. The boom of the 80's bypassed them.
I travel around the Northeast and see a remarkable similarity among cities, state to state. Americans like the suburbs. We've got our cars. We like to park closest to the mall. The old days of driving into downtown Hartford, or taking the bus or train, are gone. The suburbanization of America has hollowed out the center of cities.
We need to address the problem of transportation. One of Hartford's biggest assets is nice office space at reasonable prices in what I think is a fairly pleasant downtown. One of the things that stands in the way is easy access. We need transportation policies that better link the cities to the suburbs making it easier for people to get into the cities. Historically what we've done is make it easier for people to live outside the cities.
Q. You see economic trends regionally. How does that comport with local control?
A. I don't think we leverage our economic clout or leverage our political clout the way we should as a region. One of the assets that people are discovering is having a regional airports. Manchester, N.H., Airport and T. F.Green Airport in Rhode Island are booming. Bradley is showing signs of life. Think of Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey getting together to fully optimize on these airports instead of competing with each other.
Is it possible to do some regionalization at the margin that gives you the benefits of small towns? Do we really need seven dozen highway departments? Can we do more sharing of educational facilities?
Think of Connecticut as a little place with big borders. Can we do more partnering with our outside neighbors? Can we send high school kids across the border? Can they come here?
We've got good higher education systems in New England. We're all sharing the same challenge, which is not exactly booming enrollments. Part of it is the feedstock in Connecticut of young people. Can we think more regionally in terms of educational systems? Maybe we can only afford to have one state institution that offers Egyptology? Do we need to have eight departments in New England? Why don't we treat this more like a regional educational system? I think we're probably not getting the economies of scale that we could otherwise get. The private sector has maybe gone overboard in trying to get economies of scale. Yet I think we have hardly even thought of that at the public sector level.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for Fleet Financial, says measuring the state's economy takes good judgment as well as computer printouts. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Tax to Preserve Open Space Gets Growing Support

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH development pressures on the rise so are concerns about the loss of open space, prompting a growing number of municipalities and counties across New Jersey to establish trust funds supported by special taxes to maintain open space.
A 1992 state law gives communities and counties the option to hold referendums to set up such funds, which are supported by a special property tax imposed on residents and are used to help buy land for preservation. The enabling act was amended last year to broaden the permitted uses of the tax revenue to include park development, maintenance and historic and farmland preservation. Typically, the tax is 2 cents per $100 of assessed property value, although in some cases it is has been raised to 5 cents. 
 "Municipalities and counties are taking it upon themselves to plot out their own destiny, and with the tax they have a source of revenue to help them do that," said John L. Klevins, project manager in the Morristown field office of the Trust for Public Land, the national nonprofit land conservation organization.
Setting up local trust funds appears to run counter to a general resistance to higher taxes. But Maureen Ogden, a former Assemblywoman who is now chairwoman of the Governor's Council on New Jersey Outdoors, said towns and counties were "coming to the realization that saving open space is a pocketbook and quality-of-life issue."
She and other advocates of the trust fund said preservation had the potential to enhance property values and reduce spending since it is less expensive to buy land than to provide the services, like schools, needed to accommodate growth.
Critics say trust funds are just another way for towns and counties to try to stop development.
Some 53 of the 566 municipalities in the state have approved an open-space tax, 31 of them in the last two years, as have 13 of the state's 21 counties. Among them are Clinton Township in Hunterdon County and Washington Township in Morris County. Morris County has a trust fund, but Hunterdon County does not.
As of last spring localities, through their open-space trust funds, together had collected more than $106 million and protected nearly 17,500 acres, according to data from the Trust for Public Land and the state's Green Acres Program. The latter program, administered by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, provides state funds to acquire land for preservation as open space.
The dwindling supply of and fierce competition for such public financing is another factor stoking the push to establish open-space trust funds.
Towns and counties can use the revenue raised from the tax to leverage other funds, said James Wyse, a partner at the law firm of Schenck, Price, Smith & King in Morristown, who specializes in conservation-related real estate transactions.
"You need a hodgepodge of financing to do large land deals," said Mr. Wyse, adding that having a fund for open space enables towns and counties to move quickly to buy sites they think are important to save.
Since 1961 nearly 400,000 acres of open space have been or are in the process of being acquired under the state's Green Acres Program. The money for the acquisitions came from $1.39 billion allocated over the last 37 years under nine voter-approved bond issues.
But that money has been virtually exhausted. And estimates are that some 300,000 more acres are needed for the state -- which still has 1.7 million of its 4.8 million acres undeveloped -- to meet its open-space needs.
Last January Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she wants to preserve 1 million acres over the next decade. She also said that rather than relying on periodic bond issues she wanted to establish a stable financing source, which she is expected to announce at the end of this month. Some of the sources discussed have been a gasoline tax and a mortgage fee of $1 for every $1,000 of assessed value on new or refinanced loans.
TOWNS and counties are becoming cognizant that the state just can't do it alone and that the time to preserve open space is now or never," said Kevin S. Richardson, principal planner for the Green Acres Program's Bureau of Green Trust Management, which assists municipalities and counties.
To that end the state added the Planning Incentive Program to Green Acres in 1996. That program provides state funds -- in the form of a grant for 25 percent of the amount and a low-interest loan for the balance -- to localities and counties with an open-space tax.
"The purpose is to economize and combine funds so that not only the state, but towns and counties can stretch their dollars further," Mr. Richardson said.
The first community to take advantage of the new program was the 38-square mile township of Clinton, which has had an open-space fund in place since 1996 after its 12,000 residents approved a tax of 2 cents per $100 of assessed property, raising $240,000 a year. Last year the tax was increased to 5 cents, which will generate $640,000 annually.
"Clinton is agricultural in character, but it is losing that status quickly to development," said Lee Voorhees, its director of financing, referring to the reason residents voted for the tax.
Catherine Sipe, chairwoman of the township's open space committee, added: "You can't stop development on a site unless you buy it."
That is what Clinton did. It paid slightly more than $1 million to acquire 95 acres of woodlands, hills and pastures known as Bray's Hill Farm, named for Daniel Bray, who hid the boats George Washington used to cross the Delaware River on Christmas 1776 for his raid on Trenton. The residentially zoned site, atop Sound Hill Road, was a priority for the township when the owner -- the Exxon Corporation, which has a massive research center nearby -- put it up for sale early in 1997.
The township, working with the Trust for Public Land, obtained $1 million from the Green Acres Planning Incentive program to purchase the site last November and is using the money collected through its trust fund to pay off the loan. The site is now a nature preserve.
The township was allocated an additional $2 million from the program, which it will use to help buy 500 to 700 more acres, said Mrs. Sipe. More needs to be done, including implementation of stricter zoning, to protect the township's remaining open space, she said, while noting that the fund "is a big first step in trying to guide where development will go."
Washington Township, a 45-square mile community of 17,000 people in Morris County, has purchased, alone or with preservation partners, some 3,000 acres of open space. "We have an awful lot of land, about 10,000 acres, available to save and to have a fund that creates a pool of money made sense," said Margaret E. Nordstrom, the Mayor of the township. Its open-space fund, established in 1993, raises about $60,000 annually.
Last year, for instance, the township worked with conservation groups to preserve 120 acres within a watershed area. Mr. Wyse, the Morristown lawyer who helped structure the deal, said it involved the purchase of the land for $1.5 million by the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a private nonprofit land trust in Morristown.
The development rights for the 120 acres were sold to the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, a private preservation group, which used a Morris County grant to buy the rights.
The restricted land was traded for a 278-acre tract in Warren County, which conservation groups are also working to preserve. The smaller Morris County property will now be a horse farm and its owner will reap a tax benefit because he is getting less land in the swap.
For its part, Washington Township provided $100,000 from its open-space trust fund to purchase an easement around the 120 acres for a public pathway.
Mayor Nordstrom said the township was considering going to voters in November to double the tax to 4 cents per $100 of assessed value "because buying open space gives the township the best return on its investment."
That sentiment is echoed by Walter Krich, director of Planning and Economic Development for Morris County, which has had an open-space trust fund in place since 1993. Since then the half-cent tax, increased over the years to 2 cents, has helped the county underwrite the purchase of about 3,200 acres for $19 million.
Mr. Krich said there was talk of increasing the tax to 3 cents this year. "They are not making any new land," he said, "so we are buying what we can today to have open space 50 to 100 years from now."

HEADLINE: Help Wanted: School Superintendent

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
When Bert Nelson, Superintendent of the Hewlett-Woodmere School District, announced he would be retiring at the end of this school year, there were about 50 applications submitted for his position -- far fewer, he said, than had been expected.
In East Williston, when Superintendent David Helme informed the Board of Education that he would be retiring, the Board began a search for a new Superintendent. After two rounds of interviews, the members of the Board narrowed the choice to two finalists, but ultimately decided not to hire either. They asked Mr. Helme to stay on next year until they could find a qualified candidate. 
 Following a search for a Superintendent for Western Suffolk Boces, the Boces Board recently rejected all the candidates who had applied and decided to start the hiring process again.
These examples reflect a growing problem in recruiting School Superintendents, both for individual public school districts and for the Boces districts, which serve a number of school districts in a particular region.
Whereas a decade ago, between 100 and 150 qualified people would have applied for each vacant Superintendent's position, the pool of candidates has now diminished to an average of 30 to 40, said Charles Fowler, Superintendent of Nassau County Boces, who is leaving his position at the end of the school year.
The decline in the candidate pool has been particularly steep over the last five years, said Robert Loretan, executive director of the New York State Council of School Superintendents. While it has become a problem statewide, the high cost of living, expensive housing and high taxes on Long Island make the recruitment of School Superintendents there even more difficult.
"Cost of living is an important factor in job recruitment," Dr. Loretan said. "Today there are many more dual-career couples, and the uplifting of families means having to find a new home and often means displacing a working spouse. Even if the new job offers a salary increase of $20,000, if housing is more expensive and a spouse is out of a job and has to start over, it may not be worth it."
The average annual salary in New York State for School Superintendents is slightly less than $100,000, Dr. Loretan said. In small rural districts upstate, the figure is substantially lower than in more populated suburban areas.
In Nassau County, the average salary for Superintendents of public school districts is about $132,000, Dr. Fowler said. In Suffolk, the salaries are slightly lower and vary more from one district to another, said Edward Milliken, Superintendent of Eastern Suffolk Boces, who is retiring this year. The smaller districts offer significantly lower salaries, he said, while larger districts ofmore than 1,000 students from kindergarten through 12th grade usually pay about $120,000 a year.
In Suffolk County, two districts now looking to hire new Superintendents, Port Jefferson and Connetquot, both recently advertised the positions for salaries of more than $130,000, Dr. Milliken said.
But though salaries in some areas are rising, the job is attracting fewer candidates. Meanwhile, vacancies are increasing as more Superintendents are retiring as soon as they are eligible.
There have been significantly fewer applicants this year for the seven Superintendent vacancies in Suffolk County, said Joseph Donovan, president of the Suffolk County Council of Superintendents. The salary gap has narrowed between a Superintendent and a teacher at the highest level of the pay scale, he pointed out.
"When teachers look at the fact that Superintendents work 12 months a year, seven days a week," he added, "while they work for only 10 months, many question making a move."
In East Williston, for example, an experienced teacher with advanced degrees can make more than $90,000, Mr. Helme said.
"If you add coaching or club supervision," he said, "you can easily push the salary up by another $5,000 to $6,000. Although a teacher's job is demanding, it does not have nearly the same pressures as a Superintendent."
Indeed, several Superintendents cited job stress as a reason for the decline in applications. "It's not only an economic issue," Dr. Fowler said, "but what's involved in the position today. There are tremendous pressures from legislative actions, from having to work with locally elected officials and unions, as well as additional accountability pressures."
The State Education Department's new higher standards, which will be phased in over the next few years, will intensify these pressures, he said.
The responsibilities of School Superintendents have also changed in recent years, added Sidney Freund, Superintendent of the Herricks School District in New Hyde Park. Superintendents no longer have the decision-making authority they once did, he said.
"Fiscal, legislative and labor-related issues have taken too much time away from classroom instruction," Dr. Freund explained. "In addition, the Superintendent's job is the only nontenured position in a school district, so there is no job security. When you consider this factor, along with a smaller salary gap between lower positions and that of Superintendent, fewer people are willing to move into such a high-risk position."
In fact, job strains often contribute to a Superintendent's decision to resign. Maria Petraglia, Superintendent of schools in Manhasset, is leaving at the end of this school year to do private educational consulting.
"The job has become so demanding that it leaves little time for a personal life," she said. "It is often a job that is not understood or appreciated. As a change agent, we often upset the apple cart. Today I know many Assistant Superintendents who are just not interested in applying for the position of Superintendent."
In Nassau County, an Assistant Superintendent can make up to $120,000, Dr. Fowler said. "Even if there's a $15,000 to $20,000 salary raise when moving from Assistant Superintendent to Superintendent," he said, "after taxes and considering the additional time and pressures, it's often not worth it."
More Superintendents are choosing to work at colleges or as consultants, said Gerard Dempsey, president of the Nassau County Council of School Superintendents. Although these jobs often mean a big cut in salary, they are less demanding of time and impose fewer political pressures.
In Nassau County, there are 10 Superintendent vacancies, Mr. Dempsey said, and a diminished pool of candidates.
"Any time the pool shrinks," he said, "it becomes that much more difficult, because there's less choice in which to find a good candidate and one who will fit in with the specific community."
The experience in East Williston, where no candidate proved suitable, is a prime example of the problem.
"The district is a small, high-achieving district with a powerful faculty and strong community support," Mr. Helme said. "We should have had our pick of the best-qualified candidates. Our situation points to the difficulty today in finding top-quality Superintendents."
In terms of educational leadership, the most critical issue on the Island has become the positions of the Boces superintendents, who traditionally have been regarded as the most prestigious administrators in the state. At the end of the school year, two of the Island's three Boces districts will face uncertain leadership, with one Superintendent already departed and the other two leaving. Only Eastern Suffolk Boces has hired a new Superintendent for next year.
"Historically, when a vacancy occurred for a Boces District Superintendent, the top Superintendents from the region applied for the job," Dr. Milliken said. "It was a distinguished, well-paying job with a better compensation package than a Superintendent for a local district."
But today, because of legislative actions that froze salaries and restricted benefits, local Superintendents are receiving higher salaries and better benefits packages than Boces Superintendents, Dr. Milliken said. "When there is a Boces opening," he added, "it does not attract as strong a field of candidates as it used to. Unfortunately, because of a past situation, the Legislature classically closed the barn door after the horse got out."
For Boces Superintendents, salaries have been frozen for the last six years at $128,625. Legislation on salaries was imposed following public outrage over the near million-dollar retirement pay given in 1992 to Ed Murphy, District Superintendent of the former Suffolk Boces III, which is now Western Suffolk Boces. Dr. Murphy received the large retirement package because of accumulated sick days.
Last year, the Legislature imposed further restrictions on Boces Superintendents by including the personal use of a car and the cash value of life insurance as part of their compensation.
In essence, this move reduced their salary even further and virtually forced the Superintendents to leave their positions, said Bruce Brodsky, president of Eastern Suffolk Boces.
Following the legislation, the three Long Island Boces Superintendents all decided to leave their jobs. Daniel A. Domenech, then the Superintendent of Western Suffolk Boces, who would have lost $10,000 to $12,000 in salary, decided to go into the private sector, but has since re-entered public education as Superintendent of Schools in Fairfax, Va.
Dr. Milliken, at Eastern Suffolk Boces, had intended to stay in his position until his 60's, he said, but chose instead to retire this year at age 56.
"Although I had been grandfathered, and my salary frozen above the cap, it became illogical to stay on," he said, "when I can collect a pension, and my earning power will be identical to what I'm making now, without working."
Dr. Fowler at Nassau Boces decided to move to a local school district and will replace Dr. Nelson as Superintendent of the Hewlett-Woodmere schools. He is frustrated by the restrictions from the Legislature, which added job responsibilities while reducing his salary by $6,000. "It was not a fair thing to do," he said, "to attract someone to a position, then to increase his responsibilities while decreasing his compensation."
Recruitment efforts for Boces Superintendents have been difficult, Dr. Milliken said. Neither Western Suffolk Boces nor Nassau Boces is close to finding a new leader.
"In Eastern Suffolk, we were very fortunate to hire Eric Eversley, from a high school district in a suburb of Chicago," he said. "But there was a smaller number of candidates for the position, and the Board was concerned over the quality of the applicants. At a time when educational leadership is critical, the top positions are no longer coveted. And that's going to be a serious problem."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Eric L. Eversley, left, new Boces superintendent. Daniel A. Domenech, ex-Superintendent of Western Suffolk Boces. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times); Daniel A. Domenech, ex-Superintendent of Western Suffolk Boces. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Panel to Hear Public on Millstone Reactor

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
IN 1986, as the battle over the 800-megawatt Shoreham nuclear power plant raged across Long Island, the opening of an even larger commercial reactor less than 15 miles from East End beaches all but escaped notice.
Now, for the first time since the 1,153-megawatt Millstone Unit Three reactor gained a Federal license to operate on a 500-acre site on Long Island Sound near Waterford, Conn., Federal regulators from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission will travel to Long Island to hear local opinion on the Connecticut plant's future. 
 The commission said it agreed to take part in the one-day hearing, scheduled for 11 A.M. Tuesday at a community center in Jamesport, at the request of Representative Michael P. Forbes, Republican of Quogue.
"Congressman Forbes asked us to come to a hearing that he is holding to discuss the restart process for Millstone Three," said Diane Screnci, a commission spokeswoman. "We will certainly listen to any new information."
The regulators are likely to hear much from groups and officials in the part of Long Island where challenges to nuclear power technology are strongest, and where exposure to radionuclides from the Millstone station and from Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton is greatest.
They will say that the Connecticut facility is a major threat to Long Island, holds the potential for calamity, has a long history of safety problems and may be causing higher cancer rates in Suffolk County.
Mr. Forbes said he had arranged the meeting because "the proximity of Long Island to the Millstone facility warrants that Long Islanders have an opportunity to weigh in with any concerns they have."
One town, East Hampton, has approved a resolution opposing reopening of any of the three reactors at the Millstone station, all of which are closed.
"The close proximity of active nuclear reactors poses a health and safety threat to the Town of East Hampton from both the risk of increased cancer rate due to radioactive pollution and the potential for catastrophic nuclear meltdown," said the resolution the town board enacted last month.
Local groups are also demanding that the Millstone Three reactor, one of three at the site owned and operated by Northeast Utilities, remain closed until there is an approved evacuation plan for eastern Long Island.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has said that none of the reactors will be permitted to reopen until safety and management problems have been corrected. The reactors, with a combined capacity of 2,700 megawatts, have been shut for two years.
Northeast Utilities has said it faces bankruptcy if the Millstone Three unit, the newest and largest of the three reactors, is not opened soon. The commission is expected to rule next month.
The commission ordered the plants closed after finding that management was ignoring safety issues raised by employees. The commission ordered a change incorporate culture that would encourage employees to raise safety issues without fear of invoking management displeasure.
For years, the Millstone station has been notable for the large number of former and current employees who have spoken publicly about safety problems at the plant. Some of the employees point to problems in emergency systems they said increased the risks of serious accidents.
"Our biggest concerns are the implications of an accident at the Millstone plant and the lack of any evacuation plan for Long Island," said Scott Cullen, the legal consultant for Standing For Truth About Radiation, an East Hampton antinuclear group.
"The problem is that Millstone happens to be closest to eastern Long Island, and if at the time of an accident the wind is blowing this way the chance of people getting out is non-existent," he said.
Current Federal regulations require approved evacuation plans for a 10-mile radius of a commercial reactor. About 185,000 people live within 10 miles of the Millstone station, according to Nuclear Regulatory Commission figures. Nearly all are Connecticut residents.
The 10-mile evacuation zone includes a portion of Fishers Island, a resort community with a year-round population of about 750 that is part of the Town of Southold. Fishers Island is the only area of New York State within the evacuation zone.
David Fischler, the commissioner of Fire Rescue and Emergency Services for Suffolk County, said the current Federal emergency plan for the Millstone power station called for moving residents in the area of Fishers Island within the 10-mile zone to areas of the island outside the zone.
Mr. Fischler said there were also plans for evacuation by boat if it were necessary. No other part of the county was covered by the plan, he said.
In November, 1982, the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations released calculations of deaths, injuries and property damage that would be caused in worst-case reactor accidents involving core meltdowns resulting in massive release of radiation.
The calculations, based on studies performed by Sandia National Laboratory for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, estimated that most fatalities would occur within 20 miles of a reactor, while injuries resulting from exposure to radioactivity would extend up to 65 miles form the plant.
For Millstone Unit Three, which was under construction in 1982 but still four years from operating, the subcommittee calculated that 23,000 people would die from radiation exposure within a year. Injuries within one year that required treatment, including temporary sterility, cataracts, vomiting or thyroid nodules, would reach 30,000, and 38,000 cancers deaths would occur over the lifetime of the exposed population.
According to the calculations, the economic impact, in 1980 dollars, would be $174 billion.
Calculations if a similar accident occurred at Millstone Unit Two, an 895-megawatt reactor opened in 1975, estimated 18,000 deaths within a year, 18,000 injuries, 23,000 eventual cancer deaths and $135 billion in economic damage. The figures for Millstone Unit One, a 652-megawatt reactor opened in 1971, were calculated as 13,000 deaths within a year, 12,000 injuries, 28,000 eventual cancer deaths and an economic impact of $91.5 billion.
Some nuclear power plant critics have said that deaths, injuries and property damage caused by a catastrophic reactor accident would actually be far greater.
Mr. Forbes said he "leaned toward insisting that there be an emergency plan that is sensitive to Long Island." One option for Mr. Forbes would be to request a delay in the commission decision on reopening the Millstone Three plant pending such a plan.
The government calculations are based on prevailing wind patterns and assume a total collapse of reactor emergency systems designed to prevent a core meltdown. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has said the likelihood of such accidents is extremely remote.
"In their entire operating life," said Jacque Durr, chief of the inspection branch of a special projects office for the commission reviewing the Millstone station, "the three plants have experienced no accident or incident that would have impacted Long Island or had any known effect there.There have been releases, but they did not threaten the health and safety of the public."
But Dr. Jay M. Gould, an East Hampton resident who is a critic of nuclear power, said commission figures showed that a 1975 release from the Millstone station "was as great as the release reported in 1979 from Three Mile Island."
"It was enormous," Dr. Gould said. "It just wasn't publicized."
Dr. Gould, who plans to speak at the hearing, said his analysis of National Cancer Institute statistics showed that breast cancer mortality rates, adjusted for age, had increased by 40 percent in Suffolk County since 1950, the largest increase for any large county. He said rates were also abnormally high in areas of Connecticut near the Millstone station.
"This is simply evidence that has to be explored," Dr. Gould said. "It can't be due to chance."
Long Island breast cancer groups have also raised questions about whether years of low level releases from the Millstone station could be a risk.
"There are clearly emissions and there is a lot of research that shows low level ionizing radiation affects breast cancer rates," said Dr. Minna Barrett, a science adviser for the Long Island Breast Cancer Action Coalition and an associate professor of psychology at the State University of New York at Old Westbury.
Gerald Reardon, a nuclear safety engineer at the Millstone station who has spoken publicly about safety problems, said resident of Long Island had reason to be concerned.
"It is certainly possible to have a severe accident, and Long Island is kind of a trapped audience," said Mr. Reardon. "If the wind is blowing toward them, they can come down to the shore and watch the cloud come. Radionuclides are not going to stop at the 10-mile limit.
"For the government to imply that a serious accident can't happen is ridiculous. I've been in the nuclear power business for 26 years, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is public enemy no. 1. Its sole purpose is to promote nuclear power and anything they tell you to the contrary is a bunch of baloney."
Donald W. Del Core Sr. a former instrumentation and control specialists at the Millstone station and now a member of a group opposed to the reactors. said: "People on Long Island have a reasonable reason to be concerned about the restart of Millstone and they should do what they have to do to get the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's attention.
"I am not going to be the guy to say there is going to be an accident. But Millstone Three is not ready to restart."
There was limited opposition in Connecticut to the opening of the three Millstone reactors.
On Long Island, opposition to the now defunct Shoreham nuclear plant reflected a widely-held view by Long Island residents and elected officials led by Governor Mario M. Cuomo that no safe evacuation would be possible for residents living within 10 miles of the plant in the event of a serious accident.
During the mid 1980's, as the Millstone Three reactor glided toward licensing with none of the controversy aroused on Long Island by the Shoreham reactor, the refusal of Suffolk County and New York State to participate in a required drill of emergency evacuation plans was a major stumbling block to plant licensing.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission eventually ruled that state and local authorities would cooperate in a real emergency, despite their refusal to take part in drills. The commission then approved an emergency plan prepared by the Long Island Lighting Company after a drill in which state and local cooperation was simulated.
But by 1989, when the commission licensed the Shoreham plant, its owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, had agreed never to operate it in exchange for guarantees it could recover all prudently incurred costs and interest for the $5.5 billion plant project.

HEADLINE: Just Why Do We Buy?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The assumption that aluminum siding is a "practical" purchase that adds value to a residence is highly questionable. Covering a house with synthetic siding alters the proportions and changes its character. Many buyers reject the cold, artificial look and find loss of historic design, materials and workmanship unacceptable. 
 When siding is laid over traditional clapboards and shingles, other problems can emerge. Homeowners may have trouble finding leaks or rot, and aluminum can dent and get dirty; it is not really maintenance-free. In short, buyers have plenty of reasons for not re-siding their houses other than identifying with the rich.
 
HELI MELTSNER
Cambridge, Mass., May 6
 
The writer is an architectural historian and preservation consultant.

HEADLINE: The View From/Hartford;
Where Produce From Afar Gets Serious Attention

BYLINE: By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
THE sky is still flecked with stars as Eleanore Rhodes and her dog comb the farmers' stalls at the state's Regional Market in Hartford in search of day lily and mock orange plants.
It is just past 5 A.M., but the violet light rising behind the capital city's skyline promises sunshine. Ms. Rhodes, who lives in Vernon, is one of hundreds of gardeners and cooks who hunt and gather at the vast expanse of asphalt that sits on Reserve Road between Interstate 91 and an industrial park. "I'm very fond of day lilies," said Ms. Rhodes, who, buttoned into a long raincoat with a kerchief tied under her chin, and dog at her heels, would not be out of place in the English countryside. She continued: "The prices are good. You get to know the dealers." 
 For Peter Smith, who also lives in Vernon, fresh eggs, creamy white and pale brown, stacked in paper crates by Calvo Farms, draw him. "I'm from Jamaica," Mr. Smith said. "This is more like home."
Although the Regional Market is open seven days a week year-round, Saturday is always the busiest. In the fall, it's chrysanthemums and pumpkins and in winter, fir trees and chestnuts that lure people out of warm beds in search of bargains and varieties not found elsewhere. But it is in spring that the market swells with people pushing carts laden with plants and shrubs.
The Connecticut Marketing Authority owns and manages the market, which has been in operation since 1952. The largest food distribution terminal between New York and Boston, the market's estimated revenue in 1998 is about $822,000, said Dawn Cassada, the interim executive director for the Connecticut Marketing Authority. The 32-acre site can house up to 144 open-air stalls and 16 wholesale businesses.
Several years ago, most of the big supermarket chains that used to buy from some of the wholesalers began shipping produce directly to the stores from their own warehouses, said George Gotay, a wholesaler.
"Business is not good," he said, despite the crowd of people shopping in his warehouse store. Gotay Tropical Fruit, a Hispanic and West Indian food importer and distributor, is a hub of activity in the warehouse. A transistor radio blaring Spanish music competes with the razor saw of a meat slicer and the voices of customers.
The Gotay store symbolizes the two worlds at the Regional Market. In the parking lot below the warehouse, where Jeeps and station wagons are packed with shrubs and flowers, the shoppers are largely white and English-speaking. But in the cavernous warehouses that border two sides of the open air stalls, nearly the only English spoken is by workers calling out "$2 a box, $2 a box."
In this part of the market, a steady stream of people whisk through the narrow channels between the boxes of produce. A watermelon is hacked open to display its pink flesh. Oranges sliced in two wobble atop a cardboard carte. In addition to the shoppers, the workers -- a few appearing to be well past normal retirement age -- sling net bags of vegetables over their shoulders or push hand trucks of food through the warehouse. A few well-worn vans are loaded with produce for small, local markets.
Two women, in traditional Muslim chador inspected cardboard boxes of vegetables. Men and women from Poland lugged 20-pound sacks of potatoes. A man who was born and raised in the Calabria region of Italy scooped handfuls of mixed greens from a box in a dark corner of the warehouse; earlier, at the open market stalls, he had been in search of rabbits and chickens.
Cecelia Leois of Hartford waited with her two daughters for a bag of beef oxtails that she was planning to braise with lima beans. Jesus Aaeulo and his 6-year-old son shop at the market every Saturday, especially for Spanish cheese.
Marisa Guererra, who moved to the United States three years ago from Italy, compared citrus fruit with the two friends shopping with her. Every Saturday at 6 A.M. finds her in the warehouses. "During Christmas, I come for the chestnuts," she said, before closing her eyes in delighted remembrance of a favorite food. "Now it's anise, fresh fruit."
In addition to retail space, the wholesalers may lease backrooms to store fruit and vegetables in temperate settings. There is the "wet room," an aptly named cold and clammy space for an assortment of green vegetables. In other rooms, crates of tomatoes and bananas are stacked, their respective red and yellow colors coaxed by a pungent gas.
In the parking lot below, the farmers' spaces ranged from a makeshift table of wooden sawhorses and plywood that displayed a few flats of pansies to a forest of flowering and evergreen shrubs and potted plants. The spaces' prices range from $316 for a full year to $9 a weekday to display the trunk contents of a sedan. The farmers tend to arrive around 4 A.M. to set up their displays.
The farmers roll burlap-wrapped, seven-foot evergreens down ramps, their breath visible in the dawn air. The smell of fried eggs and bacon wafts over the trucks as it emanates from John Anthony's Market Restaurant, the diner next door where the breakfast special is $1.99.
Most of the market's farmers can remember when business was better, when as Jim Kenney, who owns the Tree Smith in Montville, said, "You'd come out here and sell everything you had in a few hours."
The selling spree diminished when the economy turned down and Home Depot moved in. The super-sized hardware store was repeatedly invoked by may of the farmers who cite it as their main competition.
Bill Discenza, who with his brother owns Meadow Springs, a farm in Wethersfield, said he hoped business would pick up as the weather grew warmer. His 14-year-old son Nicholas, who said he "likes to sell stuff" at the market, stood with him amid a crowd of tall shrubs. "Anyway, if you lay in bed, you don't make any money," the senior Discenza said.
There were dozens of pots of perennials in Hendrik Clark's stall. They sold for $5 each, or five for $20, and business was steady. Mr. Clark, who owns Clark's Greenhouses in Salem, ticked off the names of the plants, many of which were not yet in flower. His customers approached, lists in hand, seeking specific varieties and detailed answers about plant care.
"You've got to keep talking," he said. "They want to hear about the plants." His first sale was at 4:30 that morning.
For Carol McGeehan, the trip to the Regional Market with her daughter Lisa Turgenon and 5-year-old granddaughter Allie, is a treasured, thrice yearly event.
"I'm going to look around some more," Mrs. McGeehan told her daughter. "You wouldn't want to buy right away and then see the plant of your dreams." The Newport, R.I. resident said she shops at the market because the prices and selections are better than at greenhouses near her home. "We make it a treat, a rite of spring," she said. "Allie likes to garden."
The child, perched in a red wagon and wrapped in a blanket, smiled before she clambered out to look at the plants, in perfect imitation of her mother and grandmother.

A bit later it's the customers who are buzzing around all manner of goods including fresh eggs and, in the spring of course, plants and shrubs. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A Second Excelsior for Hackensack;
267 Rentals on a Ridge With Manhattan Views

 BODY:
A 267-unit rental apartment building, almost a twin to one completed next door in 1990, is rising at 170 Prospect Avenue in Hackensack, N.J., set on a ridge facing Manhattan.
The new 18-story brick tower, called Excelsior II -- the adjacent building is Excelsior I -- will have studio to three-bedroom apartments, plus penthouses. Most have balconies with views of the Manhattan skyline. 
 The buildings, set on a 5.7-acre site, are being linked by a 10,000-square-foot structure that will house a health club with swimming pool, community room and a 163-seat restaurant that will offer take-out as well as room service to tenants. There will also be boutiques and shops, including a hair salon, professional office, a concierge, a 567-car underground garage and valet parking in a building with high-tech wiring.
"Excelsior II is being designed as an apartment complex with the amenities of a hotel ," said Anthony R. Palmeri, president of Sebring Associates of Hackensack, the developer. The project, estimated to cost more than $30 million, is scheduled for completion in the fall.
The rental towers are a bit of an anomaly. They sit along a four-block stretch of Prospect Avenue where many of Hackensack's high-rise condominiums and co-ops stand.
But Mr. Palmeri said the need and demand for rental housing that led his company to build the first tower, which is fully occupied, still exists today. He said the housing recession and savings-and-loan debacle of the 80's caused the delay in construction of the second building.
Monthly rents in Excelsior II, which rise in relation to views, will range from $1,025 to $2,950 for the 640- to 1,761-square-foot apartments, with 9-foot ceilings and marble baths. The penthouses, with 1,270 to 2,555 square feet of space, will rent for $2,450 to $5,300 a month. The cost of membership in the health club, which will be open to the public, has not yet been determined. Initial occupancy is expected in October, said Mr. Palmeri.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Suddenly, for Legislators, The Living Is a Little Easier

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When the New Jersey Legislature gave final approval last week to a bill that promises to lower auto insurance rates, it seemed as if lawmakers heaved a collective sigh of relief.
Ever since voters expressed their unhappiness last fall over paying the nation's highest rates, fixing the state's automobile insurance system has dominated the legislative debate and Governor Whitman's agenda. 
 So what will lawmakers and Governor talk about now?
The budget. Education. Gasoline taxes. Transportation. Solid waste. Energy deregulation.
"The priority right now has to be the budget," said Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County.
Don't expect much controversy here. With the Wall Street boom and the economy pouring extra tax dollars into the state's coffers, there are no big budget cuts planned. The biggest challenge for lawmakers will be trying to figure out how not to spend it all.
What will make the budget process even smoother is the long-awaited decision by the New Jersey Supreme Court on school financing. The Whitman administration and legislators had been braced for a decision that would have forced them to find more than $312 million more a year for programs for the state's poorest school districts, including full-day preschool programs for children aged 3 and 4.
That is what a court-appointed judge had recommended. But on Thursday the state's highest court rejected most of the judge's recommendations, finding that the Whitman administration was on the right track with its approach. The state Department of Education promises to implement a new program called Success for All, in urban elementary schools, along with full-day kindergarten, and half-day preschool for 4-year-olds. The money for this has already been budgeted.
Then there is the Governor's proposal to raise the gasoline tax by seven cents a gallon, which is likely to cost the average motorist about $35 a year. Mrs. Whitman said last week that she wanted the tax increase to help preserve a million acres of open space, as well as pay for transportation projects.
The Governor's plan, however, is expected to run into opposition from some powerful lawmakers. Mrs. Whitman wants a gas tax to help provide a steady stream of revenue to purchase open space rather than continue relying on bond referendums, like the Green Acres program.
In the first sign of an impending battle, State Senator Robert Littell, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, introduced a bill calling for a voter referendum this fall on whether to continue the Green Acres program. And 30 members have signed on to the bill, indicating that Mrs. Whitman might have trouble getting the gas tax for open space preservation approved.
Another potentially contentious issue facing the Legislature and the Governor is how to help bail out county governments, which are $1.6 billion in debt because of a United States Supreme Court decision last year about where trash haulers can take their garbage.
Until the court ruling, trash haulers were required to dump the refuse into county-designated facilities, prompting several county governments to borrow a lot of money to expand landfills and build incinerators. Now, since the court ruled that haulers can take their trash anywhere they want, many county governments do not have enough trash coming into these facilities to pay off the debt service.
This is not an issue that is likely to rivet the public's attention, but it could end up adding to the tax burden. The question is, whose tax bill?
Two legislators have proposed creating a new statewide tax on the gross revenues of garbage haulers to repay the debt. The Whitman administration has proposed allowing each county to impose a garbage tax on municipalities to reduce the debt -- a plan that critics say will do nothing more than drive up property taxes.
Also on the agenda is energy deregulation. Whatever action the Legislature and the Whitman administration take to restructure the utility industry in New Jersey will determine how much consumers pay for gas and electric service.
What about property taxes? After auto insurance, voters cited the state's high property taxes as their biggest concern in poll after poll during last fall's gubernatorial campaign.
So far, Mrs. Whitman has not proposed any sweeping changes, although she has created a commission that is supposed to be searching for possible solutions.
But don't expect any dramatic reductions in property tax rates anytime soon. Why? The biggest portion of a homeowner's property tax bill is the cost of education. One way to wring savings out of the public school system is to merge school districts. But giving up local control in the state's more than 500 districts has not proved to be a politically popular option in the past.
Another approach would be to replace property tax revenue with a statewide tax increase, such as the personal income tax. But it is unlikely that Mrs. Whitman, whose national reputation was made cutting state income taxes in her first term, would consider raising them in her second.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Old College Try

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
A FEW years ago, some of the city's university clubs tried to shake their stuffy images and rebuild their membership rolls by changing their menus, adding sleek new gym equipment and organizing trips to SoHo. Now some clubs for graduates of elite universities, like Yale, Princeton, the University of Pennsylvania and Williams College, are doing something else to increase membership. Opening their doors wider, they have been bringing in alumni of other colleges, including some less prestigious ones.
The Penn Club, which opened in 1994 in a Beaux-Arts building on West 44th Street that was renovated at a cost of $25 million, initially restricted membership to people who attended the University of Pennsylvania, an Ivy League member. More than 10,000 enrolled soon after the opening, but since then, the rolls have declined to 6,507. 
 So the club is now offering membership to alumni of eight non-Ivy institutions, including Gettysburg and Bucknell Colleges and the University of Richmond, as well as ones with more cachet, like the University of Chicago and Haverford, Swarthmore and Bryn Mawr Colleges.
"We had room on our membership roster," said Peter M. Homberg, the club's general manager. "We're looking to support our food and beverage operations and the programs that go on."
Last year, the Williams Club on East 39th Street began accepting alumni of the University of Connecticut, the latest in a list of its more than three dozen affiliates, including Seton Hall, Rutgers and the State University of New York at Albany.
"It's the old story," said J. Roger Friedman, an honorary board member and past president of the Williams Club. "Your money is as good as my money." He added, "I think there was always that feeling that these schools weren't as good as Williams in academic standards." But, he said, "economics was the big driver."
Michael Smith, the manager, said Williams alumni account for 68 percent of membership, which is now 5,000, compared with 3,500 in 1993. "Williams is not a huge school," he said. "Given that we're in the city and it's a large building, we would like to have more traffic."
Like most older university clubs, the Yale Club, on Vanderbilt Avenue, has for years let some people who went elsewhere become members. It gave the Dartmouth Club a home after it closed in the early 70's, and since the 40's has accepted Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity members. But a couple of years ago, the Yale Club began taking University of Virginia graduates. So far, 550 have joined.
The Princeton Club, on West 43d Street, has also extended its reach. The club, which took in fellow Ivy alumni from Columbia for a time after the Columbia Club was sold in 1973, now accepts people who attended Fordham University, Washington University in St. Louis and the College of William and Mary. Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni are also permitted to join.
Though the clubs are awash in emblems and color schemes suggesting exclusive ties to the alma mater, only the Harvard Club restricts membership to those with Harvard links. "I'm sure there are many people from other schools who would be desirable club members," the president of the Harvard Club, Peter S. Heller, said. But he added, "We are a Harvard Club."
Mr. Friedman of the Williams Club said, "Harvard just has more money than the rest of us poor cousins."
For most clubs, accepting alumni of other universities as members has become "an economic reality," said Thomas Inglis, general manager of the Cornell Club. That club also admits other alumni, including those from Colgate College and Tulane University.
University clubs saw revenues drop several years ago as membership dropped during the recession. Since then, the improved economy has helped the clubs' bar, restaurant and banquet businesses. "Club food is no longer a joke, which it once was," said Ara Daglian, executive secretary of the Club Managers of the City of New York. The Harvard Club even has a sushi bar.
But the clubs have had to spend money to become more cutting edge, as Mr. Homberg of the Penn Club put it. And because dues are typically pegged to where members live, with city residents paying the most, it is New Yorkers who are prized as members, even if they went to another school. "We have many, many nonresident members, and they're infrequent users at best," Mr. Homberg said. "We seek to build our local base. That's where the affiliates come in."
Affiliation typically begins with an overture from an alumni association, though sometimes club board members suggest another school to which they have ties. But while affiliations are a way to expand membership, some clubs have their limits. The Yale Club will accept no more than 1,000 members from Dartmouth and 1,000 from the University of Virginia.
Meanwhile, the Columbia Alumni Federation, which has been at the Williams Club since 1990, is planning to go Ivy again. It has been negotiating a contract with the Princeton Club. "It's a better location with better facilities, and we're very excited about the possibility of sharing a club with another Ivy League institution," Virgil Renzulli, a spokesman for Columbia University, said.
But Mr. Smith, the manager of the Williams Club, where Columbia graduates comprise 15 to 20 percent of the membership, said many Columbia people have told him they plan to stay put.

Susan Gene Price and William Andrew Rubin are to be married today at the Forrestal Hotel in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Benjamin M. Levy is to officiate.
The bride, 36, is the director of account management at the Copeland Companies, which market and administer retirement plans in East Brunswick, N.J. She graduated from Trenton State College. Her parents, Renee and Eugene Price, live in Cranbury, N.J. 
 The bridegroom, 42, is a project manager, in Red Bank, N.J., at Bellcore, a provider of telecommunications consulting services and software systems. He graduated from the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and from which he also received master's degrees in economics and mathematics.
