HEADLINE: Mysterious Virus at Source Drives Up the Price of Pearls

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
In simpler times, only nature could make a pearl. Then mankind came up with the cultured variety, and pearls were transformed from nuggets of magic to predictable commodities.
In recent years, though, nature has struck back: a mysterious virus has teamed up with disruptive weather patterns to kill more than half the oysters in the world's busiest undersea factory. 
 At first, shoppers at jewelry counters were blissfully unaware of all this because dealers, alerted to the blight, kept plenty of pearls on hand. But those supplies are running short, and suddenly -- just in time for prom and wedding season -- pearl prices are shooting up.
Luxury chains like Tiffany & Company as well as small, family-owned jewelers like Wilson & Son in Scarsdale, N.Y., have been forced to raise prices, in some cases by as much as 25 percent, for top-quality strands. And prices are still rising.
A necklace that cost $800 to $1,200 a year ago might bring $1,500 today. A set of single-stud earrings now costs $200, up from $170 this time last year, according to the Cultured Pearl Information Center.
"This could not have come at a worse time, because pearl demand is way up," said Devin Macnow, executive director of the center, a trade group that is financed by the Japan Pearl Exporters Association.
But the surge in consumer demand for luxury items, born of the powerful economy, pales next to the death of millions of Akoya oysters in Japan's coastal waters in the last several years.
In 1996, the last year for which full figures are available, 150 million Akoya mollusks died, according to the exporters' group. Cultured pearls dominate the American market, and half of them come from Japanese Akoya oysters.
The problem has been building for a decade but became acute in 1996 and 1997, said Ichiro Nomura, a director of resources and environmental research at the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Tokyo. "The cause of increased death is yet to be known fully, and scientists of our agency are making their best efforts to identify it," he said.
So, to meet demand in the United States, the largest pearl market after Japan, exporters have been reducing shipments to other countries, like Switzerland and Singapore, and also reserving more of the finest-quality pearls for sale here. In addition, exporters have been shipping more pearls to the United States from China, but their ability to shift distribution is too limited to offset the shortfall.
So American jewelers must simply wait for nature and science to strike a balance.
When they first received word of the dying oysters, retailers increased their pearl orders and, for a time, had a surplus. But as the death rate accelerated, and inventories fell, retailers say they had no choice but to pass higher costs on to customers. The biggest price increase is for top-quality pearls, which even in a good year account for less than 5 percent of a total harvest.
"It has become more difficult to procure fine-quality pearls," said Linda Hanson, senior vice president for merchandising at Tiffany. "We have adjusted some pearl pricing over the past several months and probably will be adjusting some others prices in the next few months as well."
The supply problem will last until at least 2001, the minimum amount of time needed for young, healthy oysters to mature and produce pearls. But it could drag on even longer because it is too soon to tell whether the young oysters will remain healthy.
"All we can do is stay away from these areas considered the problem," said Koichi Takahashi, senior vice president of the Mikimoto (America) Company, the largest distributor of cultured pearls in the United States, which operates its own oyster farm in Japan.
So jewelers like Matthew Wilson are left to wonder just how long they can keep from, once again, raising prices. Because he doubled his wholesale pearl order this year, Mr. Wilson, an owner of Wilson & Son in Scarsdale, said his supply should hold up for a while. But he cannot afford to buy nearly as many pearls as he would like and says he will have an even tougher time buying enough next year.
Gold dealers and the costume jewelry trade may be counting on finding a competitive edge. But with consumer confidence so high, jewelry experts predicted, shoppers will still plunk down gold cards for pearls.
"Price is not an object in this market," said Lynn Ramsey, president of the Jewelry Information Center in New York. In fact, she added, the shortage may make pearls even more appealing. "People are willing to go to great lengths to get something of rarity and value," she said.
Still, even in this market, not everyone can afford to pay top dollar. So bargain-hunters may opt for a single-pearl pendant instead of a strand or may choose lower-quality cultured pearls, whose prices are also rising but not as rapidly.
A necklace of low-quality Akoya pearls now costs 15 percent to 20 percent more than it did last year. But at roughly $500, that is about a third what a high-quality string costs. Cheaper ones are also in short supply but not as severely as the finest pearls.
Once, natural pearls -- formed when a tiny foreign object like a grain of sand enters an oyster -- were the only ones available. But a century ago it was discovered that a foreign object could be inserted into an oyster to stimulate the formation of a pearl, giving rise to cultured pearls, which now make up about 70 percent of the American market. The rest is split between Tahitian and South Sea pearls, the most expensive variety, and freshwater pearls, the cheapest. These pearls are not affected by the Akoya problem.
That is of little comfort to the Akoya oyster farmers, particularly small suppliers who have less wherewithal to withstand a crisis. "They will suffer loss of income," Mr. Nomura said. "They are all affected."
There is one bright spot for some oyster farmers -- edible oysters have not been as hard hit. Those oysters, which are different from Akoyas, are grown in separate farms that the virus has not ravaged.
As for the Akoyas, farmers were first alerted to the problem when scientists noticed that an increasing number of oyster muscles were turning red or brown, which signaled that they were likely to die. Farmers then began to isolate healthy oysters, but even that did not make a difference.
Three factors are generally accepted as the most serious causes: climate changes, red tide -- a severe rise in plankton, microscopic organisms found naturally in the water that cause the color to turn red and kill the oysters -- and an unrelated mystery virus. Speculation about possible causes focuses on the use of chemicals in fish farming and on poor oxygen levels in water because of overcrowding of oysters in cages.
Red tide and unpredictable weather have sent the pearl industry into turmoil before, but the virus that has scientists perplexed is relatively new. Scientists are not sure of its origin, but they think that once it took hold, unseasonably warm weather increased water temperatures and enabled it to thrive.
"Everybody is blaming everything, and it is really hard to determine what is the main cause," Mr. Takahashi of Mikimoto said. What is not in dispute is that if the industry is unable to find a solution, brides may soon have as hard a time affording high-quality cultured pearls as that perfect wedding gown.

HEADLINE: Gandhi's Voice Summoned to Condemn India's A-Tests

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 23

 BODY:
For years now, it has been hard for the followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi and his creed of nonviolence to make themselves heard above the clamor and indifference of modern India.
But as S. K. Bandopadhaya has discovered in the two weeks since India erupted in jubilation over its five nuclear tests beneath the desert of Rajasthan, making the Gandhian case against Indian membership in the club of nuclear-armed nations has been like shouting into a cyclone in the Bay of Bengal. 
 So Mr. Bandopadhaya makes his case quietly, reaching for the bookshelf in his office as secretary of the Gandhi Memorial Trust, across the road from the riverbank where grieving crowds flocked to Gandhi's funeral pyre after his assassination on Jan. 30, 1948. Quiet is a watchword at the trust, which like most Gandhian institutions operates these days in the backwaters of Indian life.
Thumbing painstakingly through a Gandhi biography this week, Mr. Bandopadhaya, who at 73 is old enough to have joined the ranks of Gandhi's followers while the Mahatma was still alive, finally found the passage he wanted and began to read. It was from a commentary Gandhi wrote in his newspaper, Harijan, on June 30, 1947, referring to the American atomic bombing of Japan 22 months earlier.
"So far as I can see, the atomic bomb has decimated the finest feelings that have sustained mankind for ages," Gandhi wrote. "There used to be the so-called laws of war which made war tolerable, but now we know the naked truth, that war knows no law, except that of might. The atom bomb brought an empty victory to the allied armies, but it resulted for the time being in destroying the soul of Japan."
Picking up another book, Mr. Bandopadhaya reached into the early days of Gandhi's battle to keep the Indian freedom struggle nonviolent.
"If India takes up the doctrine of the sword, she may gain momentary victory," Gandhi wrote in Young India, as his newspaper was then called, on Aug. 11, 1920. "Then India will cease to be the pride of my heart." He added, still speaking of India, "I believe absolutely that she has a mission for all the world."
On the face of things, Gandhi's teachings have had little impact during the surge of nationalism over the nuclear tests, which surveys after the first tests on May 11 indicate won the support of more than 90 percent of Indians. The support emboldened the Hindu nationalists who lead India's Government. They quickly shifted from quiet justifications of the tests as necessary for India's national security to more strident statements about India's wishing to "silence its enemies" and give a warning to its archrival, Pakistan.
But Mr. Bandopadhaya, whose organization stands at the apex of scores of Gandhian institutions in India, says the United States and other countries that reacted with dismay to the tests should be patient. Other Indians agree, and say Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and his associates in the Bharatiya Janata Party, the Hindu nationalist group that leads the Government, may yet find that they have misjudged the nation's mood, and its needs.
"This is a passing phase, and the pendulum will swing back," Mr. Bandopadhaya said, closing his books. "So I humbly submit that the world should not feel so disappointed; the soul of India is not dead. Out of this debris, the real India will emerge. Gandhi or no Gandhi, his values of truth and nonviolence are rooted in our national consciousness. Gandhi has held up his lamp to light our path, and his values remain."
Opposition to the tests within India was slow in developing, but it has already shown signs of building. At first, even some veteran Gandhians endorsed the blasts, hunting through their own recollections for examples where Gandhi approved the use of force, as when "freedom fighters" from Pakistan rushed into Kashmir in the fall of 1947 in a vain attempt to seize the disputed territory, only to be halted by Indian troops.
But criticism has not been limited to the Mahatma's followers. A group of 100 Indian scientists signed a protest from institutes and universities here and abroad. The signers included at least one scientist in the United States, Dr. A. P. Balachandran of Syracuse University.
"We wish to recall here, emphatically, the horror that is nuclear war," the scientists wrote. "We stand firmly with the long tradition of eminent scientists who have consistently argued against the induction of nuclear weapons. The horrors of nuclear war can never be forgotten, whatever pride we feel in India's scientific and technological achievements."
Other scientists were harassed by Hindu nationalist extremists as they gathered for a protest meeting in Bangalore this week. Nationalists jostled them, shouting: "You are all anti-national. There is no difference between you, the Pakistanis and the Chinese" -- a reference to Prime Minister Vajpayee's justification of the tests as a counter to threats from Pakistan and China.
The scientists invited the nationalists to join their discussions; they refused, but eventually dispersed when the police were called.
In the first days after the tests, most major opposition political leaders lined up behind the Government's move. But later, several revised their position, perhaps sensing that public euphoria was receding.
One possible sign of the shifting mood came, awkwardly for Mr. Vajpayee, when he visited the craters at the Pokharan testing range on Wednesday. Among the villagers who had lined up to see the Prime Minister was one group lofting a banner in English reading, "We want a permanent hospital in Khetolai," the village nearest to the test site.
One leader who criticized the tests this week, after first endorsing them, was Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born leader of the Congress Party and daughter-in-law of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. (The late Mrs. Gandhi, who was not related to Mohandas K. Gandhi, approved India's only previous nuclear test, in May 1974). Sonia Gandhi, who at first said the tests were a "national matter," said Thursday that the tests were not a show of strength, as Mr. Vajpayee contended.
"Real strength lies in restraint and not in the use of it," she said. "Science should be used for removing poverty and backwardness in the country."
Her remarks touched on the issue that many opponents of the tests hope will be the nationalists' undoing -- the ephemeral increase in national pride from the tests, measured against the lasting indignities Indians suffer from poverty, disease, unemployment and other social scourges. Indian newspaper commentaries since the tests have noted that the popularity of Indira Gandhi surged after the 1974 tests, only to plummet so severely within 13 months that she declared an emergency, suspended civil liberties and lost the ensuing election in 1977.
It is a hope that inspires Gandhians like Mr. Bandopadhaya.
"While our leaders are talking about nuclear bombs as a deliverance," he said, "350 million of our people remain below the poverty line, nearly 50 percent of our population is illiterate, and 100,000 of our villages don't even have safe drinking water. In the villages of Rajasthan, where they detonated these bombs, many women still walk 10 to 12 miles a day just to fetch water."
He added: "This is the real India, the India that Indians actually live in. And when all the fuss and shouting dies down, they will realize that nuclear bombs do nothing, absolutely nothing, to help them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: S. K. Bandopadhaya says Indians will eventually realize that nuclear bombs "do nothing, absolutely nothing, to help them." (John F. Burns/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE OVERVIEW;
Indonesia Struggles to Find New Reasons to Stay Intact

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SURABAYA, Indonesia, May 23

 BODY:
To travel around Indonesia is to be overwhelmed by its diversity, from the tribespeople at the eastern end of the country who wear loin cloths (or even less) to the strict Muslims at the western tip, where some women could scarcely wear more.
About all those two areas have in common, in fact, is a history of secessionist movements. 
 So the collapse of the strongman rule of President Suharto, toppled Thursday after 32 years in power, raises basic questions about the future of an illogical chain of 17,000 islands that today are clumped together as Indonesia.
Mr. Suharto was a ruthless leader, but he forged modern Indonesia, suppressing militant Islam in a country where 90 percent of the people are Muslims and preaching harmony with the Christian, Hindu and animist minorities. Partly because of his sermons about moderation, and partly because of his readiness to use brute force, he not only held together this improbable archipelago but even expanded it by invading East Timor in 1975 and adding it to his island collection.
So when the students ousted Mr. Suharto this week, they also created profound uncertainties about what kind of a country Indonesia will be. Above all, a more democratic Indonesia will have to confront wrenching questions about religious coexistence and about whether there is anything but force that can serve as the national adhesive.
"Indonesia is not a kingdom but an empire," said an American businessman with broad experience in this country.
"Suharto was like Tito, in that he has been a very strong leader who has been able to hold a diverse country together the way Tito did in Yugoslavia.
"But now, can Indonesia stay together?"
Many experts say that Indonesia is so unpredictable in the post-Suharto era that no one knows quite how to analyze it, but the most common view appears to be that an Indonesian identity is well enough established that the country will muddle along for some time the way it is.
"I think that the possibility of Indonesia disintegrating is not so strong," said Muthiah Alagappa, a specialist on Southeast Asia at the East-West Center in Honolulu. But Mr. Alagappa emphasized the difficulties that a more open Indonesia will face in maintaining harmony among its people.
"The possibility of religious conflict is there," he said. "How the Muslim majority will treat the Christian minority and the Hindu minority and the Chinese -- that is very important."
Under Mr. Suharto, no one was allowed to preach hatred, and yet the bitterness toward the ethnic Chinese -- who are less than 3 percent of the population but control half the economy -- runs deep. The antagonisms might become still more dangerous if a more democratic Indonesia permits the news media to inflame hatreds by openly reporting the things that now are only whispered: that the ethnic Chinese are to blame for the financial crisis, that they are ruining Indonesia, that they are taking over the country.
If Indonesia adopts a system of direct presidential elections, then -- judging from comments by ordinary Indonesian workers and peasants -- a candidate might some day win votes by running on a platform of expelling the Chinese and creating an Islamic state.
"We should expel all the Chinese," said Suprapto, a 36-year-old worker doing odd jobs here in Surabaya, Indonesia's second-largest city. "If a politician said that, everybody would vote for him."
That is an exaggeration, and in many ways Indonesia is an extraordinarily mellow and harmonious mix of cultures and religions. But this harmony was fostered by Mr. Suharto's dictatorship, and some diplomats and other analysts fear that democracy may be more combustible.
"Frankly, I worry about the rise of Muslim fundamentalism in this chaos," a senior Western diplomat said.
Developments here will be watched with tremendous interest throughout Asia. Countries like Malaysia are also grappling with the appropriate role of Islam and Chinese minorities, while empires like China are facing the problem of how to deal with groups like the Tibetans or the Uighurs, who might prefer to strike out on their own.
The uncertainties arise in part because Indonesia as a country does not make much sense. Like some African countries, Indonesia is a geographic absurdity, arising in its present form simply because colonial powers were in such a rush to grab territory that they did not pay attention to the peoples who lived there.
The island of Java is the densely populated hub of Indonesia, home to 60 percent of the nation's 210 million people, and it has been civilized longer than Britain. But neighboring Bali is Hindu, and the islands to the east are mostly Christian. At the eastern tip is Irian Jaya, an undeveloped region where some women in the hills wear only grass skirts and some men wear only penis sheaths.
Irian Jaya, accounting for one-fifth of the area of Indonesia, is part of an island whose other half is the independent country of Papua New Guinea. The island is divided today because the Dutch grabbed what is now Irian Jaya while the Germans and British colonized the Papua half.
At the other end of the country, the Dutch seized part of the island of Borneo, and that part is now Indonesian, while the British took another part, now Malaysian. And parts of the island of Sumatra had historically been economically and culturally integrated with the Malay peninsula, but because the Dutch moved in they are now Indonesia.
Centuries of Dutch colonization -- and, more important, the independence struggle against the Dutch -- did create a sense of unity and common destiny in much of the country. Indonesians from many islands fought the Dutch and became the first Asian people to win independence by armed struggle.
Mr. Suharto and his predecessor, Sukarno, also worked hard to forge a sense of unity and to some extent succeeded, so that today much of Indonesia does have a shared sense of nationhood. One dialect was proclaimed the national language, Indonesian, and is now widely spoken throughout the country, helping to integrate a country where people speak hundreds of languages -- up to 700 in Irian Jaya alone.
But even now, people in remote areas often cannot speak Indonesian, and the linguistic barriers are immense. The tiny island of Alor is a rugged speck with 140,000 people divided among 50 tribes and almost as many languages, falling within 7 distinct language groups.
Secessionist sentiments have been a problem in places like Irian Jaya, East Timor, Sulawesi, and the conservative Muslim stronghold of Aceh at the western tip of the country, and no one knows if the problems will flare up again.
"One concern that people may have is that the new Government will be weak, and if Jakarta is weak then secessionist movements may gain strength," said Bruce Gale, an Indonesia expert at the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy in Singapore. Mr. Gale noted that many parts of the country believe that their resources are being exploited by the central Government or by distant conglomerates and added, "A new government will have to address this and will have to deal with criticisms from other provinces that they are being milked by Java."
The issue of how to deal with the regions is rarely discussed because it is still largely a taboo to admit that not all people in the country are happy being Indonesian.
A rare hint of the risks came from Mr. Suharto himself, when he warned shortly before his resignation that unless Indonesia sticks with its present Constitution and ideology of moderation, "then there will be a great danger to our national cohesion." He said that a result could be "great conflict that would threaten our development and even give rise to civil war."
The uncertainties have to do with political will rather than military abilities. The army is made up overwhelmingly of Muslim troops from the main parts of Indonesia and is a professional force that seems certain to stay together and to be able to fight, if so ordered, to preserve the national borders.
Yet democracies often have difficulty mustering the will to suppress secessionists. Issues of secession are among the most painful that democracies ever face, as they were in America in the 19th century and as they are in Russia today. In Indonesia, university students in the pro-democracy movement so far have not quite confronted the issue of whether democratic rights should be extended to secessionists.
When students protesting for democracy at the Parliament building in the last few days were asked how a more democratic Indonesia should deal with separatist movements, they grew extremely agitated. On several occasions, groups of students began yelling at an Indonesian interpreter, berating him for asking treacherous questions about secessionist sentiment.
"It is impossible for this country to come apart," said Yusman, 19, a management student in the Parliament building, as his friends cheered him on.
Yet when pressed hard enough, almost all students concluded -- although they were not entirely happy with their conclusion -- that Timorese or Acehnese or others should continue to be imprisoned if they advocate independence.
Still, among Indonesia's educated elite, some people do emphasize that force will no longer be an adequate glue to hold the country together. They are ambivalent, determined to preserve the country but reluctant to rely on coercion, and they emphasize that Indonesia must try new approaches.

HEADLINE: Democrats Hope to Trim Their Pool of Candidates

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In a nod to an era of politics that has almost passed in New York State, Democratic leaders and candidates will assemble in Westchester County this week for a convention that is shaping up as a freewheeling if inconclusive gathering, with just a hint of the suspense that was once a staple of such meetings.
For all the ceremony that will accompany the Democrats as they convene on Wednesday morning in Rye Brook, the role of the state committee in this year's elections is circumscribed. The selection of Democratic candidates for governor, United States senator, attorney general and perhaps lieutenant governor will almost certainly be made by Democratic voters in the primary on Sept. 15. 
 Accordingly, Democratic leaders have set themselves two main goals for their quadrennial convention: to try to limit the number of candidates who appear on the primary ballot, and thus minimize intraparty strife, and to use what they hope will be a well-covered two-day forum to begin making the Democratic case against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki.
"I don't want our message to be obscured by the process," said Judith Hope, the party chairwoman. "I'm determined to make this convention about George Pataki's failure to jump-start the economy in upstate New York, and about D'Amato's propensity to reinvent himself every six years. I want a convention that is positive and forward-looking and that gets across the Democratic message."
The convention -- 353 delegates elected from the 62 counties, gathered in a hotel in wooded central Westchester -- will stand as a testimonial to a party that is in much transition and some trouble. The Democratic Party lost its bid to unseat a Republican Mayor in New York City last November, and faces tough going again this year in its challenges to both Mr. Pataki and, to a lesser extent, Mr. D'Amato.
Mario M. Cuomo, the former Governor who dominated the Democratic Party for 12 years, is not even planning to attend; his absence will no doubt underscore the vacuum in the party as it awaits the emergence of a new generation of high-profile leaders. At the same time, the decision by Vice President Al Gore to deliver the keynote speech on Wednesday is a reminder of the influence the state party will exert in the 2000 Democratic presidential selection.
Even with these expectations, the candidates and their supporters approached the gathering in a frenzy of politicking and preconvention maneuvering. It is far from clear what the play of the field will be at the end of the week, and whether party leaders' attempts at exerting some control over the proceedings will succeed.
The main task for the delegates is to sift through the candidates seeking to run for statewide office. A candidate who wins at least 51 percent of the convention vote is the official designee of the party. It is a dubious distinction, since the designee can still be challenged in a primary, and as a rule, Democratic designees tend to lose to challengers in primaries.
Candidates need 25 percent of the delegate votes to win a spot on the primary ballot. Failing that, they have to circulate petitions to gather signatures from 15,000 registered Democrats, an expensive and, by design, prohibitive process.
Among the races, the selection of the gubernatorial candidates, scheduled for Wednesday, is shaping up as one of the more intriguing portions of the convention.
Supporters of Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker and one of five Democrats seeking the gubernatorial nomination, believe he can win 51 percent of the vote to become the party designee. Some of Mr. Vallone's advisers believe he will be able to keep any of the other four from winning 25 percent of the vote -- and that could produce one of the more interesting confrontations of the week.
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the other major contender for governor, had comparatively little support among delegates as of yesterday. But she has the financial resources to circulate petitions and get on the ballot, which her advisers said she would certainly do.
Mr. Vallone believes his best chance against Ms. McCaughey Ross is one-on-one, which is why he is trying at the convention to keep other candidates off the ballot.
But advisers to Ms. McCaughey Ross, trying to counter Mr. Vallone's move and crowd the ballot with other men, said they were likely to instruct her delegates to support any of the male candidates who comes close to 25 percent, in the hope of putting them over the top. "This is going to be a very pragmatic race," said Stephen Sabbeth, the Nassau County leader and Ms. McCaughey Ross's most prominent supporter.
Right now, the beneficiary of that strategy would likely be James L. Larocca, the former State Transportation Commissioner, or Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, who said he would not go the petition route if he did not win 25 percent. The fifth candidate, Richard A. Kahan, the former chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation, does not as of now appear to have significant support.
Mr. Vallone's supporters are trying to check Ms. McCaughey Ross's effort by suggesting that Mr. Larocca drop out and become Mr. Vallone's lieutenant governor. That would insure Mr. Vallone a commanding majority at the convention, and would present what many Democrats believe would be a reasonably strong ticket in the fall. Governor and lieutenant governor are chosen separately in the primary process but run as one ticket in the general election.
Mr. Larocca is presumably susceptible to such overtures because Mr. Sabbeth, who had been his most important patron, abandoned him for Ms. McCaughey Ross before the convention. But in an interview, Mr. Larocca heatedly said he had no interest in running as Mr. Vallone's running mate. "I am a candidate for governor," he said. "I am not a candidate for any other office."
If a Vallone-Larocca deal does not work out, Mr. Vallone is said to be leaning toward Clyde Rabideau, the Mayor of Plattsburgh, as a running mate.
A similar, if less suspenseful, struggle is going on in the Senate race. Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former vice presidential candidate, are assured spots on the ballot. The third candidate, Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, is not as of now.
There is some disagreement among Ms. Ferraro's supporters whether she should send some of her delegates to Mr. Green to force a three-way race, or try to come out of the convention with as much strength as possible. Democratic officials said yesterday that Ms. Ferraro might be spared that decision because the convention might decide to hold two ballots. Delegates could vote for Mr. Green on the second ballot, assuring him his 25 percent.
In the race for attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, a former prosecutor, and G. Oliver Koppell, a former Attorney General, are both said to have more than enough support to get on the ballot. A third candidate, State Senator Catherine M. Abate, is said to be just below 25 percent, but party leaders said that she, too, might be placed on the primary ballot on a second vote of the convention.
A fourth candidate, Evan A. Davis, a former counsel to Mr. Cuomo, is said to be short of the 25 percent.

HEADLINE: Mayor May Trade a Term Limits Deal for Support on Stadium Issue

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will consider leading a campaign to abolish term limits for City Council members if the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, drops his drive for a referendum on a new Yankee Stadium, the Mayor said yesterday.
The city's voters have twice endorsed term limits, so several city officials assert that only a high-profile campaign by someone like the Mayor could bring about a change in the law that will force the retirement of most of the current Council after the elections in 2001. 
 This is a second effort by the Mayor to head off the Speaker's plan to let voters decide whether the city can use tax money to help the Yankees build a new baseball stadium in Manhattan instead of the Bronx.
The Mayor, who has often pointed to the economic benefits of a stadium in Manhattan, retaliated by creating a panel to propose changes for the City Charter for consideration by voters in November. By law, a charter question would knock any other measure off the ballot.
As a compromise, the Mayor could propose charter changes to rescind term limits for Council members, officials said. Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone had talked about the idea of the Mayor campaigning to end term limits for Council members but not the Mayor.
"It is ironic, now, that Peter Vallone would be jeopardizing this potential initiative that would be so vital to helping his members run for re-election, by insisting on pushing a stadium referendum that can't possibly get on the ballot," Mr. Mastro said.
The possible trade was first reported yesterday by The New York Post. At a news conference yesterday, the Mayor did not dispute the possibility. "As far as term limits are concerned, that's something that the Charter Revision Commission has to look at," he said. "What I've said is that I would not seek to change the term limits with regard to the Mayor. I think two terms is a sensible rule."
Mr. Giuliani repeated his assertion that a stadium referendum could drive the Yankees out of New York City. "Referenda on baseball stadiums lead to baseball teams leaving," he said. That view was echoed on Friday by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is acting as an unpaid adviser to the principal owner of the Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner 3d.
Mr. Mastro said the Mayor and the Speaker had not discussed a deal. "Obviously, the Mayor would be helping City Council members if he were ever to support a referendum to end term limits for City Council members," Mr. Mastro said. "So in making that determination, it is certainly appropriate to consider circumstances in which he has asked the Speaker to take certain actions or forbear from certain actions."
Mr. Vallone's spokesman, Michael S. Clendenin, discounted the trial balloon. "Who's the Mayor kidding?" he said. "The voters have spoken on term limits twice already."

HEADLINE: Taxi Owners Deftly Dodge Claims of Accident Victims

SERIES: HAILING DANGER: The Liability Question

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The taxi came barreling up Third Avenue late on a damp October night. As the driver tried to bear left, the cab skidded onto a traffic island, slamming into Edward Shalala, who was waiting to cross the street. He was hurled onto the pavement, his face a bloody mess and his right leg shattered, as his surgeon put it, "like cornflakes."
In five operations since the 1992 accident, doctors put Mr. Shalala, a 48-year-old artist, back together well enough that he can hobble around on crutches. And last year a jury tried to make him whole financially with a $3.2 million award for damages. But it was mostly an empty promise. 
 Already undone by an erratic cabby, Mr. Shalala then fell victim to the dodging and weaving the taxi industry uses to avoid paying large claims, even in devastating accidents. Unable to collect the jury's award, Mr. Shalala settled this year with the taxi company for $132,000.
The sharp rise in taxi and livery accidents since 1990 and the recent spate of high-profile collisions have fed an image of rogue cabbies run amok. But the drivers are only the most visible players in a lucrative industry that has deftly used laws and regulations to keep its earnings safe, even as its cabs hurt more and more people.
Interviews and an examination of dozens of lawsuits show that cab companies are among the most recalcitrant businesses in paying claims to accident victims. And while the city has long ignored these practices, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is now roiling the industry with a proposal to clamp down on dangerous drivers and make it easier for injured people to collect.
Most of the city's 12,000 cabs and 30,000 car-service vehicles carry minimal liability insurance, far less than most trucking and bus companies. Many taxi owners, including those with large fleets, organize their operations into subsets of much smaller companies, protecting the bulk of their assets from lawsuits.
And the biggest asset in the yellow cab industry, the taxi medallion, is the hardest to seize. As the taxi industry has boomed and the limited pool of medallions -- the valuable permits to operate a cab -- has soared in value to an average of $275,000 each, owners have routinely used them as security for loans. So even when the rare victim tries to seize a medallion in court, it is common to find that the owner has attached so much debt to it that there is little money left to recover.
In Mr. Shalala's case, the owners of the taxi company -- two former city cabbies -- borrowed $100,000 against their medallions just as a state court judge was entering the $3.2 million judgment, complicating Mr. Shalala's efforts to collect.
In another instance, a taxi owner named Natan More, who was facing two suits from accident victims, defied a judge's order by borrowing $1.6 million using his medallions as collateral. He also took off on a sailing trip in the Mediterranean, according to court papers, saying he had "no clue" when he would return.
Through such tactics, the industry has transformed the medallion -- the 4-by-5-inch rectangle of aluminum bolted to the hood of every yellow taxi -- into both a source of wealth and a financial shield.
"The way the game is set up with the taxi companies," said Vito A. Cannavo, a lawyer who has pursued many injury claims, "you're chasing phantoms all over the place."
Until recently, these concerns always hovered just below the political radar screen, mainly because few of the millions of taxi patrons realize the high stakes involved in one of the most ordinary acts of city life -- hopping into a cab.
With cab and livery accidents up 41 percent since 1990, to 12,557 in 1996, the latest year for which figures were available, Mr. Giuliani has vowed to lower the stakes. He has called for more stringent safety regulations to pull reckless cabbies from the road. In 1996, police figures show, taxi accidents injured 20,000 people, about 850 seriously, and killed 29, mostly pedestrians.
Mr. Giuliani would require taxi and livery operators to increase their insurance to cover medical bills and to compensate victims for pain and physical damage. The liability coverage would rise to $100,000 for each victim, from a current minimum of $25,000. Owners of yellow cabs also would have to post a $100,000 bond to guarantee that victims who win court judgments could collect up to that much more.
The proposals, due to be considered by the Taxi and Limousine Commission this week, have been denounced as punitive in protests by drivers. Owners say they could price some companies and many independent cabbies out of the business.
"The industry has a bad reputation because it is easy to focus on the bad things," said David L. Beier, a lawyer for Transit Systems Ltd., a company owned by one of the wealthiest families in the industry. "The only thing you hear about are the terrible accidents." Mr. Beier acknowledged that the industry fights to hold down accident claims but, he said, "there are serious claims that we feel bad about, and we do everything we can to settle."
Industry analysts say that New York City has traditionally been one of the toughest places for victims of taxi accidents to collect damages. A few cities -- most notably Washington -- also have tortuous systems, with low insurance levels and high legal hurdles. But the Mayor's changes would go a long way toward bringing New York in line with cities like Chicago and San Francisco, where most cabs carry several hundred thousand dollars' worth of insurance coverage.
Alan L. Fuchsberg, a Manhattan lawyer who has represented dozens of people injured in taxi accidents, said the Mayor's plan "certainly would be an improvement, but I don't think it's enough." Noting that other business concerns, like trucking companies and commercial buildings, typically have $500,000 to $1 million in liability insurance, he said: "The concern is that a seriously injured person would still in no way be compensated for the full extent of their injuries."
 
The Owners
Medallions Produce And Shield Wealth
 The glittering promise of the medallion is embodied in a trio of Russian immigrants known in the industry as "The Three Wise Men."
Like generations of immigrants before them, two brothers, Fred and Victor Weingarten, and a relative, Jacob Popovic, the owners of Transit Systems, started out as cabdrivers. They made their first deals to buy medallions in the late 1970's, from a booth in a Queens coffee shop. Now they and their families own 240 yellow taxi medallions, worth more than $66 million.
Their wealth has given them much to protect. And like other medallion owners -- large and small -- the Wise Men have managed to insulate themselves from normal business risks and place most of their assets out of reach of accident victims. In fact, their holdings are arranged so precisely that, to someone suing them, they never seem any bigger than the small company they were when they first started out.
The industry has established this finely honed system over many years. During the Depression, the city limited the number of medallions to curb an oversupply of cabs. Since then, these limits have protected owners from open competition while propelling the cost of the permits from $10 each in the 1930's to an average of $275,000 today -- or $3.4 billion for the entire supply.
Medallions are tickets to a cash-rich business. Each cab brings in up to $100,000 a year in fares. There are even medallion brokers, who help owners -- particularly retired cabbies -- sell or lease their pieces of tin. These absentee owners are paid up to $1,700 a month simply to let other drivers use their licenses.
While the city has helped medallion owners thrive, its regulators have rarely challenged their system for limiting liability for accidents. For decades, big operators have divided their holdings into a series of small companies, each owning just two or three medallions. The practice was condemned by a State Supreme Court judge 40 years ago as "a legalized racket to avoid liability for payment of the negligent maiming and killing by taxicabs." But the appeals court later sanctioned the arrangement as long as taxi executives do not commingle the corporations' funds or treat them as personal treasuries.
Through these arrangements, even large-scale medallion owners keep the bulk of their assets safe if one of their cabs injures someone in an accident. For example, the 240 medallions belonging to the three Transit Systems partners are split into 119 corporations. Cab owners have also been allowed to use their medallions to secure loans since the taxi and banking industries pushed through a state law sanctioning the practice in 1969. Loading medallions with debt makes them less attractive to litigants.
"When one owner can own 100 cars in different corporations, and then mortgage them to protect his assets from accident victims, that's wrong," said Pam Liapakis, a former president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association. "The purpose of the corporate law is being subverted."
But Mr. Beier, the lawyer for Transit Systems, said this practice "is not a subterfuge." He added: "Every person who owns a business puts it in a form to protect him from liability."
Yet one major difference is that with their assets hidden under debt, taxi companies do not have to carry as much insurance as other businesses. A decade ago, many cabs carried $100,000 in liability coverage, but nearly all fell to minimal levels after the largest taxi insurer, American Transit Insurance Company, dropped the higher coverage.
Edward T. McGettigan Jr., the underwriting manager at American Transit, said the company's losses were too great with the higher coverage because nearly every claim cost more to settle and people tended to exaggerate their injuries. "Most people, when they get into a car accident, they think they hit the Lotto," he said.
 
The Typical Cases
Stalling Tactics Wear Out Victims
Lucille Williams hardly hit the jackpot. It has been five years since one cab collided with another, then smashed into Mrs. Williams as she walked near the Queensboro Bridge. Her injuries, including a fractured pelvis, forced her to quit her job as an aide at a day care center because she could no longer lift the toddlers.
Mrs. Williams's case bogged down amid routine stalling tactics by the cab companies. Court hearings were delayed, Mrs. Williams's lawyer, Lamont Bailey, said, because the companies sent lawyers who were not familiar with the case, and the drivers missed scheduled depositions. Mrs. Williams, worn down, finally agreed to settle two months ago. Her share: $20,000. And even that, Mr. Bailey said, "was like getting blood from a stone."
Taxi companies are known for battling over liability, using all of the tactics of the hardball world of personal-injury claims, plus their particular brand of asset protection. Plaintiffs' lawyers, who are paid a share of what their clients collect, are well aware of these frustrations, and some say they cringe when a taxi victim walks in the door.
Cases with disfiguring injuries are particularly contentious. One increasing cause of those injuries is the bullet-resistant partition now required in yellow taxis.
Robert A. Levy, a lawyer who handled a case in which the side of a woman's nose was ripped off when she hit a partition, said that if she had been hurt in a building or a bus, her injuries would have been worth $75,000. But he said she had to settle for $28,500 -- $25,000 of insurance and $3,500 from the driver himself, paid in 12 monthly installments.
When suing a large taxi operator, the best hope for a sizable settlement is to try to "pierce the corporate veil" and show that the fleet operates as a single company, not a bunch of disconnected little ones.
A rare success came in a case of a Roman Catholic nun who suffered a serious leg injury in 1993 when a taxi pulled away while she was getting into it. The fleet, with 72 medallions split among 33 companies, fought her until mid-1996, when her lawyers found that it had tied together most of the small companies to secure $3.5 million in loans. The fleet owner paid a $100,000 settlement.
But that is often difficult, if not impossible. When Rita Sklar was struck and killed by a cab on East 64th Street, her family's lawyer, Guy I. Smiley, said that the cab company's lawyer told him to expect to recover nothing more than the minimum $50,000 death benefit. "He said, 'We got a minimum policy. That's it -- no excess, no assets, nothing' " Mr. Smiley recalled.
In fact, the two-cab company was run by Fred Weingarten of Transit Systems, and it was part of the $66 million empire built by the trio of Russian immigrants. Mr. Smiley found an easier target: a construction site at the corner where the accident occurred. Both the building owner and the contractor carried $1 million in liability insurance, and the cabdriver contended that plywood sheeting around the site had blocked his view.
Employing what he calls "legal creativity," Mr. Smiley is now suing the contractor and building owner.
 
The Extreme Case
A Shattered Life And a Refusal to Pay
For Mr. Shalala, the accident altered almost every aspect of his life.
His ankle, reconstructed with metal plates and bone from his hip and covered with flesh grafted from his back, is a bulgy patchwork of skin and scar. When he walks now, using crutches, he can feel the screws in his ankle rubbing against his bones.
His recovery, incomplete as it is, took two years in a wheelchair and thousands of physical therapy sessions. After walking eight blocks to his home on Delancey Street on a recent night, he arrived nearly in tears from the throbbing pain in his right leg.
Damaged and demoralized, Mr. Shalala, a cousin of Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, depends on a nurse's aide to bring him groceries and to do his laundry. Even his artwork is different. His paintings, once five-foot-high abstracts with images burned into them with a steam iron and a torch, are now much smaller and more delicately worked in deference to his disability.
Mr. Shalala's adversaries in the six years since the accident have been a pair of former cabbies, John Letsios and Dimitrios Theofanis, owners of the Platform Cab Corporation, a small company that leases out two medallions. But unlike Mr. Shalala, they were relatively unaffected by the accident. The company kept operating. And when a judge found it to be liable for the accident, not only did the owners try to avoid paying Mr. Shalala, but they also continued borrowing money against their medallions to protect their assets.
The driver who hit Mr. Shalala was Bhagwan Singh. The accident was his third of 1992; his fourth came the next day. Since then, his license has been suspended four times. Last week, Mr. Singh completed the last suspension, for running a red light while under sanctions for drunken driving.
Mr. Shalala filed a lawsuit in March 1994. But after fighting through the legal process, he was upset to find that in December 1996, just two weeks after a judge held Platform and Mr. Singh liable, Mr. Letsios and Mr. Theofanis borrowed $132,000 against their medallions.
Then last June, after a Brooklyn jury had awarded Mr. Shalala the $3.2 million, the men applied for an additional loan of $100,000 -- "for business investment," the loan papers said. The documents show that the two men received their checks four days before Mr. Shalala's lawyer, Eric H. Green, received formal notice of the judgment, which he needed before he could block them from draining the company's assets.
State law allows businesses to borrow against an asset until a judgment is executed and collection notices are served. But moving the money around makes it harder for an accident victim to collect, and Mr. Green's plans to chase that last $100,000 stalled when he was told by Platform's leasing agent that the two owners lived in Greece.
When Mr. Green tried to seize Platform's medallions, another surprise awaited him: Platform faced lawsuits stemming from three other accidents. This allowed the company effectively to play the victims off each other for the funds that were left.
In January, Mr. Shalala, afraid that he might never get anything if he kept waiting, agreed to settle for $132,000. Much of the money will end up going to Medicaid or Medicare, which paid some of his medical bills.
Mr. Shalala said his experience with Platform has left him queasy. "I basically think they're crooks," he said. "It was the taxicab company that made this situation, and it should be their responsibility to help me. Instead I feel like they were hiding from the law and hiding from the court."
In fact, some of the money borrowed against Platform's medallions may never have left the country. Mr. Theofanis lives in Flushing, Queens, not Greece, and is a banquet waiter at a Manhattan hotel. In a brief interview at the hotel, he said he had no direct role in running his cabs.
As for the accident, Mr. Theofanis said: "Those things happen, you know? People will sue for anything. For anything. You could trip coming down this ramp, and I'll be in trouble."
 
The Regulators
Agency Views Suits From the Sideline
The Taxi and Limousine Commission, charged with overseeing the business, has historically done little to insure that medallion owners take care of accident victims.
Current and former commission officials say the agency has viewed that as a matter for the courts. It does not keep track of how much owners borrow against their medallions. Nor does it punish owners who fail to honor court judgments. It has intervened in rare cases where owners have tried to sell a medallion that is subject to a large injury claim, making sure enough money was set aside to cover an award.
Several personal injury lawyers say that even when the commission has tried to help accident victims, it has sometimes bungled.
They point to the case of Mr. More, the medallion owner who went sailing in the Mediterranean with two huge accident suits looming. He defied a judge's order last year by borrowing $1.6 million against his medallions, then quit making payments on the loans. When the lenders decided to seize the medallions, the taxi commission helped alert the lawyer for one of the victims, but inexplicably failed to tell the other's lawyer until it was too late.
The first victim was able to work out a $200,000 settlement with the lenders. Frank V. Floriani, the lawyer for the second victim, was left fuming that his client emerged empty-handed. Commission officials say they were just trying to help. But referring to the regulators, Mr. Floriani said, "They really don't care about the traveling public."
Allan J. Fromberg, the commission's spokesman, said that the increased insurance and the $100,000 bond would solve most of the problems faced by accident victims and "would clearly be far more equitable than anything that existed in the past."
The bond, which would guarantee that winners of court judgments could collect up to $100,000, in addition to the $100,000 insurance settlement, would have to be bought by every individual and corporation owning medallions. Given its cost, officials view the bond as a clever way to prod medallion owners to stop splitting their holdings and reconsolidate into fewer companies, with more assets for accident victims to go after.
But these proposals -- rushed out in reaction to the recent string of accidents -- have come under fire from the industry.
Insurers estimate that increasing liability coverage to $100,000 from $25,000 would cost taxi operators anywhere from $3,000 to $11,000 more each year in premiums. And even some former taxi regulators say the bond proposal is poorly thought out and unlikely to force medallion owners to change the structure of their businesses.
Fidel F. Del Valle, a former chairman of the taxi commission, said that fleet owners "will never do that, regardless of what kind of cost they put on it, because it still isn't worth risking your entire fleet."
Underwriters would require taxi operators to set aside at least $100,000 in cash or a credit line as collateral. Industry officials said this could crush many owner-operators and force the fleets to tie up millions of dollars, while helping only the relatively few accident victims who push their cases all the way to court judgments.
But even if these proposals are enacted, they are unlikely to end the creativity of cab companies trying to minimize liability.
Consider the case of Thomas Armstrong, a blind pencil seller who, along with his dog, Smokey, was hit by a cab in 1992 outside of Tiffany & Company. Mr. Armstrong required operations for a broken leg and shoulder, and needs a walker to get around. In 1997 he won a $965,000 award against Brant Taxi Inc., but so far he has been able to get only $10,000 of it.
Exasperated, Mr. Armstrong's lawyers moved to seize the company's medallions last fall. The company then filed for bankruptcy to prevent Mr. Armstrong from recovering money by forcing the sale of its medallions. In its bankruptcy filing, Brant Taxi said it was simply trying to reorganize "free from creditor harassment."
Its biggest creditor, Mr. Armstrong, now 70, said: "I'm getting tired of waiting. But there ain't nothing I can do."
 
Hailing Danger
The first article in this series, published earlier this month, examined the economic pressures on taxi drivers, their lack of safety training and other weaknesses in city enforcement.

HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: THE OUTLOOK;
A Key Figure Says the Need For Elections Is Imperative

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23

 BODY:
Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, swore in his new Cabinet here this morning, and one of its most influential members immediately questioned whether the Government should survive.
Ginandjar Kartasasmita, the Coordinating Minister for Economy, Finance and Industry, said in a briefing after the ceremony that it was "imperative" to hold elections for a Government with a popular mandate. Mr. Habibie, who became President on Thursday after the resignation of President Suharto, seems determined to serve out Mr. Suharto's term, which runs until 2003. 
 "One thing is for sure," Mr. Ginandjar said, "we need to have a new Government with a new mandate from the people. So it is very important that we have a general election as soon as possible."
Many of Indonesia's students are calling for the same thing. Even after they were evicted from the Parliament by hundreds of troops early today, students rallied against Mr. Habibie again today at the University of Indonesia in central Jakarta. About 2,000 soldiers guarded the Parliament to prevent the students from trying to reclaim the building, which they had occupied for five days.
Mr. Ginandjar, who is Indonesia's top economic policy-maker, as he was under President Suharto, blamed continuing political instability for the nation's economic woes. "The uncertainty comes from the fact that the economic ministers have no control over the political process," he said.
Experts say Mr. Ginandjar must play a central role if Indonesia is to mend its shattered economy. At a time when the International Monetary Fund has put a $43 billion economic rescue package on hold, he has strong ties to both the fund and to senior officials in the West. Mr. Ginandjar said he had spoken to the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and to I.M.F. officials, who pledged to help restore Indonesia's economy.
Regardless of his skepticism about the Government, Mr. Ginandjar said he would set about trying to restore confidence in Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, and on reining in spiraling inflation. He said his goal was to bolster the rupiah's exchange rate to 6,000 to the dollar -- though he added that the current political climate made it hard to predict when that could be achieved.
The rupiah seesawed wildly this week after escalating unrest forced Mr. Suharto to step down on Thursday. It finished the week at about 10,000 rupiah to the dollar, recovering from an earlier level of 14,000 to the dollar.
Outside experts agreed that Indonesia must resolve its murky political situation before it can hope to attract either aid or investment.
"I think the I.M.F. will mark time until they know who they're dealing with, and how long these people are going to be around," said Richard Margolis, a regional strategist with Merrill Lynch & Company in Hong Kong.
Expatriate business people, who fled Jakarta by the thousands after riots and looting, have begun to return to the city on flights from Singapore. But foreign investors are still holding back, according to several experts, out of fear that the unrest could flare up again.
"There seems to be a general consensus that Habibie is a transitional figure," Mr. Margolis said. "Now people who are products of Suharto's system are working out how far and fast to go. It's very chancy territory."
After reacting guardedly to Mr. Habibie's announcement of his new Cabinet on Friday, opposition leaders began to pick apart the choices -- complaining that they do not represent enough of a break with the Suharto era. Fifteen of the 36 ministers in the Cabinet, including Mr. Ginandjar, held the same posts under Mr. Suharto. Four others were simply shuffled to new jobs.
"The people in the Cabinet who have been working under Mr. Suharto for 30 years are the ones who made Indonesia the most corrupt country in the world," said Laksamana Sukardi, an adviser to Megawati Sukarnoputri, one of the most prominent opposition leaders.
Mr. Habibie did try to reach out to some opposition figures, most notably Kwik Kian Gie, a chief adviser to Ms. Megawati. But Mr. Kwik, who was sounded out about becoming State Minister for Investment, declined because he feared it would erode his credibility with reformers, according to people who know him.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An Indonesian Cabinet member and student protesters are urging President B. J. Habibie to call general elections rather than serve out his predecessor's term. Mr. Habibie's Cabinet greeted him Friday in Jakarta. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Fast Times for Engineering Graduates, as a Slump Ends

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
With the economy booming, college graduates are facing the best job market in years. And for students in engineering and computer science -- a small group who chose their majors when companies were downsizing and engineers were being tossed aside like used Kleenex -- the market is sizzling.
Most have multiple job offers, signing bonuses are common, and some are even being offered stock options, a benefit normally reserved for top executives. On many campuses in the New York metropolitan region, engineering and computer science graduates are receiving salary offers of $45,000 to $50,000 a year as employers compete for one of the smallest graduating classes of engineers in a decade. Those offers are up as much as 20 percent over last year's, and well above offers to graduates in fields like economics and psychology. Career counselors at Ivy League colleges and commuter schools are shaking their heads in amazement. 
 At Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., for example, the average annual starting salary is $45,621, and one computer science undergraduate has accepted a job for $70,000.
"Student salaries are out of sight," said Thomas Tarantelli, director of the R.P.I. career center, who said they surpassed salaries in his office long ago. "We often sit around and joke about the fact that the students are coming to us for advice."
Paul J. Kostek, a consulting engineer in Seattle and president-elect of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers-U.S.A., said: "I call the class of '98 the class of optimists. These students took a chance, and that chance has paid off."
Allison Cooke, a 25-year-old student at the City College of New York, recalls the job market when she chose chemical engineering as her major. "It was kind of grim," she said. "Dow Chemical was being sued for its silicone implants. Companies were laying off workers."
As she struggled through fluid mechanics and kinetics and passed up invitations to parties so she could spend nights in the laboratory, she questioned her choice of major again and again. But as she prepares to graduate, she has received two job offers, one for more than $45,000 a year and the other for more than $50,000.
"Now I feel I can exhale," she said. "I'm really making it. The job market for chemical engineers right now is fantastic. We are so in demand."
With computers on nearly every desk and factory floor in America, companies are hungry for people who can program and maintain them. (The Senate voted on Monday to allow more foreign workers into the United States to fill jobs in computer programming and related areas.) And as other fields like biotechnology and financial services explode, they, too, are eager to hire people with technological and analytical expertise.
Eileen Kohan, executive director of the Center for Career Services at Columbia University, said she expected annual salaries for engineering graduates to average more than $50,000 this year, with bonuses ranging between $5,000 and $10,000 at many Wall Street firms and communications companies. "I've been watching this since the fall, and I was like, 'Whoa,' " she said.
She said that although engineers have long been among the most highly paid graduates, the gap widened this year, with engineers averaging about $8,000 more than liberal arts graduates.
She said one student had accepted an offer with a high-technology company in San Francisco with a base salary of $50,000, an annual bonus of 5 to 10 percent and stock options. "It's the first time I've seen stock options," she said.
The booming market for engineers is a sharp turnaround from just a few years ago. In the early 1990's, the engineering work force was shrinking and unemployment among engineers was climbing.
Not surprisingly, the number of students going into engineering dropped. By 1996, there were only 356,000 engineering majors, down nearly 20 percent from 13 years earlier, just before the decline began. Last year, only 65,000 students earned bachelor's degrees in engineering, down from 76,000 a decade earlier. And although data are not yet available for this year's graduating class, some colleges, like Clarkson University in Potsdam, N.Y., say the number is even smaller.
For Monika Posluszna, 23, a senior in computer engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., the demand for engineers has made it easy to find a job. Ms. Posluszna, who did not learn English until she arrived in New Jersey from Poland in the 10th grade, interviewed with nine companies and accepted a job with Mars Inc., the candy company -- at more than $60,000 a year.
James Destro, 22, a chemical engineering major at R.P.I., sent his resume to 25 companies and got 22 responses. After the interviews, more than half of them invited him to visit their plants, and 7 companies made him offers. The lowest was $45,000, with a $3,000 bonus for signing on. On June 26, he will start with the Exxon Corporation at a salary of more than $50,000. Until then, he will be scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef.
"I'll be totally relaxed," he said. "The last time that happened was between high school and college."
Although salaries in the region are higher than in many other parts of the country, salaries everywhere for computer majors and other graduates in technical fields have jumped, after a long period of stagnation.
In its April salary survey, the National Association of Colleges and Employers in Bethlehem, Pa., found that salaries for chemical engineers were averaging close to $46,000, up from about $42,500 a year earlier. The average for computer science graduates was nearly $41,000, up from about $36,000 last year, and 10 percent of the offers to computer science graduates from computer software companies topped $48,000.
"Nerds are king now," said Bill Linstaedt, director of career services at the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind., where the average salary offer to computer engineers is more than $44,000 and 40 percent have received signing bonuses. "It's not easy to go through engineering school," he said, "but this is the payoff."
For students, it is a world they were not fully prepared for. Some were unsure about the ethics of accepting bonuses, others about how to balance competing job offers.
Cassandra Simmons, director of corporate recruitment at City College, said that one electrical engineering student went to her to discuss whether he could accept a $6,000 bonus if he signed on with a telecommunications company. She told him that he could, but that he should look at the job itself, not just the money. (He liked the job and took it.)
Another issue for many students was simply how to juggle so many interviews and job offers. R.P.I. brought in financial planners and time-management experts to help students like Sarah Jordan, 21, a computer science and systems engineering major, who had so many job interviews (30) and company visits (7, including trips to Texas and Massachusetts) that some weeks she had trouble fitting them in around her classes.
"People saw me in a suit almost every day," she said. "It was a plain black run-of-the-mill suit, but thank goodness it was very durable."
She ultimately chose Hewlett-Packard in Andover, Mass., because she liked the atmosphere, and will start on July 16 at a salary of $49,200.
Sometimes, though, the career office officials were not sure the students needed much help. Mr. Tarantelli cited the case of one student who went to him a month ago with a $70,000 offer, asking, "How do I negotiate?"
"Our reaction was, 'What are you, nuts?' " Mr. Tarantelli said.
For companies, the challenge has been how to lure students to interviews -- and then get them to sign on. On college campuses, companies sponsored dinners and ran lotteries for mountain bikes and trips to Hawaii to draw in students. They also sweetened their financial packages. But many also recognized that the biggest challenge was to convince students that they would be working in a good environment.
Sapient Corporation, an information-technology consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., offered salaries of $45,000 to $55,000, annual bonuses and immediate stock options. But it also brought in potential recruits -- 25 to 40 at a time -- for two-day visits that included not only interviews but also team exercises and social events.
"They really get to see that they will be working with other smart people doing really cool things, versus sitting in a cubicle, writing code," said Nikki Fisher, Sapient's vice president for marketing.
Companies also widened their recruiting to include nonengineering students who showed any hint of experience -- or interest -- in a technical job.
"We were looking at bright, smart students who might have a newly budding interest in information technology," said Allan Jones, manager of college recruiting for American Management Systems, an information-technology consulting company in Fairfax, Va., that is hiring about 600 undergraduates and 200 graduate students this year.
"We looked at students like history majors who worked in the computer center, or philosophy majors who had an internship where they stumbled on information technology and realized that was the way they wanted to go."
For now, there is no sign that next year's supply of graduating engineers will be larger, and companies are already vying for interview slots at the colleges.
Some college career-service officials say that their interviewing rooms are already booked for the fall, and that they will need to line up conference rooms and faculty offices on campuses -- as they did this year -- to accommodate all the companies that want to interview students.
Meanwhile, corporate officials and engineering experts say they hope the job market will entice more students into engineering.
But some, like Mr. Linstaedt at Rose-Hulman, remain concerned that students may be put off by what he called the "Dilbert" factor, after the comic-strip character: "the idea of engineers as nerds without lives who have lousy jobs, evil bosses, tiny offices, no sense of style and a personal life to match."
That is a real problem, said Gregory Schuckman, a spokesman for the American Association of Engineering Societies in Washington.
"If we can get people to focus on other role models than Dilbert, maybe we can get our enrollments up," he said hopefully. "Everybody likes to read 'Dilbert.' But do you know anyone who wants to be Dilbert?"

HEADLINE: May 17-23;
Trade Deficit Jumps

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit jumped sharply in March, providing the clearest evidence yet of how Asia's economic woes are being felt in the United States. The gap rose to $13 billion, far higher than analysts had expected. 
 The report showed that exporters are losing business in Asia, and hurting profits and jobs in the United States. But it might not be a bad thing for trade to slow the economy somewhat, since growth has been so strong that it might ignite inflation. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: Suharto's 'Painful' Fall? Not for Indonesians

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Suharto's Stealthy Foe: Globalizing Capitalism" (news article, May 20) does not mention a second vital element in the current world revolution: the spread of the ideas of equality and democracy. 
 Although capitalism may be creating the conditions and imperatives that lead to the demand for more open economies and political systems in Asia, Latin America and Africa, there is more. We should not underestimate the importance of the worldwide diffusion of the idea that all people are equal, that they do not need to be ruled by kings, emperors, presidents-for-life, commissars, rajahs or patriarchs.
 
HERBERT S. LEWIS
Madison, Wis., May 20, 1998
 
The writer is professor emeritus at the University of Wisconsin.
