HEADLINE: THE FALL OF SUHARTO: VOICES;
New Freedoms Feed Ethnic Frictions

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: GRESIK, Indonesia, May 24

 BODY:
Doni Setiawan leaned over the pot of boiled corn cobs that he was selling on the street and steam swirled around his flashing eyes as he argued with his buddy Sarpin.
It was a triumphal moment for democracy, the first time the two friends had ever felt free enough to discuss national affairs openly. Yet the topic they chose to discuss as they exercised their new right of free expression was this: Should Indonesia expel all citizens of Chinese origin? 
 "We're really being monopolized and colonized by the Chinese," declared Mr. Setiawan, 27, who was hovering over his pushcart on a bustling street in this city 400 miles east of the capital, Jakarta. "The Chinese should be kicked out! Then we would be freed of them forever."
Mr. Sarpin, 34, thought that was too extreme. But after more discussion he nodded his head.
"Yeah, they do treat us like slaves," Mr. Sarpin reflected. "I guess the Chinese should be kicked out."
The exchange captured the volatile mood in Indonesia these days: exultant at the overthrow of President Suharto a few days ago, exuberant at the expectation of new freedoms, and pregnant with dangers. There are plenty of signs that Mr. Suharto's resignation on Thursday marked not just the end of a tumultuous roller coaster ride but also the beginning of a new one.
The triumph of a form of "people power" in Indonesia raises critical questions about what kind of country the people seek. The answers are unclear, but conversations with dozens of people here suggest that a democracy might be less tolerant and compassionate than the dictatorship was, and that a democracy might allow an outlet for the hatreds lurking among poor workers and peasants.
 
Unexpected Threat: 'Illiberal Democracy'
No one place can fully capture the patterns of an entire country like Indonesia, but this city seems a fairly typical window into the restive national soul. An old trading port of 720,000 people on the northeast coast of the main Indonesian island of Java, Gresik -- like most places in Indonesia -- has not been the scene of any violence so far and is simply one more Indonesian hub where peasants come to sell vegetables and buy sarongs.
In Gresik, as in most cities, most Indonesians tend to live in cramped houses or shacks with dubious plumbing, while a small minority of ethnic Chinese often live in mansions with satellite dishes in the yards. Ethnic Chinese account for less than 3 percent of Indonesia's population of 210 million but control perhaps half the economy.
President Suharto emphasized ethnic and religious harmony and strictly forbade hate-mongering, so the news media never gave an outlet to the bitterness that many poor, uneducated workers and peasants feel for the Chinese.
Now, if political freedoms come to Indonesia, one possibility is what has been called an "illiberal democracy" -- a system where the majority rules and decides quite democratically to oppress a minority.
If Indonesia becomes more democratic, policy making may be based not on the considered views of the cosmopolitan ruling class in Jakarta but on the simmering anger of people like Arudji Sutanjo, a 38-year-old small businessman.
"Our blood will never mix with Chinese blood," Mr. Sutanjo said earnestly over coffee in his living room. "Actually, we hate the Chinese, but we couldn't do anything about them before, because they were protected by Suharto. But I don't think they will be protected any more."
"We should send all the Chinese men back," Mr. Sutanjo said in a genial tone. "The women can stay and marry Indonesians, and then the Chinese race here will disappear.
"And if they convert to Islam, then they can stay because they will change. Because Chinese who convert do not act like Chinese. They are not arrogant and they do not swagger."
 
A Poor Economy Feeds Hardening Attitudes
It is difficult to gauge how many people think this way, because just a week or two ago it was a forbidden topic. Now, the press has become more open, but nobody knows what the rules are.
Just this weekend, Indonesia's leading newspaper, Kompas, suggested in the course of a long article that the taboo on public discussion of the Chinese in Indonesia should be lifted. It also quoted Mr. Probosutedjo, a leading Indonesian businessman who is Mr. Suharto's half-brother, as urging that a new legal structure be established to discriminate against ethnic Chinese in business.
Attitudes toward the Chinese seem to be hardening because of the nation's economic distress. Here in Gresik, people complain about the rising prices with more passion than they discuss the fall of Mr. Suharto.
"My expenses are up, because I'm staying at a place where I can't cook and I have to eat street food, and the prices have gone way up," complained Mr. Muri, 38, who runs a portable arcade: he carries around a duffel bag full of electronic games and charges children the equivalent of a penny to play for five minutes.
"I have fewer customers now," Mr. Muri added bleakly. "Maybe that's because parents are giving their kids less pocket money."
Indonesia already has some of the most racist laws anywhere in the world, all directed at the Chinese minority. Chinese-language schools are banned, Chinese-language materials are forbidden, and it is illegal to celebrate Chinese New Year.
Any further tightening or expulsion is unlikely in the immediate future. Indonesian politics are still dominated by an educated and relatively tolerant elite, and the likely contenders for President have never given signs that they might seek to exploit Indonesia's racial issues.
A Muslim leader, Amien Rais, may eventually emerge as President, and he would represent a dramatically different style from the secular leaders of the past. But Mr. Rais has never tried to exploit racial animosities; on the contrary, he is a sophisticated moderate with a Ph. D in political science from the University of Chicago.
How Indonesia handles these issues will be enormously important for all of Asia. Few analysts believe that China would ever intervene militarily to protect ethnic Chinese in Southeast Asia, but Chinese minorities are also resented for their economic success and supposed arrogance in countries like the Philippines and Malaysia, and the only place where they have really assimilated successfully is Thailand.
 
Amid the Debate, A Call for Fairness
Among ordinary Indonesians, opinions about the Chinese range widely. While many in Gresik said that they thought that the Chinese should be expelled, there were also people who boldly expressed the opposite view.
"Chinese are Indonesian citizens, too," said Agus Supriono, who works for the power company in Gresik, as he sat on a stool in front of a hardware store and disagreed with a half-dozen of his friends who had just railed against the Chinese. "If they are good citizens, they are O. K. with me. After all, they contribute to the economy as well."
"I'm against putting restrictions on them, against expelling them," Mr. Supriono said, as his friends listened intently. "In Islam, there is nothing about treating races differently. We should treat everybody the same.
"But if there were a vote on expelling the Chinese," Mr. Supriono added sadly, "at least 75 percent of Indonesians would vote yes."
Of course, it is far from clear that Mr. Suharto's downfall will lead to the kind of democracy that will empower ordinary workers and peasants. There may be a military coup, or the educated ruling elite may continue to run the show under some authoritarian system.
While people are getting used to the idea that a dictatorship may be ending, they seem profoundly unsure what kind of country they want. Some speak of their desire to introduce Islamic law or even create an Islamic state, noting that 90 percent of Indonesians are Muslims. Others yearn for Western-style democracy and the rule of law. Yet others prefer a more authoritarian model, saying that they are wary of the chaos of democracy and the introduction of too much freedom.
"I don't like the American system at all, not at all" said Ms. Kumala, an unemployed 19-year-old who graduated from high school last year. "Americans are too free," she added. "They do not follow religion very much. And they have free sex."
Whatever political system is on the horizon, the age of strongman rule seems to be on the wane, and even a new dictatorship might have to be more responsive to public sentiment. Thus one possibility may be new restrictions on Chinese businesses, perhaps modeled on the laws in Malaysia that help indigenous people at the expense of Chinese. Even those in Gresik who did not like the idea of expelling the Chinese seemed to favor new laws to restrict their business influence.
 
Restrictions on Chinese Are Likely to Backfire
"Expelling the Chinese might work, but I don't know," said Ramsiana Kasuma, a 20-year-old college student. "My neighbor is Chinese and she is very kind and gets along with us well. So I wouldn't want her sent away.
"Maybe we should just put restrictions on the Chinese so that they do not dominate the economy."
One brake on any efforts to expel the Chinese or confiscate their wealth is that it might be catastrophic for Indonesia as a whole. East African countries like Uganda expelled ethnic Indians in the 1970's because they had dominated business and were bitterly resented. But the exodus shattered the local economies.
The most important Chinese-controlled assets in Indonesia are not the physical buildings they own but their contacts and business savvy. In a modern economy like Indonesia's, any move to drive away Chinese businesses would send the stock market and currency tumbling and would harm almost everyone.
The attitudes toward Chinese are varied and complex, not loathing so much as smoldering resentment, and all sprinkled with a grudging respect. When a visitor asks why the ethnic Chinese are invariably much richer than the Indonesians around them, the answers are often surprisingly straightforward.
"They work harder," said Mrs. Sumayah, a 36-year-old housewife. "In a Chinese family, you see the mothers working, the kids working, everyone working."
"Sometimes we feel jealous," she added. "We think, why are we Javanese below the Chinese?"
Mrs. Sumayah's husband emerged from the doorway and laughingly interjected: "Sometimes? We don't feel jealous just some of the time. We feel that way all the time!"
Most Indonesians in Gresik said that Chinese prosper because they are better at business than other people and work harder. But some also insisted that Mr. Suharto favored the Chinese.
It is true that some prominent Chinese tycoons are close to Mr. Suharto and were given monopolies that helped them prosper. But most Chinese in Indonesia struggle against acute discrimination -- in Gresik, for example, the town center has a large market with countless stalls, but ethnic Chinese are banned from operating in that market.
Religious tensions are overlaid on the ethnic division, for Indonesians are mostly Muslims while many of the Chinese are Christians. Some Indonesians complained that the Chinese are trying to build too many churches, or are trying to show up the Muslims by building fancy new churches next to old mosques.
"The Christians are over-expanding and taking advantage of religious freedom," complained Mr. Sutaryo, a 27-year-old worker in a petrochemical factory.
Still, many Indonesians here speak fondly of individual Chinese even as they complain about the Chinese as a class. On one street in Gresik, the townspeople spoke glowingly of the Chinese Christian pastor, Petrus Riady, whom they have elected as head of the neighborhood. Last week, when there was talk that there might be rioting against Chinese, the neighbors set up a 24-patrol around Mr. Riady's house to protect him.
"I was very happy about that," Mr. Riady said as he sat in the entrance to his modest house. "There may have been some riots elsewhere in society, but there are many nice and kind people as well."
One sign of progress, of a sort, is that in the upheavals of 1965-66, when Mr. Suharto pushed out his predecessor, Sukarno, and seized power, thousands of Chinese were killed in an explosion of popular rage. In recent months, there have been anti-Chinese riots in many cities, but the pattern has been for Indonesians to loot Chinese shops but not to assault the Chinese themselves.
 
Fearing for the Future While Trying to Fit In
"If the Government doesn't solve the economic crisis, the next time the riots will be even worse," said Imam Riyanto, a 37-year-old college graduate who does odd jobs. "Even so, while people would take things and burn the shops, we wouldn't actually hurt the Chinese."
Mr. Riyanto had said a moment earlier that he favored the introduction of Islamic law, including amputation of a hand for stealing. But when he was asked whether the looters in the riots should have their hands amputated, he shook his head. "No, that's a different situation," Mr. Riyanto said. "The looters took things from Chinese, not from Indonesians."
All this leaves the Chinese shopkeepers in Gresik jittery about the risks of renewed upheavals.
"We're afraid it could be like it was 30 years ago, and so we have to be very careful," said a 58-year-old Chinese shop owner who insisted on not being identified. "We have a lot of Indonesian friends, and our neighbors around here wouldn't bother us. But if there are riots, you never know what strangers might do."
In recent decades, Chinese have tried harder to fit into Indonesian society, so hard that most young people speak the Indonesian and Javanese languages, but no Chinese.
"Older folks are sad about that, of course," the shop owner said, speaking Mandarin with a strong Javanese accent. "But that's the way it is. We're living in Indonesia."

HEADLINE: Summer's Plague of Angels Arrives;
After Scraping By, Adirondack Town Braces for Crowds and Jobs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: LONG LAKE, N.Y., May 24

 BODY:
Three months ago, the streets of this Adirondack hamlet were nearly deserted. In Hamilton County, where Long Lake -- population 750 -- is practically a metropolis, the unemployment rate was up to 18 percent, higher than any other county in the state. Business was so slow at the grocery store here that the owner had to take out a loan to cover expenses, and he said later that he had stayed open only as a public service.
But in the last few days, the gloom that hung over Long Lake all winter has lifted. American flags are flying from telephone poles. Boats and docks have been moved from storage into the lake. The diner is drawing a breakfast crowd for the first time in months. And John Hosley, who owns Hoss's Country Corner, has just stocked his ice cream store across the street with 9,000 plastic spoons. 
 It happens every year, just about now. Long Lake welcomes back hundreds of summer homeowners and visitors on Memorial Day weekend, and in only a few days the number of people in this sleepy town in the state's most sparsely populated county quadruples. It is all part of the migration that transforms this region, sometimes called the Appalachia of the North, into a rustic retreat for the well-heeled refugees of New York City and its suburbs.
There are, of course, summer towns across the country that go through a similar boom every Memorial Day weekend. In all of them, urban dwellers revel in their escape to the country, while the locals brace themselves for quite the opposite: three months of hard work and an end to peace and quiet.
Still, few changes are as stark as in this lakeside getaway, nestled in the vast Adirondack wilderness. For the year-round residents, summer is the time to make the money that will support them the rest of the year. It is an irksome reminder to people who pride themselves on independence that their livelihood depends on the arrival of what they call the flatlanders.
"Wake up Saturday morning, and you see a metamorphosis," said Mr. Hosley, whose upscale general store offers everything from handmade wooden canoes to fresh dill pickles. "The intellectual world will have arrived," he added wryly.
The village of Long Lake is one of two hamlets in the town of Long Lake, population 930, in the heart of the Adirondack Park, an expanse of public and private land about the size of Massachusetts. It is about 250 miles northwest of New York City, and you can get here only by traveling at least 50 miles of two-lane highway, or chartering a seaplane.
The small downtown includes a lodge-like turn-of-the-century hotel (no telephones, no televisions, but two stuffed bears in the lobby and a big porch overlooking the water), a grocery, Mr. Hosley's store, four restaurants that close or cut back their hours come October and two summer ice cream shops. The highway into town is lined with about a dozen motels and inns, as well as a state campground.
But the town is less known for amenities than for cool lakes and lush forests, and over the last year, it has been the focal point for one of the state's biggest environmental disputes. This is where Marylou Whitney hoped to develop luxury estates on the family's immense "camp" -- the term here for all summer homes, even mansions like Mrs. Whitney's -- but instead was persuaded to sell the 15,000 acres to the park.
To many residents, that decision was a disappointment, denying them jobs and new customers, and it was yet another example of how "outsiders" -- whether environmentalists or summer vacationers -- controlled their fate.
This situation is not new. The village has attracted vacationers since the late 19th century. But in recent years, as logging, mining and other businesses have faded, the summer trade has carried its economy.
"You either make your money now, or you eat bark for the rest of the year," remarked Tom Bissell, a 70-year-old native and Town Supervisor.
Over the next few months, this town becomes a place of hotels without vacancies, crowded campgrounds and quaint turn-of-the-century stone and shingle cottages. Seaplanes shuttle some people into the back country for fishing expeditions, and other people take boats to old homes that are accessible only by water.
It is a second home to old money, like the heirs of William C. Whitney, the 19th-century industrialist, as well as a hideaway for celebrities like Sigourney Weaver, the actress.
A few miles outside town, at the state campground at Eaton Lake, Rick Martin was relieved to be back at work on Friday. In February and March, there was no work to be had, and he had run out of savings, started collecting unemployment checks of $300 a week and had little to do all day but watch television.
"You try to hunker down, but you get anxious," he said. Still, with the coming of summer, Mr. Martin's job as supervisor of the campground had started again, and on Saturday more than half the 135 campsites were filled. He was busy overseeing three newly hired employees as they raked the shoreline, fixed the restrooms and handled a flurry of last-minute phone calls.
In summer, there are jobs here for anyone who wants one, teen-agers are called at their homes and offered work, and some hotels bring in women from England because they can't find enough help locally.
But this modest prosperity does not come without a price, which is being overrun by vacationers who cause long lines at the post office, complain that their cell phones don't work and panic when the New York newspapers are a day late.
"One of the things that happens today is that you go from leaving your car keys in the ignition all the time to locking the doors wherever you park," Robert Gibson, the town's park, recreation and tourism director, remarked.
Mr. Bissell added, "We all realize that we depend one way or another on the people coming here, but that doesn't mean we aren't glad to see Labor Day."
The outsiders and the locals don't mix much. But on Friday morning, as Mr. Bissell and other regulars gathered at their usual table at the Long Lake Diner for breakfast, they happily counted the unfamiliar faces walking through the door.
"The snowbirds are coming back," said Gregg Wallace, a contractor at the table, using the term for retirees who winter in Florida and summer in the Northeast.
"No more weekends," Mr. Hosley mused.
"Thank God," Mr. Bissell remarked.
After pouring the table another round of coffee, Shea Farrell, 19, who was working her first day as a waitress after coming home from college, said that some of the new arrivals could be snooty, but that it was a welcome change. "You can get tired of being in a small town where everyone knows everything about everyone," she said.
The silver lining to the summer traffic, Ms. Farrell explained, is seeing friends from past summers and meeting new people.
George A. Woods, who grew up in the Adirondacks, described it in his memoir-like novel, "Vibrations" (Harper and Row, 1970): "Summer meant people, change, faces you hadn't seen for a year. People opening up their summer homes and camps, people pale but with smooth skin, not the leathery, beaten-down, lined expression of the year-round residents who had to live through the wind and the weather. It was the summer people who pumped blood into us and money and a new life."
It is a love-hate relationship.
On Friday morning, David Lamos, a Long Lake native who owns Northern Borne, the town's grocery, ground double the amount of hamburger that he had the day before and chatted with anyone who walked by. "These summer people are very sweet, classy people," he exclaimed at one point.
The winter had been rough. The grocery had stayed open but cut back its hours, and dropped from a dozen employees to only a couple. The business had needed to take out some loans to survive the winter. And he and his wife, who home-school their children, continued to live without basics that he dismisses as "fancy frills," like a television.
So this weekend, Mr. Lamos was pleased to see the return of families that have been coming here for generations. As he sliced some ham for one summer regular, a woman who had just arrived from Delaware, he explained to another visitor why he had never left.
"It's like a cocoon, the changes, that's what I like," he said.
The woman waiting for cold cuts added her own opinion. "What I like is that it never changes," she said. "It never gets cutesy. It just stays the way it's always been since my father started coming here in 1917." And she begged, "Don't tell people to come here."
That was not Mr. Lamos's attitude, and he said quietly as she walked away, "These people want it to themselves, but that's what it's here for -- for people to come."
And then he urged the visitor to come back and bring the entire family.

HEADLINE: Haitians Bear H.I.V. Alone, Waiting for Word on Asylum

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
When Amos Dacy fled his native Haiti in a wobbly boat, he had a simple goal: to live. But though he left behind the political persecution he says could have killed him, his ordeal continues.
Every day, Mr. Dacy sits in a Brooklyn apartment, alone and sick. "I spend many sleepless nights," he said, his eyes staring aimlessly. "I think that if I had stayed in Haiti, I would have been killed. Now I wonder if it's worse to die alone." 
 Five years have passed since Mr. Dacy and 200 other Haitian refugees with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, were confined in a camp at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Under a judge's order, they were finally allowed into the United States. But most of them still have not won the political asylum they seek. Some have sickened and died; others are poor and unable to get work.
And like Mr. Dacy, most are struggling alone: They find themselves cut off from fellow Haitian immigrants, bereft of the community support that sustains many newcomers far from family and home. The stigma of AIDS runs so deep among many Haitians that most of the H.I.V.-positive refugees hide their condition, and few fellow Haitians have extended open arms to them.
Revealing her plight "would be like a death sentence," said a woman in St. Albans, Queens, who, like most of a dozen refugees interviewed, agreed to speak only on the condition of anonymity. "This is something that my family and only close friends know about. I can't deal with that kind of publicity."
For a brief moment, back in 1993, the refugees' struggle had flared into public view. As they languished at Guantanamo -- held far longer than their fellow refugees who did not carry the AIDS virus -- they became something of a cause celebre, with vocal support from AIDS groups and celebrities like Bruce Springsteen and Susan Sarandon rallying to their side.
Eventually, they were permitted to enter the United States as they awaited a final ruling on their requests for political asylum, and about 150 came to New York City. But settling here proved to be just the beginning of their battle.
As their cases crawl through the immigration bureaucracy, most have been unable to get work permits, and hold menial jobs at best. And as attention has turned to other causes, financing has largely dried up for the nonprofit groups that were helping them resettle.
They are still haunted by their time at Guantanamo, confined in what a Federal judge called "an H.I.V. prison camp." Some still seem unable or unwilling to believe that they are infected with a deadly virus. At the same time, many are growing sicker, and about 20 have died of AIDS, including three in the last few weeks.
On top of everything has come the cold reception from their countrymen here. For many Haitian immigrants in New York, the refugees represent all the worst stereotypes Haitians have fought to overcome: impoverished, AIDS-carrying boat people. Some of the stigma lingers from the early days of the AIDS epidemic, when Haitians in general were mistakenly classified as a high-risk group. Now, some social workers say, it is almost as if Haitians are not allowed to have AIDS.
When the organizations aiding the refugees were in danger of losing public financing, pleas to organize against the cutback failed to galvanize the usually vocal community. And no one has raised any private money to offset the loss.
In February, three social service agencies lost the Federal grants -- roughly $200,000 a year for each group -- that they had used to find housing for the refugees, provide health care and counseling, and assist with immigration issues. A fourth organization had its grant sharply reduced.
City officials who dole out the Federal money, which is intended to help people with H.I.V., said only that they had received 400 applications and could only finance about 100 programs this year. "It was a competitive process," said John Gadd, a spokesman for the city's Department of Health. "There were a lot of worthy applications."
Most of the refugees still get welfare benefits and housing subsidies. But with money for additional services cut off, Haitian social workers warned that the refugees could face growing isolation and depression. They could also find it harder to get medical treatment, even as new drugs are allowing people with H.I.V. to live longer and stay healthier.
While the stark images of confinement at Guantanamo galvanized outrage and support for the refugees, their silent ordeal here has left them and their social workers wondering whether people still care. "I don't think they're totally forgotten," said Gabrielle Kersaint, executive director of the Haitian Women's Program, one of the organizations whose financing was eliminated. But, she added, "The pie is getting smaller, and people are less sympathetic toward refugees and immigrants."
Although the refugees came from every region of Haiti, the broad outlines of their stories are similar. In October 1991, after a bloody, military-led coup that overthrew Haiti's elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, soldiers hunted down many Aristide supporters. About 40,000 went into hiding and eventually fled in dangerously overcrowded sailboats, many of which were intercepted at sea by United States Coast Guard cutters.
The refugees were held at the American base at Guantanamo as officials reviewed their accounts of political persecution. Most were eventually determined to have fled for economic, rather than political, reasons, and were returned to Haiti. But about 15,000 were found to have strong claims for asylum, and were allowed into the United States while their applications were processed. Even now, however, fewer than 2 percent have formally been granted asylum.
Refugees who tested positive for H.I.V. at Guantanamo were detained longer, under immigration rules that generally denied entry to the United States for people with the virus. But in June 1993, Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, calling the detention "a tragedy of immense proportion," ordered that the camp be closed and all the remaining refugees allowed into the country.
Among them was the woman who now lives in St. Albans, who settled into a comfortable three-bedroom home with her sons and other relatives. But she said her uncertain immigration status had left her unable to find a decent job. Like most of the others, she gets by on public assistance, which pains her, she said.
"I don't want them," she said, stroking her thick corn braids and referring to food stamps and Medicaid. "I didn't come here to live off the state. But I don't have asylum."
One man refused to be interviewed at his home because he said it was not fit for a guest. Standing on a street corner along Nostrand Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, he described the routine of loneliness his life has become -- days spent wandering aimlessly around town, with an occasional trip to see his social workers or lawyers, who are themselves overloaded with cases.
Like the others, he has no green card and has not held a job in more than four years. Experts say there is little likelihood that the refugees will be deported, even if their asylum applications are for some reason rejected, but the legal limbo they live in wears on them.
"I'm constantly reminded that I'm not home," he said, a cigarette dangling between his fingers as it slowly burned. "When I walk down the street, I don't know when they're going to come and send me back. So I'm always on edge."
Getting asylum and finding work have been the most pressing goals for most of the refugees. Many left spouses and children behind in Haiti, and still hope to bring their families here one day. For some, the fact of their illness seems to be pushed to a dark corner of a mind preoccupied with more immediate problems.
"I don't think it's as much denial," said Dr. Marie Carmel Pierre-Louis, program director with the Haitian Coalition on AIDS, which is based in Brooklyn. "It's a complete disbelief."
She said the refugees' treatment at Guantanamo had left them confused and deeply suspicious.
The refugees, who were apparently mostly infected through heterosexual contact, said they were not clearly informed of their status at Guantanamo. Instead, they said, they were told that they had a "problem with their blood" and would be kept apart from the thousands of their countrymen for a while. But they remained isolated for more than a year and said they were beaten and abused.
"To them, being labeled H.I.V.-positive was part of a large conspiracy against them," said Dr. Pierre-Louis, who worked with most of the refugees when they were at Guantanamo. "Their thinking was that, 'If I was as sick as they said, how come they didn't release me so I can get help?' "
Now, some are fatalistic about their situation. "I don't even think about it," said one man who now lives in East Flatbush with his wife and son. "We're all going to die one day. So I take care of myself."
Mr. Dacy spends his days watching television and listening to a Creole-language radio station in his bedroom, which also serves as a makeshift living room. He rarely goes out and has no friends besides his social workers, he said. Mr. Dacy's life is not here, in the fifth floor walk-up in Crown Heights. It lies in the little plastic photo album perched at the edge of his bed, next to the remote control.
In the album are images of the family Mr. Dacy left behind, and every day he wonders whether he will see them again, or die first. He knows that he is in a race against time, although he has not shown any symptoms of his infection. Mr. Dacy, a small, stocky man, takes a daily cocktail of four medications in the hope of keeping his illness at bay.
"They are awful," he said.
Mr. Dacy gets $615 a month to pay his rent, $120 in food stamps and Medicaid coverage. He rents out a back room in his apartment for $215, some of which he sends back to his family in Haiti. Despite his loneliness, Mr. Dacy said he could not return to his home in "Cite Soleil," a vast expanse of cardboard huts widely considered the most wretched slum in the Western Hemisphere. His home was recently burned, he said, and his tormentors are still around.
Benedict Jean will not return home to Haiti either. His body lay peacefully last month in the Gomez funeral home at the edge of Park Slope, Brooklyn, his coffin surrounded by a wreath and two small potted plants.
The gathering was unusually small for a Haitian wake. There was no wailing, no widow, no relatives; Mr. Jean's family members are all in Haiti. Those who came to the wake -- the preacher, social workers and a couple of church members -- were all recent acquaintances, people whom Mr. Jean had met in the last days of his life. They spoke of his courage, his determination until the very end to win asylum in the adopted country where he died alone.
Although some of Mr. Jean's fellow refugees from Guantanamo have stayed in touch with one another, none of them were at the wake either. "It is a reminder of their own mortality," said Ronald Aubourg, a policy analyst with the Haitian Centers Council in Brooklyn, who met the refugees at Guantanamo and has attended nearly every wake and funeral. "They don't want to face that."
And as the refugees' cause has faded from public notice, most of the supporters who once flocked to their defense have moved on.
"No one is around anymore," said one refugee, a woman who lives in Flatbush. "When I'm hungry, there's no one to give me a dollar. I realize I have to help myself."

HEADLINE: Riding High, Bush Eases Into 2000 Election

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: CROCKETT, Tex., May 20

 BODY:
As his campaign plane bounced from town to town over the piney woods of East Texas this week, George W. Bush said he had a message: "I am totally focused on getting re-elected as Governor. My head and my heart are in Texas."
Of course, Mr. Bush has made a few quick swings out of state in recent weeks, to California, Arizona and Ohio, all to raise money for Republican candidates. ("My head and my heart is right there in Texas," he told reporters in Ohio.) And just in case, his chief political consultant has taken the helpful step of reserving the rights to some catchy-sounding sites on the World Wide Web, like www.Bush2000.org. 
 But in the main, the Governor of the nation's second-largest state is spending his time with the voters of Texas, playfully parrying reporters who constantly try to draw him out about a Presidential race with responses like, "Nice try, guy!" Should he win re-election -- polls currently show him 40 points or more ahead of his Democratic opponent -- he is almost certain to spend the first several months of next year insisting that his mind is still on Texas and the legislative session in Austin.
With a famous name and enormous fund-raising abilities, including a huge out-of-state donor list that draws heavily on supporters of his father, former President George Bush, the Texas Governor is able to wait before he kicks any Presidential effort into high gear. And with those attributes, he is clearly enjoying a luxury that many other prospective candidates for the Republican nomination in 2000 -- who are already on the rubber-chicken circuit in early-voting states like Iowa and New Hampshire -- simply cannot afford.
Even without any heavy campaigning outside of Texas, and even with his insistence that he will not think seriously about a Presidential race until well into next year, the 51-year-old Mr. Bush routinely tops polls in which likely voters are asked to survey the prospective Republican field.
A USA Today/CNN/Gallup poll earlier this month even showed him running about as well as Vice President Al Gore in a hypothetical one-on-one matchup, though that striking result begs the question of whether voters are still confusing him with his father. (In a question in a poll by The New York Times taken last week, in which people were reminded of the distinction between the father and the son, more than 70 percent of those polled said they had no opinion of the younger Mr. Bush.)
Mr. Bush does not deny that he enjoys all the attention he is generating these days, but he waves off questions about the White House.
"He's not running for Governor of Texas," he said of Mr. Gore the other day. "So therefore he's not on the radar screen."
Mr. Bush says he is working harder than he ever has in his re-election bid, crisscrossing Texas and campaigning hard even in the "Yellow Dog Democrat" stronghold of Crockett, where he got a thunderous ovation with a speech at the local community center.
Alighting from the plane in Crockett (named for Davy), Mr. Bush was greeted by a jocular county commissioner who also happens to be named George Bush, though everyone calls the official by his nickname, Buzzy. Asked if he were a Republican, Buzzy Bush gripped the other Mr. Bush's hand, and with a huge smile, said, "Well, I am today!"
The Governor said he rarely has time for indulgences like movies. He said he could not remember the last film he saw in a theater, and the last video he recalled renting was "Austin Powers, International Man of Mystery," the James Bond parody starring Mike Myers.
"Liked it! Funny guy!" said the Governor, sounding, almost exactly like his father, right down to the famous aversion to pronouns.
As he campaigns around Texas on issues like ending the social promotion of youngsters who cannot pass state reading tests, some of the broad themes of his campaign stump speeches could clearly amount to a preview of a national speech.
In variations of one of those addresses ("the legacy speech," as his aides call it), Mr. Bush invokes the sacrifices made by his father's generation, which fought and won World War II, and then asks this generation to respond to a different set of threats.
"Today's children are not afraid of a distant threat from across the world, but a threatening violence in their own schools, their own neighborhoods," the Governor said this week in a speech before a convention of retailers in Dallas. "Today's challenge lies not so much outside our borders as inside our souls."
In Crockett and in other campaign stops, the Governor routinely addresses young people in the crowd, urging them to shun drugs and alcohol and telling them, "There is honor in abstaining from sex until you've found the person you want to marry."
Mr. Bush himself has said he had some "wild years" as a bachelor in his days as a West Texas oilman, and he was a serious drinker until he quit cold turkey on the morning after his 41st birthday party. But he said he sees no conflict in squaring the moral themes he emphasizes today with his conduct in his younger days.
"I'd be the first to admit that when I was young and irresponsible, I was irresponsible," Mr. Bush said the other day. "I've assumed the mantle of being a governor and a father in a responsible way, and the signal we ought to send to our children is that in spite of what happened in the 60's and 70's, we have learned some lessons. And the lesson ought to be, don't be using drugs and alcohol. Learn the lessons from the past."
As he campaigns around the state, Mr. Bush is emphasizing education as an issue, and he is clearly basking in recent news that Texas schoolchildren are passing the state's standardized tests in record percentages. He is also benefiting from the strong economy, though the lopsided margin he enjoys in polls over his Democratic opponent, State Land Commissioner Garry Mauro, is bound to tighten up when voters start focusing on the race this fall.
Mr. Mauro recently said Mr. Bush was "darn sure testing the Presidential waters" and ought to acknowledge it to the voters. And a state Democratic Party spokesman jumped all over the Governor when Mr. Bush gave a speech to film makers in Los Angeles last month, demanding that he "explain why he is hobnobbing with Hollywood stars and political elites rather than tending to the needs of Texans."
Mr. Bush has clearly mastered one part of the political craft, that of turning aside some questions by framing the answers in totally different terms.
For instance, asked the other day whether the Republican Party should emphasize social-issue themes like opposition to abortion in this fall's campaigns, he quickly cut in with this answer: "Themes? I emphasize themes. I emphasize the importance of the Hispanic vote. I intend to hopefully get 40 percent of the Hispanic vote in the state of Texas. I think that's an important theme for the Republican Party."
Pressed on whether he favored banning abortion, a core issue for many religious conservatives, Mr. Bush said he was a "pro-life candidate" who wanted to find ways to reduce the number of abortions, but he did not specifically endorse a legal ban on the procedure.
"We should talk about parental notification, adoption, abstinence," he said. "Issues over which we can make a difference."
As he spoke in Crockett, Mr. Bush basked in a huge ovation and was mobbed afterward for pictures and autographs. Several people in the crowd said they had come because they believed they were getting a glimpse of a future President.
"I believe he's going to run," said Thomas Frizzell, an 18-year-old senior at Crockett High School. "Of course, I don't have any personal insight into the situation, but that's what I believe. You listen to what he talks about, and it sure seems like he's setting himself up for something bigger."
For his part, as the plane took off for the next stop, Mr. Bush said he could not focus on the question until late next spring at the earliest, and would need to talk it over at considerable length with his wife, Laura, and their 16-year-old twin daughters.
"I've got a campaign to run, an inauguration to give, a legislative session to end," he said. "And then we'll see."

More U.S. Reservists See Duty as Peacekeepers
The number of reservists and National Guard members who are finding themselves thrust into military life is growing sharply as the United States peacekeeping mission in Bosnia continues to eat away at military resources. The increasing resort to reservists stems from both a rise in the number of peacekeeping missions and the Army's sharp reduction in personnel. A1

Causes of Intelligence Failure
In 1995 the American Ambassador to India showed spy photos, which documented that India was preparing for a nuclear test, to top Indian officials in a successful effort to persuade them not to test. Some officials now say that sharing those photos revealed how the United States had spied on the test site and enabled the Indians to conceal their preparations for the tests this month. A3

Opposition groups planned two private investigations into the wealth of former President Suharto of Indonesia and his powerful children within hours of his resignation on Thursday, the groups' organizers said. Colombian Brigade Disbanded
A Colombian Army intelligence brigade that had come under increasing international criticism for suspected links to political killings will be disbanded and its members reorganized, the military command has announced. Members of the unit, the 20th Intelligence Brigade, are being investigated in connection with at least three killings of human rights workers, as well as church and political figures. A4

Monument Is Reopened
A cooler Washington Monument reopened to visitors on Friday, after four months of interior repairs. The first phase of an $8 million repair job included renewing a faulty ventilating system, so "now it will be much more comfortable to visit, cool in the summer and warm in the winter," Ranger Mark Ragan said. The reinstalled elevator takes 70 seconds reach the viewing platform, near the top of the white-marble obelisk, more than 555 feet from the ground. The Washington Monument was completed in 1884 after decades of off-and-on construction that began in 1848. Construction will begin in July on a web of scaffolding that will cover the monument for more than a year while workers patch and seal damaged stones. (AP)

HEADLINE: CLINTON AIDE SAYS CHINA TRIP DELAY WOULD BE MISTAKE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
President Clinton's national security adviser said today that "it would be an enormous mistake" to postpone Mr. Clinton's trip to China next month simply because of the current political storm over the export of satellite technology.
Nonetheless, White House officials are already scrambling to find diplomatic offerings they can bring to Beijing without worsening the controversy, since many of the initiatives Mr. Clinton is considering would use access to American satellites and joint space research as a lure for China to take further steps in limiting weapons proliferation. 
 Appearing on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, dismissed calls by virtually all the Republican leaders in Congress for Mr. Clinton to cancel his trip. Among those leaders was Speaker Newt Gingrich, who said on the CNN program "Late Edition," "Until we know the truth about what was going on, it is very inappropriate for the President to go to China." Mr. Gingrich added that "it would be an embarrassment to both countries to have the meeting."
White House officials say there is virtually no chance Mr. Clinton will cancel plans for his meeting with Chinese leaders in late June, which Mr. Berger said comes at a critical moment in relations with Beijing. Noting India's recent tests of nuclear weapons and the turmoil caused by the Asian financial crisis, Mr. Berger said, "China is key to all of those."
At the same time, a continuing criminal investigation and the opening of several Congressional inquiries into the actions of two satellite makers are bound to affect the agenda of the trip, according to several officials and informal advisers to the Administration on China.
"It's obvious that a lot of what we had hoped to offer in return for Chinese commitments on proliferation -- especially in the space and technology area -- are going to have to be reviewed," one senior adviser to Mr. Clinton said. "That's just the political reality."
For example, a month ago Administration officials were discussing with the Chinese the possibility of a blanket waiver of sanctions imposed after the killing of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989. The waiver would allow China to launch American-made satellites without case-by-case Presidential review. In return, the White House was looking for a commitment from China to join the Missile Technology Control Regime, the main international group that limits exports of missile technologies.
But in the current political climate, that proposal appears all but dead. Not only would it cause an uproar in Congress, according to Administration and other officials, but China has so far not indicated a willingness to join the missile regime, though it already adheres to some of its principles.
There are also questions about another major proposal: an agreement between the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its Chinese counterpart to conduct scientific observations from space.
Before the current controversy, Administration officials say, the Pentagon and the nation's intelligence agencies had insisted on restrictions to make sure that the space accord did not enable China to improve its spy satellite capability, or its ability to use global positioning satellites to allow more precise targeting of ballistic missiles. The cooperation agreement was focused mostly on observing agricultural changes and pollution.
"Even with that," one Administration official said this weekend, "people are going to look at this carefully because it has the words 'space' and 'satellite' in it."
It is unclear how, or even if, the satellite controversy will affect other offerings to the Chinese. Some are not technology-related: for example, the Administration has considered lifting an eight-year-old ban that has prevented two Government agencies, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Trade and Development Agency, from promoting deals between American companies and the Chinese Government.
The Overseas Private Investment Corporation provides political risk insurance to American companies for a fee. The Trade and Development Agency finances feasibility studies of overseas projects that could create jobs for American workers.
Last week, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed amendments to a military spending bill that would prohibit virtually all satellite exports to China. Among the House members who voted for the bill were a number who had urged Mr. Clinton to allow such exports in the past, rather than let the business go to rival European companies.
Mr. Berger suggested today that Congress had acted prematurely and emotionally. "I always thought we went from accusation to fact to conclusion to remedy," he said.
On the talk shows today and on Capitol Hill last week, participants in the debate often conflated three separate issues into a broad argument over whether the Clinton Administration has taken actions that could compromise national security.
The first of those issues concerns a waiver President Clinton signed earlier this year allowing Loral Space and Communications, a major military contractor, to export a satellite that is scheduled to be launched by the Chinese in November. The President's decision was complicated by the fact that Federal prosecutors have been investigating a 1996 incident in which Loral's engineers are accused of having breached security by advising the Chinese on how to build more reliable rockets.
That advice followed an investigation into the causes of the explosion of a Long March rocket, the mainstay of China's commercial rocket fleet and its nuclear arsenal. Classified memorandums, made public by the White House on Friday, show that there was intense debate within the Clinton Administration over whether to approve this year's launching.
The question is whether the White House was influenced by appeals from Loral to sign the waiver quickly, before contractual penalties of more than $4 million were imposed by the Chinese for a delay in delivering the satellite. Mr. Berger defended the decision to allow the export, saying that "no technology was being transferred by the license." He noted that the license could still be revoked if the investigation led to an indictment of the company or any of its employees.
The second issue concerns Mr. Clinton's pattern of issuing waivers that allow such launchings. The White House has noted that President George Bush did the same, signing nine waivers between December 1989 -- only six months after the Tiananmen Square killings -- and 1992. Mr. Clinton has signed 11 waivers since July 1993.
Documents shown to reporters on Friday made it clear that the waivers are given to the Chinese as a reward for an action that pleases Washington, or used as an incentive for future action. For example, the State Department recommended that Mr. Clinton approve the February waiver because it would "provide an incentive for China to observe M.T.C.R. missile proliferation guidelines."
But the waivers are also motivated by a desire to assure that American companies remain ahead of their European competitors in the race to get satellites aloft, serving telephone users and television viewers around the world.
Thus the Administration is open to charges that it has twisted its security judgments for the benefit of American companies, including those whose officers are known to have made large campaign contributions. The issue is complicated by the fact that some of the waivers clearly aided the China Aerospace Group, a conglomerate owned by the Chinese Government. An executive of China Aerospace, Liu Chaoying, is believed to have been the conduit for surreptitious donations to the Democratic Party in 1996. Ms. Liu has denied the accusation.
And almost lost in the Washington debate is what may be the most critical question: why President Clinton, in March 1996, overrode his Secretary of State, Warren M. Christopher, by ruling that satellites would no longer be classified as munitions. That eased the process of getting export waivers approved.
"I am convinced the national security was not compromised by any decision that we made," Mr. Berger said today.

HEADLINE: Democratic Party Loves Vallone, but He's Mostly Unknown Upstate

SERIES: EARLY STEPS: The Gubernatorial Campaign

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
For some of the Democrats running for Governor, this week's state party convention will be a struggle for delegate support, even a fight for survival. For Peter F. Vallone, the clear favorite of party leaders, it could be more like an anointment, at least among party loyalists. 
 Mr. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council, heads into the convention Wednesday in Rye Brook as the only candidate assured of getting the 25 percent of the delegates' votes needed to win an automatic place on the September primary ballot. The talk among Mr. Vallone's supporters is about whether he will top 50 percent in the delegates' balloting.
 But some of the party's strategists wonder how well Mr. Vallone, little known to voters outside the city, will shift from what has been an insiders' game, courting party officials and raising money, to a broader campaign, courting Democratic voters from Niagara Falls to Montauk in his effort to be the candidate to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki.
"He's old-fashioned in good senses and bad senses," said Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant who is not involved in the governor's race. "Goes to church, loyal to friends almost to a fault, almost small-town. The negative of that is, you run a campaign in New York State, it's more than retail politics."
Mr. Vallone and his aides say that their campaign so far has been focused largely on the convention, and that once it is over, they are ready to make the needed transition.
He has taken what most politicians consider the right steps toward a statewide campaign, including raising more money than any other Democrat in the race except Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, whose campaign fund is supplied almost entirely by her financier husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr. Mr. Vallone has assembled an experienced team, with consultants like David Doak and Stanley S. Greenberg, veterans of President Clinton's campaigns.
For a candidate who fails to win 25 percent of the delegates' votes at the convention, the only route to the primary ballot is through a difficult and expensive process of gathering thousands of signatures on petitions. That means the convention may be a make-or-break event for some contenders. But by most accounts Mr. Vallone had 25 percent of the vote sewn up months ago.
Mr. Vallone, 63, has spent decades cultivating the intertwined roots of New York City's neighborhood organizers, lobbying groups and elected officials, groundwork that has enabled him to win the backing of much of the party hierarchy, and to raise more than $3 million for this race. He often attends three or four political events a day, greeting leading lights and minor figures alike with hugs and pats on the cheek.
"I'm a product of Queens," Mr. Vallone, who is from Astoria, said between events one recent evening. "And Queens is made up of a lot of little villages. It's like everyone's from a small town, where everybody knows everybody."
The same could be said of the political world he inhabits, but Mr. Vallone needs to introduce himself to several million voters outside the city who do not know him.
Promoting himself statewide may be a tall order even with enough money for an extensive advertising campaign. Mr. Vallone, by his own admission, is not a stellar speaker -- recently he earnestly declared at a meeting of of representatives from cultural groups, "There would be no New York City without the things that make New York City special" -- and he has never been elected to office outside his Queens Council district. In addition, he is closely identified with the city, a place viewed with mistrust by many upstaters.
In the primary, he is likely to face Ms. McCaughey Ross, the erstwhile Republican, who is better known and commands attention from the news media wherever she goes. And in the general election awaits Mr. Pataki, who is popular and has more money than his would-be Democratic challengers combined.
Still, many prominent Democrats say Mr. Vallone will prevail in the primary, and fare respectably against Mr. Pataki, even if he loses.
"I believe he will win the Democratic nomination because he's the most versed in what it will take to win, and he has a very good team," said Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor, who is supporting Mr. Pataki.
Mr. Vallone insists he has no concerns about taking his campaign to places like Utica and Binghamton. "If we just stick to our game plan, I think we'll be fine," he said.
When Ms. McCaughey Ross won the Liberal Party nomination, she agreed to the party's demand that she campaign through the November election even if she did not win the Democratic primary in September. That has many Democrats complaining of a disaster in the making, one that could split the anti-Pataki vote in November.
But Mr. Vallone says he sees the matter differently. "I think it helps us," he said. "It shows she's ready to betray the Democratic Party the way she betrayed the Republican Party. The voters will figure it out."
Mr. Vallone exudes the confidence of someone with a comfortable lead, though he trails Ms. McCaughey Ross in public opinion polls. He has passed up candidates' forums and televised debates that other contenders have attended.
He also has been less aggressive than the Lieutenant Governor and another candidate, James L. Larocca, about stumping for votes upstate, the region that knows him least and accounts for a sizable portion of any statewide vote.
The other Democrats in the race are Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and Richard A. Kahan, former chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation.
Even if he gains the nomination, Mr. Vallone needs to convince voters that a change is needed. He argues that there are problems -- sluggish economic growth upstate, failing public schools, the ethics of Mr. Pataki's fund-raising -- that the Governor has ignored. "This Governor just doesn't get it," he told the Tilden Democratic Club. "He thinks there is nothing wrong. If you don't see the problems, you're not going to do anything about them."
He has also tried hard to make issues of Mr. Pataki's budget vetoes last month, and of the bid by the Governor and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to end remedial education and open admissions at the City University of New York.
But there is scant evidence, at this early stage, that such talk appeals to the public. The subject that gets Mr. Vallone the loudest reactions these days is the Yankees, with the Speaker having positioned himself as the premier advocate of keeping the team in the Bronx. But that issue is not likely to mean much to voters north of Westchester County.
Some of his advisers acknowledge privately that Mr. Vallone's unassuming manner, which has served him so well in courting the political class, may undercut his message. They say he does not get credit for being as smart or as driven as he is -- much the same complaint that Mr. Pataki's aides had four years ago. Indeed, Mr. Vallone's easy demeanor has led some political professionals to question his fire for this race, though he has been plotting his run for Governor for five years.
In many ways, he cuts an odd figure for a politician. He often does not dominate gatherings, even small ones, letting aides do much of the talking. When C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan Borough President, held a recent news conference to endorse Mr. Vallone, she spoke for six minutes, and he for less than one. He gives every speech like the emcee of an awards dinner, pointing out people in the audience.
He is a homebody who gets home nearly every night for dinner with his wife, Tena, in their home a block and a half from where he was born. He attends Mass every morning, and rarely swears, even in private conversation.
Thanks to the city's hierarchy and his own personality, in 12 years as chief of the Council, Mr. Vallone has tended to be overshadowed by mayors -- not just larger-than-life figures like Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mr. Koch, but even the more taciturn David N. Dinkins.
As a result, even many city residents are unaware of his legislative record, which includes joining Mr. Dinkins in expanding the police force by 7,000 officers, initiating campaign finance restrictions, and allowing a gay rights bill to go to the floor of the City Council, despite his personal opposition.
Surveying the contest ahead of him, Mr. Vallone said: "I know this is an uphill fight. But if it's about people's records, I can win."

A series of articles examining the political appeal and early campaign strategies of candidates in the race for governor of New York.

HEADLINE: THE N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;
Utah Plods Right Back To the Finals

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 24

 BODY:
The enduring image of the Western Conference finals will not arouse curiosity on Madison Avenue today: the balding power forward who uses a hair-growth product receiving a pass from a 36-year-old point guard with a surgically repaired knee. The play ending in a nondescript layup instead of a scintillating dunk, followed moments later by two free throws to seal the game.
Yet what Karl Malone, John Stockton and the Utah Jazz did today to the Los Angeles Lakers -- what they have done for the last eight days, really -- is far preferable to summer vacation. 
 That is where Shaquille O'Neal and his team are headed after the Jazz polished them off in four games to retain their conference title, the finale a 96-92 victory before a disbelieving crowd at the Great Western Forum.
For sentimentality's sake, Malone and Stockton earned a return trip to the finals in their 13th and 14th seasons, respectively.
For logic's sake, what happened to the highfalutin Lakers and those highlight-reel dunks?
"If I got a couple old race horses that are worn and old, and I've got a couple of thoroughbreds that are young and full of vinegar, I'd take the old horses that have won," said Malone, whose 32 points, 14 rebounds and 5 assists carried the Jazz. His 15-foot baseline jump shot with 1 minute 49 seconds remaining provided a 6-point margin and was as clutch as any shot in the series.
This was not a game -- or a series for that matter -- until midway through the fourth quarter when O'Neal and Eddie Jones began trying to siphon a smidgen of respect out of their young, immature team.
The Lakers trailed by 12 in the third quarter. Their last chance came after Kobe Bryant converted a 3-point play with 22 seconds left to cut the deficit to 92-90. But the Jazz played keep-away for the next 12 seconds, the Lakers scurrying around like the Washington Generals trying to find the dribbling Globetrotter Marques Haynes.
They finally settled on the wrong man to foul: Stockton. He made both free throws with 10.5 seconds left -- his fifth and sixth straight and Utah's 14th and 15th straight going back to the third quarter -- to give the Jazz the cushion they needed to advance.
"Guys just have to step up," said a frowning O'Neal, who finished with 38 points and was part of a team swept for the fourth time in his five post-seasons. "They have to find out what's most important to them. If they don't want to play, then they need to ask for a trade. If they don't want to play, then get off my team."
The Jazz was much more subdued than last season, when Stockton's last-second 3-pointer knocked Houston out of the conference finals. But there was a quiet dignity to their celebration that seemed to encapsulate their season, one featuring the injury to Stockton and many challenges from younger, more athletic teams in the Western Conference.
"We fought an uphill battle all year, and when the dust settled, we were the ones left standing on this side," Malone said. "We believe in each other, we hung in there, and we're going back to the big dance."
Waiting for either Chicago or Indiana to emerge from the East, Utah has a lot of time to primp and preen. The sweep could give the Jazz as much as nine days between games and will provide at least six days' rest. The finals will start no earlier than next Sunday.
"We took care of business," Malone said, "but our job is not done yet."
It was Jazz economy versus Laker excess from long range.
Utah took 30 3-pointers in the series and made 16. Howard Eisley made 3 of 4 in the first half today. The Lakers were an abominable 19 of 74 from beyond the arc in four games, including 6 of 16 today.
The Jazz outscored the Lakers in transition, 48-31, beating them at their own game.
Of course, when your opponent shoots close to 50 percent -- as Utah did -- and you have to keep removing the ball from the net, it is hard to run the floor.
And O'Neal brought his old liability to bear.
With 27.6 seconds left, he missed two free throws that could have cut the Jazz lead to 1. He made 10 of 18 on the afternoon and 25 of 55 in four games.
Yet beyond the numbers, the West was won with attitude.
You never got the feeling the Lakers truly wanted this series. They stood around between games, mulling their options but never sounding assertive about their chances. On Saturday, Nick Van Exel seemed resigned to losing, saying: "Being swept or losing 4-3, there's not much of a difference. You just lose vacation time."
Antoine Carr, the veteran forward of the Jazz, had some advice for the team Utah conquered.
"All that bouncing around they do before the games, that uses energy," he said. "They need to save it for when they get on the floor next time. We don't play any high-flying, great-looking type of basketball; ours is more nose-to-the-grindstone ball. It still works, though."

HEADLINE: High-Tech Hypocrisy About Government

BYLINE: By Mitchell Kapor; Mitchell Kapor, the founder of Lotus Development Corporation, is an investor in high-tech start-ups.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
In the mid-1980's, during my tenure at Lotus, I was, I believe, the first person to publicly compare Microsoft to Standard Oil. Both companies sought and used monopoly control over a new industry critical to the nation's economy. And both were headed by men -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. and Bill Gates -- who would stop at virtually nothing to gain what they sought. Back then no one took the comparison seriously -- except Bill Gates himself, who made it clear to me how irate he was about it.
Like Mr. Gates, I believe in and have profited from the free market. But I'm also a technorealist, which means that unlike many of my colleagues in the high-tech industry, I don't automatically see Government as the enemy of technological progress. Such views are all too fashionable in Silicon Valley, where the prospect of Government intervention causes a bad case of heartburn. 
 What my colleagues need to see is that the market cannot work unless our society sets rules of play and enforces them. Microsoft has benefited from the stability and opportunities provided by those rules, but it has been flouting them as well. The antitrust suits filed last week against Microsoft are therefore regrettable but necessary.
Despite all of Mr. Gates's talk about the right to innovate, his company uses its power to limit consumer choice and impede a free marketplace. Only the Government has the ability to take on Microsoft, and the Justice Department's antitrust chief, Joel Klein, has done his homework. He's a pragmatist, not a crusader.
Mr. Klein understands that the real threat to entrepreneurial innovation is Microsoft's anticompetitive arrogance. Great discoveries in computing often come from small start-up companies. Yet with Microsoft's dominance, vast areas of the product market -- including but hardly limited to basic applications like word processors and spreadsheets -- are barren zones where venture capitalists and entrepreneurs fear to tread because Microsoft has staked a claim or is seen as likely to do so. It is a sad but telling fact that in the high-tech field, virtually no business plan will be financed today without a convincing answer to the question of what is to be done about competition from Microsoft.
The Government also recognizes that Microsoft's dominance will only intensify as the Internet becomes an integral part of mainstream culture. The browser war is just the beginning. Microsoft claims droit du seigneur in any area of computing that becomes strategically important -- voice recognition, home appliances, auto navigation and so on.
It's unfortunate that Microsoft is so aggressively self-interested that an external check is necessary. I would prefer to live in and help create a society in which self-regulation makes antitrust suits unnecessary. But until such a business ethos prevails, we must rely on other means.
Ultimately, the extent of the Government-mandated reform may depend on Microsoft's willingness to begin acting like a more socially responsible industry leader. To the extent that the company remains recalcitrant, it's likely that radical solutions will gain favor.
The most drastic action, of course, would be to break Microsoft up into a series of Baby Bills, separating operating systems from applications and from content and services. Today that seems like overkill, but in the coming years, short of a sincere change of heart by Mr. Gates, it may well become the preferred solution.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Dollar Hits Highest Level Against Yen In 7 Years

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 25

 BODY:
The dollar rose above 137 yen today for the first time in almost seven years as expectations mounted that neither the United States nor Japan would be willing to stem the yen's decline. The dollar also gained against the mark.
"Japan would probably not be well advised to try and turn the tide while market sentiment is for a weaker yen," said Dieter Hluchy, a trader at Landesbank Schleswig-Holstein. 
 Koji Tanami, the Vice Finance Minister of Japan, suggested that the Bank of Japan may step into the currency market to take action to stem weakness in the yen.
U.S. News & World Report has reported that Robert E. Rubin, the Secretary of the United States Treasury, is willing to let the yen drop to 140 to 150 to the dollar.
When asked about the U.S. News report, Mr. Rubin said the United States shares Japanese concerns about a weak yen, but added that the strong-dollar policy remains "absolutely unchanged."
The dollar was at 137.05 yen after having climbed as high as 137.20 yen. The dollar bought 1.7657 marks, up from 1.7595 marks at the London close Friday. The mark bought 77.640 Japanese yen, up from 77.200 yen at its London close.
The Japanese central bank sometimes sells dollars when the United States currency is declining. That was the case on Dec. 17, when the bank sold about $2 billion just after it unexpectedly called for an income tax cut. The bank also sold as much as $18 billion April 9 and 10, during the Easter and Passover holidays.
Underpinning the dollar's gains against the mark were price reports in Germany showing that inflation was in check. That news bolstered expectations that the Bundesbank would leave interest rates unchanged when its policy council gathers for its meeting on Thursday.
"With inflationary pressures being so low in Germany it's very unlikely the Bundesbank will move already now," said Bastian Hepperle, an analyst at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.
A German rate rise would make mark-denominated assets more attractive to investors, aiding the mark against the dollar. While inflation is tame in Germany, analysts still expect the Bundesbank to raise interest rates by the end of the year to close the gap in short-term borrowing costs among countries joining Europe's single currency.
Long-term interest rates in most of Europe have fallen closer to the low German levels. Still, a large gap in money-market rates remains, with Italian three-month rates more than 2 percentage points higher than German three-month rates. The 11 national central banks must bring the rates in line by the end of the year.
